content.Overview: OpUSA was a campaign that was launched by Anonymous hacktivists and various Arab and Muslim hacking groups on May 7, 2013. The campaign was launched in response to the American government‚Äôs involvement in wars around the world, specifically in Iraq and Afghanistan. By the end of the campaign, dozens of American websites and servers had been hacked, hundreds of emails were leaked and thousands of social media accounts were hijacked.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
El Patron is a member of the Anonymous hacking group, operating under the moniker "El_patron_real."     

On March 3, 2022, El Patron and other Anonymous affiliates took down the Russian news website lenta.ru.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
AnonGhost is a disparate group of around 15 pro-Palestinian hacktivists who are based in Africa, the Middle East, and Europe. They have focused on disputing Israel in cyberspace since 2013 and have recently begun to target the US.

The AnonGhost Team appears to be headed by Mauritania Attacker. The group targets government, corporate and private websites around the world to bring attention to its extremist agenda. For several years,  AnonGhost‚Äôs activity has primarily involved defacing websites with anti-western, anti-Israel, and anti-Semitic messages, especially during OpIsrael and OpUSA campaigns in recent years. In the past months, Anonghost declared their support of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS) and focused on targets in the U.S. 

In addition to cyber-attacks, the network has launched a number of software tools designed to enable users to conduct their own cyber-attacks against their targets of choice. For example, in March 2015, AnonGhost alerted its supporters via its social media profiles to a new software which enables users to initiate denial of service (DOS) attacks.

On March 7, 2022, AnonGhost, affiliated with Anonymous, claimed to have hacked and shut down two Russian SCADA water supply systems.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
Ghost Angel is a member of the Anonymous hacking group, operating under the moniker "dÃ∏ùñéùñëùñÜùñåùñóùñÜùñãùñéùñä‚òÖ ùêÜùêáùêéùêíùêì ùêÄùêçùêÜùêÑùêã."

On March 1, 2022, Ghost Angel claimed to have taken down several US websites including the following:

http://iiitu.ac.in/dead.html
http://adcafrica.org/index.php
http://coinlocateplus.com/index.php
http://jukeperformance.com 
http://tejabp.com/jok3r.html

Since March 2, 2022, Ghost Angel repeatedly expressed its support in Ukraine, amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War and the Anonymous #OpRussia campaign, targeting Russian websites.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview: Ghost_Codin is a member of TheGhostSquad, an Anonymous affiliates group. In March 2022, he was observed taking part in the #OpRussia cyber campaign against Russia.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The IsaacWiper malware, first observed by cybersecurity researchers in February 2022, has been active since at least October 2021. The malware was used to attack a Ukrainian government network, amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War. IsaacWiper was not attributed to any specific threat actor, but it is assumed to be operated by Russia-supporters. 

IsaacWiper‚Äôs initial access vector is yet to be known, but it was found in Windows DLL or EXE files with no Authenticode signature. Once deployed, it enumerates the physical drives and calls DeviceIoControl to get their device numbers. Then, it wipes the first 0x10000 bytes of each disk, using the Mersenne Twister pseudorandom generator. The malware continues to enumerate the logical drives as well, wiping every file of each disk with random bytes. In addition, it is assumed that the malware operators use tools, such as Impacket, to move laterally. On some occasions, the malware was deployed alongside the RemCom remote access tool, which may imply a connection between both malware.
content.AdditionalInformation: On February 25, 2022, the IsaacWiper operators deployed a new version of the malware with debug logs, suggesting that they were unable to wipe some of the compromised devices and wanted to determine the reason for further development.

content.Overview:
The HermeticRansom ransomware (AKA PartyTicket, Elections GoRansom) was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in February 2022. The malware was used to attack Ukrainian entities and is suspectedly operated by Russian threat actors, amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War.

HermeticRansom, written in Golang, was observed to be distributed alongside the HermeticWiper malware, probably in an attempt to obscure the latter‚Äôs activity. On at least one occasion, HermeticRansom was deployed using the GPO deployment method, similar to HermeticWiper. Once deployed, the ransomware encrypts the files that are stored upon the victim‚Äôs computer, while dropping a ransomware note referencing a statement made by the United States President Joe Biden. In addition, the contact email address that appears in the note suggests voting for Joe Biden in the 2024 elections (‚Äúvote2024forjb‚Äù).
content.AdditionalInformation: Security researchers that investigated the ransomware‚Äôs cryptographic schema identified that it contains implementation errors, making its encryption breakable and slow. In March 2022, Avast published a decryptor for this ransomware. Further explanation on how to download and use the decryptor can be found here: https://decoded.avast.io/threatresearch/help-for-ukraine-free-decryptor-for-hermeticransom-ransomware/#howto.

content.Overview:
The HermeticWiper malware (AKA KillDisk.NCV), first reported by cybersecurity researchers in February 2022, has been active since at least December 2021. The malware targets Ukrainian entities and is suspectedly operated by Russian threat actors, amidst the geopolitical tension between the two countries. 

HermeticWiper, written in Golang, was observed being deployed after its operators leveraged different system vulnerabilities, such as in Microsoft Exchange servers and Microsoft SQL server, and installed webshells on the compromised machines. Once deployed, the malware abuses legitimate drivers from the EaseUS Partition Master software to corrupt compromised devices' files before rebooting the computer. In addition, it corrupts the master boot record (MBR), resulting in boot failure. HermeticWiper disguises as a ransomware, dropping a ransom note with a political message, but in fact deletes the data that is stored on the infected machines and shuts the machines down. 

HermeticWiper was used in close proximity to DDoS attacks that hit several Ukrainian government agencies and two of the largest state-owned banks in the country, so it might be an auxiliary tool for such attacks.   

The malware operators assigned it a digital certificate that was issued under a company named ‚ÄúHermetica Digital Ltd,‚Äù probably in an attempt to add credibility and avoid suspicion.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Asylum Ambuscade phishing campaign was observed by cybersecurity researchers in February 2022, amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War. The campaign was likely conducted by nation-state sponsored threat actors that targeted European government entities managing the logistics of the Ukrainian refugees (including transportation, budget allocation, administration, and population movement) within Europe.

The campaign operators were assumed to compromise a Ukrainian armed service member‚Äôs email account to send phishing email messages containing XLS files with malicious macro codes. Once the macro was enabled, a Lua-based malware, SunSeed, was downloaded to the victims‚Äô computers. The malware was likely used as a downloader for second stage payloads that were fetched from a remote command and control (C2) server with the general aim of collecting information about the logistics of the Ukrainian refugees.
content.AdditionalInformation: The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) attributed the campaign to the UNC1151 APT group (AKA Ghostwriter) that was previously observed targeting NATO personnel; however, Proofpoint researchers noted that this attribution is not definite.

content.Overview:
The Pandora ransomware group, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022, has been active since February 2022. The group targets American and Japanese organizations from various sectors, such as automotives, legal, technology, and real estate. There is little information about the group‚Äôs attack vector.

Once they have infiltrated a system, the threat actors move laterally while stealing and encrypting files, appending to them the .pandora extension. In addition, Pandora creates ransom notes named ‚Äú'Restore_My_Files.txt‚Äù in every folder. The ransom notes provide general information about the breach, contact details for ransom negotiations, and a link to the group‚Äôs data leak site that is used for double extortion purposes. 

On March 10, 2022, Pandora breached the Japanese automotive manufacturer Denso, claiming to steal 1.4 TB of files. The group started to leak the files, including purchase orders, technical schematics, and agreements. Denso confirmed the breach, that impacted its German division, but revealed no information about the extent and nature of information that was allegedly stolen. The company stated that there was no impact on other Denso facilities and no supply chain disruptions.   

Pandora is believed to be a rebrand of Rook ransomware due to code similarities. In addition, Rook also breached Denso in December 2021, so it is possible that the breach is ongoing and was conducted by the same group. Some researchers also point out similarities in the executable packer that is used by Pandora and the NightSky ransomware group.
content.AdditionalInformation: Other Pandora victims include: Jaffe Raitt Heuer & Weiss, P.C., GlobalWafers Japan, and the Rosewood Corporation.

content.Overview:
The CaddyWiper malware, used to attack Ukrainian organizations amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War, was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022. CaddyWiper was linked to pro-Russia threat groups, such as Sandworm (AKA Quedagh, Voodoo Bear).

While its initial access vector was not disclosed, CaddyWiper was deployed using the GPO deployment method, suggesting that its operators had already compromised the target‚Äôs network. Once installed, the malware was used to destroy and overwrite the data from any drives that were attached to the compromised system. To maintain system access, CaddyWiper used the DsRoleGetPrimaryDomainInformation() function to check if it operated on a domain controller. If so, it avoided erasing data.

Despite being released in close proximity to other wiping malware targeting Ukrainian organizations, such as HermeticWiper and IsaacWiper, CaddyWiper does not share any significant code similarities with them and appears to be created separately. There are indications that the malware was deployed on the same day that it was compiled.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

Techniques.Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification

content.Overview:
The Nokoyawa ransomware group (AKA UserNamme) was first observed in February 2022. Trend Micro researchers found that it primarily targets South American organizations, specifically in Argentina, although another researcher also connected it to attacks against Chinese-speakers located in Southeast Asia. Nokoyawa is assumed to be linked to the Hive ransomware, due to attack chain similarities between the two.

Like Hive, the Nokoyawa operators use Cobalt Strike for post-exploitation, and legitimate tools, such as the anti-rootkit scanners GMER and PC Hunter, for security evasion. They also use other tools to enhance their attack capabilities, such as Mimikatz for credential harvesting, the Z0Miner cryptojacking malware, and the Boxter Trojan. In addition, Nokoyawa is assumed to be spread via phishing email messages, similar to Hive.

Nokoyawa differs from Hive in that it uses a different compiler and its encryption routine is based on the BCryptGenRandom API rather than RTLGenRandom API. It uses the hardcoded expression ‚Äúlvcelcve‚Äù and Salsa to encrypt the files and an ECDH key pair to encrypt the key. The encrypted files are appended with the .NOKOYAWA extension or an extension that carries the victim‚Äôs name. The ransom note that is deployed often also carries the victim‚Äôs name, as well as the contact email addresses.

Nokoyawa operates an active leak site, in which it publishes the data of victims who refused the group‚Äôs ransom demands.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
Aberebot is an Android banking Trojan that was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in July 2021. The Trojan primarily targets banking and cryptocurrency applications in countries such as the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Italy, Spain, Germany, India, Japan, and Australia. In March 2022, a new Aberebot variant named Escobar started to be distributed among Android users. 

Aberebot usually spreads via smishing campaigns, in which SMS or instant messages are sent to the victims, enticing them to download a seemingly legitimate application (e.g. Google Chrome) or directing them to phishing websites that are used to steal their credentials. The downloaded app then asks for various permissions, such as Accessibility Service and SMS management. Once granted, the malware is able to steal information from the compromised device. Aberebot can collect contact information, intercept and send SMS messages, collect the installed applications list, trigger overlay attacks to steal credentials, and monitor the device‚Äôs activity. 

In November 2021, a newer version, Aberebot 2.0. was observed. This variant can also use Telegram APIs as a command and control (C2) server to communicate with its operators. Telegram channels are more difficult to be taken down, as the platform does not share user information with law enforcement agencies. In addition, the malware featured new capabilities, such as stealing messages from chatting apps, capturing web browser cookies, and disabling security features, like Google Play Protect.

The Aberebot developers initially put the malware for sale in underground forums for the price of 7,000 dollars. However, they later announced that ‚Äúdue to personal reasons,‚Äù the malware development stopped; a lifetime license can be bought for 300 dollars and the source code for 3,000 dollars. In addition, they stated that the malware has issues in disabling the Google Play Protect.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In March 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on a new Aberebot variant named Escobar that was spread as a fake McAfee application. The new variant was added new features, such as the ability to steal data from Google Authenticator and to take control of the infected device using VNC. The malware's author offered its beta version for rent on underground hacking forums. Escobar's renting price was initially $3,000 per month but is expected to rise to $5,000 once its development is finished.   

Among the companies whose applications were targeted by Aberebot: Barclays, Chase, Capital One, BBVA, BNP Paribas, Deutsche Bank, Akbank, National Australia Bank, Westpac Bank, Coinbase, and BitMarket.

content.Overview:
The RURansom wiping malware was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022. It is a new variant of an existing wiper that appears to only target IP addresses located in Russia.
 
Despite its name, analysis has revealed it to be a wiper and not a ransomware variant. The encryption algorithm is AES-CBC using a hard-coded salt. The keys are unique for each encrypted file and are not stored anywhere, making the encryption irreversible and marking the malware as a wiper rather than a ransomware variant due to its irreversible destruction of encrypted files.
content.AdditionalInformation:
The malware is written in the .NET programming language and spreads like a worm by copying itself to all removable disks and mapped network shares.

After successfully spreading, the malware then begins encryption, which is applied to all file extensions except for ‚Äú.bak‚Äù files, which are deleted. The files are encrypted with a randomly generated key with a length equal to base64.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
TeaBot (AKA Anatsa, Toddler) is an Android banking Trojan that was first observed in January 2021. The Trojan targets banking apps mostly in Europe, in countries such as the United Kingdom, Belgium, Italy, Spain, Germany, and the Netherlands. It supports six languages: Spanish, English, Italian, German, French, and Dutch. Sometimes, the TeaBot banking Trojan was distributed alongside other banking malware, such as FluBot (AKA Cabassous).

TeaBot usually spreads via smishing campaigns, in which SMS messages are sent to the victims, enticing them to download a seemingly legitimate application, or directing them to compromised websites from which the app could be downloaded. TeaBot uses various types of malicious apps, such as media players (e.g. VLC MediaPlayer), delivery services (e.g. UPS), streaming apps (e.g. TeaTV), and antivirus software (e.g. Kaspersky). Once the app is installed on a victim‚Äôs device, communication with a command and control (C2) server is established and the TeaBot payload is executed targeting predetermined banking apps.

Like other banking malware, TeaBot is capable of collecting system data, accessing the device‚Äôs contact list, intercepting and managing SMS messages, logging keystrokes, taking screenshots, triggering overlay attacks via Accessibility Services to steal credentials and credit card information, and gaining full control of the device. The malware can also steal Google Authentication 2FA codes and disable security software. The obtained data is exfiltrated to a remote C2 server every 10 seconds.

In November 2021, cybersecurity researchers reported on several Android campaigns that took place between August and November 2021, resulting in more than 300,000 infections of Android banking Trojans in the Google Play Store. TeaBot was among the banking Trojans that were used by the Brunhilda dropper operators, to compromise mobile devices and steal valuable information. The threat actor hid the TeaBot Trojan in decoy QR code scanners, PDF scanners, and cryptocurrency apps.

In January 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on another TeaBot campaign, in which 17 variants of the malware were hidden in fake Google Play Store applications. The applications included QR code scanners, device cleaning apps, and weather forecasting apps, that were together downloaded more than 150,000 times. The malicious APKs were distributed via paid Google Ads and ads published in legitimate Android applications, and were fetched from GitHub repositories. The malware was not executed if the device's country code belonged to Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Uruguay, or the United States.

In March 2022, Cleafy researchers reported on a new version of the TeaBot dropper masqerading as a QR code reader. The new TeaBot version can attack home banking applications, insurances applications, crypto wallets and crypto exchanges. In addition, it has advanced obfuscation routines and supports new languages, such as Russian, Slovak, and Mandarin Chinese.
content.AdditionalInformation: Among the companies whose applications were targeted by TeaBot: Chase, Wells Fargo, 	J.P. Morgan, Bank of America, Deutsche Bank, BBVA, ABN AMRO, E*TRADE, Coinbase, Raiffeisen Bank, ING Australia, Westpac One (NZ), and Emirates NBD.

content.Overview:
The DirtyMoe botnet (AKA NuggetPhantom) has been active since at least 2016. The botnet, assumed to be operated from China, spreads globally, infecting thousands of Windows computers each year, primarily located in Russia, Ukraine, Vietnam, and Brazil.

DirtyMoe is usually distributed via phishing email messages with infected files that contain malicious links to websites hosting the PurpleFox exploit kit. PurpleFox leverages various system vulnerabilities, such as EternalBlue (CVE-2017-0144) and the Hot Potato Windows Privilege Escalation, to gain admin privileges. Using these privileges, the attackers utilize Windows MSI installer to deploy DirtyMoe while abusing the Windows System Event Notification Service (SENS). To evade detection, the MSI installer replaces the SENS system DLL file with a malicious payload and executes it as a legitimate service. In addition, the DirtyMoe operators use VMProtect and file encryption to evade security mechanisms. Once installed, the botnet can be used for cryptojacking and for executing distributed denial-of-service attacks (DDoS).       

DirtyMoe has worming capabilities, generating and attacking hundreds of thousands of IP addresses that are related to the geological location of the worming module. The attacks can occur hourly or daily based on the worm module‚Äôs configuration.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Diavol ransomware group was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in June 2021. The group is linked to Wizard Spider, a Russian group responsible for TrickBot. 

Investigation of TrickBot samples lead to the discovery that besides the usual Conti ransomware payload, TrickBot delivered previously unseen ransomware that security researchers dubbed Diavol. Conti and Diavol ransomware strains seem similar, as they both use asynchronous input/output operations for file encryption and utilize command-line parameters for the same functionality, such as logging, drives and network shares encryption, network scanning.

However, there are several differences between the ransomware families. For example, Diavol lacks the data-exfiltration capabilities that Conti possesses.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Diavol ransomware's encryption procedure uses user-mode Asynchronous Procedure Calls (APCs) with an asymmetric encryption algorithm, which sets it apart from other ransomware families as they commonly use symmetric algorithms to significantly speed up the encryption process.

Diavol also lacks any obfuscation as it does not use packing or anti-disassembly tricks, but it still manages to make analysis harder by storing its main routines within bitmap images.

When executing on a compromised machine, the ransomware extracts the code from the images' PE resource section and loads it within a buffer with execution permissions.

The code it extracts amounts to 14 different routines that will execute in the following order:

    ‚Ä¢ Create an identifier for the victim
    ‚Ä¢ Initialize configuration
    ‚Ä¢ Register with the C&C server and update the configuration
    ‚Ä¢ Stop services and processes
    ‚Ä¢ Initialize encryption key
    ‚Ä¢ Find all drives to encrypt
    ‚Ä¢ Find files to encrypt
    ‚Ä¢ Prevent recovery by deleting shadow copies
    ‚Ä¢ Encryption
    ‚Ä¢ Change the desktop wallpaper

Diavol ransomware will change each encrypted Windows device's background to a black wallpaper with the following message: "All your files are encrypted! For more information see README-FOR-DECRYPT.txt".

In August 2021, IBM X-Force researchers further established the link between Diavol and Wizard Spider, by finding similarities to other malware that has been attributed to the cybercrime group. They also found that Diavol's source code has the ability to terminate arbitrary processes and that it prioritizes file types to encrypt, based on a pre-defined list set by its operator. In addition, the HTTP headers used for Diavol's command and control (C2) communication are set to prefer Russian language content, and it contains language checks to prevent it from operating on users from Russia or the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). This also strengthens the connection to the Russian Wizard Spider group.

In January 2022, the FBI formally linked between Diavol and Wizard Spider. The FBI is assumed to learn about the connection following the arrest of a Latvian woman named Alla Witte, who was involved in ransomware development for Wizard Spider. It was also reported that Diavol's current ransom demands range between 10,000 and 500,000 dollars, and that the group's ransom notes are now named "Warning.txt."

In March 2022, Emsisoft released a free decryptor for Diavol. Instructions on how to apply the decryptor can be found here: https://www.emsisoft.com/ransomware-decryption-tools/howtos/emsisoft_howto_diavol.pdf

content.Overview:
Grief ransomware, AKA PayOrGrief, emerged around the end of May 2021. A sample of the malware code and ransom note that was analyzed by security researchers indicated that it was compiled on May 17, 2021. At the same time, a reputed ransomware operation, DoppelPaymer (RaaS), seems to have suspended their activity (around May 6, 2021) and there was significantly less activity on the group‚Äôs data-leak website. The researchers‚Äô findings that the ransom link redirected to the DoppelPaymer ransom website, together with the suspension of public activity indicates that DoppelPaymer may have rebranded under the name Grief, and developed new infrastructure. 

Grief uses 2048-bit RSA and 256-bit AES, same as the encryption algorithms and distribution channel (Dridex) of the DoppelPaymer malware. Grief operators use anti-crawl protection to prevent attempts of indexing the group‚Äôs data-leak website. Grief operators try to add additional pressure on their victims to pay the ransom demand by utilizing the European Union‚Äôs General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and systems downtime statistics costs on their website.
content.AdditionalInformation: In October 2021, the Grief operators claimed to have attacked the National Rifle Association (NRA), and published screenshots of the alleged stolen data on their leak site. The data includes US tax information, investments amounts, and a 2.7 MB archive named "National Grants.zip," which may contain NRA grant applications. The NRA has not publicly acknowledged or denied the occurrence of such an incident until March 2022.

content.Overview:
The Exotic Lily threat group was first observed by Google researchers in September 2021. The financially-motivated group serves as an initial access broker for the global operations of the Conti and Diavol ransomware groups and seems to be also involved with the notorious threat groups Wizard Spider and FIN12. Exotic Lily greatly overlaps with a group that is tracked by Microsoft as DEV-0413.

The threat actors initiate phishing campaigns, distributing up to 5,000 email messages a day. The messages are usually sent from spoofed domains that are identical to real domain names of existing organizations, with the TLD being replaced with .us, .co, or .biz. To add more credibility, Exotic Lily sometimes creates fake personas posing as employees of genuine companies, while generating fake social media profiles, personal websites, and even fabricating AI-designed profile pictures. The group uses lures, such as business proposals, and even engages in further negotiations to build a relationship with their target. Once gaining the victim‚Äôs trust, the threat actors upload the malicious payload via public file-sharing services (e.g. TransferNow, TransferXL, WeTransfer, or OneDrive) and then use a built-in email notification feature to share the file with the target. This way the final email message carries the mail address of a legitimate file-sharing service and not the one that is used by the threat actors, which helps them evade security mechanisms. 

Exotic Lily initially distributed malicious documents with an exploit for a zero-day vulnerability in Microsoft MSHTML (CVE-2021-40444) but later was observed delivering ISO archives that contained concealed BazarLoader DLLs and LNK shortcuts. Since March 2022, the group has used the ISO archives to include a DLL with a custom malware loader, Bumblebee. Bumblebee uses Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to collect general system information, such as OS version and domain name, and then exfiltrates it to a remote command and control (C2) server. In addition, it can fetch secondary payloads, such as Cobalt Strike.

Exotic Lily‚Äôs members seem to work in a 9 to 5 model during weekdays, in a Central or Eastern Europe time zone, with little activity over the weekends.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The B1txor20 Linux botnet was first observed by Qihoo 360's Netlab in February 2022. As B1txor20 still seems under development, there is little information about its intended targets, except that it‚Äôs being operated on Linux ARM, X64 CPU architecture devices. The malware‚Äôs name is made up of the file name ‚Äúb1t‚Äù that is used for its propagation, the XOR encryption algorithm, and the RC4 algorithm key length of 20 bytes.

B1txor20 spreads by exploiting the Log4j vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228) and uses DNS channeling to build command and control (C2) communication channels. To protect traffic, the malware uses ZLIB compression, RC4 encryption, and Base64 encoding. Once deployed, B1txor20 can be used to perform 14 different commands that are received from the C2 server, such as creating reverse shells, executing arbitrary commands, installing rootkits, opening SOCKS5 proxies, and sending sensitive information to the C2 server.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The DarkHotel threat group, first reported in November 2014, has been active since at least 2007. It targets hotel and business center WiFi, physical connections, and peer-to-peer and file-sharing networks. The APT group usually gains initial access via spear phishing messages with highly-advanced Flash zero-day exploits

DarkHotel‚Äôs most unusual characteristic is that for several years it maintained a capability to use hotel networks to follow and hit selected targets as they travel around the world. These travelers are often top executives from a variety of industries doing business and outsourcing in the APAC region. Targets have included CEOs, senior vice presidents, sales and marketing directors, and top R&D staff. This hotel network intrusion set provides the attackers with precise global scale access to high-value targets. 

In order to pollute P2P networks to infect the chosen hotel infrastructure, DarkHotel delegitimizes certificate authorities to further their attacks, by abusing weakly implemented digital certificates to sign their malicious files.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In 2015, Kaspersky researchers identified the use of spoofed, malicious RAR attachments using right-to-left override (RTLO) technique, spear phishing, and the deployment of a Flash zero-day from this APT.

In June 2016, Microsoft researchers reported that they reverse engineered the first stage payload of the malware used by this APT dubbed DUBNIUM. The researchers reported that the malware used in the DarkHotel attacks disguises itself as a Secure Shell (SSH) certificate generation tool. 

In July 2017, Bitdefender researchers reported about a new DarkHotel campaign which they dubbed Inexsmar. This campaign differs from other campaigns as the threat actors targeted political figures rather than corporate research and development personnel, CEOs, and other senior corporate officials.

In August 2019, Trend Micro researchers claimed that the Asruex malware has been known for its backdoor capabilities and is in use by the DarkHotel APT.

In January 2020, DarkHotel used Microsoft Office documents for targeted attacks using a zero-day in Internet Explorer. 

In March 2020, the APT attacked the World Health Organization (WHO), amidst the COVID-19 pandemic outburst. It is assumed that threat actors looked for information on tests, vaccines, or trial cures.

In April 2020, researchers from Qihoo 360 identified attacks against at least 200 VPN servers around the world. The attack was carried out using a zero-day exploit that exists in an update that is triggered automatically when the VPN client starts to connect to the server. According to the researchers, ‚ÄúThe client will obtain [an] update from the configuration file at a fixed location on the connected VPN server, and download a program called SangforUD.exe.‚Äù
Due to the fact that the client doesn‚Äôt make any security checks before downloading the executable, the attackers can hijack the session, alter the update configuration file, and replace the update program with their own malicious code.

In May 2020, ESET researchers discovered a previously unreported cyberespionage framework that they dubbed Ramsay. This framework collects and exfiltrates sensitive documents and it is capable of operating within air‚Äëgapped (Isolated) networks.

In August 2020, researchers from the Chinese security firm Qihoo 360 analyzed a Trojan sample that they attributed to DarkHotel. This Trojan is hijacking and replacing the print spooler service thinmon.dll in order to inject a backdoor with abilities as a keylogger, screen capture, and file theft.

In March 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on a new DarkHotel campaign that was initiated between November 2021 and January 2022. The campaign targeted hotels in Macao using Excel files with malicious macro codes. Once the macro was enabled, it loaded the Task Scheduler Service that was used to execute malicious payloads for data collection purposes. In some cases, the threat actors impersonated government entities, such as the Macao Government Tourism Office and the Government of the Federated States of Micronesia.    

Kaspersky researchers published recommendations on how to best protect against the DarkHotel attacks:
- When accessing public (or even semi-public) WiFi, always use trusted VPN tunnels. The VPN can give you an encrypted barrier to keep out infected servers from feeding malware bait into your connection.
- Learn and understand the red flags of spear phishing attacks. Odd spelling in the sender‚Äôs email address and a prompt to open a link or attachment can be caution signs. Attackers tend to use urgency and heighten your emotions to get you to take immediate action and compromise yourself. An increase in panic, fear, or curiosity can also indicate risks.
- Verify the authenticity of the email via official phone numbers or in-person contact when possible. Do not use any contact information found within the email as it could also be fraudulent.
- Maintain and update all system software. Security patches for existing, known software vulnerabilities are packaged in software updates. You should download updates promptly, provided you have verified through official vendor channels that they are not false.
- Always verify executable files and treat files shared over P2P networks with caution and suspicion. Again, these files can easily be bait for malware infections. Even legitimate files can be modified for a hacker‚Äôs benefit.
- When traveling, try to limit software updates. If you can avoid accepting any software updates while away from secure workplace networks, you can minimize your risks of these known hotel WiFi exploits.
- Install quality Internet security software. Make sure it includes proactive defense against new threats rather than just basic antivirus scanning and malware removal. Web protection like link threat-scanning and phishing filters can help combat threats like those used by DarkHotel.

content.Overview:
The InvisiMole threat group (AKA UAC-0035), first reported by ESET researchers in June 2018, has been active since at least 2013. The cyberespionage group targets military and diplomatic entities in Eastern Europe, specifically in Russia and Ukraine. It is linked to the Russian APT group Gamaredon (AKA Primitive Bear), conducting joint operations.

InvisiMole seems to rely on Gamaredon for providing initial system access, but was also observed actively sending phishing email messages to distribute malware. The threat actors deliver their malicious payloads via four different execution chains, using living off the land techniques (LotL). To stay undetected and maintain persistence they use vulnerable executables of legitimate tools, such as Total Video Player and the SpeedFan utility. In addition, they employ DNS tunneling for stealthy command and control (C2) communications and encrypt some of the payloads using Data Protection API (DPAPI). 

InvisiMole deploys a modular spyware of the same name that has two modules acting as backdoors, RC2FM and RC2CL. RC2FM can track geolocation, open user webcams, take screenshots, record audio, and steal documents. It also uses Media Transfer Protocol (MTP) to steal photos from mobile devices that are connected to the compromised computer. RC2CL can execute files, manipulate registry keys, activate remote shells, scan wireless networks, list installed software, and more. The threat actors move laterally in the compromised system by leveraging various vulnerabilities, such as the BlueKeep vulnerability (CVE-2019-0708) in the RDP protocol and the EternalBlue vulnerability (CVE-2017-0144) in Microsoft‚Äôs Server Message Block (SMBv1), and by weaponizing documents and software installers that exist in the system.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In March 2022, the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) warned against InvisiMole phishing campaigns targeting Ukrainian organizations and spreading the LoadEdge backdoor. The threat actors sent phishing email messages that contained ZIP archives with shortcut LNK files. Once the LNK file was opened, an HTA file was deployed and executed a VBScript to fetch and decode the backdoor. The backdoor established a connection to a C2 server and downloaded additional malicious payloads, such as the RC2FM and RC2CL spyware, and also TunnelMole, abusing the DNS protocol to form a tunnel for malicious software distribution.

content.Overview:
The Serpent backdoor was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022. The malware targets French organizations in the construction, real estate, and government sectors. Serpent‚Äôs name stems from parts of the macro code, used to deploy it, and include an ASCII art depicting a snake. The ASCII art also contains the word ‚ÄúNaHash‚Äù (‚Äúsnake,‚Äù in Hebrew), indicating that the malware may have been created by a Hebrew-speaking developer.   

Serpent, written in Python, is distributed via phishing email messages that contain Microsoft Word documents with malicious macro codes. The messages impersonate a known and legitimate entity, such as the European Union's General Data Protection Regulations agency (GDPR). Once the macros are enabled, a JPG file is fetched from a remote URL, containing a base64 encoded PowerShell script that is concealed in the image using steganography. The PowerShell script downloads the Chocolatey Windows package manager that is used to install the pip Python package installer and the PySocks library. Then, another JPG is downloaded, which contains a base64-encoded Python script that executes a BAT file that deploys the Serpent backdoor. Once deployed, the malware communicates with a remote command and control (C2) server and receives commands to be executed on the compromised system, such as downloading additional malware, stealing data, and gaining remote system control. 

Serpent is assumed to be operated by a sophisticated threat actor, due to the use of steganography and the Chocolatey utility, which has never been observed to be leveraged before on cyberattacks. In addition, it uses schtasks.exe, a novel technique to execute any requested portable executable file while bypassing detection by security mechanisms.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The DoubleZero wiper, used to attack Ukrainian organizations amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War, was first reported by the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) in March 2022. The malware was attributed to the UAC-0088 threat group that is assumed to support Russia. 

DoubleZero, written in C#, was distributed via spear phishing email messages that contained ZIP archives with the malware, in the form of obfuscated .NET programs. DoubleZero was first used to overwrite files using zero blocks of 4096 bytes or the API calls NtFileOpen, NtFsControlFile. Then, it deleted Windows registry files and shut down the compromised devices.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Storm Cloud threat group has been active since at least 2018. This Chinese APT group targets organizations across Asia, specifically focusing on Tibetan entities.

Storm Cloud usually gains initial access via strategic web compromises while exhorting victims to download and install malicious software pretending to be legitimate (e.g. an Adobe Flash update). These malicious software are used to distribute various types of malware, such as PLUGDAT, STITCH, GOSLU, BRAINDAMAGE, and the custom GIMMICK malware. 

GIMMICK has a Windows variant written in .NET and Delphi and a macOS variant written in Objective C. To evade detection, it usually impersonates a software that is frequently used by the user. Once installed, it connects to a command and control (C2) server by establishing a session with Google Drive using hardcoded OAuth2 credentials. Then, it loads three malware components, DriveManager, FileManager, and GCDTimerManager, to manage the C2 communication. GIMMICK can execute commands that it receives from the C2 server, such as uploading and downloading files, exfiltrating general system information, and overwriting client work period information. In addition, it can uninstall itself and all of its associated files. On March 17, 2022, Apple issued new signatures for its XProtect suite and malware removal tool (MRT) that should block GIMMICK and remove it from infected devices.       

Storm Cloud is considered to be a sophisticated threat group, supporting attacks against multiple operating systems. The large and complex GIMMICK malware suggests that it is well resourced, probably by the Chinese government.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Scarab threat group (AKA UAC-0026), first reported by Symantec researchers in January 2015, has been active since at least 2012. This Chinese APT group primarily targets Russian-speaking individuals located both inside and outside of Russia, in sectors such as government, retail, and finance. In March 2022, the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) reported that Scarab targeted Ukranian entities amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War.    

Scarab usually gains initial system access through phishing email messages that contain RAR archives with malicious macro-embedded documents. The group uses lures, either ones adapted to the targeted entity (e.g. economic, military, etc.) or generic lures. Once the document‚Äôs macro code is enabled, it drops a DLL file that contains the HeaderTip backdoor (formerly Scieron). The C++-based malware can collect general system information, such as the computer name and OS version, download and execute additional files, exfiltrate files from the victim‚Äôs computer, delete files, list directories, and move files to other folders. In addition, it can be used as a first-stage malware loader to fetch a tool with rootkit functionalities that can create and terminate processes, read, write, and delete registry entries and directories, launch remote shells, and more.

Despite focusing on Russian-speaking victims and sometimes sending lures written in Russian, there is evidence that Scarab uses the Windows operating system in a Chinese language setting. The threat actor‚Äôs main motivation is assumed to be the collection of geopolitical intelligence.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Muhstik botnet (AKA Mushtik, Tsunami, and Amnesia) has been active since at least 2017. The botnet, based on the Mirai source code, spreads globally, infecting Linux-based IoT devices and small office/home office (SOHO) networking equipment, such as DD-WRT, GPON, and Tomato routers. 

Muhstik usually gains initial access either by performing brute force attacks or by exploiting known vulnerabilities, such as in Drupal‚Äôs CMS platform (CVE-2018-7600), Oracle‚Äôs WebLogic server (CVE-2019-2725 and CVE-2017-10271), the Atlassian Confluence server (CVE-2021-26084), the Apache Log4j library (CVE-2021-44228), and the Redis server (CVE-2022-0543). Once infiltrating the system, Muhstik connects to a command and control (C2) server using Internet Relay Chat (IRC) protocol and downloads encrypted payloads with scanners for detecting specific technologies or vulnerabilities. The scanners are used to find additional targets and then spread to them like a worm. In addition, the botnet uses the C2 server to fetch cryptominers, such as XMRig and CGMiner, to be executed on the infected machines, and to receive other commands like orchestrating distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks.  

Muhstik is assumed to be linked to a Chinese forensics firm called Shen Zhou Wang Yun Information Technology Co. Ltd., that is suspected of developing other types of malware, such as the HiddenWasp Trojan. Muhstik was observed to be used by the Team TNT group among others.
content.AdditionalInformation: Disclaimer: on the IOCs section are detailed domains and IP addresses that security researchers related to Muhstik's activity. Most of them seem suspicious, but they are not verified to have malicious intentions. We advise you to use these IOCs with caution and verify them before adding them to your block-list. Among these domains may be legitimate domains, which will cause false-positive on your organization‚Äôs network.

content.Overview:
The Beastmode botnet (AKA B3astmode) has been active since at least 2020. The botnet, based on the Mirai source code, spreads globally, initiating distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against SSH servers, different types of routers (e.g. Huawei and Totolink), and IoT devices.

The Beastmode operators gain initial system access either by performing brute force attacks or by exploiting known vulnerabilities, such as in Realtek SDK (CVE-2014-8361), Huawei HG532 routers (CVE-2017-17215), and Totolink routers (CVE-2022-26210, CVE-2022-26186, and CVE-2022-25075). The exploitation of vulnerabilities enables the botnet to take control over the devices, download a shell script to register them as part of the botnet, and use the compromised devices‚Äô hardware resources to launch DDoS attacks (e.g. TCP and UDP flood).
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The AcidRain wiper was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022, amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War. The wiper was used to attack the KA-SAT satellite broadband network, owned by Viasat, on February 24, 2022, the day of the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The attack caused satellite service outages and severe communications disruptions in Ukraine and the surrounding areas. In addition, it made 5,800 Enercon wind turbines in Germany unreachable. 

The AcidRain operators exploited a misconfiguration in a VPN appliance to deploy the malware, which is a Linux MIPS ELF executable. AcidRain first brute-forced the targeted device‚Äôs file names and then moved laterally through the compromised router or modem, wiping every file it could find. The malware executed legitimate management commands on many devices simultaneously, overwriting data and destroying flash memory, SD/MMC cards, and virtual block devices. It was designed to overwrite file contents with up to 0x40000 bytes of data or to use the following input/output control (IOCTL) system calls: MEMGETINFO, MEMUNLOCK, MEMERASE, and MEMWRITEOOB. Once the wiping process was completed, AcidRain rebooted the compromised devices, making them unusable.     

AcidRain shares similarities with the VPNFilter stage 3 plugin ‚Äúdstr,‚Äù a wiper that was previously used by Russian state-sponsored APT groups, such as APT28 (AKA Fancy Bear) and Sandworm. Thus, it is assumed to be operated by the Russian government as well.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The BlackGuard information-stealing malware was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in April 2021, after it was put for sale on underground hacking forums. The infostealer is distributed as a malware-as-a-service (MaaS) by user monikers ‚ÄúBlackGUARD07‚Äù and ‚Äúblackteam007‚Äù, for the price of $700 or a subscription of $200 per month.

BlackGuard, written in C#, initially performs checks for the presence of a debugger and aborts operation if one is identified. In addition, it blocks all mouse and keyboard inputs to disrupt debugging attempts, terminates all processes that are related to security mechanisms, such as antiviruses, and uses the Sleep() function several times as an anti-sandbox technique. Another method for avoiding detection is the use of dual decoding. The malware that is encoded in an array of bytes is first decoded into ASCII strings during runtime and then into Base64.

Once all anti-detection routines are completed, BlackGuard creates a storage directory in the compromised machine and starts harvesting various types of data such as user credentials, web browser information (e.g. cookies, history, and autofill), cryptocurrency information, email client data, and instant messaging correspondences. It also takes screenshots of the infected system. The stolen data is sorted into different folders, packed in a ZIP file, and exfiltrated to a Telegram command and control (C2) server via a POST request, along with system descriptors, such as hardware ID and geolocation.       

While the identity of the BlackGuard developers is unknown, they are assumed to be Russian or Russian speakers. This is strengthened by the fact that the infostealer stops its operation if the compromised device is located in one of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), e.g. Russia, Belarus, or Azerbaijan.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Cyclops Blink botnet has been used by the Sandworm group (AKA Voodoo Bear) since June 2019. It targets WatchGuard Firebox and other Small Office/Home Office (SOHO) network devices, and grants the threat actors remote access to networks. Cyclops Blink is estimated to affect approximately 1% of all active WatchGuard firewall appliances in the world. The most targeted countries are the United States, India, Italy, and Canada.

Cyclops Blink, written in the C language, leverages the legitimate firmware update process, and maintains system access and persistence by injecting malicious code and installing repacked firmware images. In addition, the malware is deployed along with modules that are developed to download and execute additional files from a remote command and control (C2) server, collect and send general system information, and update the malware. It uses OpenSSL functions for data encryption, based on AES-256 and RSA-2560. 

In March 2022, Trend Micro researchers reported on a Cyclops Blink variant that can target Asus routers. The Asus module can extract SSD storage information and information about network interfaces. In addition, it can download files from the Internet using DNS over HTTPS (DoH). As opposed to other Cyclops Blink modules, this module does not have an update feature.

In April 2022, the US government announced that it disrupted the operation of Cyclops Blink. The malware was removed from all identified Watchguard devices serving as command and control servers.
content.AdditionalInformation:

Most of them seem suspicious, but they are not verified to have malicious intentions. We advise you to use these IOCs with caution and verify them before adding them to your block-list. Among these domains may be legitimate domains, which will cause false-positive on your organization‚Äôs network.

content.Overview: Desert Falcons (AKA Arid Viper, APT-C-23, Two-tailed Scorpion) is considered to be the first Arabic language advanced persistent threat (APT) group. They were formed in early 2011 and started operating in 2013. The group comprises dozens of attackers, some who are known by name, that operate from various Arab-speaking locations, such as the Palestinian territories, Egypt, and Turkey. Desert Falcons targets mostly entities in the Middle East, specifically Israel, but has also been observed operating against other countries, such as the United States and South Korea. The group is primarily interested in obtaining sensitive intelligence information and its victims are companies and individuals from various sectors, such as government, military, education, finance, energy, media, trade and commerce, and religion. Currently, it is unclear whether Desert Falcons is state-sponsored.
content.AdditionalInformation:
The group‚Äôs first major operation was in 2015, dubbed ‚ÄúOperation Arid Viper,‚Äù in which spear phishing email messages were sent to one Kuwaiti organization and to five Israeli-based organizations in the government, transport, infrastructure, military, and academic sectors. Each message contained an .RAR archive file that automatically extracted an .SCR file. Once executed, the .SCR file dropped two other files, one containing a malicious payload and the other containing pornographic content, possibly in order to distract the victim. The dropped malware communicated with the command and control (C2) server and was used to steal documents from the infected systems.  

In mid-2017, cybersecurity researchers reported that the group used Windows malware dubbed Kasperagent and Micropsia, in attacks aimed mainly at targets in the United States, Israel, the Palestinian Territories, and Egypt. The malware spread through spear phishing email messages and social media instant messages that contain malicious links. The group also set up various fake news websites with lures leading to a malware download. The malware can steal web browser passwords, take screenshots, record keystrokes, exfiltrate files, and more. In addition, the threat actors used malicious apps, loaded with SecureUpdate and Vamp Android malware. Those apps were used to steal user credentials, record calls, and steal messages and documents stored on Android devices. 

Later that year, other mobile spyware, such as FrozenCell, were found to be used by the group. FrozenCell was disguised in fake updates to chat applications like Facebook, WhatsApp, Messenger, LINE, and LoveChat. It was assumed to target employees of various Palestinian government agencies, security services, Palestinian students, and those affiliated with the Fatah political party.

In February 2020, the IDF and the ISA (the Israeli NSA) conducted an operation to take down a Hamas-affiliated threat actor associated with Desert Falcons. The threat actor targeted IDF soldiers through dating apps, setting up fake profiles of attractive women to infect their devices with mobile RATs. 

In September 2020, ESET researchers reported that Desert Falcons developed an improved variant of their Android spyware. The new version, dubbed Android/SpyC32.A, was disguised as a legitimate messaging app offered via Google Play (e.g. Threema and WeMessage), and had many features, such as reading notifications from messaging apps like WhatsApp and Telegram, recording calls, capturing screenshots, and more.
Later that year, researchers discovered that the group started using a new variant for the MICROPSIA malware, dubbed PyMICROPSIA, as it was built with Python. The improved malware was able to upload and delete files, record keystrokes, collect system information, exfiltrate files, and download and execute additional malicious payloads.

In April 2021, Facebook announced that it dismantled the platform infrastructure of two hacking groups, including Desert Falcons, by taking down accounts and blocking domains associated with their activity.

In October 2021, Qihoo360 researchers discovered samples of Android spyware found in various applications that masqueraded as legitimate applications, such as Threema, Al-Aqsa Radio, Al-Aqsa Mosque, Jerusalem Guide, and PDF viewer. The malicious apps were claimed to be part of a campaign that was ongoing since 2018, targeting Israeli and Palestinean users. The users are directed to these apps through Facebook posts or WhatsApp messages that direct them to websites from which the APKs can be downloaded. The threat actors, assumed to be Desert Falcons, spread various malware during the campaign, such as SpyNote, Mobihok, WH-RAT, and 888RAT.

In November 2021, cybersecurity researchers discovered new Android spyware variants used by the group. The spyware masquerades as legitimate update apps (e.g. App Updates, System Apps Updates, or Android Update Intelligence), suspectedly delivered to users via SMS messages linking to downloads. Once installed, the malware communicates with a C2 server and is capable of collecting information about the device's contact list, SMS messages, call logs, and stealing images and documents. In addition, it can record audio, intercept calls, take screenshots, read social media notifications, and disable security apps' notifications.

In February 2022, it was reported on another campaign by Desert Falcons targeting Palestinian entities. The threat actors used spear phishing email messages with political lures, in order to distribute the Micropsia malware.

In April 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on a new Desert Falcons campaign, targeting Israeli individuals and officials working for law enforcement, military and emergency services. In the course of the campaign, dubbed Operation Bearded Barbie, the threat actors created fake Facebook profiles and used social engineering techniques to lure victims into downloading Trojanized messaging applications deploying the VolatileVenom malware or RAR archives that acted as downloaders for the BarbWire backdoor. BarbWire, deployed by the Barb(ie) downloader, could be used for various malicious purposes, such as logging user keystrokes, recording audio, stealing and exfiltrating specific file types, and downloading additional malware. The VolatileVenom Android Trojan was used to steal mobile device data, such as SMS messages, audio, contact list information, and files and images that were stored upon the device.

content.Overview:
The Machete APT group (AKA APT-C-43) has been active since at least 2010. It targets organizations from various sectors, such as government, military, telecommunications, and energy. The spanish-speaking threat actors primarily focus on cyber espionage in Latin American countries, specifically Venezuela, but were also observed operating in the United States, Europe, and Asia.

Machete usually distributes its malware using social engineering methods, such as spear phishing email messages with self extracting RAR archives or fake blogs with malicious installers (e.g. Nullsoft installers). The malware executables contain Python scripts, which are not commonly used among cyber attackers. The Machete malware is designed to steal information, such as geolocation, keystrokes, stored files, clipboard content, and general system data. In addition, the malware can take screenshots and capture audio from the computer‚Äôs microphone. At the end of the data harvesting process, it is exfiltrated to a remote command and control (C2) server. The APT group was also observed dropping other types of information stealing malware, such as LokiRat.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In June 2020, cybersecurity researchers observed a Machete campaign using a new Python-based backdoor, called ‚ÄúPyark.‚Äù The campaign, dubbed ‚ÄúOperation HpReact,‚Äù targeted Venezuealan military entities and was assumed to support the reactionary forces residing in Colombia in their battle against the Venezuealan government. The threat actors used spear phishing email messages that contained decoy documents with malicious macro codes. Once the macros were enabled, the Pyark malware was deployed with the intent of stealing sensitive information.

At the end of March 2022, Check Point Research (CPR) published a report detailing three APT groups, including Machete, that took advantage of the Russo-Ukrainian War to compromise organizations. The group used war-related lures to deliver macro-embedded documents to financial institutions in Nicaragua and government entities in Venezuela. Triggering the malicious macro codes eventually led to the deployment of the Loki.Rat backdoor that could be used for various malicious purposes, such as logging user keystrokes, stealing web browser credentials, taking screenshots, and uploading and downloading files. If the compromised machine was deemed as interesting enough for the threat actors, they deployed another malware, JavaOracle.msi, installing Python-based executables with information stealing capabilities.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Borat RAT was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022, after it was promoted on underground hacking forums. The RAT is named after the known film character, whose photo appears on the malware‚Äôs dashboard. There is little information about Borat‚Äôs specific targets and it seems to support a wide range of malicious purposes.

Borat is offered in the form of a package that includes a builder binary, operative modules, and a server certificate. Each of the modules can perform different malicious activities. The malware can be used to perform DDoS attacks, deliver ransomware payloads and create a ransom note, log user keystrokes, record audio and webcam video, collect general system information (e.g. OS version and system model), steal web browser credentials, set up reverse proxies, inject malicious code into legitimate processes to evade detection, and many other activities.

The Borat RAT shares some similarities with the AsyncRAT, and it is possible that Borat was based on the same code.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Network Battalion 65' (NB65) is a hacking group affiliated with Anonymous.

On February 26, 2022, the group announced that they hacked the Nuclear Safety Institute of Moscow, followed by a release of 40,000 files associated with the leak. 

On February 27, 2022, the group published a video of a supposed breach to a Russian Industrial equipment supplier.

On March 1, 2022, the group announced that they "shut down" the Control Center of the Russian Space Agency "Roscosmos."

On March 10, 2022, NB65 claimed to leak the source code from the Russian antivirus firm Kaspersky. However, it appears that the leaked files were only a long list of HTML files and other related, publicly available web resources.

On March 25, 2022, NB65 claimed to hack the All-Russia State Television and Radio Broadcasting Company (VGTRK), accusing them of spreading Putin's propaganda. In addition, the hackers allegedly stole 870 GB of data from the company.

On April 9, 2022, it was reported that NB65 attacked Russian organizations using a modified ransomware that was based on Conti's leaked source code. When encrypting the files that are stored on the infected computer, the ransomware appends them the .NB65 extension and creates a ransom note named R3ADM3.txt with accusations against President Vladimir Putin.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Spring4Shell zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2022-22965) was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022. The vulnerability affects the Spring Core Java framework, Spring4Shell, that is maintained by Spring.io, a subsidiary of VMware. Spring is an application framework through which software developers can create Java applications with enterprise-level features and deploy them on servers, such as Apache Tomcat. A Chinese security researcher released a proof-of-concept (PoC) exploit for the flaw, but quickly deleted it.   

The Spring4Shell flaw enables threat actors to perform unauthenticated remote code execution on targeted systems. It affects the SpringMVC and Spring WebFlux applications running on JDK versions 9 and later, but can be triggered only under specific conditions. According to Praetorian, it requires an endpoint that has DataBinder enabled. 

There are reports that the vulnerability has been actively exploited in the wild.

On March 31, 2022, Spring confirmed the zero-day vulnerability and released Spring Framework versions 5.3.18 and 5.2.20 to address it.

On April 2, 2022, VMware published security updates for Spring4Shell affecting various of its cloud computing and virtualization products. The complete advisory can be found here: https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2022-0010.html

CISA added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities Catalog, urging organizations to apply the available fixes promptly.

On April 8, 2022, Trend Micro researchers reported that the Spring4Shell vulnerability was exploited by threat actors to distribute the Mirai botnet. The observed attack focused on vulnerable web servers in Singapore. The threat actors leveraged the vulnerability to write a JSP web shell into the webroot of the server to enable remote command execution. Then, they downloaded Mirai to the "/tmp" folder and executed it with the "wget.sh" script, probably to orchestrate distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks.
content.AdditionalInformation: More details about the vulnerability can be found in our blog: https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2022/03/30/spring4shell-zero-day-vulnerability-in-spring-framework/

content.Overview:
The Denonia malware was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in April 2022. It is considered as the first malware to specifically target Amazon Web Services (AWS) Lambda cloud environments. 

Denonia, written in Golang, is used as a dropper for cryptominers, such as a custom variant of the XMRig Monero mining software. While the malware operators‚Äô initial system access vector was not disclosed, it is assumed that they use stolen AWS access credentials or secret keys to download and execute the malware. To evade detection, the malware uses DNS over HTTPS (DoH) for command and control (C2) communications, concealing the traffic with encrypted connections. 

Although Denonia was designed to target AWS Lambda environments, it can also run on some Linux systems, such as Amazon Linux boxes.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Industroyer malware (AKA CrashOverride) was first observed in December 2016, in an attack on Ukraine power stations that cut off Kyiv's power for one hour.

Industroyer is a sophisticated malware whose main goal is to destroy the working process of the industrial control system (ICS). The malware is designed to directly control electricity substation switches and circuit breakers. For the malware to be able to achieve these goals, it needs to interrupt the communication between the industrial components using a standard protocol. 

Any kind of interruption in these systems can cause different degrees of damage to vital services. The range of actions that can be performed varies from turning components on or off, to damaging the equipment.

The lack of security makes it easier for hackers to exploit communication protocols without having to search for vulnerabilities.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Industroyer's structure is as follows:

- Main backdoor - its function is to control all the other components of the malware. It communicates with a command and control (C2) server via Tor browser over HTTPS and has a set of commands that it executes and runs out of office hours to reduce detection.

- Secondary backdoor ‚Äì provides an alternative persistence solution in case the main backdoor is detected. The secondary backdoor is a Trojan version of the Windows Notepad application that connects to a different C2 server once detected.  

- Launcher component ‚Äì this is the component responsible for loading the payloads and the data wiper component.

- Payloads ‚Äì the following protocols are reportedly involved in the process:
‚Ä¢ IEC 60870-5-101 (aka IEC 101) ‚Äì monitors and controls electrical power systems. 
‚Ä¢ IEC 60870-5-104 (aka IEC 104) extension EC 60870-5-101 ‚Äì allows the protocol to be transmitted over TCP/IP.
‚Ä¢ OPC DA ‚Äì part of the OPC that allows real-time data exchange between distributed components. When used by attackers, it scans and maps ICS systems that export all the running OPC servers and the items in those servers. 
‚Ä¢ Module 61850 ‚Äì connects to devices within the network that are listed in its configuration file via port 102. If a configuration file is not available, it will enumerate potential IP subnet masks for devices in the network and try to connect to them via port 102. According to ESET's analysis of the payload, it communicates with the targets to identify whether the device controls a circuit breaker switch. For certain variables, it will change their state while also generating an action log.
‚Ä¢ SIPROTEC-DoS ‚Äì leverages CVE-2015-5374 by sending UDP packets to port 50000, thus causing the SIPROTEC digital relay to fall into an unresponsive state.

- Data wiping tool ‚Äì designed to erase system crucial registry keys and overwrite files in order to prevent tracking and recovery.

Upon installation, the main backdoor tries to connect to an internal proxy server that is hardcoded in its code. It listens on port 3128, which is associated with the Squid proxy. The malware then sends the victim machine's GUID (a unique identifier per Windows installation) to the C2 server. If there is no response from the remote server, the backdoor exits.

In April 2022, the Governmental Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) and ESET researchers reported on a campaign that was carried out by the Sandworm threat group, targeting an ICS network of a Ukrainian energy organization while using a new Industroyer variant dubbed Industroyer2. The new variant uses only the IEC-104 protocol (AKA IEC 60870-5-104) to communicate with industrial equipment. In addition, it is more configurable than its predecessor, and its settings, such as the application service data unit (ASDU) address, Information Object Addresses (IOA), and timeouts, are transferred through the IEC-104 communication routine. Industroyer2 was observed communicating with eight devices at the same time. Before establishing a connection to the targeted devices, the malware terminates a legitimate process that industrial equipment performs in its standard operation.

content.Overview:
The FFDroider information-stealing malware was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in April 2022. It spreads indiscriminately through software cracks, installers, freeware, games, and other files that are downloaded from compromised websites. The malware is named after the Windows registry key "FFDroider" that is created upon execution.

Once the malicious installer is downloaded, the FFDroider is installed, disguised as legitimate software, such as the Telegram desktop app. The malware is designed to steal cookies and account credentials that are stored in Chromium-based web browsers (e.g. Google Chrome), Internet Explorer, Microsoft Edge, and Mozilla Firefox. Unlike other infostealers, FFDroider focuses on stealing credentials for social media accounts and eCommerce websites, such as Facebook, Instagram, Amazon, eBay, and Etsy. The malware operators can track the infected machines through a dedicated URL called iplogger.org. At the end of the harvesting process, the user credentials are sent as cleartext to a remote command and control (C2) server via HTTP POST. In addition, the malware attempts to upgrade itself and expand its features by downloading additional modules from an update server at fixed time intervals.   

The FFDroider operators were observed using the stolen credentials to log into the user accounts and steal all the available information, including personally identifiable information (PII) and account billing and payment information. The obtained data can be used to orchestrate malicious ad campaigns on social media to expose FFDroider to a larger audience.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Karakurt extortion group was first observed in June 2021. The financially motivated group targets relatively small organizations from various sectors, such as professional services, technology, retail, healthcare, manufacturing, and energy, primarily based in North America. Karakurt means ‚Äúblack wolf‚Äù in Turkish, and is also a species of a venomous spider found in eastern Europe and Siberia.

Karakurt achieves initial system access using VPN credentials; it is yet to be known how these credentials are obtained. To achieve persistence, Karakurt uses the VPN IP pool or deploys either Cobalt Strike beacon or AnyDesk remote access tool to establish command and control (C2) communication. Then, the threat actor abuses admin privileges, sometimes by using Mimikatz or PowerShell, and moves laterally in the system. Finally, it uses 7-Zip and WinZip to compress the files stored on the compromised system and exfiltrates them to Mega.io cloud storage using Rclone or FileZilla (SFTP). Karakurt does not encrypt the files, but rather steals them and contacts the victims while threatening to publish or sell them.

The group has been successful in avoiding common post-exploitation tools or commodity malware, in order to evade detection and bypass security software.

Karakurt operated a leak site that was registered in June 2021. The leak site contains several sections: an about page, news about the latest victims and their leaked files, an ‚Äúauction‚Äù section that seems offline, and a ‚Äúcontact us‚Äù page with bogus contact details and a contact form. The group operators also encourage the website users to vote, via the contact form, for the next victims whose files will be uploaded. In addition, the group holds a Twitter account, called ‚ÄúKarakurtLair,‚Äù in which it publishes news about its victims.

In April 2022, researchers from different cybersecurity vendors established a link between Karakurt and the Conti ransomware group. The researchers gained access to an internal Conti VPS server and discovered that the groups share the same infrastructure and victims. Karakurt also transferred payments from victims to cryptocurrency wallets controlled by Conti. In addition, the researchers penetrated Karakurt's web server for their leak site and found documentation of tools that were used by the group, including the Ligolo-ng tunneling and pivoting tool, the Metasploit post-exploitation tool, Impacket for performing NTLM-relay attacks, and Danted for reverse tunneling.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Among the victims whose names were published on the group‚Äôs leak site: Jones Studio Inc., RI Analytical Laboratories Inc., Contech TopSystems AG, Petro Serve USA, Fiberstar, Inc., MIND Technology, Inc., and Better World Books.
