content.Overview:
OldGremlin, active since at least March 2020, is a Russian-speaking ransomware group that was discovered by researchers from Group-IB in August 2020. The group was identified targeting Russian enterprise networks with malware and ransomware from multiple industries, including banks, manufacturers, software developers, and medical labs. 
Typically, Russian hackers avoid attacking organizations in Russia and former Soviet countries. The evidence of attacks on Russian enterprises leads security researchers to believe that the group might run test operation campaigns in Russia before targeting worldwide companies.

Security researchers assume that OldGremlin is behind ransomware attack strains that were dubbed as TinyCryptor and decr1pt. The OldGremlin group was identified in a successful ransom attack on a Russian clinical laboratory company in August 2020. The attackers, using decr1pt stain, completely encrypted the company‚Äôs corporate network and demanded a ransom of $50,000 for the decryption key. They provided a Proton email address for contact.
OldGremlin‚Äôs ransomware campaigns are based on sophisticated social engineering skills along with custom backdoors, dubbed as TinyNode, and TinyPosh.
content.AdditionalInformation:
OldGremlin uses the spear phishing technique to gain initial access to victim environments. The phishing emails impersonate current events, such as the COVID-19 pandemic and the protests in Belarus as well as known Russian institutes, such as RosBiznesConsulting (RBC), a major media holding company in Russia. Those phishing email messages include ZIP files, carrying the attacker‚Äôs self-made backdoors, which enables the group to access the victim networks for deploying ransomware.

In April 2022, Group-IB reported on the resurgence of OldGremlin after more than a year. The threat actors launched two phishing campaigns against Russian organizations. The threat actors impersonated a senior accountant at a Russian financial organization and sent email messages with malicious macro-embedded documents, stored in Dropbox. Once triggered, the macro codes were used to download a new variant of the TinyNode backdoor, dubbed TinyFluff, granting the attackers remote system access. Then, OldGremlin performed reconnaissance to check if the application runs in a test environment and to collect information about the infected system, connected drives, installed plugins, and files that were stored in specific directories on the system drive. At the final stage of the attack, the threat actors deployed the TinyCrypt/TinyCryptor ransomware payload, encrypting files and dropping a ransom note.

content.Overview:
The Hafnium threat group was first reported by Microsoft in March 2021, attributing the group to several intrusions since January involving several zero-day exploits in Microsoft Exchange Server 2013, 2016, and 2019 (collectively known as ProxyLogon). The threat actors leveraged the zero-day vulnerabilities to primarily target infectious disease researchers, law firms, higher education institutions, defense contractors, policy think tanks, and NGOs in the United States.

According to Microsoft, Hafnium is a Chinese state-sponsored group. It is a ‚Äúhighly skilled and sophisticated actor,‚Äù and conducts its operations primarily from leased virtual private servers (VPS) in the United States.

The following zero-day vulnerabilities were leveraged by Hafnium to infiltrate the Microsoft Exchange servers:

1. CVE-2021-26855, a server-side request forgery (SSRF) vulnerability in Exchange that allowed the attacker to send arbitrary HTTP requests and authenticate as the Exchange server.

2. CVE-2021-26857, an insecure deserialization vulnerability in the Unified Messaging service that gave the threat actor the ability to run code as SYSTEM on the Exchange server (this requires administrator permission or another vulnerability to exploit).

3. CVE-2021-26858 and CVE-2021-27065, two post-authentication arbitrary file write vulnerabilities in Exchange that allowed the group to write a file to any path on the server (after authenticating by exploiting CVE-2021-26855 or by compromising a legitimate admin‚Äôs credentials).

4. CVE-2021-26855 is remotely exploitable and does not require authentication of any kind, nor does it require any special knowledge or access to a target environment. ‚ÄúThe attacker only needs to know that the server is running Exchange and the account from which they want to extract email,‚Äù Volexity researchers explained.

After gaining initial access, Hafnium deployed web shells on the compromised servers to steal data and perform additional malicious actions. They were able to download the Exchange offline address book that contained information about the organization and its users.

On March 5, 2021, only three days after Microsoft announced the Hafnium zero-days, security experts reported that the same Chinese cyberespionage group dramatically stepped up attacks on any vulnerable, unpatched Exchange servers worldwide. It was published that at least 30,000 organizations across the United States, including a significant number of small businesses, cities, and local governments were hacked in these attacks that were focused on stealing email contents from victim organizations.

In July 2021, the United States government, the European Union, the United Kingdom National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC), and NATO officially blamed China for backing up the Microsoft Exchange hacking campaign, attributed to Hafnium. They also linked China to other APT groups targeting the West, APT31 and APT40, and pressed charges against four of their alleged members.

In December 2021, Microsoft Threat Intelligence Center (MSTIC) released a report naming several threat groups, including Hafnium, that exploited the Critical Log4j vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228) to attack organizations.

In April 2022, Microsoft researchers reported on a new malware that was used by Hafnium to evade detection and maintain persistence on compromised Windows systems. The malware, dubbed Tarrask, creates scheduled tasks and hides them from "schtasks /query" and Task Scheduler by deleting the associated Security Descriptor registry value. This enables the threat actors to maintain system access even after reboots by restoring dropped connections to their command and control (C2) server. The researchers also observed the use of the Impacket tool for lateral movement.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Recommendations:

The vulnerabilities affect Microsoft Exchange Server 2013, 2016, and 2019. Exchange Online is not affected.
- It is highly recommended to update Exchange Servers that are externally facing. All affected Exchange Servers should be updated.
- It is recommended to restrict any untrusted connections on port 443, and setting up a VPN to separate the Exchange server from external access.
- It is highly recommended to run the Exchange Server Health Checker script. Running this script will tell you if you are behind on your on-premises Exchange Server updates (note that the script does not support Exchange Server 2010).

The security updates can be found here: https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/exchange-team-blog/released-march-2021-exchange-server-security-updates/ba-p/2175901.
The Exchange Server Health Checker script can be found here: https://github.com/dpaulson45/HealthChecker#download.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The SunnyDay ransomware was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in April 2022. There is little information about the ransomware‚Äôs intended targets.

Once deployed, SunnyDay terminates all processes and services to prevent interruptions in the encryption process and encrypts the files that are stored on the infected system using the Salsa20 and RSA 2048-bit encryption keys. The encrypted files are appended the .sunnyday extension and a ransom note named ‚Äú!-Recovery_Instructions-!.txt‚Äù is dropped. SunnyDay also deletes volume shadow copies (VSS) and can remove itself at the end of the encryption process. During its execution, the ransomware collects general system information, such as the device name, total RAM, and the number of connected CPUs. This information is grouped in a large string and sent to a remote command and control (C2) server that is assumed to be hosted on Tor.    

SunnyDay shares similarities with other ransomware strains, such as Ever101, Medusa Locker, Curator, and Payment45, however, no solid connection could be established between the different ransomware operators.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The ZingoStealer malware (AKA Ginzo Stealer) was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022, after it was offered for free to members of the Haskers Gang Telegram group. 

ZingoStealer, which is under constant development, spreads through software cracks, game cheats, and key generators that are advertised on YouTube. In many cases, the malware‚Äôs .NET executable is hosted on the Discord CDN, indicating that it is also distributed within gaming-related Discord servers. ZingoStealer is primarily designed for Russian speakers and performs geolocation checks to avoid operating on devices of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS).

When deployed, ZingoStealer creates a directory for harvested data and steals sensitive information from web browsers, including Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, and Opera, general system information (e.g. IP address, OS version, and computer name), account tokens for installed applications and software (e.g. Telegram and Discord), and cryptocurrency information. 

At the end of the data collection process, all the information is packed in a ZIP file and exfiltrated to an attacker-controlled server. In addition, the attack logs are processed and published on Haskers Gang‚Äôs Telegram channel so ZingoStealer users can access them. The infostealer can also be used as a loader for other malicious payloads, such as RedLine Stealer and XMRig. A new version of the malware even incorporates an XMRig-based malware, dubbed ZingoMiner, for harvesting Monero.   

As noted above, the malware is available for free, however, Haskers Gang also offered a paid version for 300 rubles (around $3), which includes a crypter named ‚ÄúExoCrypt‚Äù for better antivirus evasion, and its source code was made available for $500.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
BotenaGo is a botnet that was first observed by AT&T researchers in November 2021. The botnet targets various types of routers, modems, NAS, and IoT devices. There is little information about Botena Go's specific targets.

The botnet, written in Golang, leverages 33 vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2020-9054, CVE-2020-10987, and CVE-2020-8958), some of which are almost 10 years old. Once installed, it can receive commands in either of the following methods: 
The first is to create two backdoor ports, 31412 and 19412, and listen to the latter port to receive the target‚Äôs IP address. Once a connection to that port is established, it maps the vulnerabilities on the receiving address and exploits them to gain an initial foothold. The second method is to set a listener to system IO (terminal) user input and receive a target to exploit through this terminal. After gaining access, the botnet executes remote shell commands on the compromised devices and uses different payloads to match each infected system.

The botnet does not seem to have any active communication to a command and control (C2) server, which implies it is only one module in an infection chain and there is another module operating it. In addition, BotenaGo bears some resemblance to the Mirai botnet, so it may be a new tool operated by the same developers on specific tools known to them.

BotenaGo and its variants have very low detection rate by most antivirus vendors.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In January 2022, BotenaGo's source code was made publicly available through GitHub. This might result in new variants of the malware emerging in the near future. 

In April 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on a new BotenaGo variant targeting Lillin DVR devices. The newly observed variant, dubbed "Lillin scanner," used only one remote code execution exploit, enabling it to elevate its stealthiness. In addition, it seemed to rely on an external mass-scanning tool (e.g. Shodan) to form IP address lists of vulnerable devices to target. The attack chain led to the deployment of Mirai payloads, targeting a wider range of exploits and devices and expanding the infection.      


MITRE ATT&CK¬Æ TTPs:

TA0008: Lateral Movement
T1210: Exploitation of Remote Services
T1570: Lateral Tool Transfer
TA0011: Command and Control
T1571: Non-Standard port

content.Overview: The Lemon Duck cryptocurrency mining botnet has been active since at least the end of December 2018. The botnet attacks mostly Asian targets, but also the USA, LATAM, and several targets in Europe, with the top five targeted countries being Iran, Egypt, The Philippines, Vietnam, and India.
content.AdditionalInformation:
The Lemon Duck malware can attack both Linux and Windows systems, using two different branches. The Linux branch consists of bash scripts that are executed after the attacker successfully compromises a Linux host using the Redis, YARN, or SSH attack vectors.
The Windows branch has at least 12 independent infection vectors. These capabilities range from server message block (SMB) and RDP password brute-forcing, sending emails with exploit attachments, or targeting the RDP BlueKeep flaw (CVE-2019-0708).

After the initial infection, a PowerShell loading script is downloaded, which disables Windows Defender‚Äôs real-time detection and puts powershell.exe on the list of processes excluded from scanning. It also checks if the script is running with administrative privileges. If it is, the payload is downloaded and run. If not, it leverages existing system executables to launch the next stage.

The Lemon Duck modules include the main loader, which checks the level of user privileges and components relevant for mining, such as the type of the available graphic card. If these GPUs are not detected, the loader downloads and runs the commodity XMRig CPU-based mining script. Other modules include a main spreading module, a Python-based module packaged using Pyinstaller, and a killer module designed to disable known competing mining botnets. Lemon Duck also includes an email-spreading module. These emails use a mix of COVID-19-related subject lines and text, as well as other emotion-driven lures.

Between March 2020 and October 2020, researchers identified activity associated with Lemon Duck affecting three different companies in the government, retail, and technology sectors. 

Between the end of August and October 2020, researchers observed an increase in DNS requests connected with the Lemon Duck command-and-control (C2) and mining servers, in attacks centered on Asia, including ones targeting Iran, Egypt, Philippines, Vietnam, and India.

In April 2022, Crowdstrike researchers reported on a Lemon Duck campaign targeting exposed Docker APIs on Linux servers to mine cryptocurrency. Once Lemon Duck was deployed, it ran a malicious container to download a Bash script disguised as a PNG image file. Then, it created a cronjob that downloaded a Bash file (a.asp). This file was used to terminate processes of known mining pools and competing cryptomining groups, terminate known daemons   (e.g. crond, sshd and syslog), delete known indicator of compromise (IOC) file paths and C2 network connections of rival cryptomining groups, and disable Alibaba Cloud‚Äôs monitoring service. Next, the Bash file downloaded and executed the XMRig cryptomining tool and attempted to perform lateral movement by searching for SSH keys on the filesystem and using them to repeat the infection chain.

content.Overview:
The Stormous hacker group has been active since July 2021, operating mainly on Telegram. The group conducts ransomware attacks targeting companies from various industries and locations with no specific focus.

The origin of the group is currently unknown, as well as any affiliation to other threat actors or groups. Stormous ransomware notes and Telegram posts are written in Arabic.
content.AdditionalInformation:
On February 27, 2022, Stormous started shifting its focus towards Ukraine and US-based companies, publishing a leak from a Ukraine-based design company that creates drafts and plans for aircraft engines, followed by a leak from The Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and a US-based company.

On March 1, 2022, Stormous announced its "support for the Russian government" stating: "if any party in different parts of the world decides to organize a cyber-attack or cyber-attacks against Russia, we will be in the right direction and will make all our efforts to abandon the supplication of the West, especially the infrastructure."

Later on March 1, the group published a leak from a US-based fiberglass fabricator of composite-based products and parts for the military and commercial markets.

On March 2, 2022, Stormous announced they breached a school district in Phoenix, Arizona. In addition, it released login details of two US-based companies, an IT services company located in Palo Alto, California, and a company from the aerospace industry located in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

On April 24, 2022, Stormous claimed to breach Coca-Cola Company, allegedly stealing 161 GB of data. The company that has yet to acknowledge the breach, previously ‚Äúwon‚Äù a Telegram poll for the next company to be breached by Stormous. According to the group‚Äôs posting, Coca Cola was demanded a ransom of 1.65 bitcoins (approximately $64,500).

content.Overview:
The Malsmoke cybercriminal group, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in September 2020, has been active since early 2020. Its name stems from the most frequent payload that it used to distribute, SmokeLoader, although Malsmoke is currently more recognized with the ZLoader malware (AKA Zeus, Zbot). The group spreads malware globally, usually by using malvertising or social engineering methods.

Malsmoke first received attention from the cyber community in a malvertising campaign that took place in 2020. During the campaign, the threat actors used JavaScript code embedded in malicious ads on adult content websites. The code redirected users to malicious sites hosting the Fallout exploit kit that is designed to exploit browser and Flash Player vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2019-0752, CVE-2018-15982) and deploy information stealing malware, such as SmokeLoader and ZLoader. 

In mid-October 2020, the threat actors were observed switching their attack vector into popping fake Java plug-in updates in decoy adult videos. Once the user installed the plug-in, it downloaded a DLL file that executed an encrypted variant of ZLoader. In addition, the malware distribution evolved from infecting all browser users, rather than only ones who use Internet Explorer. Malsmoke was noted for using sophisticated redirection mechanisms that include client-side fingerprinting and connectivity checks to avoid VPNs and proxies, and only targeting legitimate IP addresses.

In January 2022, Checkpoint researchers reported a new Malsmoke campaign that started around November 2021. The campaign infected more than 2,100 users around the world, primarily from the United States, Canada, and India. The threat actors gained system access through the installation of a legitimate remote management software named ‚ÄúAtera.‚Äù It is unknown how the software installer was distributed to the victims, but it is assumed to be via spear phishing email messages or through downloading pirated software. Atera granted the attackers full system control, enabling them to execute scripts and download malicious files, including Zloader executables that communicate with a remote command and control (C2) server. Other files were used to modify Windows Defender settings and disable other detection and analysis tools, such as task manager. In addition, the DLL file that was used to execute the ZLoader malware carried a valid code signature, so it bypassed Microsoft‚Äôs digital signature verification process and evaded detection. This was an exploitation of known Microsoft signature validation vulnerabilities (CVE-2020-1599, CVE-2013-3900, CVE-2012-0151) that were incompletely patched by the company.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Onyx ransomware group was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in April 2022. The group targets American organizations from various sectors, such as healthcare, manufacturing, agriculture, and finance. It seems to be different from the Georgian ransomware group of the same name that operated around 2016.

Although there is little information about Onyx‚Äôs technical functionality, the ransomware was found to only encrypt files smaller than 200 MB and to overwrite larger files with random data (skidware), making them unusable. Onyx takes the double-extortion approach, stealing the company‚Äôs data and threatening to release it if the ransom demands are not met. Its ransom notes seem to be copied from the ones that are used by the Conti ransomware group. 

The Onyx operators manage an active leak site, Onyx News, that contains general information about the compromised organizations along with their leaked files. The leak site also contains a contact section.
content.AdditionalInformation: Among Onyx‚Äôs past victims, according to the group‚Äôs leak site: Pacific Maritime Industries Corp., Wayne Family Practice Associates P.C., Advantage Direct Care, C&C Farmers' Supply Corp., Semaphore Solutions Inc., and Ackerman Plumbing Inc.

content.Overview:
The Hive0117 threat group, first reported by IBM‚Äôs X-Force team in April 2022, has been active since at least February 2022 and perhaps as early as November 2021. The financially-motivated group targets Eastern European organizations from different sectors, such as telecommunications, electronics, and industrial.  

Hive0117 gains initial system access through phishing email messages, impersonating Russian government agencies or other Russian organizations. The messages, written in Russian, contain malicious ZIP attachments with self-extracting installers (SFX) and the DarkWatchman JavaScript RAT that is bundled with a C# keylogger. To evade security mechanisms, DarkWatchman uses a novel fileless persistence method. It utilizes Windows Registry for almost all storage tasks and does not write anything on the disk. In addition, the malware uses a domain generation algorithm (DGA) to generate a list of command and control (C2) domains, which makes it harder to map the threat actor‚Äôs malicious infrastructure.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Naikon advanced persistent threat (APT) group (AKA Lotus Panda), was initially observed carrying out a large-scale cyber-espionage campaign between 2009 and 2015. The Chinese APT was found to be state-sponsored and belonged to the Chinese People‚Äôs Liberation Army‚Äôs (PLA) Chengdu Military Region Second Technical Reconnaissance Bureau (Military Unit Cover Designator 78020). According to MITRE ATT&CK, Naikon shares some characteristics with APT30, however, the two groups do not appear to be exact matches.

Naikon's attacks utilized CVE-2012-0158, via spear-phishing email messages, each of them designed to be of interest to the potential victim. These emails carried attachments that looked like a Word document, but were actually custom malware. The RAT that was used by Naikon featured 48 commands, including instructions for downloading and uploading data, installing add-on modules, or working with the command line.

The cyber-espionage group targeted government, military, and civil organizations around the South China Sea with these schemes for at least five years. Some of the institutions that were affected by Naikon‚Äôs espionage campaign in the various targeted countries were the Office of the President
Military Forces, Office of the Cabinet Secretary, and the National Security Council.

In 2018, Naikon developed a set of crafted backdoors called Aria-Body. The backdoors are relatively difficult to detect, as much of the code operates in memory, injected by other loader components without touching the disk.

These backdoors are capable of persistence handling, file and directory handling, keylogging, shell/process management, system information collection and management, download management, location/IP verification, and network communication over HTTP.

Between June 2019 and March 2021, Naikon launched a series of attacks against military organizations in Southeast Asia. Naikon introduced two new backdoors dubbed Nebulae and  RainyDay. The latter is similar to another malware called FoundCore by another security firm. In addition, they used five legitimate software tools in the attacks, including Mobile Popup Application, Outlook Item Finder, Sandboxie, VirusScan On-Demand, and ARO, all primarily used for exfiltration purposes.

In April 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on a new Naikon cyber campaign targeting an unknown entity that was assumed to be a South Asian government institution. The threat actors sent spear phishing email messages that contained Microsoft Office documents with a malicious macro code. Once the macro was enabled, a loader named HexINI was deployed executing a shellcode that injected a beacon for the Viper penetration tool. Similar to Cobalt Strike, Viper enables easy payload generation, such as Meterpreter, ReverseShell, and other custom beacons, and features over 80 modules that can be used for initial access, establishing persistence, command execution, and more.
content.AdditionalInformation:
YARA rules for detecting Aria-Body:

rule apt_ZZ_Naikon_ARstrings : Naikon 
{
    meta:
        copyright = "Kaspersky"
        description = "Rule to detect Naikon aria samples"
        hash = "2B4D3AD32C23BD492EA945EB8E59B758"
        date = "2020-05-07"
        version = "1.0"

    strings:
        $a1 = "Terminate Process [PID=%d] succeeds!" fullword wide
        $a2 = "TerminateProcess [PID=%d] Failed:%d" fullword wide
        $a3 = "Close tcp connection returns: %d!" fullword wide
        $a4 = "Delete Directory [%s] returns:%d" fullword wide
        $a5 = "Delete Directory [%s] succeeds!" fullword wide
        $a6 = "Create Directory [%s] succeeds!" fullword wide
        $a7 = "SHFileOperation [%s] returns:%d" fullword wide
        $a8 = "SHFileOperation [%s] succeeds!" fullword wide
        $a9 = "Close tcp connection succeeds!" fullword wide
        $a10 = "OpenProcess [PID=%d] Failed:%d" fullword wide
        $a11 = "ShellExecute [%s] returns:%d" fullword wide
        $a12 = "ShellExecute [%s] succeeds!" fullword wide
        $a13 = "FindFirstFile [%s] Error:%d" fullword wide
        $a14 = "Delete File [%s] succeeds!" fullword wide
        $a15 = "CreateFile [%s] Error:%d" fullword wide
        $a16 = "DebugAzManager" fullword ascii
        $a17 = "Create Directroy [%s] Failed:%d" fullword wide

        $m1 = "TCPx86.dll" fullword wide ascii
        $m2 = "aria-body" nocase wide ascii

    condition:
        uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and
        filesize < 450000 and
        (2 of ($a*) and 1 of ($m*))
}


rule apt_ZZ_Naikon_codebase : Naikon 
{
    meta:
        report = "Naikon New AR Backdoor Deployment to Southeast Asia"
        description = "Naikon typo"
        author = "Kaspersky"
        copyright = "Kaspersky"
        version = "1.0"
        date = "2018-06-28"
        last_modified = "2018-06-28"

    strings:
        $a1 = "Create Directroy [%s] Failed:%d" wide

    condition:
        uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and
        filesize < 450000 and
        $a1
}

content.Overview:
The Moshen Dragon threat group was first reported by Sentinel Labs researchers in May 2022. Moshen Dragon, probably of Chinese origin, targets telecommunication companies in Central Asia. The cyberespionage group partially overlaps with the Chinese-speaking threat groups RedFoxtrot and Nomad Panda. 

While the exact initial access vector of Moshen Dragon is currently unknown, it involves the abuse of legitimate antivirus software of known vendors, such as Symantec, TrendMicro, BitDefender, McAfee, and Kaspersky, to perform DLL search order hijacking and stealthily sideload malicious DLL files. These DLLs contain malware, such as ShadowPad and PlugX variants (e.g. Talisman). In addition, the threat actors deploy the Impacket tool for performing lateral movement and remote code execution through Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI). Impacket is also used by Moshen Dragon to deploy an LSA notification package to harvest credentials and capture password change events. The group was also observed dropping the GUNTERS loader. GUNTERS first checks if it is executed on the correct machine, and if so, it uses WinDivert to intercept incoming traffic until it gets the string that is required for decrypting and launching the threat actors‚Äô malicious payloads.   

Moshen Dragon is considered to be a highly resourceful group, adapting its tools to the defensive obstacles that it faces.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The UNC1151 APT group (AKA Ghostwriter) has been active since at least 2016. The cyber-espionage group is assumed to be state-sponsored by the Belarusian government and supported by Russia. It primarily targets activists, journalists, government officials, military entities, politicians, academicians, and lawyers, in various European countries such as Lithuania, Latvia, Germany, and Poland, but was also observed operating in Colombia and Kuwait. 

UNC1151 is attributed to the 2017 Ghostwriter disinformation campaign. This campaign consisted of numerous incidents of website compromise and email spoofing that were used to distribute falsified news, documents, and correspondence. The initial goal, which has changed over time, was to spread narratives that object to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization‚Äôs (NATO) presence in Eastern Europe. 

In addition to what was attributed as part of the Ghostwriter campaign, UNC1151 engaged in other operations involving credential stealing and malware distribution, using phishing domains and email messages with malicious attachments. The malware used in these operations include RADIOSTAR, VIDEOKILLER, and HALFSHELL.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In January 2022, the Ukrainian government accused UNC1151 of defacing dozens of government websites as part of the ongoing geopolitical tension between Russia and Ukraine. The websites displayed a message in Russian, Ukrainian, and Polish, stating that all the data on the computer was destroyed and mentioning some politically disputed Polish and Ukrainian regions.

In February 2022, The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) warned about a spear phishing campaign that was attributed to UNC1151 targeting Ukrainian armed forces personnel. The attackers compromised the email accounts of their targets and sent phishing messages to their contact list. In addition, Meta (formerly Facebook) announced that it blocked accounts and phishing domains that were used by the group to target Ukrainian officials and military personnel. 

On March 7, 2022, researchers from Google‚Äôs Threat Analysis Group (TAG) reported that UNC1151 actively conducts phishing campaigns against Polish and Ukrainian government and military organizations, while targeting webmail users from the following providers: i.ua, meta.ua, rambler.ru, ukr.net, wp.pl and yandex.ru. In addition, Google blocked phishing domains that were used in these campaigns.

On March 23, 2022, the CERT-UA reported that UNC1151 deployed Cobalt Strike beacons in the devices of Ukrainian entities, using phishing email messages with macro-embedded documents. 

On March 30, 2022, Google‚Äôs Threat Analysis Group (TAG) reported that UNC1151 used the "Browser in the Browser" technique in their phishing campaigns, hosting credential phishing landing pages on compromised websites.

In May 2022, Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) reported on five active threat groups, including UNC1151, targeting organizations and individuals in Eastern Europe. UNC1151 specifically targeted Ukrainian Gmail users with phishing email messages leading to credential harvesting pages. In addition, the group targeted Facebook users, primarily in Lithuania, sending them phishing messages impersonating the Facebook security team.

content.Overview:
The Curious Gorge threat group was first reported by Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) in March 2022, amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War. The APT group, attributed to China‚Äôs Liberation Army Strategic Support Force (PLA SSF), targets government, military, logistics, and manufacturing organizations in Ukraine, Russia, and Central Asia. There is little information about Curious Gorge‚Äôs TTPs. 

In March 2022, Curious Gorge was observed targeting government and military organizations in Ukraine, Russia, Kazakhstan, and Mongolia. 

In May 2022, Google reported that Curious Gorge attacked multiple government organizations in Russia, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs as well as Russian defense contractors, manufacturers, and a logistics company. 

The attacks of a Chinese state-sponsored group against Russian entities are interesting, as the two countries are allies. It may reflect a possible shift in China's intelligence collection objectives amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
Operation CuckooBees is an ongoing campaign by the Chinese APT group Winnti (AKA APT41, Blackfly, and Barium) since at least 2019. The campaign has been targeting technology and manufacturing companies, primarily in East Asia, Western Europe, and North America. Operation CuckooBees aims to steal intellectual property, including sensitive documents, blueprints, diagrams, formulas, and other proprietary information. In addition, the campaign operators target user accounts and credentials, and customer data.   

Winnti attains initial system access by exploiting different vulnerabilities in ERP platforms, some of which are zero-day flaws. Once infiltrating the system, the threat actors employ various methods to establish persistence, such as installing a JavaScript-based webshell, tampering with the WinRM protocol for remote access, abusing the legitimate Windows services IKEEXT and PrintNotify to sideload DLLs, and loading a signed kernel rootkit. Then, they perform reconnaissance using Windows commands and create scheduled tasks to run batch files and gain system information. In addition, the threat actors attempt to crack user passwords, using different credential dumping techniques. 

Next, Winnti creates remote scheduled tasks using the Windows Schtasks command and executes malicious code to move laterally in the system. Finally, the threat actors deploy a Chinese-language version of WinRAR to create password-protected archives, collect stored sensitive information, and exfiltrate it to a remote command and control (C2) server. To evade detection, the WinRAR executable masquerades as a legitimate Windows program rundll32.exe.

In the course of the campaign, Winnti deployed a new DEPLOYLOG malware loader and new versions of Spyder Loader, PRIVATELOG, and WINNKIT. The group also abused the Windows Common Log File System (CLFS) mechanism to conceal the malicious payloads and evade detection by common security software.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The NetDooka malware was first reported by TrendMicro researchers in May 2022. As the malware still seems under development, there is little information about its specific targets.

NetDooka is dropped through the PrivateLoader pay-per-install (PPI) malware distribution service, that is downloaded to the victim‚Äôs computer. PrivateLoader is mostly distributed through pirated software that are promoted to the top of the user‚Äôs search results using SEO poisoning techniques. Once deployed, PrivateLoader first checks that it is not running in a virtual environment and disables antivirus tools on the infected machine. In addition, it deobfuscates strings, such as the command and control (C2) server address. Then, it downloads and executes another dropper component that decrypts the final payload, the NetDooka RAT. On some occasions, the loader installs a driver to act as kernel-mode protection for the RAT to prevent the deletion or termination of its activity. 

The RAT, written in .NET, receives commands via TCP, and can be used to log user keystrokes, collect web browser data, take screenshots, gather general system information, record audio through the device‚Äôs microphone, control the device‚Äôs camera, use the host‚Äôs resources to launch distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, perform remote desktop operations, and more actions.       

It seems that NetDooka is primarily used to steal user data; however, threat actors might take advantage of its incorporated loader to fetch additional malware strains as part of a broader attack chain.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Jester Stealer malware was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in July 2021, after it was promoted on underground hacking forums in a malware-as-a-service (MaaS) model. The infostealer is sold by a Russian-speaking threat group of the same name, offering it for $99 per month, $249 for lifetime access, or $999 for three-month builder pack access. The group has also developed other malware, such as the Lilith botnet, the Trinity miner, and the Merlynn clipper.

The Jester Stealer, written in .NET, is distributed in malspam campaigns using email messages or instant messaging platforms, such as Discord. The infostealer is loaded into the %TEMP% directory and checks if it runs on a virtual environment or a sandbox. If such an environment is detected, the malware terminates its execution. After this verification, Jester Stealer creates text files to save the stolen data, which is collected from various applications, such as web browsers, VPN clients, password managers, instant messaging apps, email clients, cryptocurrency wallets, and gaming software. Jester Stealer also collects general system information and user credentials, and takes screenshots of the infected system.

The collected information is packed in a ZIP file and exfiltrated via TOR to Telegram bot, or AnonFiles in case of a communication failure. The command and control (C2) communications are encrypted using the AES-CBC-256 algorithm. Once the exfiltration process is finished, Jester Stealer deletes itself from the infected machine to obscure the data breach.
content.AdditionalInformation: In May 2022, the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) reported a phishing campaign in which threat actors used email messages with macro-embedded XLS documents to distribute Jester Stealer. The messages that were sent amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War used the title "chemical attack," to lure the recipients to open the malicious documents.

content.Overview:
The Axxes ransomware group was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in April 2022. The group targets organizations from various sectors, such as technology, manufacturing, healthcare, travel, food & beverage, law, and construction, in countries such as the United States, China, Spain, Germany, Italy, Belgium, and the United Arab Emirates. There is little information about the group‚Äôs attack vector. 

Once deployed, Axxes encrypts the files that are stored on the victim‚Äôs computer, appending them with the .axxes extension. It also creates ransom notes named RESTORE_FILES_INFO.hta and RESTORE_FILES_INFO.txt. The ransom notes detail the data that was encrypted and warn the victims not to use third-party services in attempts to restore the data. In addition, the ransom notes contain a link to the threat actor‚Äôs leak site, which includes details on each of Axxes‚Äô victims, a chat section, and a Contact Us section. The leak site also includes a seemingly inactive ‚ÄúAuction‚Äù section that might be used for selling compromised databases. The group members present themselves as ‚Äúa group of pentesters who use our skills to audit the security of corporate networks.‚Äù Their declared goal is ‚Äúto point out companies about their network security problems, albeit in such a rude way, and get a reward for it.‚Äù  

Based on the logo of the ransomware group, Axxes appears to be a rebrand of the Midas ransomware group.
content.AdditionalInformation: Among Axxes' past victims, according to the group‚Äôs leak site: The H Dubai, Jiangsu Kaili Carpet Co., Ltd., Grupo Couceiro, Keuerleber GmbH, Max International Converters, NewWave Technologies, Texas Enterprises, Inc (TEI), G.E.W. Corporation Limited, Haiti Meat Processing SA, Xiamen Naier Electronics Co., Ltd., Shanghai Cyeco Environmental Technology Co., Ltd., Capital Distributors (S) Pte Ltd, Dongguan IMR Technology Co., Ltd, RaiseTech, Cabinet Cazanave, Eisenberg Hefler & Levy LLP, RWL GmbH, IDS Fulfillment, Bouquet Mulligan DeMaio, Chaddad Group, Westrup A/S, and CurIT.

content.Overview:
The Nerbian RAT malware was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in May 2022. The RAT was observed targeting entities in Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom, although its distribution might be wider. 

Nerbian RAT, written in Golang, is distributed through phishing email messages impersonating legitimate entities, such as the World Health Organization (WHO). The messages contain Microsoft Word documents (sometimes placed inside RAR archives) with malicious macro code. Once the macro is enabled, a BAT file is dropped and performs a PowerShell execution to download a UPX-packed dropper named "UpdateUAV.exe." The dropper reuses code from different GitHub projects, such as Chacal, to perform anti-analysis and anti-detection checks before deploying the RAT. Nerbian can be used to log user keystrokes, take screenshots, and execute arbitrary commands. The collected data is then exfiltrated to a command and control (C2) server over an encrypted SSL protocol.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The GriftHorse Android Trojan, first observed by cybersecurity researchers in September 2021, has been active since at least November 2020. The malware spreads globally infecting millions of Android devices.

GriftHorse lurks inside seemingly legitimate applications that can be downloaded from Google Play and other third-party app stores. The malicious apps take many forms, such as utility tools, dating services, and entertainment apps. Once downloaded, the malicious apps start flooding the victims with alerts inviting them to receive a prize. If the prize invitation is accepted, the victims are redirected to geo-specific web pages, based on their IP address, where they are asked to submit their phone numbers for verification. As the malware acquires the victims‚Äô phone numbers, it subscribes them to a premium service with monthly charges without their knowledge or consent.

The malicious applications are developed using the Apache Cordova framework. This enables the GriftHorse operators to deploy application updates without requiring user interaction. In addition, the threat actors employ different techniques to help the malware stay undetected, such as avoiding hardcoding URLs in the malicious apps, not reusing the same command and control (C2) domains, and encrypting the C2 communications.

In May 2022, Kaspersky researchers reported on two different variants of GriftHorse: GriftHorse.l that requires an active subscription to some fraudulent service with automatic billing, and GriftHorse.ae that secretly subscribes its victims to an attacker-controlled ‚Äúservice‚Äù by acquiring their phone numbers. The researchers found that both variants were active, primarily in Russia.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Sysrv botnet (AKA Sysrv-hello) was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in December 2020. The botnet spreads globally, targeting vulnerable Windows and Linux servers.

Sysrv, written in Golang, gains initial system access either by performing brute-force attacks or by exploiting known vulnerabilities that are found in web applications and databases, such as PHPUnit (CVE-2017-9841), Apache Struts (CVE-2017-5638), Atlassian Confluence (CVE-2019-3396) and Jira (CVE-2019-11581), and Oracle WebLogic (CVE-2020-14882). Once infiltrating the system and gaining remote access, the botnet operators deploy Monero (XMRig) miners and other malicious scripts that help the botnet to self-propagate. One of the malicious scripts, ldr.sh, attempts to uninstall security software and to terminate the activity of all competing cryptocurrency miners that are discovered on the compromised system, to ensure exclusivity. The botnet also harvests SSH private keys to move laterally in the network, creating more bots and cryptomining infrastructure to increase profits.     

In May 2022, Microsoft reported a new Sysrv variant, named Sysrv-K, with improved capabilities, such as scanning for vulnerabilities in the Spring Framework (e.g. CVE-2022-22947) and WordPress. This variant can be used to look for WordPress configuration files and their backups to steal database credentials and use them to take over the webserver.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The WizardUpdate (AKA UpdateAgent, Vigram) MacOS Trojan was first observed by Microsoft in November 2020. The malware seems to be under constant development, adding new functionalities on each upgrade cycle.

WizardUpdate is commonly distributed via drive-by-downloads while impersonating legitimate software, such as Flash Player. Once the system is compromised, the malware starts to collect system information that is transferred to a command and control (C2) server. Then, it abuses cloud infrastructure to deploy second stage malicious payloads, such as Adload adware, while bypassing Gatekeeper, a Mac security feature. 

In addition, WizardUpdate leverages user permissions to create and modify folders on the compromised device. For instance, it uses modified property lists (Plists) in LaunchAgent/LaunchDaemon to achieve persistence. The malware covers its tracks by deleting created folders, files, and other items from the infected machines.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In February 2022, Microsoft reported that the WizardUpdate operators leverage public cloud infrastructures, such as Amazon S3 and CloudFront services, to host their secondary payloads (e.g. Adload) in the form of DMG or ZIP files.

In May 2022, Jamf Threat Labs researchers reported changes in WizardUpdate's operation. The researchers observed that the malware operators used a Swift-based dropper masquerading as Mach-O binaries named "PDFCreator" and "ActiveDirectory." Once executed, the dropper established connection to a remote server and fetched a bash script to be executed upon the infected machine. In addition, the malware was found to use AWS infrastructure to host its payloads.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The XorDDoS Linux malware was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in 2014. The malware is used in distributed denial-of-service campaigns against Linux machines, in countries such as the United States, India, Spain, and Italy. Blackberry researchers attribute the malware to the Chinese Winnti Group (AKA APT41). 

XorDDoS, acting as a botnet with an embedded LKM rootkit component, gains initial system access either by performing SSH brute-force attacks or by exploiting known vulnerabilities that are found in Linux environments, such as ARM (IoT) or x64 servers. The malware‚Äôs main executable is an ELF binary, written in C/C++, that once deployed, communicates with a remote command and control (C2) server using XOR-based encryption. To maintain persistence, it also copies itself multiple times inside the compromised machine. Then, it can be used to initiate different types of DDoS attacks, such as SYN flood, ACK flood, and DNS amplification. Furthermore, it can receive additional commands from the C2 server to download and execute other malicious payloads, such as the Tsunami backdoor, which leads to the deployment of the XMRig cryptominer. XorDDoS features various obfuscation and security evasion mechanisms and it employs anti-forensic techniques to prevent system analysis.
content.AdditionalInformation: In May 2022, Microsoft researchers reported that the preceding six months saw an increase of 254% in activity associated with XorDDoS.

content.Overview:
The Space Pirates threat group, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in May 2022, has been active since 2017. The Chinese APT group overlaps with other Chinese APT groups, such as APT41 (AKA Winnti), APT27 (AKA Bronze Union), and Mustang Panda. Space Pirates targets government, aerospace, IT, and electric power organizations in Russia, Georgia, and Mongolia. It was also observed targeting Chinese companies in the financial sector. 

Space Pirates usually gains initial system access through spear phishing messages containing decoy documents and an SFX archive. The latter embeds an EXE file using DLL side-loading to execute the MyKLoadClient loader for malware distribution. Sometimes the EXE file hides inside a PDF document and acts as a dropper for the malicious payloads. The group was observed distributing various types of malware, such as a variant of PcShare, the Zupdax and ShadowPad backdoors, the PlugX and Poison Ivy RATs, and the custom BH_A006 backdoor. The latter is a modified version of the Gh0st backdoor, featuring many obfuscation and security evasion mechanisms. In addition, Space Pirates uses a custom Trojan, called Deed RAT, that supports different protocols for command and control (C2) communications (e.g. TCP, HTTP, UDP, and DNS). This Trojan can collect system information, update the shellcode for an injection that is stored in the registry, and deactivate the C2 connection. In addition, the malware can remove itself from the system. 

Space Pirates was observed lingering in the compromised systems for a long time (about a year), infecting numerous servers and harvesting sensitive data for the purposes of espionage and financial gains.
content.AdditionalInformation:

content.Overview:
Snake Keylogger (AKA 404 Keylogger) is an information stealing malware that was first reported in November 2019, and initially released on a Russian hacking forum in August 2019. It is mostly used in malspam campaigns set against various entities around the world. The malware is named after strings found in its log files and obfuscation code.

The Snake Keylogger is written in .NET and primarily spreads through phishing emails with malicious attachments or links to drop sites. However, it was also observed to spread in encrypted Telegram messages. Once the payload is executed, it creates a copy with a randomized name in the victim‚Äôs AppData folder. This generated copy runs as a scheduled task to achieve persistence on the network. Before the exfiltration process, the malware searches for general system information, such as the operating system version, IP addresses, and geolocation. In case the IP address or geolocation matches a blocklist of addresses, the malware does not proceed to the credential harvesting stage. 
Then, Snake sets a keyboard connection to log the victim‚Äôs keystrokes and parallelly continues to search for saved credentials in over 50 supported applications, such as web browsers (e.g. Chrome and Firefox), email management apps (e.g. Microsoft Outlook), and social media and instant messaging platforms (e.g. Discord). In addition, it can take screenshots of the infected system. All of the exfiltrated data is stored in a folder and sent to the threat actor either via email messages, FTP or SMTP servers, Pastebin sites, or an HTTP POST request in a dedicated telegram channel. In order to avoid detection, it terminates all the associated processes running on the network, including security programs.

The infostealer was created by an Iraqi developer, nicknamed on online forums as Razer, aka Brwa, Brwa65, HiDDen PerSOn, and 404 Coder. Its code bears many similarities to the Matiex malware‚Äôs code, suggesting a possible connection between their developers. The malware is sold on dark web forums for a price ranging from 25 to 500 dollars, depending on the selected configuration and services. The operators of the malware are allowed independence in choosing the malware features that will be activated upon deployment, and may reduce the use of some features in order to stay hidden on their targets‚Äô networks.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In July 2021, the Snake keylogger was reported as one of the malicious tools utilized in a global phishing campaign, targeting large international companies in the energy, oil & gas, and electronics industries. It was found in malicious attachments sent by email used to obtain sensitive information, log keyboard strokes and steal browsing data.

In May 2022, HP Wolf Security researchers reported that Snake was observed to be distributed through phishing email messages with PDF attachments. The PDF files led to the download of malicious RTF documents with malformed OLE objects. They abused a known Microsoft Equation Editor vulnerability (CVE-2017-11882) to run arbitrary code and deploy the Snake keylogger.

content.Overview:
The Wizard Spider (AKA GOLD BLACKBURN) criminal enterprise, comprises other notorious cybercriminal groups such as Grim Spider and Lunar Spider. The Russia-based financially motivated group is most famously known for operating the TrickBot banking malware and the BazarLoader. They target various organizations around the globe, primarily from the US and Europe, ranging from major corporations to hospitals.

The group also operates the Ryuk and then Conti ransomware, which they spread mostly through spear phishing campaigns.

Wizard Spider usually engages in spam campaigns, distributing malware, such as  Qakbot (aka QBot) and SystemBC, and uses them to drop additional malicious tools like Cobalt Strike for lateral movement and ransomware strains. The threat actors also exploit system vulnerabilities, such as the Apache Log4Shell (CVE-2021-44228).

Note: for specific information and IOCs belonging to Wizard Spider‚Äôs malware and associated threat actors, please visit the dedicated cyber terms found in the Threat Library.
content.AdditionalInformation:
