Techniques.Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification

Origins: Macedonia, The Former Yugoslav Republic of
content.Overview:
The Predator spyware was first reported by Citizen Lab researchers in December 2021. The malware was created by the commercial surveillance developer, Cytrox, based in North Macedonia. Predator was observed targeting Android and iOS mobile devices of people of interest, such as politicians and journalists, in countries such as Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Greece, Serbia, and Indonesia. Sometimes, this malware is deployed along with other spyware like NSO‚Äôs Pegasus.

Predator is distributed through phishing links, impersonating legitimate services, that are sent to the victims via email messages or instant messaging platforms (e.g. Whatsapp). Once clicked, the malicious link redirects the victims to an attacker-controlled domain, deploying exploits for various zero-day vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2021-38000 in Chrome and CVE-2021-1048 in Android), before redirecting their browser to a legitimate website. The exploits enable the background installation of malware loaders, such as the Alien Android banking Trojan or a Python-based loader, that fetch and execute Predator. The malware can be used to record audio, add CA certificates, and hide certain applications to evade detection.
content.AdditionalInformation: Predator‚Äôs developer, Cytrox, is part of the ‚ÄúIntellexa Alliance,‚Äù a consortium of mercenary surveillance vendors that was founded in 2019 by the Israeli-national Tal Dilian. Cytrox runs a seemingly shady operation and it provides surveillance tools primarily to autocratic regimes. In December 2021, Meta announced that it removed 300 Facebook and Instagram accounts linked to Cytrox, along with accounts belonging to other surveillance-for-hire companies, such as Cobwebs, Cognyte, Black Cube, and Bluehawk.

content.Overview:
The Twisted Panda cyberespionage campaign, first reported by Check Point researchers in May 2022, was active from at least June 2021 through April 2022. Twisted Panda was likely conducted by an unnamed Chinese threat actor with connections to other Chinese APT groups, Stone Panda (AKA APT 10, Cicada) and Mustang Panda (AKA Bronze President, HoneyMyte). The campaign intensified following the Russo-Ukrainian War and targeted Russian and Belarusian defense research institutes.

In the course of the campaign, the threat actors used spear phishing email messages that contained decoy Microsoft Word documents with malicious macro codes. Once the macro was enabled, it dropped a 32-bit DLL loader using name hashing for evasion and anti-analysis purposes. The loader created a scheduled task to establish persistence and executed a second-stage multi-layered loader to inject the final payload into memory. The injected payload was a previously undocumented backdoor, dubbed Spinner, that used two compiler-level obfuscations and collected system information, such as the victim‚Äôs IP address, computer name, username, and OS version. Then, Spinner generated a random 8-byte RC4 key to encrypt the information packet and send it to a remote command and control (C2) server over HTTP/S. Furthermore, the backdoor could be used to run arbitrary commands and fetch additional malicious payloads from the C2 server.

Although the attribution of this campaign to Chinese threat actors is not definite, its targets are consistent with China‚Äôs long-term interests to become a world technological leader.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The BPFdoor malware (AKA JustForFun), first reported by cybersecurity researchers in May 2022, has been active since at least 2017. The backdoor targets Linux and Solaris systems of organizations from various sectors, such as telecommunications, government, logistics, and education, in countries such as the United States, South Korea, Turkey, India, and Vietnam. BPFdoor is named after its use of a Berkeley Packet Filter (BPF) sniffer that enables it to see all network traffic. 

BPFdoor is a passive backdoor, as it listens on one or more ports for incoming packets from the host and enables its operators to remotely send commands to the compromised network. The backdoor is unique in its ability to monitor any port for ICMP, UDP, or TCP packets, even if these ports are used by other legitimate services, such as web servers, FTP, or SSH. The malware operators do not need to open any new network ports to perform remote code execution and they use a ‚Äúmagic‚Äù password to control the malware‚Äôs actions. To gain root-level permissions and establish persistence, the threat actors were observed leveraging a vulnerability in the XScreenSaver component of the Solaris operating system (CVE-2019-3010) and using SysVinit scripts.  

BPFdoor is considered to be a very stealthy malware and cannot be stopped by firewalls. To evade detection, the malware renames its binary to one of 10 random names masquerading as a normal Linux daemon. The malware also changes the binary‚Äôs date and deletes it after it starts running, to make it more difficult for system analysis tools.

PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) researchers attributed BPFDoor to a Chinese threat actor dubbed Red Menshen. They found that the threat actors used Virtual Private Servers (VPS), administered via compromised routers in Taiwan, to send commands to the BPFDoor on infected devices.

Crowdstrike attributed the malware to a threat actor that they track as DecisiveArchitect.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In May 2022, Crowdstrike researchers provided a set of commands that could help defenders detect BPFDoor by identifying running processes with a raw socket open: 

Linux:

lsof -RPnl | grep SOCK_RAW | grep IP

Solaris:

for _PIDno in /proc/*; do line=$(pfiles "${_PIDno}"); echo $_PIDno $line | grep bpf; done

for _PIDno in /proc/*; do line=$(pmap "${_PIDno}"); echo $_PIDno $line | grep libpcap; done

for _PIDno in /proc/*; do line=$(pldd "${_PIDno}"); echo $_PIDno $line | grep libpcap; done

A full explanation on how to detect BPFdoor can be found here: https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/how-to-hunt-for-decisivearchitect-and-justforfun-implant/

content.Overview:
SilverTerrier is a collective name used to describe approximately 100 unique threat actors or groups operating from Nigeria since at least 2014. The threat actors primarily target organizations in the high tech, higher education, and manufacturing sectors around the world. In addition, during the COVID-19 pandemic, they have been observed targeting organizations leading national responses to Coronavirus, in sectors such as government, healthcare, insurance, medical research and publishing, and utility. The targeted organizations were located in the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada, Italy, and Australia. 

SilverTerrier usually distributes its malware via BEC attacks, in which compromised email accounts are used to spread phishing messages, impersonating a company's executives or vendors. Sometimes the email messages impersonate other legitimate organizations, such as shipping, banking, or law enforcement agencies. The email messages contain various types of information stealing malware, such as Agent Tesla, AzoRult, LokiBot, and Zeus, or RATs, such as DarkComet, NanoCore, Remcos, and WSHRat. These are used to steal sensitive information and user credentials and to exfiltrate the data to a remote command and control (C2) server. In addition, the email messages contain lures exhorting the recipients to transfer money to the threat actors‚Äô bank accounts. 

According to law enforcement organizations, over the years, SilverTerrier caused business losses estimated at more than three billion dollars.

Other malware used by SilverTerrier: Predator Pain, Pony, KeyBase, ISpySoftware, ISR Stealer, Atmos, LuminosityLink, NjRat, Quasar, WarZone, Netwire, ImminentMonitor, Adwind, Hworm, Formbook, Renals, and Revenge.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In January 2022, it was reported that Interpol and the Nigerian Police arrested 11 individuals suspected to engage in global BEC scams. Some of which were believed to be part of SilverTerrier. The law enforcement operation codenamed "Falcon II," was conducted between December 13 and 22, 2021.

In May 2022, the Nigeria Police Force arrested Murtala Mohammed, the alleged leader of SilverTerrier. The Nigerian national was arrested as part of "Operation Delilah," a year-long investigation that involved Interpol and several cybersecurity companies, such as Palo Alto Networks. Palo Alto linked the suspect to other BEC scammers, Onuegbu Ifeanyi Ephraim, Darlington Ndukwu, and Onukwubiri Ifeanyi Kingsley, that were arrested during Interpol's Operation Falcon II.

content.Overview:
The EnemyBot malware was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022. The botnet, based on the Gafgyt and Mirai source codes, spreads globally, initiating cryptomining and distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against modems, routers, IoT devices, and desktop/server architectures such as BSD (e.g. Darwin and x64). It is operated by a threat actor nicknamed Keksec (AKA Kek Security, Necro, and FreakOut) who has been linked to other botnets, such as Simps, Ryuk (not to be confused with the ransomware), and Samael.  

The EnemyBot operators gain initial system access either by performing brute-force attacks or by exploiting known vulnerabilities, such as in Seowon Intech routers (CVE-2020-17456), D-Link DWR routers (CVE-2018-10823), and iRZ mobile routers (CVE-2022-27226). Once deployed, the botnet connects to a command and control (C2) server and waits for commands to execute. EnemyBot supports various commands, such as performing different kinds of DDoS attacks (e.g. TCP, UDP, and HTTP), spreading to other devices using SSH/Telnet brute-forcing and exploits, running shell commands, and updating the download server for exploit payload. Some of the commands may indicate that the botnet is used in extortion campaigns. 

To mask its presence in the system, EnemyBot uses different obfuscation techniques; its C2 domain uses XOR encoding with a multi-byte key and is only accessible through Tor, credentials that are used for SSH brute-forcing use Mirai-style encoding (single-byte XOR encoding with 0x22), and commands are encrypted with a substitution cipher.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In May 2022, AT&T Alien Labs observed new EnemyBot variants that were designed to exploit 24 different vulnerabilities, including newly discovered flaws in VMware products (CVE-2022-22954), the Spring framework (CVE-2022-22947), and F5 BIG-IP (CVE-2022-1388). The new variants were also found to support the creation of a reverse shell on the infected system, enabling threat actors to bypass firewalls. The security vendor recommended the following mitigation measures:
1. Maintain minimal exposure to the Internet on Linux servers and IoT devices and use a properly configured firewall.
2. Enable automatic updates to ensure your software has the latest security updates.
3. Monitor network traffic, outbound port scans, and unreasonable bandwidth usage.

content.Overview:
The AsyncRAT malware has been active since at least 2019. The malware was used in numerous campaigns around the world, targeting various sectors such as information technology, enterprise services, hospitality, and transportation. AsyncRAT shares code and behavior similarities with RevengeRAT, and some consider them to be the same malware. A December 2020 report by JPCERT/CC claimed that AsyncRAT was partially copied from the Quasar malware family. 

AsyncRAT, written in C#, was originally created for educational purposes (available on GitHub) and was designed to remotely monitor computers through secure connections. Nevertheless, it was soon adapted for malicious purposes by different threat actors employing its diverse capabilities to log user keystrokes, record audio/video, steal user credentials and other sensitive information, remotely control users‚Äô desktops, capture screens, and upload additional malware. The RAT usually spreads through phishing, malvertising, and watering hole attacks, sometimes as part of exploit kits.

AsyncRAT has been used in different cyber campaigns, including:
- Operation Comando - a phishing campaign that was initiated at the end of 2018, primarily targeting the Brazilian hospitality sector. The campaign operators sent phishing email messages with macro-embedded documents, distributing the CapturaTela Trojan and different types of RATs, such as AsyncRAT, LimeRAT, and NanoCoreRAT.
- Operation Spalax - a 2020 cyberespionage campaign targeting Colombian entities, using phishing email messages with malicious RAR archives. The threat actors infected their victims with RATs, such as AsyncRAT, Remcos, and njRAT.  
- A 2020 Sidewinder campaign, in which the threat actors used spear phishing email messages to deliver modified versions of AsyncRAT.  
- Operation Layover - a series of malicious campaigns, reported in September 2021, targeting the aviation industry using AsyncRAT and njRAT.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In January 2022, Morphisec researchers reported a phishing campaign distributing AsyncRAT. The campaign, believed to be initiated in September 2021, included the sending of email messages with decoy HTML attachments. Once the users opened the attachments, they were redirected to an attacker-controlled domain exhorting them to save an ISO file, leading to the eventual deployment of AsyncRAT. To evade detection, the ISO file was not generated from a remote server, but from within the victim's browser using an embedded JavaScript code. 

On April 5, 2022, Cisco Talos researchers reported that they observed a series of phishing campaigns distributing AsyncRAT and LimeRAT. The campaign operators used a new version of the 3LOSH crypter to obfuscate the RAT payloads.  

On April 27, 2022, AsyncRAT was observed being distributed through a spoofed website of Thailand Pass. The decoy website pretended to issue travel documents to Thailand, but actually infected users with the malware.

content.Overview:
The GoodWill ransomware group was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022 and reported in May 2022. The group is assumed to be based in India, as some of its infrastructure sits on Indian IP addresses and the ransomware strain contains strings in Hinglish (a mixture of Hindi and English). The GoodWill operator motivations are unique, as they claim to extort victims to help the poor, rather than for personal financial gains. There is little information about the group‚Äôs specific attack vector and victimology.

When deployed, the .NET-based ransomware, packed with UPX, encrypts the files that are stored upon the compromised machine using the AES algorithm and then sleeps for 722.45 seconds to interfere with dynamic analysis. In addition, GoodWill drops a multiple-paged ransom note that requires the victims to fulfill three social tasks in order to obtain the decryption key. The tasks include donating new clothes to the homeless, taking five less-fortunate children to Dominos, Pizza Hut, or KFC for a treat, and providing financial assistance to anyone who needs urgent medical attention but cannot afford it. The victims need to record their activities by taking screenshots and selfies and posting them on their social media accounts.

Once the three tasks are completed, the victims should write a note on social media explaining ‚ÄúHow you transformed yourself into a kind human being by becoming a victim of a ransomware called GoodWill‚Äù and send the threat actors links of documentation in exchange for a full decryption kit (the decryption key, a password file, and a tutorial).   

The GoodWill ransomware strain is based on the HiddenTear open-source ransomware that was developed by a Turkish programmer back in 2015.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
ERMAC is an Android banking Trojan that was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in July 2021. The malware was initially targeting only users in Poland, but its distribution seems to be expanding with time, as it was observed infecting users from other countries as well, such as the United States. ERMAC is considered to be a descendant of the BlackRock banking Trojan, both developed by a threat actor nicknamed ‚ÄúDukeEugene.‚Äù

ERMAC infects users by masquerading as legitimate Android applications, such as banking, government, media players, delivery services, and antivirus solutions (e.g. McAfee). Like other banking malware, ERMAC abuses Android's Accessibility Service and is capable of stealing contact information and text messages, recording audio, opening applications, obtaining financial data, and triggering overlay attacks to steal credentials. In addition, it has some unique features, like clearing the cache of a specified application and stealing the device‚Äôs accounts list. 

ERMAC‚Äôs code is almost fully based on the Cerberus banking Trojan, whose code was put for sale on hacking forums in August 2020. However, ERMAC is different in its obfuscation techniques and the Blowfish encryption algorithm that it uses for command and control (C2) communications.

In November 2021, cybersecurity researchers reported on several Android campaigns that took place between August and November 2021, resulting in more than 300,000 infections of Android banking Trojans in the Google Play Store. ERMAC was one of the banking Trojans that were used by Brunhilda dropper operators, to compromise mobile devices and steal valuable information.

In May 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on a new version of ERMAC (2.0) increasing the number of targeted applications from 378 to 467. This version had been made available on underground hacking forums for $5,000 per month.
content.AdditionalInformation: Among the companies whose applications were targeted by ERMAC: Uber, WhatsApp, Instagram, Twitter, Netflix, Wells Fargo, HSBC Australia, Akbank, Barclays, BBVA, Kutxabank, and Capital One.

content.Overview:
The Formbook information stealing malware was first observed in February 2016 after it was put on sale on various underground hacking forums by a user nicknamed ‚Äúng-coder.‚Äù The malware‚Äôs name stems from its form-grabbing capabilities which enable it to steal user credentials before they reach a secure server, thus bypassing HTTPS encryption. It was initially attacking Windows users from dedicated sectors, such as aerospace, defense, and manufacturing, in the United States and South Korea, but over the years spread to many other countries and sectors. At the end of 2020, it was ranked by CheckPoint as the third-most popular malware used by threat actors, accounting for 4% of the compromised organizations. In February 2020, Formbook was rebranded as ‚ÄúXLoader‚Äù and was reworked to operate on macOS systems in addition to Windows.

Threat actors distribute Formbook primarily via malspam campaigns, while at the same time leveraging various remote code execution (RCE) vulnerabilities, such as CVE-2017-8570, CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-11882, and CVE-2021-40444. The spam email messages may contain PDF files with download links, Microsoft Office files (e.g. DOC or XLS) with malicious macros, or archive files (e.g. ZIP or RAR) with EXE payloads. Once installed, Formbook can log user keystrokes, monitor clipboard data, take screenshots, steal user credentials from web browsers and email clients, and execute additional commands it receives from a command and control (C2) server, such as reboot and shutdown the system, clear browser cookies, and download and execute files. All the acquired data is then exfiltrated to a remote C2 server.

The malware is able to evade security mechanisms, such as antivirus software and sandboxes by using sophisticated obfuscation methods. In addition, it offers a PHP panel, where threat actors can track their victims' information, including screenshots, keylogged data, and stolen credentials.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In March 2020, Formbook was one of many malware that was spread using COVID-19 lures. The malware operators sent spam email messages, masquerading as updates from the World Health Organization (WHO). The decoy messages included ZIP attachments with malicious executables, triggering GuLoader that downloaded the Formbook malware.

In May 2020, cybersecurity researchers reported that the RATicate threat group used the legitimate Nullsoft Scriptable Install System (NSIS) to create Windows installers, deploying various malware, such as LokiBot, Agent Tesla, and Formbook. The group targeted industrial firms in Europe, the Middle East, and South Korea, using malspam email messages.

In December 2021, threat actors bypassed a previously fixed remote code execution vulnerability affecting Microsoft‚Äôs MSHTML component (CVE-2021-40444) to deliver Formbook. The attackers used a ‚ÄúCAB-less 40444‚Äù exploit, which bypassed Microsoft‚Äôs fix by enclosing a malicious Word document in a custom RAR archive. The file was sent in spam email messages, and included a JavaScript code that launched a WSH script and an embedded PowerShell command to deploy the Formbook malware.

In May 2022, Check Point researchers reported a new XLoader version that obfuscates its C2 servers to evade detection. The malware was observed to overwrite eight C2 domains with new values in every communication attempt, disguising the real C2 servers.


Disclaimer: on the IOCs section are detailed domains and IP addresses that security researchers related to Formbook's activity. Most of them seem suspicious, but they are not verified to have malicious intentions. We advise you to use these IOCs with caution and verify them before adding them to your block-list. Among these domains may be legitimate domains, which will cause false-positive on your organization‚Äôs network.

content.Overview:
Flubot is an Android (Google, Huawei, and Samsung devices) banking malware that was discovered by PRODAFT, a cyber intelligence and security company, on November 10, 2020. The malware was dubbed Flubot due to its ability to rapidly spread with infection vectors that resemble the common flu, but it is also named "Cabassous" and "FedEx Banker" by several other security researchers.

The malware's main purpose is to steal user credentials, credit card details, and collect private information from the victim‚Äôs infected device. The FluBot massive spam campaign was first identified targeting Spain, but based on malware analysis reports of several FluBot versions (3.6, 3,7, 3,8, 4.0) conducted by security researchers, the malware is also targeting various countries in Europe such as the United Kingdom, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Poland, Norway, Finland, Denmark, Netherlands, and also in different languages (a Japanese version was detected). FluBot will probably keep spreading globally, with the United States a likely next target.

A FluBot campaign usually starts with a text message sent to a potential victim‚Äôs mobile phone disguised as a delivery service company (DHL, FedEx, Correos, but also companies such as Asda, Amazon, and Argos). Then, by using different message themes, the victim is asked to click on the attached link in order to track package delivery. When the victim clicks on the link, he will be redirected to a compromised website, encouraging the victim to download a malicious app containing FluBot malware embedded and encrypted within the APK files. 

Once installed, the user will be required to provide the malware permissions via the Android Accessibility service and Notification, authorizing the malware to use: Internet access, reading/sending SMS, reading the phone book, performing calls, deleting an application, ability to use accessibility service, read notifications, access protected accounts and more. Additionally, the malware is exporting the victim‚Äôs contact list to a remote C&C server which later will be used for spamming and spreading again by sending a text message. The Flubot blocks all incoming notifications and intercepts SMS messages to prevent its detection. Once the Flubot detects a target application launch, the malware starts an overlay attack, downloading fake login pages webview-based on various famous banks and other applications sending the data to a remote C&C server.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Based on the PRODAFT report, FluBot has already infected more than 60,000 devices, with 97% of the victims located in Spain. Another report related to Flubot malware and conducted by Proofpoint, revealed that the English-language campaign used more than 700 unique domains, infecting about 7,000 devices in the UK.

On March 2, 2021, four hackers were arrested by the Catalan police in Barcelona, and suspected of being behind a massive criminal scheme, associated with the Flubot malware campaign. Among the group members arrested, one of them was in charge of the malware technical side by writing the malicious code and creating the fake bank login pages.

In October 2021, the New Zealand CERT team published a warning on fake security updates utilized by threat actors to infect users with Flubot. The security notifications alerted the victims that their device was infected by Flubot, enticing them to install an update that in fact delivered the malware.    

At the end of November 2021, Finland's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC-FI) issued an alert warning against an Android smishing campaign, distributing the Flubot malware. The SMS messages contained links to compromised websites, from which malicious APK installers were downloaded and deployed Flubot. This campaign added up to another large Flubot malspam campaign in 2021, targeting Finnish users and spamming thousands of them between June and August.

In January 2022, Flubot was reported to be distributed as part of a widespread smishing campaign. The SMS messages exhorted victims to upload some video via a link. Once the victims clicked on the link, they were directed to a page from which they could download a fake Flash Player APK deploying the Flubot malware. The malware was updated three times since December 2021, adding more functionalities, such as a domain generation algorithm (DGA) that uses 30 top-level domains instead of just three in earlier versions, and a C2 connection via DNS tunneling over HTTPS, rather than a direct HTTPS port 443.

In the same month, cybersecurity researchers reported on a similar Flubot campaign targeting users from Australia and various European countries, such as Germany, Spain, Italy, Poland, Romania, and the Netherlands. Since the beginning of December 2021, the researchers identified over 100,000 phishing messages trying to distribute Flubot. The messages that were distributed either via SMS or through Facebook messenger, included fake courier messages, and fake software update notifications. In addition, Flubot operators continue with "Is this you in the video" scams, in which this message is allegedly sent from an individual that appears on the device's contact list. The message contains a link leading the victim to a credential harvesting page, or to an installation notification of a fake Flash player or other Android components that in fact deliver Flubot.

In February 2022, Flubot was observed spreading via smishing messages alongside the Medusa Android banking Trojan. The malware demonstrated a new functionality to abuse the ‚ÄúNotification Direct Reply‚Äù feature, enabling it to directly reply to push notifications from targeted applications on the victim‚Äôs device. This might lead to bypassing two-factor authentication, signing fraudulent transactions on the victim's behalf, and replying to social application notifications with malicious phishing links.

In June 2022, Europol announced the takedown of the Flubot operation. During the takedown operation that involved 10 countries, including Australia, Spain, the Netherlands, and the United States, the Spanish police arrested four suspects for allegedly taking part in the Flubot operation, and the Dutch police disconnected 10,000 victims from the Flubot network and prevented more than 6.5 million spam SMS from reaching their destinations. Europol stated that the FluBot infrastructure was seized by law enforcement and thus could not be reinstated.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Prometheus traffic direction system (TDS) malware was first observed on underground hacking forums in August 2020. It is a malware-as-a-service (MaaS) that is sold by a Russian-speaking threat actor, nicknamed ‚ÄúMa1n,‚Äù for 250 dollars a month. Prometheus TDS was used in global campaigns targeting organizations from various sectors, such as government, finance, retail, energy, and healthcare, in countries such as the United States and Belgium. 

Prometheus TDS is used to redirect users to phishing or malware-hosting websites, delivering various malware, such as Campo Loader, IcedID, QBot, SocGholish, Hancitor, and Buer Loader. These usually lead to the deployment of secondary payloads like ransomware. 

Service subscribers can use an administration panel to choose their targets (based on preset conditions, such as geographical location, web browser, or operating system) and upload a list of compromised web servers. Then, Prometheus TDS scans the list and delivers its own malware, a PHP-based backdoor named ‚ÄúPrometheus,‚Äù to the targeted servers. The backdoor collects user data, such as IP address, user agent, time zone, and language, and sends it back to the attacker. Based on the received data, the attacker can decide whether to send spam email messages with direct links or documents with links that lead the victim to malicious URLs used to download malware or harvest credentials. In some cases, once the malware was downloaded, the malicious documents redirected users to legitimate websites (e.g. DocuSign and USPS) as a way to mask the infection. 

The developers of Prometheus TDS based their developments on the cracked and leaked copies of Cobalt Strike, and also created other malicious software, such as the BRChecker brute-forcing tool.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The LuoYu threat group has been active since at least 2008. The Chinese APT group primarily targets technology, media, defense, telecommunications, education, and foreign diplomatic organizations in China and its surroundings, with occasional infections in other regions, such as Europe and North America. 

LuoYu, named after a Chinese mythological creature, originally used watering hole attacks to deliver its malware, but in 2020 switched to man-on-the-side attacks leveraging the automatic update mechanism of select legitimate applications. Man-on-the-side attacks are considered to be very dangerous and destructive, as they do not require any direct interaction with the target, only that the user device be connected to the internet. 

The threat actors monitor their targets' network traffic for update requests of popular Asian apps, such as QQ, WeChat, and WangWang, and replace them with malicious installers. These installers deploy various information stealing malware, such as WinDealer, ReverseWindow (AKA Demsty), and SpyDealer. The deployed malware can harvest general system information (e.g. hostname, username, OS version, CPU information, and IP address), install backdoors to maintain persistence, manipulate files, take screenshots, scan for other devices on the network, and run arbitrary commands. To establish command and control (C2) connection, LuoYu‚Äôs malware do not use hardcoded C2 information, but rather connect to a random ChinaNet (AS4134) IP address out of a pool of 48,000 IP addresses.   

LuoYu is considered to be a very sophisticated threat actor, employing advanced attack vectors and able to infect various operating systems (Windows, macOS, Linux, and Android).
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Parrot traffic direction system (TDS) malware, first reported by Avast researchers in April 2022, has been active since at least October 2021, although some suggest it was already used in February 2019. The malware was used in global campaigns, targeting countries such as the United States, Brazil, India, and Singapore.

Parrot is used to redirect users matching a specific profile to seemingly legitimate credential-harvesting pages or malware-hosting websites that deliver RATs, such as SocGholish (AKA FakeUpdate) and NetSupport Client RAT. These might also lead to the deployment of additional payloads like ransomware.

The malware operators first inject a JavaScript code into the HTML of compromised websites, mostly WordPress-based. Then, a PHP backdoor script is triggered that gathers the site visitor‚Äôs information (e.g. IP address, OS version, web browser type) and sends it to the Parrot TDS command and control (C2) server. Sometimes the operators do not use the PHP script and send the request directly to the Parrot infrastructure. Based on the information that was provided earlier, the TDS determines the exact payload that will be delivered to the victim and loads it from a third-party website.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The SMSFactory Android malware, first reported by Avast researchers in June 2022, has been active since at least May 2021. The malware targets Android consumers around the world, primarily in Russia, Brazil, Argentina, Turkey, and Ukraine.

SMSFactory usually spreads through malvertising campaigns, push notifications, and pop-up alerts on websites and videos that promote game hacks or adult content. These are used to exhort victims into downloading malicious APKs requesting different permissions, such as location data, SMS access, and the ability to make phone calls. Once the APK is installed, it usually provides the victim a service that does not work or is mostly unavailable while continuing to operate in the background, establishing a connection to a command and control (C2) server and sending it an ID profile of the infected device (e.g. location, phone number, operator information, and the device‚Äôs model). Then, SMSFactory unknowingly registers the victim to premium services, sending premium SMS messages and making calls to premium phone numbers. The charges were observed to reach $336 per year. In addition, some of the malware versions can steal the device‚Äôs contact list and create new admin accounts on the device; abilities that are most likely used for further distribution.   

Avast reported that between May 2021 and May 2022 it alerted more than 165,000 users that they were infected with SMSFactory.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The WatchDog threat group, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in February 2021, has been active since at least January 2019. The group primarily targets vulnerable Windows and NIX cloud instances and infects them with cryptomining malware.

Watchdog gains initial access by exploiting misconfigured Docker Engine API endpoints and system vulnerabilities, such as documented in Elasticsearch (CVE-2015-1427 and CVE-2014-3120), Spring Data Commons (CVE-2018-1273), and Oracle WebLogic (CVE-2017-10271). The threat actors might also extract credentials for AWS and Docker systems from compromised servers and use them as part of their infection cycle. Once infiltrating the system, WatchDog deploys its three-part binary set and a Bash or PowerShell script file. The deployed toolset is used to remove cloud security tools and previously installed and cryptomining software, and then to prepare the ground for the download of the XMRig miner. Using previously obtained root privileges, WatchDog drops XMRig and adds a systemd service unit for persistence. Then, the threat actors deploy another payload incorporating ZGrab, Masscan, and pnscan, to search the network for valid pivoting points before dropping the final two scripts that are used for propagation.    

Most of WatchDog‚Äôs scripts include logos and references to the TeamTNT group, suggesting that WatchDog may be stealing the tools from its rival.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The SVCReady malware loader was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in April 2022. As the malware is still under development, there is little information about its specific targets.

SVCReady usually spreads through phishing email messages with malicious macro-embedded documents. Unlike the common practice of distributing malicious payloads through VBA macros, the SVCReady operators use VBA to run shellcode hiding in the file properties. This enables the threat actors to bypass security software and conceal their malware. Different shellcode is loaded depending on if the system architecture is 32 or 64-bit. Once executed via SetTimer API, a DLL file is dropped into the %TEMP% directory and uses a copy of rundll32.exe as a downloader for SVCReady. 

The malware establishes a connection to a command and control (C2) server and starts collecting general system information (e.g. username, computer name, and timezone) through Registry queries and Windows API calls. The collected information is packed in a JSON format and exfiltrated to the C2 server through HTTP POST using RC4 encryption. After the exfiltration process, the malware creates a scheduled task and a new registry key to achieve persistence, and then begins another exfiltration process of OS information, including taking screenshots. In some cases, SVCReady loads additional malware, such as RedLine stealer. To evade analysis, the malware makes two WMI queries to check if it runs in a virtual environment and it sleeps for 30 minutes.     

Security researchers that investigated SVCReady found that it uses similar infrastructure (e.g. lure images and resource URLs) as TA551 (AKA Shatak), indicating a possible link between the malware and the threat actors.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Aoqin Dragon threat group, first reported by SentinelLabs in June 2022, has been active since at least 2013. The Chinese APT group primarily targets government, education, and telecommunication organizations in Southeast Asia and Australia. Aoqin Dragon is assumed to be a small cyberespionage group, potentially associated with UNC94 and the Chinese APT group, Naikon (AKA Lotus Panda). 

Aoqin Dragon‚Äôs attack vector has evolved over the years. Until 2015, the group used weaponized Word documents exploiting known vulnerabilities, such as CVE-2012-0158 and CVE-2010-3333. To exhort their victims into opening the malicious documents and infect themselves with backdoors, the threat actors used lures involving APAC political affairs and pornographic topics. Later on, Aoqin Dragon started using fake antivirus executables acting as droppers to execute backdoors and establish a command and control (C2) connection. From 2018, the threat group turned to fake removable-disk shortcut files acting as malware loaders, to exhort victims into clicking the wrong folder. Once clicked, the files execute a malicious process, named "Evernote Tray Application," and perform DLL hijacking to load an encrypted backdoor. If the loader detects any connected removable devices, the payload is copied to infect other devices in the network. 

Aoqin Dragon uses two different backdoors, Mongall (HJ-client.dll) and a modified version of Heyoka. The first is equipped with an encryption protocol and Themida packer to protect against reverse engineering and can be used to exfiltrate data about the victim‚Äôs machine, create remote shells, and upload and download files. The second backdoor uses spoofed DNS requests to establish a bidirectional communication tunnel, and can create and delete processes, files, and folders, and collect information about the host.
content.AdditionalInformation:
MITRE ATT&CK¬Æ TTPs: 

T1566 ‚Äì Phishing
T1091 ‚Äì Replication Through Removable Media
T1569 ‚Äì System Service
T1204 ‚Äì User Execution
T1547 ‚Äì Boot or Logon Autostart Execution
T1055 ‚Äì Process Injection
T1055.001 ‚Äì Dynamic-link Library Injection
T1211 ‚Äì Exploitation for Defense Evasion
T1027 ‚Äì Obfuscated Files or Information
T1055 ‚Äì Process Injection
T1033 ‚Äì System Owner/User Discovery
T1082 ‚Äì System Information Discovery
T1560 ‚Äì Archive Collected Data
T1071.001 ‚Äì Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1071.004 ‚Äì Application Layer Protocol: DNS
T1571 ‚Äì Non-Standard Port
T1132 ‚Äì Data Encoding

content.Overview:
The Hexane threat group (AKA Lyceum) targets organizations in the oil and gas industry and attacks telecommunication providers in Africa, the greater Middle East and Central Asia. The Iranian group started its operations around mid-2018 and its activity accelerated in early- to mid-2019.

The threat actors attack third-party service providers to compromise their victims. The malicious activity could be made through a trusted vendor, bypassing much of the entity‚Äôs security stack. Hexane's intrusion activity includes the sending of malicious documents that drop malware to gain an initial foothold for further activities.
content.AdditionalInformation:
At the beginning of May 2021, ClearSky researchers detected a new espionage campaign related to Hexane, dubbed Siamesekitten, targeting an Israeli IT company. The threat actors established a large infrastructure that enabled them to impersonate the Israeli company and its HR personnel. This campaign is similar to the North Korean ‚ÄúJob seekers‚Äù campaign, employing impersonation techniques. This attack vector was used in past campaigns, such as the Dream Job campaign conducted by Lazarus in 2020 and the 2021 campaign of the Iranian group OilRig (AKA APT34) targeting Middle Eastern victims.

In July 2021, ClearSky researchers detected a second wave of similar attacks against additional companies in Israel. In this campaign, Hexane upgraded a new backdoor variant called ‚ÄúShark‚Äù to replace the older version ‚ÄúMilan.‚Äù  

The full report with the malware analysis can be found here: https://www.clearskysec.com/siamesekitten/

At the end of March 2022, Check Point Research (CPR) published a report detailing three APT groups, including Hexane, that took advantage of the Russo-Ukrainian War to compromise organizations. The group used war-related lures to deliver macro-embedded documents or decoy PDF files to Israeli and Saudi Arabian entities. These were used to deploy various malware: a .NET DNS backdoor that can download and upload files and execute commands; a .NET TCP backdoor that can execute commands, take screenshots, upload and download files, and list files, directories, and applications; and a Golang HTTP backdoor that can upload and download files and execute shell commands. Hexane was also observed to use security evasion techniques, such as DNS tunneling for command and control (C2) communications.

In June 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported that Lyceum started using a .NET-based DNS backdoor, a customized version of the open-source tool ‚ÄúDIG.net.‚Äù The threat actors sent their victims phishing messages with macro-embedded Word documents. Once enabled, the macro code dropped the DNS backdoor onto the Startup folder. The malware was used to perform DNS hijacking, manipulating DNS queries to execute commands remotely, exfiltrate data, and upload and download files from the C2 server using the DNS protocol.

content.Overview:
The Symbiote malware, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in June 2022, has been active since at least November 2021. This Linux malware primarily targets the financial sector in Latin America. Symbiote is named after its parasitic nature, living in symbiosis with other system components and using its resources, while remaining undetected.   

Unlike most malware, Symbiote is not delivered as an executable, but rather as a shared object (SO) library that is loaded into running processes using LD_PRELOAD. It hooks the "libc" and "libpcap" functions to hide its presence, injects itself into the inspection software's process and uses the extended Berkeley Packet Filter (eBPF) feature to filter out network traffic results that would uncover its activity. Once infecting all running processes, Symbiote provides its operators with rootkit functionality, harvests credentials by hooking the ‚Äúlibc read‚Äù function and exfiltrates them via DNS requests, and grants remote system access through Pluggable Authentication Module (PAM) functions. To better undermine its victims, Symbiote uses domains that impersonate legitimate entities such as major Brazilian banks and the Federal Police of Brazil.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The FakeCrack campaign was first reported by Avast researchers in June 2022. The ongoing campaign targets approximately 10,000 users a day, primarily located in Brazil, India, Indonesia, and France.

The FakeCrack operators use the Black SEO technique, abusing search engine indexing mechanisms to elevate the position of malicious websites in the victims‚Äô search results. Most of the websites exhort the victims to download cracked versions of legitimate software, such as the Windows optimization program, CCleaner Pro. The websites contain a link that, once clicked, redirects the user through several websites, eventually leading to a landing page offering to download a ZIP file. To avoid suspicion, the landing pages are hosted on legitimate file hosting platforms, such as filesend.jp or mediafire.com. The ZIP file is usually protected by a weak password (e.g. 1234) that is sufficient for preventing it from being analyzed by antivirus software. 

The ZIP file contains a single executable that, once installed, scans the user‚Äôs computer, collects system information, takes screenshots, and steals web browser data, such as account passwords, saved credit cards, and cryptocurrency wallet credentials. All the harvested information is packed in an encrypted ZIP file and exfiltrated to a remote command and control (C2) server. In addition, the malicious executable drops two more files (AutoIt compiler and script) that scan the clipboard for copied wallet addresses and replace them with ones that are controlled by the attackers. The malware also uses proxies to steal credentials and other sensitive data from cryptocurrency marketplaces using a man-in-the-middle technique, setting up an IP address and downloading a malicious Proxy Auto-Configuration script (PAC). Every time the victim accesses any of the listed domains, the traffic is redirected to a proxy server under the threat actor‚Äôs control.
content.AdditionalInformation:
If one‚Äôs system has been compromised, Avast recommends checking the proxy settings and removing malicious ones by employing the following steps:
- Remove the AutoConfigURL registry key in the HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings

Alternatively, using GUI:
- Click Start.
- Type Settings and press enter.
- Go to Network & Internet > Proxy.
- Delete Script Address and click Save.
- Disable the ‚ÄúUse a proxy server‚Äù option.

content.Overview:
The HelloXD ransomware group (AKA VhlamAV-MicloZ0ft) was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in November 2021. The group‚Äôs ransomware strain, based on the leaked source code of Babuk, is assumed to be developed by a Russian-speaking threat actor, ‚Äúx4k‚Äù (AKA L4ckyguy, unKn0wn, unk0w, _unkn0wn, and x4kme). There is little information about HelloXD's specific targets. 

While HelloXD‚Äôs initial access vector was not disclosed, its operators were observed deploying an open-source backdoor named MicroBackdoor, embedded within the ransomware payload. This backdoor enabled them to browse through the file system, upload and download files, execute commands, and then remove itself at the end of the process. Once executed, HelloXD attempts to delete volume shadow copies and encrypts files that are stored on the compromised machine, appending them with the .hello extension. In addition, a ransom note named Hello.txt is dropped, containing a Tox Chat address to communicate with the attackers and what seems like an extortion onion site, currently offline (might be under development). Newer HelloXD variants also change the desktop background to display a picture of a ghost. HelloXD‚Äôs binaries are packed using two main methods, a modified UPX packer and a custom packer with two layers of obfuscation.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The RobbinHood ransomware group (sometimes written as RobinHood) was first observed in April 2019. The group targets organizations from various sectors, such as government, energy, and insurance, in countries like the United States and India. 

The malware spreads through hacked remote desktop services. Once infiltrating the system, RobbinHood deploys its Golang-based ransomware strain, encrypts files with the RSA+AES cryptographical combination, and changes their name to Encrypted_XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.enc_robbinhood (in some cases the files are appended with the .rbhd extension). The ransomware uses the * /DELETE /Y command to disconnect all network shares from the victim's computer and is deployed to each machine individually, probably through a domain controller or PsExec. Finally, it drops a ransom note with instructions on how to make contact to initiate negotiations. The ransomware‚Äôs main_CoolMaker function contains sub-functions that were designed to disable and disrupt the victim‚Äôs PC backups and services (e.g. antivirus software and mail servers).   

In April 2019, Robbinhood ransomware hit several electric power companies in India, taking down their websites and making them inaccessible to utility customers. The ransomware encrypted the companies‚Äô servers, however, the companies stated they had backups. 

Also that month, the City of Greenville, NC was hit by the ransomware group.

In May 2019, RobbinHood attacked the City of Baltimore, MD. The ransomware note on the victims‚Äô system demanded payment of three bitcoins per system or 13 bitcoins (around $80,000) in exchange for decrypting all the systems. The attack was estimated to cause losses amounting to $18 million. At first, it was assumed that the threat actors gained initial access by exploiting EternalBlue/BlueKeep vulnerabilities, but this assumption was later ruled out. During the attack on Baltimore, the Twitter account @Robihkjn (or "Robbinhood") was communicating threats to the victims and offered to provide evidence that they could decrypt the locked files if the ransom is paid. The account has since been suspended.

In October 2019, RobbinHood changed its ransom note and asked the victims to search for incidents reporting on the group's impact. Apparently, this act was made to make sure the victims know that there is no decryption tool and it is very difficult to recover the files without paying the ransom.

In February 2020, Sophos researchers observed that RobbinHood exploited the CORE-2018-0007 vulnerability in the GIGABYTE driver (CVE-2018-19320) to install a malicious and unsigned driver into Windows in order to disable antivirus and other security software. This was done by deploying an executable named Steel.exe that extracted another file (ROBNR), disabling Windows driver signature enforcement. 

In June 2022, it was revealed that RobbinHood attacked Toyota Motor three months earlier, causing disruptions in all 14 Toyota factories. The attack seemed to start from the automobile parts manufacturer "Kojima Industries," which found the infection on February 26, 2022, shutting down its ordering system. This was the first reported RobbinHood attack in Japan.
content.AdditionalInformation:
The group used to operate a data leak site: robinhoodleaks.tumblr.com, which currently seems offline.

Among RobbinHood's past victims: the City of Baltimore, MD, the City of Greenville, NC, Besson Seguros, ABE Courtage, and Maad McCann.

Bitcoin addresses that were used by RobbinHood: 
14yos7dpe4bx3imnoGVUcMsNBwU1hLutfj 
132wg6kkJJ4MpNKnuhVoptYPmYHf6C5xHE

content.Overview:
The Follina zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2022-30190) in the Microsoft Windows Support Diagnostic Tool (MSDT) was first observed in May 2022, although some claim it was reported to Microsoft a month earlier. It enables threat actors to remotely execute arbitrary code on Windows systems. The vulnerability was detected by the Japanese security researcher, nao_sec, after exploring a malicious Word document that exploited CVE-2021-40444 and abused the ms-msdt scheme. 

Follina can be exploited through a maldoc (e.g. Word) to load an HTML file from a remote server and use the ms-msdt scheme to execute PowerShell code. Then, an unauthenticated attacker can install programs, view, change, or delete data, create new accounts, and practically take control of the victim‚Äôs machine. This while bypassing Windows Defender detection.
content.AdditionalInformation:
On May 30, 2022, Microsoft published mitigation measures for Follina exploits, including the disabling of the MSDT URL protocol on Windows machines by performing the following steps:
- Run Command Prompt as Administrator.
- To back up the registry key, execute the command "reg export HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\ms-msdt ms-msdt.reg"
- Execute the command "reg delete HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\ms-msdt /f"

The full Microsoft guidance document can be found here: https://msrc-blog.microsoft.com/2022/05/30/guidance-for-cve-2022-30190-microsoft-support-diagnostic-tool-vulnerability/ 

On May 31, 2022, Proofpoint researchers reported that the Follina vulnerability was exploited in the wild by the Chinese APT group, TA413. The threat actors initiated a phishing campaign against the Tibetan community, in which they sent email messages containing ZIP archives with Word documents. Once the documents were opened or previewed by the victims, the vulnerability was exploited to execute malicious code via the MSDT protocol.

On June 1, 2022, an unofficial patch for the vulnerability was published on the 0patch blog. The patch concerned the following Windows versions: Windows 11 v21H2, Windows 10 (from v1803 to v21H2), Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008 R2. Full details can be found here: https://blog.0patch.com/2022/06/

On June 6, 2022, Proofpoint reported that it blocked an apparent state-sponsored phishing campaign targeting European and US government organizations, while leveraging the Follina vulnerability. The threat actors sent their victims malicious RTF documents concerning some salary increase, to lure them into opening the documents and infect their systems with a Powershell-based infostealer.

On June 7, 2022, the TA570 threat group was observed to leverage the Follina vulnerability to deliver the Qbot malware (AKA Qakbot). The threat actors used hijacked email messages to send malicious HTML attachments leading to the download of ZIP archives. These contained IMG files with Qbot DLL payloads and shortcut files to execute them. 

On June 10, 2022, Ukraine's Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT-UA) issued a warning against active exploitation of the Follina vulnerability, as part of phishing campaigns targeting media organizations in Ukraine. The phishing campaign was attributed with a medium level of confidence to the Sandworm Team (AKA Quedagh, Voodoo Bear) and was aimed to distribute the CrescentImp malware.   

On June 14, 2022, the Follina vulnerability was patched by Microsoft, as part of its monthly cumulative Windows Updates.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Hydra banking Trojan is an Android-based malware, which was first used around 2018-2019, first as a dropper and then as an Android bankbot. At the beginning of its life, the malware users targeted exclusively Turkish banks and crypto wallet applications; however, since early 2020, the targets expanded to major banks around the globe (e.g., ING Australia Banking, AXA Banque France, Deutsche Bank Mobile, Wells Fargo Mobile, and many more).

Like other banking Trojans, Hydra can screencast - mirroring the victim‚Äôs device screen back to the threat actor in real-time - as well as perform other remote features, such as remote installation and screen locking. It is unique in that it also has a back-connect proxy option that enables the threat actor to impersonate the compromised device in order to perform fraud.

At the end of September 2021, a new Hydra campaign was discovered by MalwareHunterTeam and analyzed by a cybersecurity research team. This new campaign targeted European e-banking platforms, particularly Commerzbank, the second-largest financial institution in Germany. Banking platform users were infected with a malicious Android package (APK) called ‚ÄúCommerzbank Security,‚Äù which mimicked the official bank application. The new malware version incorporates TeamViewer functionality, which abuses various permissions, most notably accessibility permissions (‚ÄúBIND_ACCESSIBILITY_SERVICE‚Äù) and another crucial permission (‚ÄúBIND_DEVICE_ADMIN‚Äù) that allows it to obtain admin privileges. The enabled permissions allow the threat actor to perform different malicious activities, such as spreading SMSs to the victim‚Äôs contact list, stealing user credentials (e.g. passwords and PINs), and modifying the infected device‚Äôs settings. In addition, the new version uses encrypted TOR communication, which disables the Android security feature, Play Protect, and makes it harder to detect.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In November 2021, cybersecurity researchers reported on several Android campaigns that took place between August and November 2021, resulting in more than 300,000 infections of Android banking Trojans in the Google Play Store. Hydra was one of the banking Trojans that were used by the Brunhilda dropper operators to compromise mobile devices and steal valuable information.

In June 2022, Hydra was observed to be distributed through a downloader masquerading as a PDF document manager app that was promoted on phishing websites. The app has gained more than 10,000 downloads since April and was still available for download two months later.

content.Overview: The Blue Mockingbird threat group has been active since at least December 2019. Blue Mockingbird attacks public-facing servers running ASP.NET apps that use the Telerik framework for their user interface (UI) component.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In May 2020, Blue Mockingbird infected thousands of enterprise systems with cryptocurrency-mining malware. The threat actors exploited the CVE-2019-18935 vulnerability to plant a web shell on the attacked servers. Then, they used a version of the Juicy Potato technique to gain admin-level access and modify server settings to obtain (re)boot persistence. Once infiltrating the system, Blue Mockingbird downloaded and installed a version of XMRRig, a popular cryptocurrency mining app for the Monero (XMR) cryptocurrency.

Security researchers said that in case the public-facing IIS servers were connected to a company's internal network, the group also attempted to spread internally via weakly-secured RDP or SMB connections.

In June 2022, Sophos researchers reported that threat actors resembling Blue Mockingbird were observed leveraging vulnerabilities in Telerik UI to install Cobalt Strike beacons and XMRig. The threat actors obtained the Telerik UI encryption keys and then compiled a malicious DLL to be executed during deserialization and ran it within the context of the "w3wp.exe" process. They established persistence through Active Directory Group Policy Objects (GPOs) and used them to create scheduled tasks to be run together with a Base64-encoded PowerShell. Then, the attackers used AMSI-bypassing techniques to evade detection and deployed their malware.

content.Overview:
The SeaFlower campaign, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in June 2022, has been active since at least March 2022. The campaign operators, assumed to be Chinese, target Android and iOS devices and aim to steal cryptocurrency assets.

To spread their malware, the SeaFlower threat actors set up clones of legitimate websites and promote them in search results (mainly in Baidu) using SEO poisoning techniques. The websites embed Trojanized applications of crypto wallets that once downloaded by the victims, plant backdoors onto their devices. On iOS, the websites also abuse provisioning profiles to side-load the malicious applications on the device to bypass security mechanisms. 

The malicious apps contain a code that collects seed phrases of Web3 wallets (Coinbase, MetaMask, TokenPocket, and imToken) and exfiltrates them to remote domains that mimic those of legitimate vendors. This enables the attackers to access victims‚Äô crypto assets and steal them. Some of the classes that are used in the exfiltration process are obfuscated and encrypted using base64 encoding and RSA cryptography.       

SeaFlower‚Äôs operators are considered to be technically sophisticated‚Äîimplementing advanced code functionality in backdoors and relying on infrastructure that does not overlap with other threat groups or cyber operations.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The QNAPCrypt ransomware group (AKA eCh0raix) was first observed in 2019. This ransomware, written in GO language, initially targeted Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices from Taiwanese companies QNAP Systems and Synology. The devices were compromised by brute-forcing weak credentials and exploiting known vulnerabilities to encrypt files found in the system.

QNAP is a vendor selling NAS servers, which the malware operators intended to infect and encrypt its files for ransom. NAS servers normally store large amounts of important data and files, which make them a valuable target for attackers.

In July 2019, Intezer researchers detected the use of this ransomware against Linux-based NAS and shut them down.

In September 2019, Intezer researchers attributed this ransomware to a new Russian cybercrime group that operates from Russia, Belarus, and Ukraine, dubbed ‚ÄúFullofDeep.‚Äù
Most ransomware groups work in a similar way, which is encrypting all files and delivering a ransom note. However, the QNAPCrypt ransomware demonstrated a few
important differences:

1. The ransom note was included solely as a text file, without any message appearing on the screen.
2. Every victim was provided with a different, unique Bitcoin wallet. This method could help the attackers avoid being traced.
3. Once the victims were compromised, the malware requested a wallet address and a public RSA key from the command and control server (C&C) before file encryption.

Following these events, QNAP published a statement in which they strongly recommended updating QTS and Photo Station to their latest versions, in order to keep the user device safe from ransomware attacks and unauthorized usage.

In June 2020, there was a surge of QNAPCrypt attacks targeting QNAP NAS devices. The threat actors leveraged three vulnerabilities (CVE-2018-19943, CVE-2018-19949, and CVE-2018-19953) that enabled them to install the ransomware strain on vulnerable devices.

In March 2021, Intezer researchers found a connection between the QNAPCrypt and the SunCrypt malware. They suggested that both malware families share identical code logic for the file encryption, which was likely compiled from the same source code.

In May 2021, QNAP warned its customers that the QNAPCrypt actively exploited a Roon Server zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2021-28810 and CVE-2021-28811), enabling the attackers to execute remote arbitrary commands on vulnerable QNAP NAS devices and install ransomware.

In August 2021, Palo Alto researchers reported on a new QNAPCrypt variant that exploited a critical vulnerability (CVE-2021-28799) to provide its operators remote access to QNAP and Synology NAS devices. This vulnerability was previously exploited to deploy the Qlocker ransomware. The researchers estimated that there are approximately 250,000 vulnerable devices that could manifest as potential targets. 

In December 2021, it was reported that the QNAPCrypt group increased its activity a week before Christmas, taking control of QNAP NAS devices and encrypting files, while leveraging admin privileges. The threat actors demanded a ransom payment ranging between 1200 and 3000 dollars.

In June 2022, cybersecurity researchers detected a new QNAPCrypt campaign targeting QNAP NAS devices. Details regarding the attack vector of the new campaign were not disclosed; however, new samples were published and are available in the IOC section of this cyber term.
content.AdditionalInformation: It is strongly advised to follow QNAP's recommendations to ensure device protection that can be found here: https://www.qnap.com/en/how-to/faq/article/what-is-the-best-practice-for-enhancing-nas-security

content.Overview:
The DriftingCloud threat group, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in June 2022, has been active since at least March 2022. The Chinese APT group primarily targets organizations in South Asia.

DriftingCloud gains initial system access by leveraging an authentication bypass vulnerability that affects the User Portal and Webadmin of Sophos Firewall (CVE-2022-1040). The threat actors install webshell backdoors to enable remote code execution (RCE), and then conceal their traffic by accessing these installed webshells through requests to the legitimate file "login.jsp." To maintain persistence, DriftingCloud creates VPN user accounts and associate certificate pairs on the firewall. The group members write and execute the "pre_install.sh" file that runs a malicious command to download a binary, which is later deleted from the disk. 

Once infiltrating the system, the threat actors modify DNS responses for specific websites that are controlled by the victim organization to perform man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks, intercepting user credentials and session cookies from administrative access to the websites' content management system (CMS). DriftingCloud then leverages the stolen credentials to access the websites‚Äô admin panel and installs the File Manager plugin to upload, download, delete, or edit files. Finally, the threat actors deploy open-source malware, including PupyRAT, Pantegana, and Sliver, that can be used to remotely execute malicious activity.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Panchan botnet, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in June 2022, has been active since March 2022. The peer-to-peer (P2P) botnet, likely operated by Japanese threat actors, primarily targets Linux servers of Asian organizations in the telecommunications and education sectors. It was also observed targeting organizations in Europe, North America, and South America.

Panchan, written in Golang, gains initial system access using stolen SSH keys (also used for lateral movement) or an existing list of usernames and passwords to perform brute-force attacks. To conceal its presence, the botnet creates a hidden folder and uses SFTP to copy itself there under the name ‚Äúxinetd.‚Äù Panchan then executes its binary on the compromised machine and initiates an HTTPS POST request to a Discord webhook (probably for victim monitoring). Finally, the botnet establishes command and control (C2) communication over TCP port 1919 and deploys Base64-encoded cryptominer binaries of XMRig and nbhash as memory-based files, to be executed directly from memory, without any disk presence. Panchan also features an anti-monitor mechanism that shuts down all other running cryptomining processes and an anti-kill system that detects Linux termination signals (e.g. SIGTERM) and ignores them. In addition, to avoid detection and establish persistence, the botnet copies itself to /bin/systemd-worker and creates a seemingly legitimate systemd service with the same name.

Panchan has an embedded ‚Äúgodmode‚Äù admin panel that can be used to change the mining configuration and monitor the infection status. The admin panel is written in Japanese, which may hint at the origin of its developers. While analyzing the admin panel, security researchers found a link to a Discord server, probably used by Panchan‚Äôs operators.
content.AdditionalInformation:
YARA rules:

rule panchan {
    meta:
        author = "Stiv Kupchik"
        filetype = "ELF"
        version = "1.0"
        reference = ""

    strings:
        $go_magic = "\xFF Go buildinf:" ascii // All go binaries have this magic header - we use this to verify we have a Go binary
        $str_p2p_header = "pan-chan's mining rig hi!" ascii
        $str_sharepeer = "sharepeer" ascii
        $str_sharerigconfig = "sharerigconfig" ascii
        $str_godmode_login = "(*Ôæü„ÉºÔæü)/)ÔºèÔºº" ascii
        $public_key = "MIIBIjANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAAOCAQ8AMIIBCgKCAQEAwaZwxk7A5U7cejo/8STO\x0a6TjEArLaG+EXhWQxjg2jwgtmNfYTOHg5Ss9e3vHdZCTEo/OIdJQC6If7POa+NbbR\x0a9HkagE0ZYjTXTWNP0PgUxEmcboYkO38fxMpI7Gp+331xzaYT4VY8t5Ko01lvkIoV\x0amxjDKJhSiUbCnFkz76qbjZHpLa0hcpXgO1sXx1IciwaVqlLpzncbmK7Ok3ymS3Ee\x0aG3KWQ/NEm4x8yHx07NI6b/cV/z5YOja9jul7POK8Owo17HuFIhfICgFk8Goc1VnM\x0aiypx91Thqz7IWaF5fTFdBp+0p/cUajcA6vDd3TM0FDzT4HafWppjsofOSoLvTwnq\x0aCwIDAQAB"
    
    condition:
        $go_magic and (all of ($str*) or $public_key)
}

Source: https://github.com/akamai/akamai-security-research/blob/main/malware/panchan/panchan.yar

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The MailBot Android banking Trojan was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in June 2022. The malware targets online banking and cryptocurrency wallet customers in Spain and Italy. 

MailBot usually spreads through smishing campaigns, in which SMS messages are sent to the victims, exhorting them to download a seemingly legitimate application, or directing them to compromised websites from which the app can be downloaded. MailBot masquerades as a cryptocurrency mining app named ‚ÄúMining X‚Äù or ‚ÄúThe CryptoApp,‚Äù or uses other guises such as ‚ÄúMySocialSecurity‚Äù and ‚ÄúChrome.‚Äù Once the app is installed on a victim‚Äôs device, communication with a command and control (C2) server is established and the MailBot payload is executed, targeting predetermined cryptocurrency and banking apps, such as ones belonging to UniCredit, Santander, CaixaBank, and CartaBCC. 

Like other banking malware, MailBot can steal user credentials, web browser cookies, cryptocurrency data (e.g. total balances and seed phrases), and general device information, including IP address, ‚Äã‚ÄãAndroidID, and installed applications list. In addition, it can steal multi-factor authentication (MFA) codes and bypass MFA authentication, take screenshots, intercept and send SMS messages, intercept calls, read notifications, delete applications, and trigger overlay attacks by abusing Android‚Äôs Accessibility Services.    

MailBot‚Äôs C2 infrastructure was found to be located in Russia and has been used in various smishing campaigns since June 2020. It was also used to distribute the Sality malware (a modified version of SOVA), which may hint at similar developers of both MailBot and Sality.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Cerber ransomware has been sold as a service in the Russian underground black market since February 2016. Its distribution model is based on an affiliate program, in which users share their income with the malware‚Äôs author, "crbr," for its usage.

Cerber uses 4 different crypters, and implements unique features such as the voice message which plays upon encryption of the victim‚Äôs files. Cerber is constantly undergoing developments by its author and was implemented a polymorphic-hash feature for avoiding detection by antivirus solutions. The ransomware commonly spreads using the Rig, Neutrino and Magnitude exploit kits.

Cerber does not infect users from Russia and CIS countries (Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan, Moldova, Russia, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Ukraine).

In October 2016, researchers discovered new variants of Cerber that could shut down database connections to increase infection impact. That new feature only worked from privileged accounts, and it was therefore recommended to limit user privileges to the minimum that is required.

At the end of March 2017, it was reported that the Cerber Ransomware gained the ability to recognize virtual machines, and avoid the detection of anti-viruses and other cyber security tools.

The ransomware disappeared at the end of 2019, but reappeared in December 2021, under the name Cerber2021 (AKA CerberImposter), targeting organizations around the world, while leveraging remote code execution vulnerabilities in Atlassian Confluence and GitLab servers. The ransomware operators used the vulnerabilities to gain initial system access, before encrypting the victims' files, appending them with the .locked extension, and dropping ransom notes named __$$RECOVERY_README$$__.html. The reported ransom demands ranged between 1,000 and 3,000 dollars. This reincarnated version of Cerber has a different code than the older version and is assumed to be operated by a new threat actor who adopted the ransomware's name, ransom note, and Tor payment site. In addition, the new version has a Linux variant, which the older version did not have.

Cerber2021 supports the following languages: English, Arabic, Chinese, Dutch, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Portuguese, Spanish, and Turkish.
content.AdditionalInformation: In June 2021, Cerber2021 was among the ransomware strains that were observed exploiting Atlassian Confluence's OGNL injection vulnerability (CVE-2022-26134) to take over unpatched servers.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
BRATA, a Brazilian-developed Android banking Trojan, was first reported by Kaspersky researchers in August 2019, and has been active since January 2019. The malware was initially targeting only users in Brazil, but its distribution seems to be expanding with time, as it was observed infecting users in other countries, such as the United States, Spain, and Italy. The name BRATA is an abbreviation for ‚ÄúBrazilian RAT Android.‚Äù 

BRATA usually spreads either by using SMS or WhatsApp messages that are sent to the victims, enticing them to download a seemingly legitimate application or update, or via push notifications on compromised websites. Sometimes the messages and notifications contain links to phishing pages, mostly of banking apps, asking the victims to enter their credentials. The malware operators even disguised it as a CVE-2019-3568 vulnerability patch for WhatsApp, which registered over 10,000 downloads. 

Once installed, BRATA asks for Accessibility Service permissions, abusing them to capture the device‚Äôs screen, record keystrokes, and modify the device settings. In addition, it connects to a command and control (C2) server to exfiltrate user data, including instant messages, location, browsing history, and credentials, especially for banking apps which enables the malware operators to perform fraudulent transactions. The malware is also capable of disabling the Google Play Store functionality, and as a result Google Play Protect.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In January 2022, cybersecurity researchers discovered an evolved version of BRATA which includes new functionalities, such as the ability to use multiple communication channels (HTTP and TCP). In addition, BRATA can now actively detect and remove antivirus apps installed on the infected device, and can delete itself once the bank fraud has been completed or if it is installed on a virtual environment. The new BRATA version was observed in attacks against users from the United Kingdom, Poland, Italy, Spain, China, and Latin America.

In June 2022, it was reported that a new BRATA version (BRATA.A) was observed targeting banking applications in Europe. This version was added a new phishing technique, used to harvest user credentials through decoy login pages of the targeted banks. In addition, the new BRATA version was designed to ask for more permissions, enabling it to get the device's geolocation, intercept and send SMS messages, and perform overlay attacks. Once deployed, BRATA.A fetched a ZIP archive from the C2 server containing a JAR file named "unrar.jar," responsible for monitoring events that were generated from installed applications. Security researchers assumed that it might be a preemptive step before abusing Android's Accessibility Service. In addition, the security researchers discovered another malicious module, connected to BRATA's C2 infrastructure, that was only designed to steal short text messages. This module was found targeting the United Kingdom, Italy, and Spain.

content.Overview:
The ToddyCat threat group (AKA Websiic) has been active since at least December 2020. The APT group initially targeted government entities in Taiwan and Vietnam, then spread to attack organizations from other sectors and countries in Asia and Europe.

Up until September 2021, ToddyCat relied exclusively on the exploitation of vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange servers (e.g. ProxyLogon) to gain initial system access and deploy ChinaChopper web shells. Later, the group was also observed distributing malicious loaders through Telegram. ToddyCat uses two previously undocumented malware, the Samurai backdoor and the Ninja Trojan. These obfuscated malware enable the threat actors to execute arbitrary commands, manipulate files, take control of the infected machines, and move laterally in the network while remaining undetected. 

ToddyCat‚Äôs victims overlap with multiple Chinese-speaking threat groups, such as the ones distributing the FunnyDream backdoor, which may indicate ToddyCat‚Äôs origin; however, this is not sufficient evidence to link ToddyCat to other previously observed threat actors. In addition, ToddyCat‚Äôs focus on governmental and military entities might imply geopolitical interests and potential state sponsorship.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The AvosLocker ransomware group emerged in late June and early July 2021 (although according to the group's Tor website, the first announcement was on Jan 1, 2021). One of the ransomware operators, ‚ÄúAvos,‚Äù posted on two major Russian cybercrime forums that he is seeking partners with specific requirements and skills (pentesters/access brokers). The ransomware operators announced on "dread" (A dark web discussion forum) that they are willing to collaborate through an affiliate program, offering their ransom as a service (RaaS) model with handling the negotiation, extortion, and the leak publication.

AvosLocker, written in C++, uses strong encryption algorithms (AES-256 and RSA) to encrypt the generated AES keys. Once the encryption process is done, the file extension changes to .avos or .avos2, and a ransom note with instructions "GET_YOUR_FILES_BACK.txt‚Äù is created on the victims‚Äô machine. AvosLocker targets the following file extensions upon infection:
