ndoc docx xls xlsx ppt pptx pst ost msg eml vsd vsdx txt csv rtf wks wk1 pdf dwg onetoc2 snt jpeg jpg docb docm dot dotm dotx xlsm xlsb xlw xlt xlm xlc xltx xltm pptm pot pps ppsm ppsx ppam potx potm edb hwp 602 sxi sti sldx sldm sldm vdi vmdk vmx gpg aes ARC PAQ bz2 tbk bak tar tgz gz 7z rar zip backup iso vcd bmp png gif raw cgm tif tiff nef psd ai svg djvu m4u m3u mid wma flv 3g2 mkv 3gp mp4 mov avi asf mpeg vob mpg wmv fla swf wav mp3 sh class jar java rb asp php jsp brd sch dch dip pl vb vbs ps1 bat cmd js asm h pas cpp c cs suo sln ldf mdf ibd myi myd frm odb dbf db mdb accdb sql sqlitedb sqlite3 asc lay6 lay mml sxm otg odg uop std sxd otp odp wb2 slk dif stc sxc ots ods 3dm max 3ds uot stw sxw ott odt pem p12 csr crt key pfx der dat.

AvosLocker has a dedicated Tor leak website, where its operators publish the stolen data of victims who have not responded or refused to pay the ransom demand. The group usually accepts payments in Monero (XMR), but also accepts Bitcoin for a 10-25% premium. Based on the AvosLocker website, the first leak was on July 13, 2021, and the companies that were hit by the ransomware were from the United States, United Kingdom, United Arab Emirates, Belgium, Germany, Turkey, Spain, and Lebanon.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In October 2021, AvosLocker claimed to breach the tech company Gigabyte INC, leaking 14.9 MB of data in the form of an archive file. The allegedly stolen data included user credentials, HR agreements with personal employee details, information about job candidates, business agreements, and more.

In December 2021, AvosLocker was observed to improve its attack vector by disabling endpoint security solutions that interfere with the encryption process. The threat actors do so by rebooting the compromised systems into Windows Safe Mode using Windows batch scripts that modify or delete the Registry keys of specific security mechanisms, such as Windows Defender and Kaspersky, and execute a reboot command. 

Later that month, the AvosLocker operators released a free decryptor after accidentally encrypting the data of an American police department. The threat actors stated that they do not have a target policy, but usually tend to avoid attacking government agencies and hospitals. 

In January 2022, it was reported that AvosLocker started to use a Linux variant to attack VMware ESXi virtual machines. This variant terminates all ESXi machines on the compromised server, appending the .avoslinux extension to all encrypted files.

In March 2022, the FBI issued an advisory warning against AvosLocker and stating that the group and its affiliates attacked multiple organizations from critical infrastructure sectors in the United States. The law enforcement agency detailed the group's main TTPs including the use of double extortion, and even triple extortion while threatening to execute distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks during negotiations in addition to leaking the stolen victim data. In some cases, the AvosLocker operators call their victims over the phone, instructing them about the negotiations procedure and threatening them to pay. Furthermore, the FBI mentioned specific vulnerabilities that were likely used by AvosLocker for initial access, and listed tools that were used by the group, including Cobalt Strike, Rclone, PuTTY, AnyDesk, WinLister, and PowerShell scripts. For achieving system persistence, the threat actors usually modify Windows Registry "Run" keys and use scheduled tasks. 

The following mitigation measures were proposed on the advisory:
- Implement a recovery plan to maintain and retain multiple copies of sensitive or proprietary data and servers in a physically separate, segmented, and secure location (i.e., hard drive, storage device, the cloud). 
- Implement network segmentation and maintain offline backups of data to ensure limited interruption to the organization.  
- Regularly back up data, password protect backup copies offline. Ensure copies of critical data are not accessible for modification or deletion from the system where the data resides.  
- Install and regularly update antivirus software on all hosts, and enable real time detection.  
- Install updates/patch operating systems, software, and firmware as soon as updates/patches are released.  
- Review domain controllers, servers, workstations, and active directories for new or unrecognized user accounts.  
- Audit user accounts with administrative privileges and configure access controls with the least privilege in mind. Do not give all users administrative privileges.  
- Disable unused ports.  
- Consider adding an email banner to emails received from outside your organization.  
- Disable hyperlinks in received emails.  
- Use multifactor authentication where possible.  
- Use strong passwords and regularly change passwords to network systems and accounts, implementing the shortest acceptable timeframe for password changes. Avoid reusing passwords for multiple accounts.  
- Require administrator credentials to install software.  
- Only use secure networks and avoid using public Wi-Fi networks. Consider installing and using a VPN.  
- Focus on cyber security awareness and training. Regularly provide users with training on information security principles and techniques as well as overall emerging cybersecurity risks and vulnerabilities (i.e., ransomware and phishing scams). 

https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2022/220318.pdf

In May 2022, Trend Micro researchers reported on a new AvosLocker variant that uses a legitimate Avast Anti-Rootkit Driver file (asWarPot.sys) to disable antivirus solutions. In addition, this variant can be used to scan multiple endpoints for the Log4j vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228) using the Nmap NSE script. The researchers observed this variant in an attack, in which the threat actors leveraged a remote code execution flaw in Zoho's ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus software (perhaps CVE-2021-40539) to run an HTML application (HTA) from a remote C2 server. The HTA executed an obfuscated PowerShell script that downloaded an ASPX webshell and an installer for the AnyDeskMSI remote desktop software. AnyDeskMSI was used to deploy additional tools, such as Netscan for network scanning, Mimikatz and Impacket for credential dumping and lateral movement, and the previously mentioned Nmap and asWarPot.sys. In addition, the AnyDeskMSI fetched a mass deployment tool called PDQ to deliver a malicious batch script with various capabilities, such as disabling Windows Update, Windows Defender, and Windows Error Recovery, preventing safeboot execution of security products, and setting the ground for the execution of the AvosLocker executable.

In June 2022, AvosLocker was among the ransomware groups that were observed exploiting Atlassian Confluence's OGNL injection vulnerability (CVE-2022-26134) to take over unpatched servers. The threat actors were found to compromise systems in different parts of the world, including the United States, Europe (e.g. Czech Republic, Romania, and Portugal), and Australia.

In addition, Cisco Talos researchers reported that AvosLocker was engaged in a month-long campaign in February. The threat actors leveraged the Apache Log4j vulnerabilities in VMWare Horizon Unified Access Gateways (UAG) to gain initial system access and execute malicious code remotely. Then, AvosLocker used living-off-the-land binaries (LoLBins) to establish persistence and perform lateral movement while deploying malware and hacking tools, such as Cobalt Strike, Sliver, and Mimikatz. The group's ransomware strain was deployed using a legitimate software deployment tool called PDQ Deploy.

content.Overview:
Tropic Trooper (AKA Earth Centaur, KeyBoy, Pirate Panda) is a Chinese state-sponsored APT group that has been active since at least 2011. It is known for targeting Southeast Asian institutions, mainly from Taiwan, India, and Vietnam.

The group's most significant attack was in March 2018, known as the "Operation Tropic Trooper." This operation targeted institutions in Taiwan, Hong Kong, and the Philippines in the healthcare, government, and industrial sectors. The threat actors implemented spyware in their victims' networks for three years.

The group‚Äôs weapons are not only their own equipment, such as the Yohaoyah malware, but also known malware in the cyber world, such as the Poison Ivy RAT. There are also indications that they have used a PC Share malware family.

Tropic Trooper is known to be very professional, as they perform a thorough background check on their targets before they attack. Their phishing campaigns are well crafted and manage to trick many victims into installing malware on their devices. In addition, the group is proficient at bypassing security mechanisms and lingering in the system undetected for long periods of time.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In December 2021, cybersecurity researchers reported that Tropic Trooper reemerged in July 2020 after a certain halt, under the name Earth Centaur, targeting organizations in the transportation industry and government agencies related to transport. The group was observed to gain access via vulnerable Internet Information Services (IIS) or Microsoft Exchange servers, installing web shells. Then, it deployed first stage loaders (e.g. Nerapack and Quasar RAT), and second stage backdoors, such as ChiserClient and SmileSvr, and customized versions of Gh0st RAT and Lilith RAT. The latter was used to collect sensitive data that was then exfiltrated to cloud storage providers using Rclone. In addition, the threat actors deployed other post-exploitation tools, such as SharpHound, for network discovery, and legitimate tools, such as ProcDump.exe, that were used for credential dumping. In order to hide their activities, they used a customized wiper that deleted specified event logs.

In June 2022, Check Point researchers observed a new campaign that was attributed with a high level of confidence to Tropic Tropper. The threat actors deployed a previously undocumented loader called "Nimbda," written in Nim, that was bundled with SMS Bomber, a greyware tool commonly used for denial of service (DoS) attacks against phones. In addition, the loader injected shellcode into a notepad.exe process to connect with an attacker-controlled GitHub or Gitee repository and fetch an obfuscated executable of the Yahoyah Trojan. The Trojan, encrypted with a modified AES cipher (AEES), was used to collect and exfiltrate general information about the host (e.g. OS version, installed antivirus products, and MAC address). The final dropped payload was identified as the TClient backdoor that was frequently used in past Tropic Tropper campaigns.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Hermit mobile spyware, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in June 2022, has been active since at least 2019. The spyware was observed targeting entities in Italy, Syria, and Kazakhstan, although the target distribution might be broader. It is believed that Hermit was developed by the Italian spyware vendor, RCS Lab S.p.A, and a telecommunication company called Tykelab Srl, suspected to be operating as a front company. 

Hermit is usually distributed through SMS messages that contain a link to download seemingly legitimate applications from companies, such as WhatsApp, Samsung, Vivo, and Oppo. It is assumed that in some cases, the malware operators work with the targets‚Äô ISP to disable their mobile data connectivity. Then, the threat actors send them malicious SMS messages exhorting them to install an application to recover their data connectivity. Hermit infects both iOS and Android devices. On iOS, the malware, signed with an enterprise certificate, is sideloaded to victims‚Äô devices. This malware version contains different built-in exploits, enabling it to escalate privileges on the compromised devices and exfiltrate sensitive files. On Android, Hermit does not use embedded exploits; it asks the victims to enable the installation of apps from unknown sources and uses the DexClassLoader API to fetch and execute remote modules communicating with the main app. In addition, upon installation, the malware requests many permissions through the manifest file.

Like other mobile spyware, Hermit can obtain the device‚Äôs contact list, call logs, GPS location, SMS messages, and stored photos. In addition, it can gain root privileges, abuse the Accessibility Services, record audio, and make and redirect phone calls.

Hermit‚Äôs developers, RCS Lab, are vendors of so-called ‚Äúlawful intercept‚Äù spyware, similar to NSO Group‚Äôs Pegasus and Gamma Group‚Äôs FinFisher. Although its developed spyware may be used for legitimate purposes, such as law enforcement, it might also be easily abused for unlawful citizen tracking. As such, the company was linked to providing surveillance tools to military and intelligence agencies of authoritarian regimes, such as in Vietnam, Myanmar, and Turkmenistan.
content.AdditionalInformation: In 2019, Hermit was used by the Italian authorities in an anti-corruption operation. In addition, the malware was used to spy on Kurdish people living in northern Syria, and in April 2022, it targeted Kazakh citizens, in a campaign that was possibly initiated by the government.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The DarkCrystal RAT malware (AKA DCRat) has been active since 2018. The RAT is sold on Russian hacking forums for a very low price of 500 RUB (around $5) for a two-month license and 4,200 RUB (around $40) for a lifetime subscription. This low price makes it extremely prevalent in cybercampaigns and consistently ranked among the top 10 malware threats of ANY.RUN. 

DarkCrystal RAT was developed by Russian-speaking threat actors, nicknamed "boldenis44" and "crystalcoder," and –ö–æ–¥–µ—Ä (‚ÄúCoder‚Äù). The malware, written in .NET, is commonly distributed through phishing email messages with macro-embedded documents and via drive-by downloads from compromised websites hosting the malware. It is usually deployed with the help of additional tools, such as Cobalt Strike beacons and the Prometheus traffic direction system (TDS).

Once deployed, DarkCrystal RAT can collect web browser data (e.g. cookies and saved passwords), take screenshots, log user keystrokes, collect clipboard data, steal user credentials and access tokens from Steam, Telegram, Discord, and FileZilla, gather general system information, access the infected device‚Äôs camera and microphone, initialize UDP/TCP flood attacks, manage files, and execute remote commands. In addition, affiliates can expand the malware‚Äôs functionalities by developing their own plugins using a dedicated integrated development environment (IDE) called DCRat Studio. The DarkCrystal RAT‚Äôs developers also used JPHP to create an administration tool, enabling the malware operators to sign into active command and control (C2) servers, execute commands, submit bug reports, and terminate the malware‚Äôs process.   

There is an active Telegram channel called ‚ÄúDarkCrystal RAT [NEWS]‚Äù with thousands of subscribers, in which the malware developers share information about added features and plugin updates.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In October 2021, Cisco Talos researchers reported a phishing campaign targeting Afghanistan and India, in which threat actors distributed malicious RTF documents exploiting a Microsoft Office vulnerability (CVE-2017-11882) to deploy a variety of commodity RATs, such as DarkCrystal RAT, QuasarRAT, and AndroRAT. 

In January 2022, ThreatLabz observed a crypto scam, dubbed "FreeCryptoScam," in which threat actors lured crypto users to download malicious payloads of DarkCrystal RAT, leading to further deployment of RedLine and TVRat malware.

In June 2022, the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) reported that threat actors used phishing email messages containing RAR archives with macro-embedded documents to distribute DarkCrystal RAT among Ukrainian telecommunications operators. The same type of malware was also used in an attack against Ukrainian media organizations two weeks earlier, in which the Follina MSDT vulnerability (CVE-2022-30190) was exploited.

content.Overview:
The Revive Android banking Trojan was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in June 2022. The malware was only observed targeting banking apps of BBVA Spain; however, it is possible that it also targets other banking apps from Spain and abroad. Revive is named after one of its functions that enables the malware to restart itself if terminated.  

Revive, based on the open source code of the Teardroid spyware, usually spreads through phishing messages that lead the victims to malicious pages hosting seemingly legitimate two-factor authentication (2FA) apps. The pages have a professional look and even contain video tutorials to guide the users on how to install the malicious app. Once it is downloaded, the app requests permissions to the device‚Äôs Accessibility Service, enabling the embedded malware to get complete control of the screen. In addition, it requests access to SMS and phone calls and conducts ‚Äúon-device phishing‚Äù by presenting the victim with a credential harvesting page impersonating the bank‚Äôs login page. Revive also features a keylogger module and has the ability to intercept received SMS messages, mainly aimed at stealing one-time passwords and 2FA codes. All the gathered information is sent to a remote command and control (C2) server.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Matanbuchus malware-as-a-service (MaaS), first reported by Palo Alto researchers in June 2021, has been active since at least February 2021. The malware was previously observed targeting education and high-tech organizations in the United States and Belgium, but as a MaaS it can potentially target organizations from any sector or country around the world. 

Matanbuchus was developed by the known Russian threat actor, BelialDemon (AKA MasterVzloma), who is attributed with the development of other malware loaders, such as HimeraLoader and TriumphLoader. It was initially offered on underground hacking forums for a basic rental price of $2,500.

Matanbuchus usually spreads through malspam email messages containing ZIP files with MSI installers (with valid certificates) or Microsoft Excel documents with malicious macro codes. These lead to the deployment of obfuscated DLL files embedding the malware. Once deployed, the malware creates a scheduled task to maintain persistence and establishes communication with a command and control (C2) server. Matanbuchus can be used to launch EXE and DLL files in memory and execute custom PowerShell commands. In addition, it makes Base64-encoded POST requests to the C2 server to load different types of malware, such as Cobalt Strike beacons and QakBot (AKA Qbot). To evade detection, the malware makes a number of API calls that are commonly used in anti-virtualization and anti-debugging checks.
content.AdditionalInformation: In June 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported a new malspam campaign, in which Matanbuchus was used to distribute Cobalt Strike beacons on compromised machines.

content.Overview:
The DragonForce Malaysia hacktivist group has been active since at least June 2021. The Malaysian pro-Muslim group targets organizations in Asia and the Middle East, especially in countries that are considered by them enemies of the Muslims, such as Israel, India, and the United States. 

DragonForce Malaysia primarily engages in distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks and website defacements. The threat actors are assumed to gain initial access through brute-forcing and by exploiting system vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2022-26134). They use mobile devices or Kali Linux as the main attack platforms.

DragonForce Malaysia operates a dedicated website, containing a radio channel, active hacker forums with around 15,000 registered members, information about active campaigns, and tutorials of hacking techniques and tools. In addition, the group is very active on social media, operating Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, and Telegram accounts. The group members use these accounts to make announcements and also to leak stolen content, in addition to Pastebins, AnonFiles, and Google Drive.
content.AdditionalInformation:
DragonForce Malaysia gained recognition following its widespread campaign against Israeli entities initiated in June 2021. The #OpsBedil campaign was considered a response to Israel‚Äôs attempts to establish diplomatic relations with Southeast Asian nations with a Muslim majority (e.g. Indonesia) and to Israel's operation against terrorist groups in the Gaza Strip (Operation Guardian of the Walls). The campaign included the defacement of AcadeME, an Israeli job searching website for students, while stealing and leaking the personal data of more than 280,000 AcadeME users. In a subsequent campaign, #OpsBedil 2.0, the threat actors initiated DDoS attacks against the Israeli banking sector, leaked passport data of Israeli citizens, leaked VPN credentials of dozens of Israeli companies, and defaced the websites of the Ramon Airport and other aerospace organizations. The campaign operators used various DoS tools, such as Torshammer, LOIC, HOIC, and mobile tools like Garuda.   

Since then, DragonForce Malaysia and its affiliates initiated several other cyber campaigns against Israel, such as #OpsBedilReloaded and #OpsRWM (Raids Without Mercy).

In June 2022, DragonForce Malaysia launched a campaign against the government of India. The #OpsPatuk campaign included DDoS attacks and defacements of Indian websites in both the private and public sectors. The attacks followed controversial remarks about the Prophet Mohammed that were made by Nupur Sharma, a spokesperson for the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP). The threat actors likely gained initial access by exploiting a zero-day vulnerability in Atlassian‚Äôs Confluence Server and Data Center (CVE-2022-26134) and by deploying web shells (e.g. SQL upload shell to bypass the Admin SQL). In addition, the group members used Google dorks to efficiently identify their targets (e.g. limiting the search to domains ending with .gov.in) and applied the Script Deface (SC) tool for website defacement.

In addition, CloudSEK researchers reported that DragonForce Malaysia shared a proof-of-concept (PoC) of an exploit for Windows Server local privilege escalation (LPE) and local distribution router (LDR) vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities might be used by the group in active campaigns. The group operators also expressed their intent to engage in ransomware operations.   

DragonForce Malaysia is assisted by the following hackers and hacktivist groups: HarimauMalayaCyberArmy, BlackShieldCrew, Varians19Crew, HacktivistOfGaruda, TeamRevolutionPK, FoursdeathTeam, YameniHacker, X7R00T, BangladeshMuslimHackers, QwertyCode, BazTeamHackers, FroggBaba, ElegantCyberSecurity, RzkyO, 1877, 4EXPLOITATION, AnarchistAllies,  GanoSecTeam, KarawangCyberTeam, TeamRevolutionPK, Matigan1337, MrNyx, KosameAmegai, Cyber00t, Calutax07, ClashHackers, BDKR28, ABDO10, mranderson, Newbie_Tersakiti, Toku, silver_sword, CodeBoy187,7 n0m0r3, and Cubjrnet7.

content.Overview:
The Legion pro-Russian hacktivist group (not to be confused with the Indian hacktivist group of the same name) has been active since April 2022, amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War. The group seems to be part of the Killnet hacktivist group, initiating distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks against Western organizations and governments, primarily in NATO countries and Ukraine. Legion (AKA Cyber Spetsnaz) uses MHDDoS, Blood, Karma DDoS, Hasoki, DDoS Ripper, and GoldenEye scripts, to generate malicious traffic and shut down its targets‚Äô domains. The group operates a Telegram channel that is used to announce its latest victims and coordinate attacks.   

In April 2022, Legion built one of its first divisions called ‚ÄúZarya‚Äù and announced that it was looking for experienced penetration testers, OSINT specialists, and hackers. Not long after, the group initiated a vast DDoS attack against NATO, taking down domains assigned to the NATO infrastructure.   

In May 2022, Legion came to prominence when it attacked Italian organizations and threatened to launch DDoS attacks against the 2022 final of the Eurovision song contest, following Russia‚Äôs exclusion from the event. In addition, the group announced the launch of a new campaign, Panopticon, aiming to recruit 3,000 volunteer hackers willing to participate in attacks against the European Union and Ukrainian entities.   

In June 2022, another sub-division called ‚ÄúSparta‚Äù was created by Legion, aiming to perform cyber sabotage, disrupt internet resources, steal data, and gather financial intelligence, specifically on NATO and its allies.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Other sub-divisions associated with Legion‚Äôs activity include: Phoenix, Rayd, Vera, FasoninnGung, Mirai, Jacky, DDOS Gung, and Sakurajima. Some of them were responsible for attacks against five logistic terminals in Italy (Sech, Trieste, TDT, Yilprort, VTP), major financial institutions, web resources in Germany, and government entities in Poland, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Senate, Border Control, and the Police.

On June 21, 2022, Legion declared war against Lithuanian organizations from different sectors, such as government entities, banks, logistic companies, internet providers, airports, energy firms, and mass media groups. Two days later, the National Cyber Security Center (NKSC) of Lithuania issued a warning against an increase in DDoS attacks targeting public authorities in the country. As a result of the attacks, Lithuania's transportation agencies, financial institutions, and others experienced temporary service disruptions. The NKSC did not blame Legion for the attacks, but the proximity of events suggests its attribution.

On June 29, 2022, Norway's National Security Authority (NSM) warned against DDoS attacks targeting the country's websites and online services. Although the NSM's announcement did not reveal the identity of the attackers, some of the targeted websites appeared on the Legion Telegram channel. The targeted entities included Norway's national police, the country's public services, and immigration agencies. Legion seemed to target Norway in response to its pro-Ukraine actions amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The ZuoRAT malware, first reported in June 2022, has been active since at least October 2020. The malware targets organizations in North America and Europe by breaching small office and home office (SOHO) routers (e.g. ASUS, Cisco, DrayTek, and NETGEAR) of remotely-working employees, especially since the COVID-19 outburst.

ZuoRAT, a heavily modified version of the Mirai botnet, is loaded into vulnerable networks in the form of a MIPS file, with the help of an authentication bypass exploit script. Then, the malware performs in-depth network reconnaissance, collects network traffic on UDP, DNS, and TCP connections, conducts DNS and HTTPS hijacking, and drops a C++-based shellcode loader. The loader delivers Cobalt Strike and custom backdoors, such as CBeacon and GoBeacon, which enable the threat actors to gain persistence, upload and download files, hijack network communications, inject new processes, and execute arbitrary commands on Windows, macOS, and Linux systems. The ZuoRAT operators rely on an obfuscated, multi-stage command and control (C2) infrastructure and use a dedicated virtual private server (VPS) to deploy their first-stage payloads. In addition, to conceal their presence, the threat actors leverage the compromised routers themselves as proxy C2 servers.  

The identity of the ZuoRAT operators is yet to be known, although they are assumed to be Chinese (possibly state-sponsored), based on some code hints and the use of Alibaba's Yuque and Tencent as part of their C2 infrastructure.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The SessionManager backdoor, first reported by Kaspersky researchers in June 2022, has been active since at least March 2021. The malware primarily targets government and military organizations across the globe, but was also observed infecting organizations from other sectors, such as manufacturing, healthcare, energy, transportation, and non-government organizations (NGOs).

SessionManager, written in C++, is a malicious native-code module for Microsoft's Internet Information Services (IIS) web server software that is loaded to the victim‚Äôs system by exploiting known vulnerabilities, such as ProxyLogon in Microsoft Exchange servers. SessionManager masquerades as a legitimate module aiming to process HTTP requests that are constantly sent to the server, but in fact is designed to process specific requests from the threat actors, execute their instructions, and then cunningly pass them to the server just as any other request. The malware‚Äôs main purpose is to help the attacker maintain system persistence and keep access while remaining hidden. Once deployed, SessionManager enables its operators to manipulate files (read, write, and delete), execute arbitrary commands, and establish communications with other endpoints in the network while manipulating traffic. In addition, the backdoor provides access to the victim‚Äôs email messages, steals in-memory user credentials, collects general system information, and can be used to deliver additional payloads, such as Mimikatz and ProcDump. 

SessionManager is attributed to the Gelsemium threat group, based on similar victimology and the use of the OwlProxy backdoor variant as part of its malicious campaign.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The X-Files information stealing malware was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in March 2021. X-Files is sold on underground hacking forums for the price of 500 RUB (around $10) for a monthly subscription and 1500 RUB (around $30) for a lifetime license. There is little information about the malware‚Äôs specific targets.

X-Files, written in C#, usually spreads through malicious documents that are likely attached to spam email messages. The malicious documents contain an OLE object that leads to the deployment of an HTML file with JavaScript code exploiting system vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2022-30190). Then, a Base64-encoded string is downloaded and executes PowerShell commands to create persistence in the Windows startup directory and trigger the malware. Once deployed, X-Files can collect general system information (e.g. OS version and geolocation), take screenshots, and steal web browser data (e.g. saved passwords and credit cards, cookies, and history), cryptocurrency information, files that are stored on the desktop, and user credentials for Discord and Telegram. The collected data is stored in newly created directories and then exfiltrated through Telegram. To avoid detection, X-Files runs as "Svc_host," a legitimate Windows process.

The X-Files operators maintain an active website and Telegram channel, ‚ÄúXFiles Reborn,‚Äù that is used for new member recruitment and the announcement of new projects, such as a cryptominer called ‚ÄúPunisher Miner.‚Äù One of the group‚Äôs recruitments is the author of the Whisper Project infostealer.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The RedAlert ransomware group (AKA ‚Äã‚ÄãN13V) was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in July 2022. The group primarily targets European organizations from various sectors, such as engineering, technology, legal, and insurance.

RedAlert encrypts both Windows servers and Linux VMWare ESXi servers using the NTRUEncrypt public-key encryption algorithm, supporting different levels of security parameters. In addition, the ransomware shuts down all running virtual machines to prevent any interference with the encryption process. Upon encryption, the files are appended with the .crypt658 extension, and a ransom note named ‚ÄúHOW_TO_RESTORE‚Äù is dropped in every system folder. The ransom note contains a description of the data that was stolen and a link to a unique Tor payment site. The ransom payment can be made only in Monero.

The RedAlert operators maintain an active Tor leak site called ‚ÄúBoard of Shame,‚Äù in which they publish the stolen data of victims who refused to pay the ransom.
content.AdditionalInformation: Among RedAlert‚Äôs past victims, according to the group‚Äôs leak site: Syredis, Vahanen, Keystone Legal, Group G4, and Bay Bridge Administrators.

content.Overview:
The AstraLocker ransomware group was first observed in August 2021. There is little information about the group‚Äôs specific targets. In March 2022, AstraLocker introduced a new variant called AstraLocker 2.0. 

AstraLocker, based on the leaked source code of Babuk, usually spreads through phishing email messages that contain malicious Word documents with an embedded OLE object. Once triggered by the victim, the OLE object executes the ransomware payload, which is packed with the SafeEngine Shielden v2.4.0.0 protector. The ransomware performs an anti-analysis check to make sure that it is not running in a virtual environment and then encrypts the files that are stored on the compromised system using the Curve25519 algorithm, appending them with different extensions (.babyk, .AstraLocker, .piton, .Astra, or a randomized extension). In addition, AstraLocker terminates processes that could interfere with the encryption, deletes volume shadow copies (VSS) to prevent file restoration, and stops backup and antivirus services.        

The AstraLocker operators take the ‚Äúsmash and grab‚Äù approach of maximizing profits in minimum time. They do not waste time on reconnaissance, evaluation of valuable files, and lateral movement, and only focus on local encryptions for small ransom payouts of 50$ to be paid in Monero or Bitcoin. 

There are some links between the operators of AstraLocker and Chaos ransomware.
content.AdditionalInformation: In July 2022, the AstraLocker operators announced that they shut down their operation and released decryption keys for the ransomware. A few days later, Emsisoft released another AstraLocker decryptor that can be downloaded from their servers. Further instructions can be found here: https://www.emsisoft.com/ransomware-decryption-tools/howtos/emsisoft_howto_astralocker.pdf

content.Overview:
The Chaos ransomware builder (AKA FakeRyuk, RyukJoke, Ryuk .Net) was first observed in June 2021. It is in a high probability an upgraded version of the Bagli ransomware, developed by a Russian-speaking threat actor, with a certain affinity to Azerbaijan. The ransomware developers presented it as a .NET version of the Ryuk ransomware, however apart from the GUI presentation, there are not many similarities between them in terms of functionality.

Since being discovered, the ransomware has been issued six recorded versions, each adding more functionalities. The first version (Chaos v1.0) acted more like a wiper trojan, rather than a ransomware, not providing any incentive for the victims to pay the ransom. Instead of encrypting the files, it corrupted them by replacing their content with random bytes and then encoding them in Base64. The malware searched for certain file paths and extensions to infect, before dropping a ransom note dubbed ‚Äúread_it.txt,‚Äù containing a ransom demand in bitcoin. In addition, it had a worming function, which enabled it to infect all the drives found on the compromised network.

The second version (Chaos v2.0) had more options for admin privileges, the ability to delete shadow copies and other backups, and the ability to disable Windows recovery mode.

The third version (Chaos v3.0) added the ability to encrypt files, using AES/RSA encryption, and the fourth version expanded the upper limit of files that can be encrypted to 2 MB.

The fourth version (Chaos v4.0) also provided the ransomware builders the ability to add different extensions to the encrypted files and change the victims‚Äô desktop wallpaper. This version was weaponized by the Onyx ransomware group.

The fifth version (Chaos v5.0) was primarily created to enable the ransomware to encrypt files larger than 2 MB without corrupting them and go beyond the C:// drive. This version used the AES-256 algorithm to encrypt files and was added the capability to disable the Windows task manager.

The sixth Chaos installment was observed in the wild in May 2022 and was named "Yashma." It featured the ability to terminate its operation based on the victim's location and to stop the activity of various processes, such as antivirus software, remote desktop applications, and vault, backup, and storage services.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In October 2021, cybersecurity researchers observed the Chaos ransomware spread in gaming forums, infecting Minecraft players, specifically Japanese. The lure was ‚ÄúMinecraft alt list‚Äù text files, allegedly containing stolen Minecraft account credentials. Once those files were downloaded, the Chaos ransomware executables were triggered, encrypting the files on the victims‚Äô computers, appending them an extension of four random characters or digits, and dropping a ransom note. The ransom demand was equal to 2,000 yen, to be paid either by bitcoin or pre-paid cards.

In July 2022, Emsisoft released a decryptor for the AstraLocker ransomware, which was based on the Yashma variant. The security vendor released three keys to decrypt files with .AstraLocker or a random .[a-z0-9]{4} extension. Further instructions can be found here: https://www.emsisoft.com/ransomware-decryption-tools/yashma

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview: TrickBot emerged in September 2016 from the banking Trojan, Dyre. Security researchers noted many similarities between Dyre and TrickBot, which targets banking information. Dyre was shut down after the authorities conducted a successful raid in November 2015. The malware‚Äôs authors, however, seem poised to make a comeback with this TrickBot Trojan.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Initial TrickBot samples only had one functional module present, which was designed to record the system information of the infected device. Researchers spotted a new module in October 2016 that contained web injects, but these appeared to be in the developmental phase and not yet finalized.

In the first half of 2019, a triple threat attack was discovered, targeting large enterprises. The threat actors used spam emails to deliver the Emotet trojan in order to distribute the TrickBot malware. Once a machine is infected with the TrickBot malware, it begins to steal sensitive information and the malware tries to determine if the company is an industry target. If so, they deliver the Ryuk ransomware and encrypt the data.

In November 2019, TrickBot was deployed by phishing emails that contain fake sexual harassment complaints, targeting employees of large companies. Those complaints appear as if they came from the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

In mid-November 2019, Virtual Care Provider Inc. (VCPI) was hit by the Ryuk ransomware. VCPI declined to pay the ransom demand, and the attack cut off many of VCPI‚Äôs elder care facilities from their patient records, email, and telephone service for weeks while VCPI rebuilt its network. The threat actors laid the groundwork for the attack using Emotet, which primed VCPI‚Äôs servers and endpoints. Then, they used Trickbot to download other malware and steal passwords from infected VCPI endpoints. Several data logs suggest that the attackers had breached VCPI‚Äôs network on multiple occasions over 14 months.

In April 2020, security researchers discovered a campaign delivering the 'BazarBackdoor' malware. Security researchers strongly assess that the developers of the TrickBot trojan are behind BazarBackdoor, due to the spam origin, method of operation, code overlap analysis, and infrastructure. Both the BazarBackdoor and Trickbot utilize the same crypter and email chain deliverables as previous TrickBot campaigns. Furthermore, BazarBackdoor's command and control servers (TLS communications) have been seen using certificates created in the same manner that historic TrickBot certificates have been created.

Between October 2019 and April 2020, the operators of the Trickbot malware and also the FIN6 threat group have paired up to target several organizations with TrickBot‚Äôs malware framework, Anchor. Anchor is an ‚Äúall-in-one attack framework,‚Äù made up of various submodules that can help attackers spread laterally on a network, for example with the ability to install backdoors. In these attacks, they also use the PowerTrick tool, which enables attackers stealthiness, persistence, and reconnaissance inside infected high-value targets such as financial institutions. The attackers used Anchor and PowerTrick to download and execute a loader, called Terraloader, which then installed a backdoor known as More_eggs, which is associated with FIN6. The victims of this campaign were mostly enterprise networks, including PoS systems. The attacks are likely initiated through malicious spam (malspam) campaigns, which is how TrickBot is typically delivered.

In June 2020, a phishing email campaign that claimed to deliver a survey on ‚ÄòBlack Lives Matter‚Äô was spreading the TrickBot information-stealing malware. When a recipient opens the attached Word document, they will receive a message to 'Enable Editing' and 'Enable Content' to view the contents properly. Once they click on these buttons, the Word document will run macros that download and execute a malicious DLL. This DLL is the TrickBot Trojan that will download further modules to the infected computer to steal files, passwords, security keys, and allow other threat actors to install ransomware.

After being downloaded, Trickbot spreads laterally through a network, to steal saved browser credentials, Active Directory Services databases, cookies and OpenSSH keys, credentials for RDP, VNC, and PuTTY, and more.

In October 2020, a Virginia, USA court granted Microsoft control over many internet servers that Trickbot uses in its malicious operations, based on claims that the crime machine abused Microsoft‚Äôs trademarks. To take down the backend infrastructure of the TrickBot botnet, Microsoft worked with a coalition of tech companies including Microsoft, ESET, Symantec, and FS-ISAC.

The coalition spent months collecting more than 125,000 TrickBot malware samples. During this time, the coalition analyzed the content and extracted and mapped information about the malware's inner workings, including all the servers the botnet used to control infected computers and serve additional modules. It appears, however, that this operation has not completely disabled the botnet.

Despite the coalition's attempt to disable the servers that Trickbot uses to control infected computers and serve additional modules, on October 15, 2020 researchers discovered that the malware is still being used in active campaigns, delivered by the Emotet Trojan.

On October 28, 2020, researchers discovered that TrickBot's authors have moved portions of their code to Linux in an attempt to widen the scope of victims that could be targeted.

In December 2020, the Trickbot botnet has integrated into its toolset a module that focuses on Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) vulnerabilities. This demonstrates the actor‚Äôs effort to take attacks at a level that would give them ultimate control over infected machines. With access to UEFI firmware, the threat actor could establish persistence on the compromised machine that resists operating system reinstalls or replacing of storage drives. Its main use is to foil recovery attempts from ransomware attacks.

In the same month, the TrickBot operators initiated a phishing campaign in the UK, spreading malicious email messages pretending to be Subway order confirmations.
TrickBot was also connected to an Emotet campaign, involving the deployment of the Ryuk ransomware or attempts to steal bank account credentials via the TrickBot banking Trojan.

In February 2021, cybersecurity researchers reported that TrickBot started to use a copy of the Masscan open-source utility, dubbed "masrv," in order to scan local networks for other systems with sensitive or open ports that can be attacked.

On October 10, 2021, another phishing campaign involving TrickBot was detected. The campaign included the spreading of phishing email messages with malicious macro attachments that once enabled dropping the TrickBot malware into the victim's system. This attack came despite the arrest of two TrickBot developers earlier that year.

On October 28, 2021, a Russian citizen assumed to be a member of the TrickBot malware development team has been extradited to the United States. The Russian national called Vladimir Dunaev (AKA FFX) was arrested in South Korea two months earlier and was accused of various cyber crimes that could put him 60 years in prison.

In November 2021, cybersecurity researchers reported that the TrickBot and Conti operators were responsible for the resurrection of the Emotet botnet.

Later that month, it was reported that the TrickBot operators started to implement a screen resolution verification code in the HTML attachments that were sent to victims as part of malspam email messages. The threat actors already added a year earlier a malware feature that terminated the infection chain, in case a device was using non-standard screen resolutions of 800x600 and 1024x768. However, in a new variation of this feature, the verification code has been added to the HTML attachment itself, as a security evasion mechanism.

In January 2022, IBM researchers reported that the TrickBot developers equipped it with new security evasion and anti-analysis mechanisms. The malware was added several obfuscation and base64 layers, such as minified code that makes it unreadable to human eyes, string extraction and replacement, dead (redundant) code injections, and monkey patching functions. In addition, malicious code injections to web pages were designed to not use local resources in the process, but only rely on the threat actors' servers, and the C2 communication is now made via HTTPS protocol. The new malware features also include anti-debugging script in the JavaScript code (RegEx) that can detect analysis tools and crash the researcher's web browser upon discovery of such tools.

In February 2022, Check Point researchers reported that since 2020, TrickBot was used in more than 20 modules to target customers of 60 financial and technology companies, including Google, Amazon, Microsoft, American Express, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, and PayPal. The researchers detailed some of the evolved TrickBot techniques and tools, such as the injectDll web-injects module that is used to steal banking and credential data, while utilizing anti-deobfuscation and anti-analysis techniques. In addition, they mentioned the pwgrabc credential stealer, and the tabDLL module that is also used to steal user credentials and utilize them to furtherly spread the malware via the SMBv1 network share, while leveraging the EternalRomance exploit.

In the same month, AdvIntel researchers reported that the Conti ransomware group completely took over the operation of the TrickBot malware, and plans to permanently replace it with the more advanced and stealthy BazarBackdoor.

On February 24, 2022, TrickBot‚Äôs server infrastructure was finally taken down, marking the end of the malware activity. However, shortly after the shutdown IBM Security X-Force reported that the TrickBot operators continue to refine their arsenal. The threat actors were observed deploying a new version of the AnchorDNS backdoor, dubbed AnchorMail. The new backdoor version uses an email-based C2 server, while communicating with SMTP and IMAP protocols over TLS.

In March 2022, amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War, a Ukrainian member of the Conti ransomware group leaked internal chats concerning TrickBot and its C2 server source code. The leaks provided further support for the connection between the operations of Conti and TrickBot.

In April 2022, the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) issued a warning against phishing attacks, attributed to the TrickBot operators, targeting Ukrainian organizations. The threat actors used macro-embedded documents with lures related to the Azovstal factory (connected to the Siege of Mariupol), leading to the deployment of Cobalt Strike.

In July 2022, IBM Security X-Force published a broad overview of TrickBot's activity amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War. Since February 2022, the TrickBot operators have initiated at least six campaigns targeting Ukrainian entities. The threat actors used phishing email messages to distribute different types of malware and hacking tools, such as IcedID, CobaltStrike, AnchorMail, and Meterpreter. Some of which were deployed using a novel Microsoft Excel downloader. To evade detection, the threat actors used a new crypter dubbed Forest that was sometimes used in conjunction with the Bumblebee loader.

In February 2023, the United States and the United Kingdom imposed sanctions on seven Russian individuals for their involvement in the operations of TrickBot. As a result of the sanctions, all property and funds that belong to these individuals in the United States and the United Kingdom were blocked and it is now prohibited to perform any kind of transactions with them. According to the UK government, the threat actors were responsible for 149 attacks on UK individuals and companies and received ransom payments of at least ¬£27,000,000.

content.Overview:
The Checkmate ransomware group, first observed by cybersecurity researchers in June 2022, has been active since at least May 2022. The group targets unupdated and weakly-protected QNAP NAS devices.

Checkmate gains initial system access through brute-force attacks against Server Message Block (SMB) services that are exposed to the internet. Upon encryption, the ransomware appends files with the .checkmate extension and drops a ransom note named !CHECKMATE_DECRYPTION_README. The ransom notes contain details about the encrypted data, a ransom demand to be paid in Bitcoin (around $15,000), and a link to a Telegram channel through which to contact the threat actors.

On July 7, 2022, QNAP issued a security advisory against Checkmate attacks and recommended its customers not expose their NAS devices to internet access and to use VPN to reduce the attack surface. In addition, QNAP advised disabling SMB 1, updating the operating system to the latest available version, using strong passwords, and ensuring regular data backups for easy restoration.
content.AdditionalInformation: Further information on how to disable SMB 1 and update the software can be found here: https://www.qnap.com/en/security-advisory/QSA-22-21

content.Overview:
The 0mega ransomware group, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in July 2022, has been active since at least May 2022. There is little information about the group‚Äôs specific victims. As of July 10, 2022, 0mega was only observed compromising two victims, one undisclosed and the other, an electronics repair company.

Upon encryption, 0mega appends the files with the .0mega extension and drops ransom notes named DECRYPT-FILES.txt that are customized for each victim. The ransom notes contain a link to a Tor payment negotiation website with a "support" chat to contact the threat actors. To log into the site, the victims need to upload their ransom note that includes a unique Base64-encoded blob for identification.  

0mega operates an active leak site, in which it uploads the data of victims who refused to pay the ransom.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The ABCsoup malware was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in July 2022. The malware, likely operated by threat actors of Eastern European and Russian origin, primarily targets Russian users of Google Chrome, Opera, and Mozilla Firefox web browsers. 

ABCsoup spreads through adware campaigns promoting malicious browser extensions that impersonate Google Translate add-ons by copying their extension ID. The malicious extensions are installed by sideloading Windows executables, bypassing security mechanisms. Once deployed, ABCsoup establishes a command and control (C2) connection and starts collecting personal information to deliver personalized ads, fingerprinting searches, and injecting malicious JavaScript codes to log user keystrokes and monitor web browser activity. The customized code is injected on active websites that are opened in the web browser, such as Yandex, Rambler, and Kismia. In addition, ABCsoup searches for active social networking services like Odnoklassniki and VK, and if found, collects user data, such as name, date of birth, and gender. All the collected information is then sent to the C2 server.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Rozena backdoor (AKA Bedep) has been active since at least January 2015. The malware targets Windows systems by exploiting vulnerabilities found in various Windows components, such as Windows VBScript engine (CVE-2018-8174) and Windows Support Diagnostic Tool (CVE-2022-30190).

Rozena is distributed through various methods, including malware loaders, phishing email messages containing malicious attachments, and drive-by downloads from compromised websites. Once deployed, Rozena connects to a remote server (e.g. Discord CDN) to fetch additional files and execute obfuscated PowerShell scripts. These scripts lead to the injection of a shellcode that launches a reverse shell back to the attackers‚Äô machine enabling them full remote access. With this access, the malware operators can collect information, download and upload files, and deploy additional malware into the infected machine. To avoid detection, Rozena employs the ‚Äúfileless‚Äù technique of running malicious commands or launching scripts directly from memory, and it also downloads legitimate files (e.g. Microsoft Word) as decoy. In addition, the malware was observed using the server-side polymorphism technique to hide some of its executed files. 

Rozena terminates its operation if it detects that it runs in a virtual environment or if the default system language is Russian, Ukrainian, Belarusian, or Chinese. The latter feature may imply the origin of the malware operators (Eastern Europe or China).

Security researchers found similarities between Rozena‚Äôs PowerShell scripts and the ones used by the Ursnif malware (AKA Gozi).
content.AdditionalInformation: In July 2022, the Rozena operators were observed using weaponized Office documents exploiting the ‚ÄúFollina‚Äù MSDT zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2022-30190). Once executed, the malicious documents fetched an HTML file (index.htm) that invoked the msdt.exe tool with a PowerShell command and downloaded additional files. These included the Rozena executable and a batch file (cd.bat) that was designed to terminate MSDT processes and establish the backdoor's persistence by adding registry run keys.

content.Overview:
The SharpBoys threat group has been active since at least December 2021. The Iranian hacktivist group targets Israeli websites from various sectors, such as technology, pharmaceuticals, retail, and tourism.

SharpBoys engages in distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks and website defacements, sometimes resulting in data leaks. The group‚Äôs specific attack vector was not disclosed.

SharpBoys gained prominence at the end of 2021, hacking two Israeli hiking websites (Tiyuli and Lametayel), leaking the information of 100,000 users, and offering the information of around 3,000,000 people for sale. The group claimed to steal 500 GB of data belonging to Israeli users, including email addresses, photos, and phone numbers.

‚Äã‚ÄãThe threat actors operate an active leak site, in which they leak data that they have stolen. In addition, SharpBoys maintains Telegram channels for publishing different announcements and data leaks.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In June 2022, SharpBoys hacked Israeli travel booking sites, allegedly gaining control of the backend administration of the websites. The group also leaked spreadsheets containing the personal information of more than 300,000 Israeli users, including names, ID numbers, addresses, and credit card information. Following the attack, the Israeli Privacy Protection Authority seized the servers of Gol Tours LTD, which managed many of the breached websites, for not applying the necessary cybersecurity measures and not fixing system vulnerabilities that were exploited in the attack.

In July 2022, SharpBoys announced that it breached 48 Israeli websites from different sectors, such as technology and pharmaceuticals.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The HavanaCrypt ransomware group was first reported by Trend Micro researchers in July 2022. There is little information about the group‚Äôs specific targets.

HavanaCrypt deploys its ransomware by disguising it as a Google Software Update application, likely sent through phishing messages. The ransomware, written in .NET, is obfuscated using the Obfuscar tool and employs various anti-virtualization techniques to avoid dynamic analysis. Then, it downloads and executes a batch file from a command and control (C2) server that is hosted on a legitimate Microsoft Web hosting service. To evade detection, the batch file configures Windows Defender scan preferences and terminates any running processes that might interfere with the encryption, including database applications (e.g. MySQL) or desktop applications (e.g. Microsoft Office). HavanaCrypt then deletes volume shadow copies and other system restore functions, collects and exfiltrates general system information (e.g. the processor name and ID), and encrypts files appending them with the .Havana extension. 

The ransomware uses KeePass Password Safe modules to generate random keys that are needed for encryption to make it difficult for malware researchers to independently develop decryption tools. In addition, HavanaCrypt uses the .NET function "QueueUserWorkItem" to speed up encryption.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Anubis Network phishing campaign has been ongoing, intermittently, since at least November 2020. The campaign targets online banking customers in Brazil and Portugal with the aim of stealing user credentials to access bank accounts.

Anubis Network is the name of a command and control (C2) server hosting credential harvesting landing pages impersonating banking portals and applications. Victims are led to these landing pages through phishing email messages and smishing (SMS). To avoid suspicion, the threat actors use the Let‚Äôs Encrypt CA to create valid HTTPS certificates for their pages. In addition, the landing pages‚Äô source code is obfuscated using JavaScript to evade detection by keywords.

The Anubis Network operators use a backend interface to monitor the campaign progress and to mask their original IP addresses through the Cloudflare content delivery network (CDN) by configuring new DNS zones. In addition, the interface contains the ‚Äúemail temp‚Äù feature enabling the threat actors to create new domains and use internal email messages to manage the campaign.

Anubis Network has an active Telegram channel to provide technical support to the different campaign operators. In addition, it has a MySQL database that is used to synchronize the data between all components of the malicious ecosystem.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Lilith ransomware group was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in July 2022. There is little information about the group's specific targets. 

Lilith, written in C/C++, attacks 64-bit versions of Windows operating systems. Once executed, the ransomware attempts to terminate various running processes that might interfere with the encryption, such as Outlook, SQL, Thunderbird, Steam, PowerPoint, WordPad, and Firefox. Then, Lilith drops ransom notes containing a Tox address for communicating with the threat actors, and encrypts all the files that are stored upon the compromised system, excluding EXE, DLL, and SYS files, as well as a list of directory and file names (e.g. the Program Files and Recycle Bin directories). The ransomware encrypts files using Windows cryptographic API and the Windows‚Äôs CryptGenRandom function (random key generation), appending them with the .lilith extension. 

Lilith‚Äôs file and directory exclusion list also contains ‚Äúecdh_pub_k.bin,‚Äù which stores the local public key of the Babuk ransomware, suggesting a possible link between the two ransomware strains.           

Lilith operates an active leak site, in which it uploads the data of victims who refuse to pay the ransom or who do not initiate ransom negotiations within three days.
content.AdditionalInformation: As of July 13, 2022, the leak site only contains one victim, a South American construction company.

content.Overview:
The Sality malware has been active since at least 2003. The malware was attributed by Crowdstrike to the Salty Spider threat group. Sality (also referred to as W32.Sality family) is an entry point malware that is used for further malware infection. 

Sality is a polymorphic worm affecting .srs and .exe files. It can be used to overwrite existing file codes with viral ones, disable local security software, open connections to remote sites, download additional malware from various URLs and P2P sources, or steal data from the host. The malware can also inject itself into running processes and abuse the Windows autorun function to copy itself onto USB devices, network shares, and external storage drives. 

Since its first incarnation, Sality has been spread in various versions.
content.AdditionalInformation: In July 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported that threat actors advertised a password cracking tool for unlocking programmable logic controller (PLC) and human-machine interface (HMI) terminals, that was used as a dropper for the Sality malware. The cracking tool exploited a known system vulnerability (CVE-2022-2003) to extract the password, but also dropped Sality onto the machine. Once deployed, the malware downloaded another malicious payload that was used to hijack clipboard data to divert cryptocurrency transactions.

content.Overview:
APT31 (AKA ZIRCONIUM, JUDGMENT PANDA, BRONZE VINEWOOD) is a Chinese state-sponsored hacking group that has been active since at least early 2016, and has historically targeted foreign companies to steal intellectual property, it was also known to target diplomatic entities.

Although this threat actor was first seen in 2016, very little is known about it in the cyber security community.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In June 2020, researchers published that this group was targeting the Biden campaign and staff in the US election campaign. The targets of these attacks usually fell into two categories:
1. People who are closely associated with US presidential campaigns and candidates.
2. Prominent individuals in the international affairs community and staff members of international affairs departments in the US.

Google security researchers detected phishing attempts against the personal email accounts of staffers on the Joe Biden and Donald Trump campaigns. The attacks were committed by Chinese and Iranian state-sponsored threat groups APT31 and APT35, respectively. As a part of the campaign, APT31 also deployed targeted malware on its victim‚Äôs systems.

Between July and September 2020, Google terminated more than 3,000 fake YouTube channels. These channels were part of a large spam network linked to China that attempted to run an influence operation on YouTube. First, these channels posted spam content in Mandarin such as videos of animals. Then, they started posting content in Mandarin about issues related to Hong Kong and China's response to Covid-19. Finally, they posted content in English and Mandarin about current events in the US, such as protests around racial justice, the wildfires on the West Coast, and the US response to Covid-19.

In February 2021, Check Point researchers reported that Chinese threat actors cloned and used a Windows zero-day exploit stolen from the NSA's Equation Group years before the privilege escalation flaw was patched. This tool called Jian was actively utilized between 2014 and 2017 exploiting CVE-2017-0005 (Windows GDI Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability).
The researchers reported that the investigation into Jian exposed a module containing four privilege escalation exploits that were part of Equation Group's DanderSpritz post-exploitation framework. 

Two of the exploits in the framework, dating back to 2013, were zero-day flaws. One of the exploits was ‚ÄúEpMe‚Äù, whereas another, dubbed "EpMo," appears to have been quietly patched in May 2017 by Microsoft as a follow-up fix in response to the Shadow Brokers leak but was not assigned a CVE. The remaining code names are EIEi and ErNi.
Credits:
https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/the-story-of-jian/

In March 2021, Finnish officials blamed APT31 for breaching the Parliament‚Äôs internal IT systems in the fall of 2020. 

In June 2021, Norway accused APT31 of the 2018 breach of the government‚Äôs IT network. Security researchers discovered some overlaps between APT31 and APT10, another Chinese group that was earlier associated with that breach.

In March 2022, Google announced that it blocked phishing messages that were sent by APT31 a month earlier. The messages were sent as part of a campaign targeting Gmail users affiliated with the US government.

In July 2022, Proofpoint researchers named APT31 among threat groups that have been observed targeting journalists for cyberespionage purposes since early 2021. APT31 sent phishing email messages to US-based journalists covering US politics and national security, as well as the US and European engagement in the Russo-Ukrainian War. The messages contained web beacons that alerted the threat actors once they were accessed and enabled them to gather information, such as the victim's IP address, geolocation, and the internet service provider (ISP). This information might have been used to initiate further system infiltration. 

In the same month, the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Belgium published an announcement stating the involvement of several Chinese APT groups, including APT31, in attacks targeting the country's defense and interior ministries. The Belgian minister urged the Chinese authorities to take action against the threat groups; however, China denied the accusations.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Joker Android Trojan (AKA Bread) has been active since at least 2017. It spreads globally, masquerading as legitimate Google Play applications, and steals sensitive information. The malware is named after one of its command and control (C2) domains. The UI of the Joker‚Äôs C2 panel, as well as some of the comments in its code, are written in Chinese, which may point to the origins of the malware‚Äôs developers. 

Joker was observed in thousands of Android apps that take many forms, such as security software, QR scanners, wallpaper and emoji stores, and medical apps. Once installed, the malware connects to a C2 server and downloads a malicious Dalvik executable (DEX) payload, which provides access to the device‚Äôs NotificationListenerService. Then, Joker can intercept SMS messages, access the contact list, collect general device information, and even create a simulation of clicks that enable it to register to premium services (also known as "toll billing" or "fleeceware"). 

The malware employs various obfuscation techniques to evade security software detection and adapts to the latest updates by Google Play Protect in order to bypass its defenses. In addition, it receives dynamic code and commands over HTTP and runs them through JavaScript-to-Java callbacks, which provides an additional protection layer. Recent malware versions also leverage a developer tool called ‚ÄúFlutter‚Äù that prevents detection.

In January 2020, Google stated that Google Play Protect detected and removed approximately 1,700 Joker-infected apps from its play store since 2017; however, new malicious apps keep emerging.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In April 2021, it was reported that more than half a million Huawei users were infected with the Joker malware, after downloading malicious apps that masqueraded as virtual keyboards, camera apps, online messenger, and coloring programs.

In December 2021, cybersecurity researchers observed the ‚ÄúColor Message‚Äù Android application infected with Joker. The app was downloaded over half a million times before Google removed it. The researchers found that the app communicated with Russian servers.

In May 2022, Kaspersky researchers reported on another set of Trojanized applications spreading in Google Play and distributing the Joker malware. The applications masqueraded as messaging apps, apps for monitoring blood pressure, and for document scanning. The researchers found that between January 2021 and March 2022, Joker most frequently attacked users in Saudi Arabia, Poland, and Germany.

In July 2022, a new Joker variant dubbed Autolycos was observed to be distributed through malicious apps that were promoted on Facebook and Instagram. The new variant employed an improved security evasion mechanism of executing URLs on a remote browser and then including the result in HTTP requests. This instead of using WebView, which elevates the risk of the user noticing the infection.

In addition, cybersecurity researchers reported on dozens new malicious apps that acted as droppers for Joker, as well as other Android malware (e.g. Facestealer and Coper). To evade detection, the Joker operators hid the malicious payload in a common asset file and package application using commercial packers.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Facestealer Android Trojan, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in November 2021, has been active since July 2021. It spreads indiscriminately in the Google Play Store and seems to be operated from Russia. 

Facestealer, short for Facebook credential stealer, impersonates legitimate Android apps, such as photo editors and VPN services, with the goal of stealing confidential Facebook information like user credentials and profile content. The compromised Facebook accounts might be used for various malicious purposes, such as committing financial frauds, sending phishing messages, and spreading fake news. 

Once installed, the app uses the Android WebView object‚Äôs loadUrl API to launch a Facebook login page and asks the users to log into their accounts. Then, the malware injects malicious JavaScript code into the page, extracts sensitive information, and exfiltrates it to a command and control (C2) server at a Russian-registered domain.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In May 2022, Trend Micro researchers reported that they observed over 200 apps containing the Facestealer malware. The apps included VPN services, camera apps and photo editing services, among others. They were designed to steal user credentials and collect personal information associated with the victims' Facebook accounts.

In July 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on dozens new malicious apps that acted as droppers for Android malware, such as Facestealer, as well as Joker and Coper. Facestealer, hiding in a camera app with 5,000 downloads, exhorted victims to log into their Facebook accounts and stole their credentials.

content.Overview:
The Gallium threat group (AKA Soft Cell, Red Dev 4) has been active since at least 2012. The Chinese APT group, likely to be state-sponsored, primarily targets telecommunication providers, financial institutions, and government entities in Southeast Asia, Europe, and Africa.

Gallium uses network scanning tools to detect and exploit vulnerable internet-facing services, such as WildFly/JBoss, and gain initial access to the victim‚Äôs network. Then, the threat actors typically install web shells, dump credentials, and use off-the-shelf as well as modified tools (e.g. PsExec and Mimikatz) to move laterally within the compromised system while evading security mechanisms. Some of the tools are even signed with valid (probably stolen) certificates to avoid suspicion. 

Gallium has been observed using different types of malware, including BlackMould, China Chopper, Poison Ivy, and QuarkBandit. Some of the malware used was observed to be modified to increase stealthiness. Gallium uses malware for various malicious purposes, such as enumerating local drives, manipulating files, exfiltrating data, and executing arbitrary commands. Additionally, the threat actors were observed to employ SoftEther VPN software to gain access to and maintain persistence on the targeted systems. They typically lean on dynamic DNS subdomains to provide command and control (C2) infrastructure, hosted in China, Hong Kong SAR, and Taiwan. 

Gallium was linked to the 2018 Operation Soft Cell, a global cyberespionage campaign targeting telecommunications providers. The tools that were used in the campaign were previously employed by other Chinese state-sponsored groups, such as APT10 and APT27, indicating a possible overlap between Gallium and these groups.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In June 2022, Palo Alto researchers reported a new and stealthy malware named PingPull that was used by Gallium in attacks against financial institutions and government entities in countries like Australia, Belgium, Russia, the Philippines, and Malaysia. The malware, written in Visual C++, enabled the threat actors to access a reverse shell and run arbitrary commands for file manipulation, enumeration of storage volumes, and more. The researchers discovered three PingPull variants with similar functionality using different C2 communication protocols (ICMP, HTTPS, and TCP). In addition, they were able to link Gallium to over 170 IP addresses, some dating back to 2020. 

In July 2022, the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Belgium published an announcement stating the involvement of several Chinese APT groups, including Gallium, in attacks targeting the country's defense and interior ministries. The Belgian minister urged the Chinese authorities to take action against the threat groups; however, China denied the accusations.

Other tools that were used by Gallium include: HTRAN, NBTScan, Netcat, Windows Credential Editor (WCE), and WinRAR.

content.Overview:
The CloudMensis backdoor, first reported by ESET researchers in July 2022, has been active since at least February 2022. The malware targets macOS devices for data collection purposes. There is little information about the malware operators‚Äô attack vectors and specific targets. 

CloudMensis, developed in Objective-C, is deployed on the compromised device using code execution and elevation of administrative privileges. In the two-stage process, the first stage downloader fetches and executes a next stage malicious payload from a public cloud storage service, such as pCloud, Yandex Disk, or Dropbox. Once deployed, CloudMensis bypasses the Transparency, Consent, and Control (TCC) security framework to receive permissions to take screenshots,  scan connected removable storage devices, and capture keyboard events. If the Mac‚Äôs System Integrity Protection (SIP) is disabled, CloudMensis grants itself permissions by adding new rules to the TCC.db file. If SIP is enabled and the Mac is running any version of macOS Catalina earlier than 10.15.6, CloudMensis exploits a vulnerability (CVE-2020-9934) to make the TCC daemon (tccd) load a database to which CloudMensis can write. The malware supports 39 commands that enable it to steal documents, email messages and attachments, and files from removable storage devices. In addition, CloudMensis can run shell commands and download and execute arbitrary files.
content.AdditionalInformation:

content.Overview:
The Luna ransomware group was first observed by Kaspersky researchers in June 2022, after it was promoted on underground hacking forums. As the ransomware still seems under development, there is little information about Luna‚Äôs attack vectors and specific targets. 

Luna, written in Rust, encrypts files that are stored on compromised Windows, Linux, and ESXi systems, appending them with the .luna extension. The ransomware uses an uncommon encryption combination of x25519 and AES algorithms.   

Luna seems to be designed for Russian-speaking affiliates, which may indicate the origin of the ransomware developers.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Evilnum threat group (AKA DeathStalker, TA4563) was first discovered in 2018 during an attack on fintech companies. The group, possibly operating in a hack-for-hire model, primarily targets companies located in EU countries and the UK. There is some evidence that Evilnum also operated in other countries, such as Australia and Canada. 

The main goal of the Evilnum group is to spy on and obtain financial information from highly targeted companies and their customers. The group‚Äôs initial infection vector typically begins with spear phishing email messages. The email messages contain malicious attachments or links that point to documents containing malicious VBA macros that execute the group‚Äôs malware. The group primarily uses the custom malware PowerPepper and Powersing, while constantly issuing newer versions of these malware.
content.AdditionalInformation:
This group focuses on the fintech market by abusing the know-your-customer (KYC) regulations. KYC processes are employed by companies of all sizes to ensure that their proposed customers, agents, consultants, or distributors are anti-bribery compliant and are actually who they claim to be.

Evilnum‚Äôs spear phishing email messages attempt to deliver ZIP archives that contain LNK files masquerading as photos of different documents. Once an LNK file is opened, it deploys the JavaScript Trojan, which in turn replaces the LNK file with a real image file, making this whole operation invisible to the user. The JavaScript agent can upload and download files, steal cookies, collect antivirus information, execute commands, and more.

The group‚Äôs toolset and infrastructure consist of a mix of custom, homemade malware combined with tools purchased from Golden Chickens, a malware-as-a-service (MaaS) provider whose infamous customers include FIN6 and Cobalt Group. They were also seen using More_eggs, TerraPreter, TerraStealer, and TerraTV in their campaigns.

Evilnum steals information such as:
- Passwords
- Spreadsheets and documents with customer lists, investments, and trading operations
- Internal presentations
- Software licenses and credentials for trading software/platforms
- Cookies and session information from browsers
- Email credentials
- Customer credit card information and proof of address/identity documents
