In June 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported that since the beginning of 2022 they observed several Evilnum attacks against organizations in the United Kingdom and other parts of Europe. One of the attacks targeted an intergovernmental organization dealing with international migration services. The attack's targeting and timeline corresponded with the Russo-Ukrainian War, in which pro-Russian threat actors were repeatedly observed targeting migration organizations. The threat actors sent their targets phishing email messages that contained Microsoft Office documents with malicious macro codes, leveraging VBA stomping technique to bypass static analysis and reverse engineering. Once the macro code was triggered, it executed a heavily obfuscated JavaScript that created a scheduled task to maintain persistence and dropped two files, a malware loader and an encrypted binary. To evade detection, the binary was injected using the "Heaven's gate" technique. Finally, a backdoor was deployed taking screenshots of the machine and exfiltrating them to a command and control (C2) server through an HTTP POST request.

In July 2022, Proofpoint researchers reported that the TA4563 was observed using the Evilnum malware to target European financial and investment entities, especially the ones engaging in forex, cryptocurrency, and decentralized finance (DeFi). The threat actors sent phishing email messages containing malicious Microsoft Word, ISO, or LNK files (sometimes packed in ZIP archives), leading to the deployment of the Evilnum backdoor. The backdoor, consisted of JavaScript and C# components, could be used for reconnaissance, data theft, or to load additional malware.

In August 2022, Kaspersky reported recurring attacks by Evilnum against foreign and cryptocurrency exchanges around the world from September 2020 until June 2022. The threat actors used spear phishing email messages with macro-embedded documents to distribute the VileRAT malware. The malware can execute arbitrary commands, log user keystrokes, establish persistence by creating scheduled tasks, detect security solutions, and update itself through its connected C2 server.

In December 2022, Kaspersky linked Evilnum to attacks against legal entities in 2020 and possibly 2021 using the Janicab malware. These attacks were also assumed to be part of an older campaign that has been traced back to early 2015 and targeted legal, financial, and travel agencies in the Middle East and Europe. The threat actors used spear phishing email messages that contained ZIP archives with LNK-based droppers. Once executed, the droppers led to the deployment of the VBScript-based Janicab implant. Evilnum has used YouTube dead-drop resolvers (DDRs), i.e. employing unlisted old YouTube links to host C2 information that is later deciphered by the malware. Similar to other malware used by Evilnum, such as Powersing, Janicab can be used to execute commands received from the C2 server, import registry files, and download additional malware. While older Janicab versions also featured audio recording capabilities, newer malware versions were added a keylogger module instead.

content.Overview:
The Atlas Intelligence Group (A.I.G, AKA Atlantis Cyber-Army), first reported by cybersecurity researchers in July 2022, has been active since at least May 2022. The hacker-for-hire threat group indiscriminately targets organizations around the world (e.g. the United States, Israel, and Pakistan) in various sectors, such as government, finance, manufacturing, and technology.

A.I.G employs a unique business model of outsourcing entire hacking campaigns to independent cyber mercenaries with different areas of expertise (e.g. pentesting or social engineering). The cyber mercenaries are recruited through the group‚Äôs Telegram channels and seem to change for each campaign. This way the group leaders can exclude themselves from the illicit activities and also make it difficult for security researchers and law officials to link between the campaigns. A.I.G offers a variety of services on its website, including access to stolen databases, distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, and initial access to enterprise networks through remote desktop protocol (RDP) clients and webshells. In addition, the group offers ‚ÄúVIP‚Äù access to sensitive information that was allegedly acquired through connections within law enforcement agencies.

All the activities are managed and coordinated by the group‚Äôs leader, "Mr. Eagle." Other identified group members (El Rojo, Mr.Shawji, S41T4M4, and Coffee) are responsible for tasks such as advertising A.I.G's services, communicating with customers, and operating the group‚Äôs Telegram channels.

A.I.G maintains at least three Telegram channels for different purposes; one is a marketplace for leaked databases, another contains ads for recruiting hacking experts, and the third serves as a communication channel with announcements, lists of intended targets, doxxing posts, and details about attack toolkits. Interestingly, the group also engages in voluntary hunting for pedophiles, publicly publishing their personal details, such as home addresses, phone numbers, and pictures. In addition, the group operates an e-commerce store on the Sellix.io platform, in which users can purchase the different A.I.G services as well as stolen databases, using cryptocurrency.

The Atlas Intelligence Group might be linked to the DDoSArmy threat group, based on some communications.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Redeemer ransomware was first observed in June 2021, after it was promoted on underground hacking forums. Redeemer follows a unique ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) model, allowing a free download of the ransomware builder along with an obligation to set aside 20% of the ransom payment to the ransomware developer, ‚ÄúCerebrate.‚Äù In July 2022, a newer version, Redeemer 2.0 was released, targeting Windows Vista, 7, 8, 10, and 11.

Once deployed using admin privileges, Redeemer creates a mutex to make sure that only one instance of malware will run on the victim‚Äôs computer. Then, the ransomware, written in C/C++, creates a folder, copies itself into the Windows directory with legitimate file names, and executes itself as a new process using the ShellExecuteW() API function. In addition, Redeemer clears event logs and deletes volume shadow copies (VSS) and any system backups to cover its tracks and prevent file restoration. The ransomware terminates any process that might interfere with the encryption (e.g. mySQL) and generates ransom notes in the Winlogon registry key to warn the victim of the ransomware infection during the system restart. Next, Redeemer encrypts the files that are stored on the compromised system while appending them with the .redeem extension and changing their icon. The ransomware also adds a registry entry for the encrypted files that pops up a message with instructions once they are opened.

The Redeemer developers provide their affiliates with a GUI interface to build the ransomware executable and decryption tool, add communication channels (XMPP and Tox channels and up to two email addresses), provide the ransom amount (in Monero), and insert a campaign ID for tracking purposes. In addition, the developers operate a dedicated page on Dread, from which the affiliates can download the ransomware builder, get instructions, and receive support.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The DevilsTongue spyware was first reported by Microsoft researchers in June 2021. The malware targets politicians, human rights activists, journalists, academics, embassy workers, and political dissidents, in many countries around the globe, such as the United Kingdom, Israel, Iran, Spain, Turkey, and Singapore. DevilsTongue was developed by the Israeli surveillanceware vendor, Candiru (AKA Sourgum).

DevilsTongue, written in C/C++, can be deployed through various methods, including weaponized documents, malicious links on phishing messages, watering hole attacks, and man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks. The malware is designed to exploit system vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2021-31979 and CVE-2021-33771) enabling it to evade detection and elevate privileges. Once deployed, the malware loads encrypted DLL files into memory and uses COM hijacking to inject them into legitimate processes (e.g. svchost.exe) and achieve persistence. DevilsTongue can collect files, tamper registries, run Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) commands, and query SQLite databases. In addition, it can turn on the victim‚Äôs webcam and microphone, take screenshots, exfiltrate data from the Signal private messaging platform, and steal cookies and user credentials from LSASS and web browsers, such as Chrome and Firefox. These credentials can later be used to log into user accounts on social media (e.g. Facebook and Twitter) and email clients (e.g. Gmail, Yahoo, and Mail.ru). The compromised accounts might also be used to send phishing messages to additional victims and expand the scope of the attack. 

DevilsTongue‚Äôs command-and-control (C2) infrastructure involves more than 750 websites, including domains that impersonate legitimate organizations, such as advocacy organizations (e.g. Amnesty International and the Black Lives Matter movement), international media channels (e.g. CNN and France 24), tech companies (e.g. Microsoft, Apple, and Google), social media (e.g. Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube), and international organizations (e.g. the United Nations and the World Health Organization). 

Like other surveillanceware vendors, such as the NSO Group and RCS Lab, DevilsTongue‚Äôs developers, Candiru, sells its spyware and surveillance tools to military and intelligence agencies in countries of authoritarian regimes, such as in Uzbekistan, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates. The use of Candiru‚Äôs spyware is restricted in other countries, including the United States, China, Iran, Israel, and Russia; however, this does not mean that the company‚Äôs products are not being used in those countries.
content.AdditionalInformation: In July 2022, Avast researchers reported that since March 2022, DevilsTongue was observed leveraging a zero-day vulnerability in Google Chrome (CVE-2022-2294) to target journalists in the Middle East (e.g. Lebanon, Turkey, and Yemen). The malware was distributed through watering hole attacks, in which the DevilsTongue‚Äôs operators compromised websites and injected them with malicious JavaScript codes redirecting victims to attacker-controlled domains.

content.Overview:
The GoMet backdoor, first reported by Cisco Talos researchers in July 2022, has been active since at least 2020 (although the original malware code was already posted on GitHub in March 2019). The malware was observed targeting Ukrainian entities amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War; however, it might have also been used to target entities from other regions as well.

GoMet, written in Golang, gains system access by exploiting system vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2020-5902 and CVE-2022-1040). Once deployed, the malware can be used to create cronjobs (every two seconds), list files, connections, and processes, upload and download files, execute arbitrary commands, and use the initial access to spread to other connected networks and computers (‚Äúdaisy chain‚Äù). To evade detection when establishing persistence, GoMet enumerates the autorun values instead of creating a new one, and replaces one of the legitimate autorun executables with the malware. The malware communication with the command and control (C2) server is done through HTTPS on the default port. In case the C2 is unreachable, GoMet sleeps for a random amount of time between 5 and 10 minutes.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Luca Stealer malware was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in July 2022, after its source code was released for free on underground hacking forums. In its latest version, Luca Stealer can target only Windows users. There is little information about the malware‚Äôs initial access vectors. 

Once deployed, the Rust-based Luca Stealer can harvest information from Chromium-based browsers (e.g. user credentials, credit card data, and cookies), password manager browser extensions, chat applications (e.g. Discord, ICQ, Telegram, and Skype), crypto wallets, and gaming applications (e.g. Steam and Uplay). In addition, it can take screenshots and collect general system information (e.g. username, OS version, and geolocation) using its implemented ‚Äúwhoami‚Äù library. The collected data is packed in ZIP archives and exfiltrated through Telegram bots, or, for files larger than 50 MB, in Discord webhooks. Luca Stealer also sends its operators a summary of the stolen data as a chat message.

Being a freely available malware, Luca Stealer has the potential of becoming a prevalent malware in the threat landscape.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Knotweed threat group has been active since at least February 2020. The group targets law firms, banks, and strategic consultancy organizations in countries such as Austria, the United Kingdom, and Panama. In July 2022, Knotweed was linked to the Austrian surveillanceware vendor, DSIRF (estd. 2016), which is tied to shady individuals, such as the white-collar criminal, Jan Marsalek.

Knotweed gains initial system access by sending email messages containing Excel documents with malicious macro codes or PDF documents designed to exploit system vulnerabilities in Windows (e.g. CVE-2022-22047 and CVE-2021-31199) and Adobe Reader (CVE-2021-28550). These vulnerabilities enable the threat actors to gain administrative privileges, escape sandboxes, and execute malicious code remotely. Once infiltrating the system, Knotweed deploys Subzero spyware (AKA Corelump) that can log user keystrokes, take screenshots, exfiltrate files, and run remote shells and arbitrary plugins that are fetched from a command and control (C2) server. Knotweed also uses the heavily-obfuscated Jumplump malware loader to load the spyware into memory to evade detection. In addition, the threat actors were observed using these post-exploitation tools: Mex, containing multiple red teaming or security plugins copied from GitHub (e.g. Chisel, Mimikatz, and SharpExec), and the PassLib credential dumping tool, stealing passwords from web browsers, email clients, LSASS, the Windows credential manager, and more.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Microsoft recommends several mitigation measures to counter Knotweed attacks:
- Patch system vulnerabilities, such as CVE-2022-22047.
- Confirm that the Microsoft Defender antivirus is updated to security intelligence update 1.371.503.0 or later.
- Use the included indicators of compromise (IOC) to investigate whether they exist in your environment and assess for potential intrusion.
- Change Excel macro security settings to control which macros run and under what circumstances when you open a workbook. 
- Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) to mitigate potentially compromised credentials and ensure that MFA is enforced for all remote connectivity. 
- Review all authentication activity for remote access infrastructure, with a particular focus on accounts configured with single factor authentication, to confirm authenticity and investigate any anomalous activity.

The full list of recommendations can be found here: https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/07/27/untangling-knotweed-european-private-sector-offensive-actor-using-0-day-exploits/

content.Overview:
The Octo Android banking Trojan (AKA ExobotCompact.D) was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in April 2022, after its name surfaced on underground hacking forums in January 2022. Octo is a rebrand of the ExobotCompact malware (AKA ExoCompact) that targets banking, financial, and instant messaging apps mostly in Europe, in countries such as the United Kingdom, Germany, Italy, Spain, and Portugal. The malware is offered for sale by a threat actor using the monikers "Architect" and "goodluck."

Octo is usually distributed by threat actors using landing pages that promote seemingly legitimate apps or software updates for download. The malware was observed to be distributed as part of various types of malicious applications acting as malware droppers, such as device cleaning, screen recording, and financial apps. Once the app is installed on a victim‚Äôs device, it disables Google Protect, establishes connection to a command and control (C2) server, and executes an obfuscated Octo payload. 

Like other banking malware, Octo can log user keystrokes, intercept and send SMS messages, lock the device‚Äôs screen, and launch applications. In addition, it has an advanced remote access module that enables its operators to perform on-device fraud (ODF) by abusing the Android AccessibilityService and performing overlay attacks. The malware can blacken the screen to hide its actions, while setting the screen brightness to zero and disabling all notifications. It also enables live screen streaming through Android's MediaProjection which captures the device‚Äôs screen in real-time.
content.AdditionalInformation: Among the companies whose applications were targeted by Octo: Facebook, Twitter, Telegram, Uber, WeChat, Skype, Spotify, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, Chase, Barclays, Capital One, HSBC, BBVA, Banco Santander, Coinbase, and Bitfinex.

content.Overview:
The HiddenAds Android Trojan has been active since at least February 2019. The malware targets Android users around the world, in countries such as the United States, South Korea, Japan, and Brazil.

HiddenAds impersonates seemingly legitimate applications, such as games, system cleaners and optimizers, image and video editors, and collections of desktop wallpapers, that spread through adware campaigns on social media (e.g. Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, and Youtube). Once deployed, the apps abuse the Contact Provider Android component to flood users with marketing ads, sometimes demanding small charges from the users. HiddenAds can also download and install APK-embedding spyware or ask for device admin permissions. To evade detection, the apps constantly change their icons and names and even masquerade as the Settings utility or the Google Play Store.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The DawDropper dropper-as-a-service (DaaS) was first reported by Trend Micro researchers in July 2022. The dropper is used by the operators of Android banking Trojans, such as Octo, Hydra, ERMAC, and TeaBot, to drop their malware that targets Android users around the world.

DawDropper impersonates seemingly legitimate utility applications, such as document scanners, QR code readers, VPN services, and call recorders. Once downloaded, the malicious payloads, hosted on GitHub, are executed on the victim‚Äôs machine, stealing sensitive information (e.g. user credentials and stored data), taking screenshots, and gaining control of the device. The dropper uses the legitimate cloud hosting service, Firebase Realtime Database, as a command and control (C2) server to evade detection and fetch the malicious payloads.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Pegasus spyware was developed by the Israeli cyber firm NSO Group. This tool can be covertly installed on mobile phones (and other devices) running most versions of iOS and Android.

Pegasus was discovered in August 2018 after a failed attempt of installing it on an iPhone belonging to a human rights activist. It led to an investigation revealing details about the spyware, its abilities, and the security vulnerabilities it exploited. 

Pegasus' iOS exploitation was first identified in August 2016. An Emirati activist named Ahmed Mansoor received a text message promising "secrets" about torture happening in prisons in the United Arab Emirates by following a link. Mansoor sent the link to Citizen Lab, which launched an investigation, with the collaboration with mobile security company Lookout.

As of 2016, Pegasus could read text messages, track calls, collect passwords, track location, access the target device's microphone and camera, and harvest information from apps. News of the spyware generated significant media coverage. It was called the "most sophisticated" smartphone attack ever and was the first time that a malicious remote exploit using jailbreak to gain unrestricted access to an iPhone had been detected.
content.AdditionalInformation:
On August 23, 2020, according to intelligence obtained by the Israeli newspaper Haaretz, the NSO Group was reported to have sold Pegasus spyware software for hundreds of millions of US dollars to the United Arab Emirates and the other Gulf States, for surveillance of anti-regime activists, journalists, and political leaders from rival nations.

In July 2021, widespread media coverage of the Project Pegasus revelations and in-depth analysis by human rights group Amnesty International uncovered that Pegasus was still being widely exploited against high-profile targets. It showed that Pegasus was able to infect all modern iOS versions up to the latest release, iOS 14.6, through a zero-click iMessage exploit.

In an article published by The Washington Post On July 18th, 2021, it was reported that Pegasus was used in attempted and successful hacks of 37 smartphones belonging to journalists, human rights activists, business executives, and two women close to murdered Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, according to an investigation by The Washington Post and 16 media partners.

The phones appeared on a list of more than 50,000 numbers that are concentrated in countries known to engage in surveillance of their citizens. The numbers on the list are unattributed, but reporters were able to identify more than 1,000 people spanning more than 50 countries through research and interviews on four continents: several Arab royal family members, at least 65 business executives, 85 human rights activists, 189 journalists, and more than 600 politicians and government officials ‚Äî including cabinet ministers, diplomats, and military and security officers. The numbers of several heads of state and prime ministers also appeared on the list. Among the journalists whose numbers appear on the list, which dates to 2016, are reporters working overseas for several leading news organizations, including a small number from CNN, the Associated Press, Voice of America, the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, Bloomberg News, Le Monde in France, the Financial Times in London and Al Jazeera in Qatar.

The NSO chief executive Shalev Hulio expressed concern in a phone interview with The Washington Post reporters about some of the details that were reported in this case, while continuing to dispute that the list of more than 50,000 phone numbers had anything to do with NSO or Pegasus. ‚ÄúThe company cares about journalists and activists and civil society in general,‚Äù Hulio said. ‚ÄúWe understand that in some circumstances our customers might misuse the system and, in some cases like we reported in [NSO‚Äôs] Transparency and Responsibility Report, we have shut down systems for customers who have misused the system.‚Äù He said that in the past 12 months NSO had terminated two contracts over allegations of human rights abuses, but he declined to name the countries involved. In addition, Hulio said that they are investigating every allegation.

Also in July 2021, Amnesty International Security Lab and additional partners published a list of IOCs related to the Pegasus spyware:
https://github.com/AmnestyTech/investigations/tree/master/2021-07-18_nso

In addition, The Amnesty International Security Lab has also released an open-source tool, the Mobile Verification Toolkit (MVT). MVT can be used with the pegasus.stix2 indicators to check a device for potential signs of compromise with Pegasus spyware: https://github.com/mvt-project/mvt

In October 2021, it was reported that the phone of New York Times journalist Ben Hubbard was repeatedly hacked by Pegasus between June 2018 to June 2021, as he was reporting on Saudi Arabia. It was believed that the NSO Group leveraged at least three different iOS exploits: an iMessage zero-click exploit in December 2019, a KISMET exploit targeting iOS 13.5.1 and iOS 13.7 starting July 2020, and a FORCEDENTRY exploit aimed at iOS 14.x until 14.7.1, since February 2021. NSO denied any involvement in the alleged breach.

In November 2021, the United States Commerce Department added four surveillanceware companies, including NSO Group, to the Entity List for engaging in "malicious cyber activities." This decision practically imposed trade restrictions on NSO and mandated U.S. organizations to acquire a special license from the government to conduct business with the company.  

In the same month, Apple sued NSO Group and its parent company Q Cyber Technologies for spying on iPhone users with Pegasus. The lawsuit also aimed to prevent NSO from breaking into any Apple software, services, or devices. 

In December 2021, it was reported that Apple notified 11 U.S. Embassy officials and State Department employees that their iPhones might have been infected with Pegasus. The officials were stationed in Uganda or focused on issues relating to the country.

 In January 2022, Finland's Ministry for Foreign Affairs announced that the devices of Finnish diplomats were hacked and infected with Pegasus. The malware infected both Apple and Android and might have been used to steal sensitive data.

In April 2022, Reuters reported that at least five senior officials in the European Union, including European Justice Commissioner Didier Reynders, were infected with Pegasus. NSO Group denied the claims and stated that the targeting "could not have happened with NSO's tools."

In June 2022, NSO Group admitted to the European Union lawmakers that Pegasus was used by at least five countries in the region. The statement was made after a special inquiry committee was launched in April 2022 to investigate the accusations claiming that Pegasus was used to spy on European politicians, diplomats, and civil society members.

On July 17, 2022, Citizen Lab researchers reported that between October 2020 and November 2021 Pegasus was used to target at least 30 pro-democracy activists, academics, lawyers, and NGO workers in Thailand. The malware was distributed by leveraging two zero-click exploits, KISMET and FORCEDENTRY. 

On July 27, 2022, the U.S. House Intelligence Committee held a hearing to discuss Pegasus and its implications for national policy. The House stressed the dangers of spyware to democracies around the world and was bound to pass legislation regulating the spyware industry.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Mars Stealer malware was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in May 2021, after it was put for sale on underground hacking forums. The infostealer, which is promoted at the price range of $140-$160, is a redesign of the Oski malware.

Mars Stealer, written in ASM/C, is distributed through malspam campaigns spreading malicious macro-embedded documents, or social engineering techniques luring victims into downloading seemingly legitimate software, cracks, or keygens containing the malware. Once deployed, the Mars Stealer initiates security evasion routines to hide its WinAPI calls and uses the Sleep() function to disrupt debugging attempts. The malware also features string encryption techniques using a combination of RC4 and Base64 and its command and control (C2) connections are encrypted with the SSL protocol.

Mars Stealer retrieves its configuration from the C2 server and starts harvesting various types of data, such as general system information (e.g. IP address, geolocation, and timezone), user credentials, web browser information (e.g. autofill and extension data), credit card data, and cryptocurrency information. In addition, it uses the ‚Äúgrabber‚Äù function to steal private keys from two-factor authentication plugins. The Mars Stealer can also be used as a loader for other malware. At the end of the data gathering process, the stolen data is packed in a ZIP file and exfiltrated to the C2 server. Then, the malware deletes itself to cover its tracks.

While the identity of the Mars Stealer developers is unknown, they are assumed to be Russian or Russian speakers. This is strengthened by the fact that the infostealer checks the language of the compromised operating system and aborts if it is one of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) languages: Russian, Ukrainian, Kazakh, Kyrgyz, Armenian, Tajik, and Uzbek.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In March 2022, the Mars Stealer was reported to spread through Google Ads for fake OpenOffice websites. The malware operator targeted Canadian users, including a healthcare infrastructure provider, and several high-profile service companies in Canada. The users were exhorted to download OpenOffice installers that contained Mars Stealer executables packed with the Babadeda crypter or the Autoit loader. The security researchers who investigated the campaign attributed it to a Russian-speaking threat actor and discovered his GitLab account, operated under the name ‚ÄúTony Mont.‚Äù The researchers also revealed that the malware operator used stolen information to pay for the Google Ads and elevate their page rank.

In August 2022, the Mars Stealer was observed to be distributed through a fake website impersonating the portal of Atomic Wallet, a popular decentralized wallet and cryptocurrency exchange platform. The fake website contained a button for downloading the Atomic Wallet app, but instead downloaded a malicious ZIP archive. The ZIP contained a batch file executing a PowerShell command that led to the deployment of Mars Stealer, hosted on a Discord server.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Manjusaka attack framework was first reported by Cisco Talos researchers in August 2022. The post-exploitation tool, likely developed in China, was observed in attacks against entities in the Haixi Mongol and Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture. 

Manjusaka ("cow flower" in Simplified Chinese), written in Rust, is deployed alongside Cobalt Strike using macro-embedded documents, likely spread through phishing messages. Once deployed, Manjusaka connects to a command and control (C2) server and can execute arbitrary commands, harvest web browser credentials from Chromium-based browsers, gather Wi-Fi SSID information, collect general system information (e.g. network account names and processor power information), and take screenshots of the desktop. It can also activate a file management module to enumerate files, create and delete files and directories, read and write file data, and move files between locations. Manjusaka‚Äôs C2 binaries can be either EXE files (for Windows systems) or Golang-based ELF files (for Linux systems).   

Manjusaka has a user interface in Simplified Chinese on GitHub that enables users to generate new implants with custom configurations with ease. This is expected to make this attack framework popular among threat actors, who might use it alongside other hacking tools, such as Sliver and Cobalt Strike.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Woody RAT malware was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in August 2022. The malware was observed targeting a Russian aerospace and defense organization.

Woody RAT is distributed using spear phishing email messages containing either ZIP archives with malicious executables or Microsoft Office documents exploiting the Follina zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2022-30190). Once deployed, the malware connects to a remote command and control (C2) server using encrypted communication (RSA-4096 and AES-CBC) and executes commands, such as listing directories and running processes, downloading, uploading, and deleting files, and taking screenshots. In addition, Woody RAT is embedded with two .NET-based DLL files, WoodySharpExecutor and WoodyPowerSession, that enable it to execute .NET codes and PowerShell commands. To evade detection, the malware uses the process hollowing technique and injects itself into a suspended notepad process. Then, it deletes itself from the disk to cover its tracks.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The GwisinLocker ransomware group was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in July 2022. The group primarily targets industrial, pharmaceutical, and healthcare organizations in South Korea. GwisinLocker was developed by a Korean-speaking threat actor, Gwisin (‚Äúghost‚Äù or ‚Äúspirit‚Äù in Korean). 

GwisinLocker attacks both Windows and Linux environments. The ransomware is not operated automatically and requires command line arguments to be executed. For Windows operating systems, GwisinLocker gains initial access through an MSI installer file that loads an embedded DLL into a Windows process to evade antivirus detection. One of these arguments supports the operation of the ransomware in safe mode. For Linux operating systems, the encryption process usually takes place on VMware ESXi virtual machines. The GwisinLocker operators use command line arguments to terminate VM processes and several Linux daemons before initiating encryption using AES symmetric-key encryption with SHA256 hashing. The ransomware skips specific directories (e.g. ‚Äúbin,‚Äù ‚Äúboot‚Äù, and ‚Äúsys‚Äù) and VMware ESXi-related files (e.g. state.tgz, useropts.gz, and jumpstrt.gz) to avoid making the Linux server unusable.

Upon encryption, GwisinLocker appends the files with either the .mcrgnx extension or a unique extension that carries the targeted company‚Äôs name. In addition, the desktop wallpaper changes to include an encryption notification, and a ransom note named ‚Äú!!!_HOW_TO_UNLOCK_[company_name]_FILES_!!!.TXT‚Äù is dropped. The ransom note is customized for each victim and contains the victim's name, the data that was stolen, and a dedicated Tor address for contacting the threat actors, along with a warning not to report the case to law enforcement or government agencies (e.g. the Korea Internet & Security Agency - KISA).
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Bitter threat group (AKA Hazy Tiger, APT-C-08, Manlinghua) has been active since at least 2013. This South Asian APT group primarily targets energy, engineering, and government organizations, in countries such as China, Pakistan, and Saudi Arabia.

Bitter usually gains initial system access through spear phishing email messages that impersonate government entities or legitimate organizations, or through strategic web compromises. In each of these methods, the threat actors exhort their victims either to download a RAR archive that contains a Microsoft Office document (RTF or XLXS) that exploits remote code execution vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2017-11882 and CVE-2021-1732), or to trigger malicious Android applications. Bitter was observed using the ArtraDownloader malware for its Windows campaigns and variations of AndroRAT for its Android campaigns. These variations include a custom malware, BitterRAT (AKA SlideRAT), that was also observed being used by other South Asian APT groups, such as Patchwork. BitterRAT can gather sensitive information and send it over HTTP POST requests to a remote command and control (C2) server.

Bitter was linked to other threat groups, such as Confucius, Patchwork, and Bahamut, through its used infrastructure and malicious arsenal; however, no solid connection could be established between the groups.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In May 2022, Cisco Talos reported that Bitter initiated a new campaign against the government of Bangladesh. The threat actors used spear phishing email messages with documents that exploited known vulnerabilities to deploy a novel Trojan named ZxxZ. The malware, compiled in Visual C++, featured anti-detection mechanisms and terminated antivirus processes. It was used to collect general system information, such as the victim's hostname, username, and operating system, and exfiltrate it to a remote C2 server.

In a follow-up report that was published by SECUINFRA in July 2022, the security researchers added that during its latest campaign in Bangladesh, Bitter used different types of malware, such as keyloggers, infostealers, and RATs, including the newly observed Almond RAT. Almond RAT, written in .NET, could be used to collect and exfiltrate data, execute arbitrary commands, load additional tools, and to establish persistence. The malware was observed using string encryption techniques to evade detection and reverse engineering.

In August 2022, Meta (formerly Facebook) announced that it took action against Bitter to block the group's activity and domain infrastructure. Bitter was reported to use social engineering techniques, creating fake online personas of attractive young women, journalists, or activists, to trick victims into clicking on malicious links or downloading malware. On some occasions, the threat actors posted broken links or images of malicious links so users would have to type them into their browser rather than click on them. In addition, Bitter tried to convince users to download a chat application for iOS through Apple‚Äôs Testflight service for developers, that either contained malicious code or was used for further social engineering attempts. The group also used a new Android malware dubbed Dracarys that was injected into Trojanized applications impersonating YouTube, Signal, Telegram, WhatsApp, and other legitimate services. Once installed, the malware could be used to access the device's stored files, call logs, contact list, text messages, microphone, and geolocation, take photos, and install new apps.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The TAC-040 threat group was first reported by Deepwatch researchers in August 2022. At the end of May 2022, the group was observed targeting a non-profit organization in the research and technical services sector.

TAC-040 gains initial access by exploiting system vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2022-26134 in Atlassian Confluence or CVE-2022-22965 in the Spring framework) and runs various commands to collect information about the local system, network, and Active Directory environment. In addition, TAC-040 uses the open-source tool, NBTscan, to scan internal IP addresses for NetBIOS name information. To achieve persistence, the threat actors create the VBoxxSDS service that runs the executable DrSDKcaller.exe; however, its exact functionality is unknown. Then, the threat actors deploy their malware, including the XMRig cryptominer and a novel Ljl backdoor that can run a reverse proxy, exfiltrate files and directories, collect general system information (e.g. CPU name, physical memory, and LAN IP address), get the victim‚Äôs geolocation data, and load arbitrary .NET assemblies.

TAC-040‚Äôs activity is most likely aimed at cyberespionage, but can also be financially-motivated.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Other tools that were used by the group and were cloned from GitHub include: NetRipper, PowerSploit, Invoke-Vnc, CME-PowerShell-Scripts, CrackMapExec, Invoke-Obfuscation, SessionGopher, mimipenguin, mimikittenz, RID_Hijacking, and RandomPS-Scripts.

MITRE ATT&CK¬Æ TTPs:

T1583.003 - Acquire Infrastructure: Virtual Private Server
T1588.006 - Obtain Capabilities: Vulnerabilities
T1588.002 - Obtain Capabilities: Tool
T1587.001 - Develop Capabilities: Malware
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery
T1119 - Automated Collection
T1560.001 - Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
T1110.003 - Brute Force: Password Spraying
T1543.003 - Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service
T1558.003 - Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets: Kerberoasting
T1558.004 - Steal or Forge Kerberos Tickets: AS-REP Roasting
T1567 - Exfiltration OverWeb Service

content.Overview:
The Classiscam cybercrime operation has been ongoing since at least 2019. The scam-as-a-service affiliate program is aimed at stealing payment and personal data from users of known web marketplaces and classifieds through phishing schemes. Classiscam has been run by dozens of cybergangs, mostly of Russian origin, targeting the United States, the Middle East, Central Asia, and different European countries, such as France, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Poland, and Romania. 

The Classiscam fraudsters can pose as both buyers and sellers. When acting as sellers, the threat actors publish advertisements on popular marketplaces and classifieds (e.g. Leboncoin, Allegro, OLX, FAN Courier, and Sbazar) promoting products at low prices. If the victims contact the fraudulent seller, they are encouraged to continue the conversation over a third-party messaging service, such as WhatsApp or Telegram, where they are asked for personal details (e.g. full name, address, and phone number). For Telegram communication, the scammers use Telegram bots for automated conversations. Then, the scammers employ a phishing kit for sending links to a fake popular courier service website (e.g. DHL or FedEx) or a fraudulent website impersonating a classified or a marketplace with a payment form. The victims enter their payment details which are directly transferred to the scammer. Sometimes, the victims are scammed twice when they are tricked by ‚Äútech supporters‚Äù into requesting a refund, but instead of being credited, they are getting charged again by the threat actors. 

When acting as buyers, the scammers contact random marketplace or classified sellers and use automated Telegram bots to generate a phishing page with the real name, photograph, and price of the goods. The phishing page includes a payment form asking for the seller‚Äôs bank card details in order to receive the payment. 

The Classiscam affiliate program consists of three primary elements: workers, communicating with the victims and sending the phishing URLs (earning 70-80% of the stolen sum); admins, responsible for recruiting new members, creating scam pages, establishing new accounts, and providing assistance in case of any payment issues (earning 20-30% of the stolen sum); and callers, pretending to be tech support specialists (earning 5-10% of the stolen sum). 

By the end of 2020, more than 5,000 scammers were registered to the Classiscam program on dedicated Telegram channels. It was estimated that each Classiscam cybergang earns around $61,000 per month, with around $522,000 for all the groups in total. One cybergang, Dreamer Money Gang (DMG), was observed earning around $3,000 a day. 

In August 2022, it was reported that the Classiscam operation has expanded to Singapore since March 2022. The attack infrastructure comprised over 200 phishing domains, out of which 18 were specifically created to target Singaporean classified users. Other fake websites impersonated marketplaces, banks, food and crypto brands, and delivery companies, in Europe, Asia, and the Middle East.
content.AdditionalInformation:
The following mitigation measures are recommended to avoid getting scammed: 
- Check the URL requesting payment details, especially when it is received through a messaging platform. If the URL only exists for a short time, it is most probably a scam. 
- Keep all seller communication in the official chat of the used platform, never moving to a third-party messaging service. 
- Do not agree to prepaid transactions; only pay after the goods are received or there is reliable evidence of shipment. 
- Be suspicious of unreasonable discounts and low prices.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Orchard botnet, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in August 2022, has been active since at least February 2021. There is little information about the botnet‚Äôs specific targets. 

Orchard, written in C++ (with one version also combining Golang code snippets), is injected through the Windows StartUp directory to the System32 folder using process hollowing and is propagated by infecting USB devices. Once deployed, the botnet connects to a command and control (C2) server, receiving commands and exfiltrating device and user information (e.g. CPU data, computer name, RAM size, number of processors, and antivirus information). Orchard can also be used to launch the XMRig cryptominer and download additional malicious payloads to the victim‚Äôs machine. To evade detection, the botnet uses the information found in the Bitcoin Genesis Block (believed to belong to the Bitcoin founder, Satoshi Nakamoto) to generate domain names through a domain generation algorithm (DGA). In addition to DGA, Orchard contains hardcoded DuckDNS dynamic domain names as C2 infrastructure.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The PennyWise information-stealing malware was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in May 2022. The malware targets users indiscriminately through YouTube. 

PennyWise spreads through videos promoting free Bitcoin mining software, which is in fact malicious. The videos guide the users to links to download the software that is often embedded in the video description. The links lead the users to cloud storage and file hosting services (e.g. Mega, Mediafire, OneDrive, Discord, and GitHub) where the malware executables are hosted and downloaded to the victims‚Äô computers in the form of password-protected file archives. The hosting websites also contain instructions for disabling the antivirus before downloading the malicious software. 
 
Once deployed, PennyWise is injected into a legitimate .NET binary, AppLaunch.exe, using process hollowing, and then it starts stealing information. The malware can steal web browser data (e.g. login credentials, encryption keys, and cookies), Discord tokens, Telegram sessions, and cryptocurrency information, collect general system information (e.g. username, machine name, and system language), and take screenshots. PennyWise uses multithreading for faster execution and stealing. It only steals files smaller than 20 KB with RTF, DOC, DOCX, TXT, or JSON extensions. The harvested information is packed in a compressed folder and exfiltrated to a remote command and control (C2) server. To evade security mechanisms, the malware runs multiple anti-analysis and anti-detection checks and identifies the presence of antivirus applications and sandbox environments. 

PennyWise converts the system timezone into Russian Standard Time (RST), which may indicate the origin of its operators. In addition, the malware terminates its execution if it detects that the system is located in Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, or Kazakhstan.
content.AdditionalInformation: In August 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported that they discovered over 5,000 PennyWise executable samples during the preceding three months. The malware was observed to be deployed through YouTube videos allegedly guiding users to get paid subscriptions for free, but in fact, tricking them into installing the malicious software.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The TA428 threat group has been active since at least 2013. The Chinese APT group primarily targets government agencies in East Asia and Eastern Europe dealing with government information technology, domestic affairs, foreign affairs, economic development, and political processes. Sometimes TA428‚Äôs campaigns overlap with other Chinese APT threat groups, such as APT27 (AKA LuckyMouse), Tropic Trooper (AKA KeyBoy), and Space Pirates. 

TA428 gained prominence with the 2019 Operation LagTime IT that targeted government organizations in East Asia. The campaign included the sending of spear phishing email messages from both free email accounts and compromised user accounts. The email messages included RTF documents (built using Royal Road) with exploits for Microsoft Equation Editor (CVE-2018-0798) leading to the deployment of different malware, including Cotx RAT, Poison Ivy, Tmanger, and nccTrojan.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In August 2022, Kaspersky researchers linked TA428 to a campaign targeting industrial plants, research institutes, and government agencies, Eastern Europe countries, and Afghanistan. The threat actors sent their victims phishing email messages with Word documents containing exploits for a Microsoft Office vulnerability (CVE-2017-11882). Successful exploitation of the flaw led to the deployment of various malware, such as PortDoor, nccTrojan, Logtu, Cotx, DNSep, and the novel CotSam backdoor. The malware were used to steal sensitive information and system data, later exfiltrated to a command and control (C2) server as encrypted and password-protected ZIP archives. In addition, TA428 used the Ladon hacking utility to move laterally in the compromised networks while conducting system reconnaissance and dumping credentials. Finally, the threat actors hijacked the domain controller to gain full control of the servers. To evade detection, the threat actors used DLL hijacking and process hollowing techniques. 

Other malware that were observed to be used by TA428: SManager, Mail-O, PhantomNet, CoughingDown, Albaniiutas, and PlugX.

content.Overview:
The CopperStealer malware (AKA Mingloa), first reported by Proofpoint researchers in March 2021, has been active since at least July 2019. It seems to be closely related to SilentFade, a Hong Kong-based malware that was first reported by Facebook in 2019. CopperStealer targets users of major service providers (including Apple, Amazon, Bing, Google, PayPal, Tumblr, and Twitter), especially in India, Indonesia, Brazil, Pakistan, and the Philippines. The malware‚Äôs name originates from observed PDB and process memory strings referencing ‚ÄúDavidCopperfield.‚Äù

CopperStealer spreads through malicious websites promoting the download of fake software cracks. The malware‚Äôs binary is encrypted and appended to the downloaded executable, which is overwritten by a shellcode. The shellcode reads the XOR decryption key from the executable and leads to the deployment of a UPX-packed DLL dropper, containing two additional executables, a browser stealer and a remote desktop component. Once deployed, CopperStealer harvests web browser information, including cookies and login credentials. In addition, it steals user data from online messenger platforms, such as Telegram, Discord, and Elements, the Steam game distribution service, and email clients (e.g. Outlook and Thunderbird). The infostealer also retrieves the victims' User Access Token from Facebook, enabling it to gather the account‚Äôs friends list, advertisement information, and a list of Facebook pages with access permissions to the account.

The stolen information is compressed into a password-protected 7-Zip archive and exfiltrated to a dedicated Telegram channel that acts as a command and control (C2) server. CopperStealer‚Äôs C2 infrastructure initially relied on domain generation algorithms (DGA) to randomize its C2 domains and abused the content delivery network (CDN) proxy to conceal the actual IP address of the C2 server; however, newer malware versions seem to use an encrypted configuration of C2 domains, hosted on third-party web pages (e.g. Pastebin), and the fast flux DNS service for switching IP addresses.

CopperStealer‚Äôs remote desktop component supports two tasks, ‚Äúinstall‚Äù and ‚Äúkillme.‚Äù ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù enables the threat actors to add new user accounts to the compromised machine, establishes remote desktop connections, disables firewall and network level authentication (NLA), and more. ‚ÄúKillme‚Äù terminates the running processes, deletes files, and removes the users that were added as part of the ‚Äúinstall‚Äù task. The malware also embeds an anti-analysis mechanism preventing it from running in virtual environments.

In addition to information stealing, CopperStealer can also be used to fetch a download configuration from the C2 server that executes a legitimate download manager called Xunlei. Xunlei might be abused to download the configuration for additional malicious payloads, such as the Smokeloader backdoor.
content.AdditionalInformation: In August 2022, Trend Micro researchers observed CopperStealer being distributed through fake crack websites as a malicious Chrome browser extension, creating and stealing API keys from infected machines when the victim logged into a major cryptocurrency exchange website. The API keys enabled the malicious extension to initiate transactions and send cryptocurrencies from the victims' accounts to attacker-controlled wallets.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Andariel threat group (AKA Silent Chollima, Stonefly) has been active since at least 2009. The North Korean state-sponsored group, considered to be a subgroup of Lazarus, primarily targets South Korean government agencies and military organizations, as well as private organizations in the energy, finance, healthcare, media, and technology sectors. Andariel also targets other countries, such as the United States, Canada, Russia, China, Japan, India, Brazil, Germany, and Israel. The group‚Äôs targeting seems to reflect the national interests of the North Korean government. Andariel mostly focuses on cyberespionage, but since around 2015, has put more emphasis on financial-oriented campaigns targeting ATMs, banks, cryptocurrency exchanges, and online gambling websites. 

Andariel gains initial access through various methods, including spear phishing email messages with macro-embedded documents, watering hole attacks exploiting Active-X vulnerabilities, vulnerability exploits on security and IT asset management systems, and supply chain attacks. All of these methods eventually lead to the deployment of common backdoors such as Aryan and Gh0st RAT, as well as custom backdoors such as Andarat, Andaratm, Rifdoor, and Phandoor. In addition, Andariel uses destructive malware (e.g. Crash.exe and Test.exe) to destroy hard disk contents and utility tools like Putty Link and port scanner for communication and reconnaissance purposes. 

Andariel was linked to several high-profile campaigns, including Operation Black Mine, that ran between May 2014 and June 2015 and targeted South Korean organizations in the energy, transportation, telecommunications, broadcasting, IT companies, finance, and political sectors. The threat actors distributed the Bmdoor malware, whose executables were disguised as work-related files, graduation albums, and invitations to alumni associations. In addition, the group hacked domestic websites distributing malware to the general public. 
 
The South Korea Financial Security Institute linked Andariel to a series of cyber campaigns referred to as the ‚ÄúCampaign Rifle‚Äù that were initiated between 2015 and the first half of 2017, targeting financial institutes, national defense organizations, large corporations, security companies, and others. The attacks, which included spear phishing, source code and code signing certificate theft, and the exfiltration of confidential documents, shared similar characteristics with the 2013 DarkSeoul campaigns targeting media, finance, and ISP companies. 
 
Another high-profile campaign that was associated with Andariel was Operation GoldenAxe, running from June 2016 to May 2017 and targeting South Korean websites related to diplomacy, space aviation, labor, finance, and the unification with North Korea. The threat actors used watering hole techniques to spread malicious codes exploiting ActiveX vulnerabilities, in order to infiltrate systems and destroy hard disks.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In September 2019, the United States Department of the Treasury‚Äôs Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) proposed sanctions against three North Korean state-sponsored groups that were identified separately as the Lazarus Group, Bluenoroff, and Andariel. The sanctions included the confiscation of all properties and financial assets owned by the three groups in the United States and a prohibition of all dealings involving these properties and assets. In addition, the US government prohibited facilitating a significant transaction or providing financial services for any of the entities. 

In June 2021, Kaspersky researchers reported that Andariel initiated a campaign against South Korean entities in the manufacturing, home network service, media, and construction sectors. The threat actors used spear phishing messages with weaponized documents to distribute backdoors and a custom ransomware encrypting files to exhort the victims paying a Bitcoin ransom. 
 
In August 2022, the Maui ransomware operation was linked to Andariel with low to medium confidence. The link was made through an observed attack in April 2022 against a Japanese housing company. The attack also included the use of a DTrack malware variant and the 3Proxy server utility that was previously observed in various Andariel campaigns.

content.Overview:
The S.O.V.A. Android banking Trojan was first reported by Amsterdam-based cybersecurity researchers in early August 2021, after it was observed on a Russian cybercrime forum in mid-July 2021 by a threat actor named "sovenok". "Sova," means "owl" in Russian, which might indicate the malware origin, although the malware targets several Russian banks, and "sovenok" was even criticized by other forum members for that.

S.O.V.A., which was developed from scratch, is written in Kotlin programming language and relies on RetroFit (a legitimate open-source project) for its communication with the command-and-control (C2) server. According to the threat actor, the malware was designed to be the most spotlighted and advanced Android Banking Trojan with new features (e.g. DDoS, man-in-the-middle attacks, two-factor authentication codes interception, and ransomware) to be released in the future, in addition to the existing features, including credential stealing, overlay attacks, keylogging, notification manipulation, and session cookies theft. In its current state, the malware appears as a collection of banking, cryptocurrency wallet, and shopping applications from the U.S. and Spain, but can be customized based on the buyer‚Äôs specifications and requests.
content.AdditionalInformation: In August 2022, Cleafy researchers reported a new S.O.V.A. version (v4), active since May 2022, targeting more than 200 mobile applications, including banking apps and crypto wallets. The new malware version demonstrated an improved cookie stealing mechanism targeting a broad list of Google services (e.g. Gmail, GPay, and Google Password Manager) and other applications. In addition, the malware was added the ability to take screenshots, execute commands (e.g. screen click, swipe, and copy/paste), and prevent the uninstallation of the malicious app. Although the list of targeted apps was expanded, some malware samples removed the targeting of Russian and Ukraine apps. The cybersecurity researchers also detected an even newer S.O.V.A. version (v5), still under development, with ransomware capabilities.

content.Overview:
The Conti ransomware group, first discovered in June 2020, has been active since December 2019. The group mainly targets corporate networks. The ransomware was first seen distributed in isolated attacks at the end of December 2019. Over time, attacks slowly increased, until the end of June, when there was a sharp increase in the affected victims.

Security researchers suspect that this ransomware shares the same malware code as Ryuk ransomware (version 2 of Ryuk). In addition to similarities in the malware code, the Conti ransom note uses the same template as Ryuk‚Äôs ransom note. Moreover, a security researcher has seen the same TrickBot infrastructure being used by both Ryuk and the Conti threat actors as part of ransomware attacks.

The Conti operators breach corporate networks and move laterally until they gain domain admin credentials. Once administrative privileges are achieved, the threat actors deploy the ransomware to encrypt drives and installed devices.

The group follows the "double extortion" approach, of not only encrypting the victims' files, but also stealing them and threatening to publish their contents on their leak site in case the ransom demand is not met. Conti encrypts user data using the AES-256 algorithm and then uses the RSA-4096 algorithm to encrypt the AES keys. Its ransom demand is in BTC.

In August 2020, the threat actors behind the Conti ransomware opened a designated leak site, one of the signs of the hybrid attack (aka double extortion). After infiltrating the system, they first steal the data on the compromised system and then encrypt it. If the victims do not pay the ransom demand, the attackers release the stolen data. On its opening day, the site already listed 26 companies that had fallen victim to the group's attacks and have declined to pay the ransom. For each company listed on the site, the group has leaked documents obtained from their networks, as proof of their hack.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In September 2020, Conti operators attacked the Fourth District Court of Louisiana and published proof of the attack on its dark web page.

In January 2021, The Scottish Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) reported that some of its contact centers, internal systems, processes, and internal communications were affected following a ransomware attack that took place on Christmas Eve. SEPA added that after isolating the compromised systems, recovery will probably take "a significant period" and some of the infected SEPA systems will have to be replaced with new ones. While SEPA did not attribute the attack to any specific ransomware operation, the Conti ransomware gang claims the attack and has already published 7% of the stolen data on its leak site. According to SEPA, roughly 1.2 GB of data was exfiltrated during the attack, with evidence showing that at least 4,000 files were probably accessed and stolen. The information stolen by the Conti operators during the attack included business information, such as publicly available regulated site permits, authorizations, and enforcement notices, information related to SEPA corporate plans, priorities, and change programs, procurement information, such as publicly available procurement awards, project information related to commercial work with international partners, and SEPA's staff personal information.

In May 2021, Conti initiated a vast ransomware attack against Ireland's national health services provider (Health Service Executive), encrypting computers and severely disrupting the healthcare services in the country for nearly two months.

In August 2021, cybersecurity researchers reported that Conti leveraged ProxyShell vulnerabilities to hack Microsoft Exchange servers. During this campaign, the threat actor used various tools to achieve remote access to the infected devices, such as Anydesk and Cobalt Strike beacons.

In September 2021, Ireland‚Äôs cybercrime police initiated an operation targeting the IT infrastructure of a threat actor, assumed to be Conti. As part of the operation, the police seized several domains used in the attack performed four months earlier. However, later that month, GSS, the Spanish and Latin America division of Europe's largest call center provider - Covisian, reported on a ransomware attack conducted by Conti that shut down its IT systems and affected call centers across its Spanish-speaking customers. Among other affected services were: Vodafone Spain, the Masmovil ISP, and television stations. In addition, a few days later, Advanced Intelligence researchers reported that the threat actor is developing new methods to destroy backups, specifically the Veaam recovery software. In a campaign conducted in 2021, Conti was observed to install Cobalt Strike beacon backdoor through spam messages, impersonate privileged backup users in order to get Veeam backup privileges, exfiltrate Veeam backups using Rclone, and then manually remove the backups. At the end of that month, JVCKenwood, a Japan-based multinational electronics company, reported another ransomware attack conducted by Conti on September 22nd, targeting the servers of its European sales companies. The threat actor claimed to have stolen 1.5 TB of files and demanded a ransom of seven million dollars.

In October 2021, Sandhills Global, an American information processing company, suffered a ransomware attack attributed to Conti. As a result, the company‚Äôs website, all of their hosted publications, and their phones went offline. It is still unknown whether data was stolen during the attack.

Later that month, it was published that the Conti operators started to sell access to their victims' networks in their shaming blog, where they add organizations that refuse ransom negotiations. In another reported incident that occurred that month, Conti attacked the high society jeweler "Graff," demanding millions as a ransom payment. The threat actor already leaked 69 thousand documents, including customer lists, invoices, receipts, and credit notes, some of which belong to high profile figures, such as David Beckham, Oprah Winfrey, and Donald Trump.

IBM X-Force reported that since July 2021 TA551 (AKA Shatak) partnered with the TrickBot developers to create phishing campaigns and eventually deploy Conti ransomware on targeted systems. The phishing email messages contained malicious attachments with a script that installs either TrickBot or BazarBackdoor. Then, a Cobalt Strike beacon was deployed before dropping the Conti ransomware. The Conti operators then took over to steal credentials, system directory information, and other valuable data before encrypting the files on the victims' networks. The campaigns focused on European countries, such as Germany, Slovakia, and the Netherlands.

In November 2021, researchers observed a new partnership between the Emotet botnet operators and the Conti group. Ryuk, Conti's predecessor, already used Emotet as part of its infrastructure. However, it was reported that Conti is also expected to start delivering its payload via Emotet.

Also in the same month, the Prodaft research team reported on Conti's money operation. The researchers analyzed the group's Bitcoin wallets and reported that between July and November 2021, Conti earned at least 25.5 million dollars in ransom payments. In addition, the research shed light on the Conti affiliates' money-laundering operation. In order to evade law enforcement activity, the threat actors use various services, such as exchanges, coin swaps, privacy enhancing wallets (e.g. Wasabi), and the darknet marketplace Hydra.
The researchers also revealed verified IP addresses used in the group's operations and three Conti recruiters, which are active on hacking forums. They discovered a vulnerability in the recovery servers that Conti uses and leveraged it in order to discover the real IP addresses of the hosting provider of the group‚Äôs recovery website. This turned out to be the Ukrainian web hosting company ITL LLC.

On December 7, 2021, the Norwegian Nordic Choice Hotels confirmed that they were breached by Conti. The incident disrupted the hotel's guest reservation and room key card systems. In addition, some of the guests' booking information may have been leaked, including their names, email addresses, telephone numbers, and any other information the guests may have provided. To date the ransomware operators have not published a ransom demand, however the hotel chain representatives already stated they will not negotiate with them.

On December 10, 2021, the Australian Cyber Security Centre (ACSC) published a report warning against the Conti group, after it attacked multiple Australian organizations from various sectors during November and December 2021. The ACSC mentioned that TrickBot and Cobalt Strike were deployed upon the victims' networks before the Conti ransomware strain. The report was published following the attack against the Australian electricity provider CS Energy at the end of November.

On December 12, 2021, Conti breached ‚Äãthe McMenamins restaurant and hotel chain. The group encrypted servers and workstations, causing the company to shut down its IT systems, credit card point-of-sale systems, and corporate email. The company stated that it is possible that employee data was leaked, such as names, addresses, email addresses, telephone numbers, dates of birth, SSNs, and bank account information. It is uncertain whether customer information was also compromised.

On December 17, 2021, it was reported that Conti started to leverage the critical Log4Shell vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228), in order to get initial access to internal VMware vCenter servers and encrypt virtual machines. This attack vector is different from the group's usual infiltration method, which is phishing email messages.

The compromise of VMware vCenter servers adds to the existing Conti attack chain, which includes the use of Emotet and Cobalt Strike to gain system access and establish persistence, and Kerberoasting and brute-forcing to acquire user credentials and elevate admin privileges.

On December 27, 2021, it was reported that Shutterfly suffered a Conti ransomware attack that occurred two weeks earlier. The group claimed to encrypt over 4,000 devices and 120 VMware ESXi servers, demanding millions of dollars as a ransom payment. Some of the stolen data were uploaded to Conti's leak site, including legal agreements, bank and merchant account info, and user credentials. It was also suspected that customer information was leaked, including credit card information, but the company denied storing this kind of data. In addition, Conti claimed that they acquired the source code for Shutterfly's store. Shutterfly confirmed the breach and stated that it disrupted their services and the services of some of their brands, such as Lifetouch and Groovebook.

On January 19, 2022, RR Donnelly (RRD) confirmed that they were breached by Conti a month earlier. The company representatives stated that they were forced to shut down their network to prevent the attack from spreading, which caused some disruptions among customers. The threat actors leaked 2.5 GB of stolen company data and published it on their leak site, however soon removed it. It was not disclosed what was the ransom demand and whether the company agreed to it.

On January 20, 2022, Bank Indonesia (BI) admitted that it suffered a ransomware attack in December, in which data of employees was stolen. Although the bank did not attribute the attack to any specific threat actor, the Conti operators claimed responsibility, uploading some of the stolen files to their leak site. The threat actors threatened to leak 13.88 GB of documents in case the bank does not pay the ransom. The bank representatives stated that the attack was stopped before affecting its public services and that the stolen data was not critical.

On January 27, 2022, it was reported that Conti attacked Delta Electronics, a Taiwanese electronics company and a contractor for Apple, Tesla, HP, and Dell. The company that disclosed the attack five days earlier, stated that it had no significant impact on its operations, although the company's website was still down one week after the attack. The Conti operators claimed that they encrypted 1,500 servers and 12,000 computers on Delta Electronics' network and demanded a 15 million dollar ransom. The group was reported to leverage Cobalt Strike with Atera for achieving network persistence.

On February 2, 2022, KP Snacks, the British food producer, disclosed a ransomware attack that was attributed to Conti. The attack impacted the company‚Äôs operations and caused delays and cancellations in product deliveries to supermarkets. The threat actors uploaded samples of stolen data, including credit card statements, birth certificates, employee addresses and phone numbers, confidential agreements, and other sensitive documents.

On February 16, 2022, AdvIntel researchers reported that Conti completely took over the operation of the TrickBot malware, and plans to permanently replace it with the more advanced and stealthy BazarBackdoor.

On February 21, 2022, the Meyer Corporation informed the U.S. Attorney General Office of a data breach that took place at the end of October 2021, and was later revealed to be conducted by Conti. The threat actors gained access to the personal information of employees, including names, physical addresses, SSNs, medical records, ID and passport numbers, and driver's licenses. Conti published 2% of the allegedly stolen data on November 7, 2021, however, did not publish the remaining 98%. The reason may be the start of ransom negotiations with the company or just loss of interest.

On February 25, 2022, Conti announced its support for the Russian government's attack on Ukraine. In addition, the threat actors threatened to attack the critical infrastructure of countries acting against Russia. In response, a Ukrainian security researcher leaked over 60,000 internal messages belonging to the Conti ransomware operation. The messages included information about the shutdown of the TrickBot operation, conversations about the Diavol ransomware operation, and 239 bitcoin addresses containing $13 million in payments. The leaks were dubbed in the cyber community "Conti Leaks."

On March 1, 2022, other details involving the Conti operation were leaked, including the source code for Conti Locker v2 and a decryptor that only works on older victims. In addition, the leak included other group members' chats and training materials mentioning hacking tools, such as Cobalt Strike, Metasploit, AnyDesk, and Mimikatz, and the following TTPs:
- Active Directory Enumeration.
- SQL Databases Enumeration via sqlcmd.
- How to gain access to Shadow Protect SPX (StorageCraft) backups.
- How to create NTDS dumps vs vssadmin.
- How to open New RDP Port 1350.

On March 9, 2022, CISA published an alert about Conti, and provided indicators of compromise (IoCs) including approximately 100 domain names that are used by the group (added to this term). The agency mentioned that Conti has attacked more than 1,000 organizations around the world, primarily using Cobalt Strike and Trickbot as part of its attack vector.

On March 11, 2022, Check Point researchers provided additional details about Conti's internal operations. They mentioned that Conti is structured like a high-tech company, with arranged management, finance, and HR functions. In addition, the group hires people from legitimate sources, with some of them not even knowing that they are part of the Conti operation. The group has physical offices in Russia and other locations, headed by an entity named Stern. The researchers also revealed chatters discussing Conti's future plans to create a private crypto exchange system and establish a darknet social network.

On March 20, 2022, the Conti Leaks continued with the publishing of the source code for Conti version 3. The source code was released in a Visual Studio file, enabling any user with access to compile the ransomware locker and decryptor.

On April 7, 2022, the American automotive tools manufacturer Snap-on confirmed that it suffered a data breach at the beginning of March 2022, later claimed by Conti. The threat actors started to leak files out of the 1 GB of data that was allegedly stolen from the company, including personal employee data. However, they quickly removed the data leak, which may indicate that the company paid the ransom.

On April 14, 2022, Conti claimed responsibility for the attack against Nordex Group, one of the world‚Äôs largest manufacturers of wind turbines. The company confirmed that it was hit by a cyberattack, forcing it to shut down IT systems across multiple locations and business units. Although Conti opened an entry for Nordex on its leak site, it has not yet leaked any data, indicating that the company may be negotiating with the threat actors or that no data was stolen in the attack.

On April 15, 2022, researchers from different cybersecurity vendors established a link between the Karakurt extortion group and Conti. The researchers gained access to an internal Conti VPS server and discovered that the groups share the same infrastructure and victims. In addition, it was found that Karakurt transferred payments from victims to cryptocurrency wallets controlled by Conti.

On May 6, 2022, the United States Department of State published a statement in which it offered rewards of up to $10,000,000 for information about Conti‚Äôs leaders and up to $5,000,000 for information about any member of the Conti operation. The rewards were offered as part of the Department of State's Transnational Organized Crime Rewards Program (TOCRP) aiming to ‚Äúdisrupt and dismantle transnational organized crime globally, including cybercrime.‚Äù

On May 7, 2022, Conti announced that it breached the Peru MOF ‚Äì Direcci√≥n General de Inteligencia (DIGIMIN), the premier intelligence agency in Peru. The group claimed to steal 9.41 GB of data and published it on its leak site.

On May 8, 2022, Costa Rica declared a national emergency after Conti attacked different government entities, such as the Costa Rican Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Labor and Social Security, and the Ministry of Science, Innovation, Technology, and Telecommunications. The threat actors claimed to steal 672 GB of data, which they leaked following the government's refusal to pay the ransom. Conti even threatened to "overthrow" the new government of the country. The group raised its ransom demand to $20 million and stated it will delete the decryption keys in a week if the ransom demands are not met. The attack against the Costa Rican government was attributed to an affiliate actor dubbed "UNC1756."

On May 13, 2022, the Parker-Hannifin Corporation confirmed that it was breached by Conti two months earlier. The threat actors gained unauthorized access to Parker's computer systems and stole employees' personal information, including names, SSNs, addresses, driver's license numbers, passport numbers, financial information, user credentials, and health insurance details. Conti already leaked the stolen data (419 GB), which may indicate that the ransom negotiations with the company had failed.

On May 19, 2022, it was reported that Conti shut down its operation, taking some of its infrastructure offline. While the group's leak site remained active, the Tor admin panels that were used for ransom negotiations were taken down, as well as other internal services. It was assumed that the Conti members migrated to smaller ransomware operations, including semi-autonomous groups, loyal to Conti, such as ALPHV (AKA BlackCat), Hive, and AvosLocker, and autonomous data exfiltration groups, such as Karakurt, BlackBasta, and BlackByte. All were reported to be part of the Conti cybercrime syndicate that no longer operates under the Conti name. In addition, cybersecurity researchers assumed that the reported "war" between Conti and the Costa Rican government was only a facade of a live operation to obscure the slow migration of the group's members to other threat groups.

On June 2, 2022, cybersecurity researchers, investigating the leaked Conti chats, reported that members of Conti actively developed firmware hacks.
