Specifically, Conti created a proof-of-concept (PoC) code that leveraged Intel‚Äôs Management Engine (ME) to overwrite the flash memory hosting UEFI/BIOS firmware and gain System Management Mode (SMM) execution with the highest possible system privileges while evading all the available security mechanisms.

On June 22, 2022, it was reported that Conti shut down its two last Tor servers that were used to leak victims' data, presumably putting an end to the operations bearing its name.

On June 23, 2022, Group-IB researchers reported on a Conti campaign, dubbed ARMattack, that took place between November 17 and December 20, 2021. In the course of the campaign, the group compromised more than 40 organizations from multiple sectors around the world (primarily in the United States), encrypting their files and stealing sensitive documents. It was not disclosed whether any of the victims paid the ransom demands.

On August 10, 2022, AdvIntel researchers reported three groups that split from Conti and use BazaCall phishing attacks (AKA BazarCall) primarily targeting the finance, technology, legal, and insurance sectors. The groups, Silent Ransom (AKA Luna Moth), Quantum, and Roy/Zeon, used call-back phishing as an initial access vector to breach targeted networks. The threat actors sent their victims email messages with a phone number for canceling some subscriptions; however, once the victims called the number they were tricked into granting the attackers remote desktop control.  

On August 11, 2022, the United States State Department announced up to $10 million for information regarding five high-ranking Conti members, nicknamed "Target" (office manager and team leader for Ryuk/Conti), "Tramp" (the owner/leader of BlackBasta), "Dandis," "Professor," and "Reshaev." The US government also published a picture of the Conti associate known as "Target."


Disclaimer: on the IOCs section are detailed domains and IP addresses that security researchers related to Conti's activity. Most of them seem suspicious, but they are not verified to have malicious intentions. We advise you to use these IOCs with caution and verify them before adding them to your block-list. Among these domains may be legitimate domains, which will cause false-positive on your organization‚Äôs network.

content.Overview:
The RedAlpha threat group (AKA DeepCliff, Red Dev 3) has been active since at least 2015. The Chinese, likely to be state-sponsored, cyberespionage group primarily targets humanitarian agencies, think tanks, social movements, media groups, and government organizations belonging to Chinese ethnic and religious minorities (e.g. Tibetans, Uyghurs, and Falun Gong) in China and abroad. In addition, RedAlpha targets defense and government organizations in South and Southeast Asia, in countries such as Taiwan, India, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, and Thailand.

RedAlpha usually compromises victims through phishing email messages containing PDF files with malicious links leading to credential harvesting domains. The group uses hundreds of different domains impersonating major email clients (e.g. Yahoo, Outlook, and Zimbra), cloud service providers (e.g. Google and Microsoft), and known government, media, and humanitarian organizations and think tanks, such as the International Federation for Human Rights (FIDH), Amnesty International, the Mercator Institute for China Studies (MERICS), Radio Free Asia (RFA), the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT). The harvested credentials are used to gain access to the targets‚Äô email accounts and other communication platforms, in order to gather valuable information. In addition, RedAlpha was observed exploiting known Microsoft Office vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2017-0199) and deploying various backdoors and infostealers, such as njRAT, NetHelp Striker, and other commodity and custom malware.

Cybersecurity researchers linked RedAlpha to a Chinese information security company called Nanjing Qinglan Information Technology Co., Ltd. (later known as Jiangsu Cimer Information Security Technology Co. Ltd.), which appears to be the registrant of multiple RedAlpha domains. In addition, RedAlpha‚Äôs tools and infrastructure were linked to other threat groups, such as NetTraveler, Icefog, and DeputyDog.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
APT-C-35 (aka DoNot Team, Donot Team, or Sector E02) is an Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group, assumed to be state-sponsored by the government of India. Even though the group was first reported by 360 Core Security Team in mid-2017, there is evidence that they have been operating since April 2016, maybe even earlier. APT-C-35 orchestrated attacks mainly against South Asian entities, predominantly in Pakistan, but was also observed operating in Argentina, Togo, the United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom. They usually engage in cyber espionage, to obtain valuable information from government and military officials, and have also been observed targeting Kashmiri non-profit organizations.

The threat actor uses cybersquatting techniques to register domains that resemble legitimate applications, companies, and services, like Adobe and Gmail (e.g. adobeupdater.com), but in fact contain bait files and malicious APKs. The group also uses spear-phishing emails with Microsoft Office attachments containing either a vulnerability or malicious macro code.

In January 2018, cybersecurity researchers detected a new modular/plugin-based malware framework presumably used by the group, dubbed ‚Äúyty.‚Äù The malware code was similar to the EHDevel malware reported by Bitdefender in 2017, which itself bore similarities to malware used in Operation Hangover in 2010-2013 and attributed to the Indian APT Patchwork. There is no conclusive evidence of collaboration between the two groups.

Malware variants of the yty framework that evolved over time include Jaca, Gedit, and DarkMusical.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In August 2018, it was reported on a spear-phishing campaign against entities in the Kashmir region. In the campaign that was active from July 2017, the group used either emails or SMSs to lure their victims into downloading malicious applications disguised as locally known service providers (e.g. KNS Lite - Kashmir News Service).

In March 2019, researchers discovered a credentials stealing campaign attributed to the group, targeting mostly South Asian governments. In the campaign, dubbed ‚ÄúLucky Elephant,‚Äù the attackers used websites that imitated South Asian government entities, such as the Pakistan Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Bangladesh Air Force as well as Microsoft Outlook 365 login pages hosted on cybersquatted domains. The researchers suspected that phishing emails were used to deceive victims into providing their credentials. A fairly similar campaign was detected around that time by the ThreatRecon team, that targeted the Government of Pakistan and Pakistani defense and intelligence organizations. The campaign was initiated with spear-phishing emails that contained malicious Excel files.

In April 2019, a research team reported another APT-C-35 attack against Pakistani entities, this time using an Android APK framework, dubbed ‚ÄúStealJob.‚Äù The attack vector included the use of decoy malicious applications planted in dedicated websites.

In November 2019, Positive Technologies detected an ongoing spear-phishing campaign mainly against countries in South Asia (e.g. Bangladesh, Thailand, and the Philippines), but also in the United Kingdom, Argentina, and the United Arab Emirates. The phishing emails contained Microsoft Word RTF documents that exploited the CVE-2018-0802 vulnerability in Microsoft Equation. In this campaign, the researchers noticed that the management servers were leased from the provider ‚ÄúDigitalOcean, LLC‚Äù and located in Amsterdam. In addition, the attackers did not use the same servers for different DNS names.

In September 2020, cybersecurity researchers followed Twitter reports from earlier that year (May and June 2021) to find new malware samples linked to the group‚Äôs malicious mobile application infrastructure. In their investigation, the researchers learned that the group has developed better antivirus evasion techniques, as most of their previously plaintext strings were now Base64-encoded. In addition, they uncovered a relatively unique group feature: Most of the Android packages in its operations communicated to a certain domain (www.geoip-db.com) to acquire geolocation information and victim‚Äôs external IP address, rather than relying on internal Android functions to obtain this information.

In October 2020, an intelligence team observed a new campaign, in which the group started to use a new Android loader, dubbed ‚ÄúFirestarter.‚Äù The malware abuses Google‚Äôs Firebase Cloud Messaging (FCM) server for command-and-control (C2) communication, in order to avoid detection. It was executed through malicious APK files (e.g. kashmir_Voice_v4.8.apk), and likely spread through direct messages. The campaign targeted mainly end users and non-profit organizations connected to the Kashmir area (India and Pakistan).

In April 2021, researchers analyzed malicious Android applications that were published in a Twitter post in relation to the group. They found that all the apps lead to a fake application package masquerading as a legitimate Google update application (com.update.gooqle).

In October 2021, Amnesty International linked the group to a spyware attack against a Togolese activist in December 2019-January 2020, during the 2020 Togolese presidential election period. The Android spyware was first distributed through a WhatsApp message, soliciting the installation of a chat app called ‚ÄúChatLite.‚Äù However, as this distribution method failed, the attackers used an email sent from a Gmail account, containing a Microsoft Word file leveraging a remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2017-0199) to drop the spyware. The spyware featured various capabilities, such as keylogging, taking screenshots, and stealing files. In addition, the spyware was traced back to an Indian cybersecurity company ‚ÄúInnefu Labs,‚Äù which denied any connection to the group. Due to the unusual location of the attack, it is possible that the group started to offer 'hacker for hire' services to governments.

In November 2021, APT-C-35 was reported as one of three APT groups using a novel RTF template injection technique, as part of their phishing campaigns. This technique enabled them to retrieve malicious content from a remote URL using RTF files. The RTF files are also less detected by security software.

In August 2022, Morphisec researchers reported that APT-C-35 upgraded its Windows malware framework (YTY, Jaca) to include an improved infostealer module, designed to steal information from Google Chrome and Mozilla Firefox browsers. In addition, the framework included other modules, which were downloaded from a remote C2 server and could be used to log user keystrokes, take screenshots, upload and exfiltrate files, steal removable disk files, and launch a reverse shell for granting remote access to the victim's machine.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Grandoreiro banking Trojan was first observed in 2016. The malware, operating in the malware-as-a-service (MaaS) model, targets banking customers and organizations in the automotive, civil and industrial construction, logistics, and machinery sectors, primarily located in Brazil, Mexico, Spain, and Portugal. Kaspersky tracks Grandoreiro as part of a collective of four Brazilian-based banking Trojan families, Tetrade, which also includes Guildma, Javali, and Melcoz (AKA Mekotio). 

Grandoreiro, written in Delphi, usually spreads through malspam campaigns, in which phishing email messages using lures (e.g. COVID-19) or impersonating a legitimate entity (e.g. tax authorities or government entities) are sent to the victims exhorting them to click on attached links. These links lead the targets to malicious websites that promote web browser plugins or fake Flash/Java updates, which then download VBS (sometimes MSI) installers. The installers, often stored on public online sharing services (e.g. GitHub), execute the Grandoreiro payload, which is usually archived in a ZIP file. Sometimes, the malware operators use Google ads to distribute their malicious loaders. 

Once deployed, Grandoreiro establishes connection to a remote command and control (C2) server, using the RealThinClient SDK, and starts collecting data, such as system information (e.g. computer name, username, and OS version), clipboard data, cryptocurrency information, and web browser data. The malware can access the browsers‚Äô history and steal cookies and user credentials for banking accounts to make fraudulent money transactions. In addition, Grandoreiro can perform overlay attacks, log user keystrokes, simulate mouse and keyboard actions, manipulate windows, block access to specific websites, log the victim out of the system, and restart the machine. The malware establishes persistence by creating an LNK file in the Windows startup directory. To evade detection, Grandoreiro disables banking protection software (e.g. Diebold Warsaw) and terminates running processes that might interfere with its operation. In addition, it uses the binary padding technique to avoid sandbox analysis. The C2 address is hidden using a domain generation algorithm (DGA).
content.AdditionalInformation: In July 2021, the Spanish police arrested 16 individuals suspected of stealing and laundering funds using the Mekotio and Grandoreiro banking Trojans. According to the authorities, the suspects stole more than ‚Ç¨275,000 from compromised bank accounts and had access to other accounts storing around ‚Ç¨3.5 million that were yet to be diverted.

Techniques.Name: Windows File and Directory Permissions Modification

content.Overview:
The TA558 threat group, first reported by Proofpoint researchers in August 2022, has been active since at least 2018. The financially-motivated group targets hospitality, hotel, and travel organizations, primarily located in Latin America, but also in North America and Western Europe. The activities of TA558 have intensified in 2022, probably due to the renaissance of tourism following the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions. 

TA558 distributes its malware using phishing email messages with reservation-themed lures, such as hotel bookings. The messages either contain documents with malicious macro codes or Microsoft Office exploits (e.g. CVE-2017-11882 and CVE-2017-8570) or with URLs that lead to a booking-themed ISO file (sometimes hosted on compromised hotel websites), which then launches a PowerShell script. Both infection vectors eventually end with the deployment of 15 different malware families, such as Loda, Vjw0rm, AsyncRAT, and Revenge RAT, that achieve persistence by creating a scheduled task. The malware are used to steal personal and financial customer data, perform reconnaissance, enable lateral movement, and deliver additional payloads. 

TA558‚Äôs phishing messages are usually written in Portuguese or Spanish (sometimes in English), which may indicate the group‚Äôs specific targeting. The threat actors often switch the languages of their phishing messages, probably in an attempt to avoid detection.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The IceFire ransomware group was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in March 2022. The group primarily targets web hosting providers and ISPs from different countries, such as Turkey, Iran, Pakistan, and Morocco. There is little information about IceFire‚Äôs attack vector. 
 
Upon encryption, the victim‚Äôs files are appended with the .iFire extension and a ransom note (iFire-readme.txt) is dropped. The ransom note contains instructions on how to make the ransom payment (in Monero) and a dedicated username and password for logging into the victim‚Äôs account on IceFire‚Äôs website. The payment should be made within five days, to avoid the leakage of stolen data. 
 
Since August 2022, IceFire maintains an active Tor leak site, in which it uploads the data of victims who refused the ransom demands.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The XCSSET malware family was first discovered by security researchers from TrendMicro in August 2020. XCSSET is a malicious code infection on the macOS integrated development environment (IDE) framework, Xcode, that can distribute malicious payloads. The researchers discovered two zero-day exploits on affected systems with the XCSSET code. One is used to steal cookies via a flaw in the behavior of Data Vaults and the other to abuse the development version of Safari. The malware can hijack Safari and inject various Javascript payloads.

Once a local Xcode project development framework is infected with the malicious code, the code will run on the project. Infection on Xcode could lead to a supply-chain attack and allows attackers to control the victim machine once that machine is injected with the XCSSET malware. Affected developers distribute the Trojan to users in the form of compromised Xcode projects or applications shared on GitHub, which could escalate the distribution of the malware. 

According to the report, two Xcode projects distributing the malware have been found, as well as 380 IP addresses of users infected with XCSSET. Out of them, 152 were located in China followed by 103 victims from India.

XCCSET has a wide variety of payload modules that attackers can perform on infected systems. The XCCSET payload modules are capable of exploiting Safari and other installed browsers. The malware can read and dump Safari cookies from macOS‚Äôs Data Vaults and has a module that can use Safari development mode to inject JS backdoors. Moreover, XCSSET contains modules that can exfiltrate files from the infected system and can steal information from users' applications, such as Notes, Evernote, QQ, Skype, Telegram, and WeChat. In addition, XCSSET contains modules that can take screenshots of the victim‚Äôs current screen and visited websites, as well as ransomware modules.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In April 2021, TrendMicro researchers reported that XCSSET was adapted to work on both ARM64 and x86_x64 Macs and could fit macOS 11 Big Sur. The malware was observed masquerading as legitimate Big Sur to trick victims into downloading it to their computers. The updated malware could also bypass macOS 11's security policies and steal confidential data from websites, such as 163.com, Huobi, binance.com, nncall.net, Envato, and login.live.com.

In August 2022, SentinelOne researchers reported that the XCSSET operators increased their activity since May 2022 and updated the malware to support macOS Monterey by upgrading its source code components to Python 3. Besides using AppleScripts to steal web browser and chat apps' data, the malware was observed abusing a public Github repository, DockUtil, and leveraging Python scripts to drop fake application icons on the macOS Dock and steal data from users' Notes app.

Techniques.Name: Compromise Software Dependencies and Development Tools
Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification

content.Overview:
The Donut Leaks extortion (possibly ransomware) group was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in August 2022. The group targets European organizations from various sectors, such as technology, agriculture, industrial manufacturing, engineering, and construction. It is still undetermined whether the threat actors actively engage in ransomware operations or only publish stolen data for extortion purposes. 
 
While Donut Leaks‚Äô attack vector was not disclosed, the threat actors have sent links to their managed Tor sites to the employees of compromised organizations. These sites include a data leak site (stylized as D0N#T__::LEAKS::) in which the names and data of breached organizations are published as well as a storage archive, embedded with the File Browser application, which enables the visitors to browse and download the stolen data. 
 
Some of the data leak entries include the names of victims whose breach was already claimed by other ransomware groups, such as Ragnar Locker and Hive. It is possible that the threat actors repurpose data that was published on other ransomware groups‚Äô leak sites for extortion schemes, or that they are affiliates of these groups.
content.AdditionalInformation: Among Donut Leaks' past victims, according to the group‚Äôs leak site: Sheppard Robson, PlanET Biogas Solutions, CMZ UK, Sando, and Enso Detego.

content.Overview:
The BlueSky ransomware group was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in June 2022. There is little information about the group‚Äôs specific targets. 

BlueSky usually gains initial system access either through malicious websites, which promote Trojanized cracks and keygens (some also host other malware), or through email messages with malicious attachments. Some infection cycles include the use of third-party frameworks, such as Cobalt Strike and Brute Ratel C4 (BRc4). The ransomware is downloaded and executed by a Base64-encoded PowerShell script that escalates privileges by exploiting known system vulnerabilities (e.g. CVE-2021-1732 or CVE-2022-21882) or by using the JuicyPotato local privilege escalation tool. 

The BlueSky ransomware payload is saved locally on the disk while masquerading as a legitimate Windows application (javaw.exe). The payload embeds multiple anti-analysis techniques, including string encryption, API obfuscation using DJB hashing functions, and anti-debugging mechanisms. BlueSky was observed leveraging NtSetInformationThread to hide threads that are launched by the malware executable. Then, BlueSky moves laterally in the system through Server Message Block (SMB) and starts encrypting files using the ChaCha20 encryption algorithm along with Curve25519 for key generation. The ransomware uses multithreading for faster encryption and, to thwart analysis, sometimes sleeps between each remote connection attempt. Unlike other ransomware that target specific file extensions to encrypt, BlueSky lists file types to be excluded from encryption (e.g. LDF, SCR, CMD, and BIN). Once encrypted, the files are appended with the .bluesky extension, and a ransom note (# DECRYPT FILES BLUESKY #) is dropped in both TXT and HTML formats. The ransom notes include a general notice about the encryption and a link to a Tor payment website along with a unique recovery ID. The victims are given seven days to pay the ransom demand or the ransom amount is doubled. 

Security researchers found code similarities between the multithreaded architecture of BlueSky and Conti‚Äôs v3 ransomware strain; however, the groups apply different encryption algorithms. In addition, some of BlueSky‚Äôs domain infrastructure was found to have originated from Russia.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The 0ktapus phishing campaign has been active since at least March 2022. The campaign has targeted over 100 organizations from various sectors, such as IT, telecommunications, finance, education, and retail. Most of the victims are located in the United States and are customers of the identity services provider, Okta. The threat actor behind this campaign was dubbed by Okta "Scatter Swine." 
 
On August 7, 2022, the cloud communications company, Twilio, disclosed a data breach following an SMS phishing attack (smishing) against its employees. The threat actors, whose identity was not disclosed, impersonated Twilio's IT department to steal employee credentials that they used to gain unauthorized access to the data of at least 125 customers. In addition, the breach affected Signal users, exposing the registered phone numbers of 1,900 accounts. Twilio revoked the compromised employee credentials, but not before the damage was done. Further investigation by Twilio uncovered that the attackers managed to breach 93 Authy user accounts and they registered unauthorized devices to these accounts. 

On August 9, 2022, it was revealed that the same modus operandi was used to breach Cloudflare employees' accounts; however, unlike the Twilio incident, the threat actors failed to access the company systems, as they could not acquire their victims' company-issued security keys. 
 
On August 25, 2022, Group-IB researchers reported the incidents were part of a larger campaign that has already compromised around 10,000 accounts belonging to employees of 130 organizations around the world. The campaign operators sought to obtain Okta identity credentials, two-factor authentication (2FA) tokens, and one-time passwords (OTPs), using over 150 unique phishing domains impersonating the Okta authentication page. The stolen credentials could later be used to access and gather sensitive information from corporate VPNs, networks, and internal customer support systems of the targeted organizations using remote access software (e.g. AnyDesk). Stolen customer data was observed being used for performing supply-chain attacks against other companies (e.g. DigitalOcean and Signal). 

The campaign was also linked to other data breaches, including that of the food delivery service DoorDash, the marketing firm Klaviyo, and the email client Mailchimp. In those breaches, the threat actors used stolen credentials to compromise customer information, including names, email and physical addresses, phone numbers, and even credit card information in a small number of cases. 

The security researchers were able to connect the phishing kit that has been used in the campaign to a Telegram channel, set for dropping compromised data. In addition, the Telegram channel was found to be managed by a 22 year-old software developer, ‚ÄúSubject X,‚Äù based in North Carolina.
content.AdditionalInformation: Among the targeted organizations: Twilio, Cloudflare, T-Mobile, MetroPCS, Verizon Wireless, AT&T, Slack, Twitter, Binance, KuCoin, CoinBase, Microsoft, Epic Games, Riot Games, Evernote, HubSpot, TTEC, and Best Buy.

content.Overview:
The Sliver command and control (C2) framework was first made public by the US-based cybersecurity company BishopFox in late 2019. The open-source red team toolkit (freely available on GitHub) is used by organizations to perform security testing; however, threat actors have adopted it for malicious purposes in numerous campaigns targeting organizations from multiple sectors and countries. 

Sliver, written in Golang, is utilized by threat actors to gain an initial foothold, maintain system access, deliver additional payloads (e.g. ransomware), scan for system vulnerabilities (e.g. Log4j), and enable lateral movement (through PsExec). It is delivered through various methods, such as weaponized attachments in email messages or compromised websites and malware loaders (e.g. Bumblebee). The toolkit supports the major operating systems (Windows, macOS, and Linux) and multiple protocols (DNS, HTTP/TLS, MTLS, TCP). 

Sliver accepts C2 connections from implants on compromised systems and enables the C2 operators to interact with the implants and execute arbitrary commands. In addition, it can host files to emulate a legitimate web server and generate implants in several formats (e.g. shellcode, executable, and DLL). Like other C2 frameworks (e.g. Cobalt Strike), Sliver runs many process injection commands, such as loading and running DLLs and .NET assemblies, injecting a Metasploit framework, and migrating into a remote process. Yet, Sliver offers more customization in terms of payload delivery compared to other similar frameworks, a trait that enables it to evade detection. Sometimes, it is being delivered along with other such frameworks and malware, such as Cobalt Strike, Metasploit, IcedID, PupyRAT, and Pantegana. 

Since December 2020, there has been an uptick in the use of Sliver by threat actors, such as APT29 (AKA Cozy Bear), FIN12, and TA551 (AKA Shathak).
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The APT40 has been active since at least 2013. The Chinese state-sponsored group conducts cyber espionage campaigns against multiple sectors including defense, education, government, etc. It targets the United States, Western Europe, and Southeast Asia countries.

In 2017, campaigns started with spear phishing emails with themes such as ‚ÄúApplication for an internship‚Äù, ‚Äúresume‚Äù, ‚Äúrelevant research,‚Äù and others. The emails contained malicious attachments that exploited several vulnerabilities, such as CVE-2017-8759, CVE-2017-0199, and CVE-2017-11882. All of these are Microsoft Office vulnerabilities that allow remote access execution. The group quickly developed the exploits for those vulnerabilities which were disclosed only a few days before the attack. Besides spear-phishing and exploiting vulnerabilities, the group also develops web shells for initial access.

After the exploitation, several backdoors were downloaded to the victim networks. One of them, NanHaiShu, leverages Javascript libraries and has the ability to gather information on the computer and execute other JavaScript. A similar tool called Orz can also overwrite registry settings in order to avoid detection, execute shell commands, etc.
content.AdditionalInformation:
According to security researchers, between 2018-2019, the group was involved in targeting and monitoring the elections of countries that neighbor China.

On February 5, 2020, Malaysia‚Äôs CERT (MyCERT) announced that a Chinese threat group has been targeting Malaysian government officials. The threat actor behind that campaign is most likely APT40, due to the tools and the TTPs used in the attacks. The purpose of the attacks was to infect the computers of government officials in Malaysia with malware and to steal confidential documents. The threat actors, pretending to be journalists and representatives of a military organization and a non-governmental organization (NGO), infiltrated the network using spear-phishing emails against high-value targets. The email messages contained malicious attachments that require that macros be enabled. The malicious macros used two Office exploits, CVE-2014-6352 and CVE-2017-0199, to execute malicious code on the victim's system to download and install malware.

In September 2020, security researchers uncovered a campaign of the group that started with spear phishing emails with malicious attachments. Some of the emails dealt with the COVID-19 situation. The group used the Azure infrastructure for its command and control servers. The campaign targeted higher education and government organizations in Asia.

On July 19, 2021, the US Department of Justice (DOJ) published an announcement that four Chinese nationals (Ding Xiaoyang, Cheng Qingmin, Wu Shurong, and Zhu Yunmin) working with the Ministry of State Security (HSSD) were charged concerning a global computer intrusion campaign associated with the state-sponsored hacking group known as APT40 between 2011 and 2018. During that period APT40 was responsible for hacking into various companies, universities, and government entities in the U.S. and worldwide targeting intellectual property and confidential information to leverage the compromised data in the purpose of boosting economic growth, serving China‚Äôs agenda. The four established a so-called ‚Äùlegitimate‚Äù company named Hainan Xiandun Technology Development Co. Ltd. (Hainan Xiandun) based in China, covering their illegal activities used in several operations.

In August 2022, Proofpoint researchers linked APT40 with moderate confidence to a cyberespionage campaign, ScanBox, targeting Australian government and media organizations, and wind turbine fleets in the South China Sea. In the course of the campaign that took place between April to June 2022, the threat actors sent their victims phishing email messages from Gmail and Outlook accounts while impersonating employees of media outlets. The messages contained links to seemingly legitimate news websites that delivered the ScanBox reconnaissance framework through JavaScript execution and staged module loading. The ScanBox modules could be used to log user keystrokes, identify installed web browser plugins, implement WebRTC to real-time communication over APIs, and detect installed antivirus software. Once deployed, the framework established command and control (C2) connection and exfiltrated victim data, including general system and web browser (e.g. version, language, and location). The ScanBox campaign was also linked to older APT40 campaigns that targeted users through RTF template injections to load Meterpreter onto their machines. 

Following the 2020 Malaysian campaign, security researchers published a relevant YARA rule:

rule APT_APT40_Implant_June2020 {
meta:
version = "1.0"
author = "Elastic Security"
date_added = "2020-06-19"
description = "APT40 second stage implant"
strings:
$a = "/list_direction" fullword wide
$b = "/post_document" fullword wide
$c = "/postlogin" fullword wide
$d = "Download Read Path Failed %s" fullword ascii
$e = "Open Pipe Failed %s" fullword ascii
$f = "Open Remote File %s Failed For: %s" fullword ascii
$g = "Download Read Path Failed %s" fullword ascii
$h = "\\cmd.exe" fullword wide
condition:
all of them
}

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Nitrokod cryptomining campaign, first reported by Check Point researchers in August 2022, has been active since at least 2019. The campaign, orchestrated by a Turkish threat actor, has targeted over 111,000 users from 11 countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, Germany, Australia, and Israel.

The campaign operators have been promoting seemingly legitimate programs (e.g. Google Translate Desktop) on search engine results. The programs, hosted on popular websites such as Softpedia and Uptodown, delay the execution of their malicious components for up to a month so as to evade detection. The program installer is downloaded by the user as an encrypted RAR archive which starts a seven-staged infection chain of repeated installation of droppers, along with the creation of scheduled tasks to maintain persistence. The droppers employ various anti-analysis and anti-detection techniques that enable them to thwart sandboxes, detect antivirus software, bypass firewalls, and avoid running on virtual machines. At the seventh attack stage, an XMRig cryptojacking software is fetched from a remote command and control (C2) server and exploits the system resources to mine cryptocurrency. The cryptominer sends the C2 a full system report through HTTP POST requests, in order for it to determine its functionality (e.g. the amount of CPU power to use and when to abort).
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Evil Corp threat group, also known as Indrik Spider or the Dridex gang, started its operations in 2007 when several members were in an affiliate group to distribute the ZeuS banking Trojan.

Their initial efforts were focused on distributing the Cridex banking Trojan, a malware strain that later evolved into the Dridex banking trojan, and later subsequently evolved into the Dridex multi-purpose malware toolkit.

Over the years, Evil Corp, through its Dridex operation, became one of the largest malware and spam botnets on the internet. The group distributed their own malware, together with malware for other criminal groups, along with custom spam messaging.
content.AdditionalInformation:
The group started spreading ransomware in 2016 with the Locky ransomware that targeted home consumers. The group stopped using the Locky ransomware when they shifted their targets from home consumers to enterprise targets. For that purpose, they created a custom ransomware named BitPaymer.

Evil Corp used their vast botnet of computers infected with the Dridex malware to look for corporate networks and then deploy BitPaymer on the largest enterprise targets they could identify. They operated BitPaymer between 2017 and 2019.

In December 2019, the US Department of Justice charged Russian citizens Maksim V. Yakubets and Igor Turashev for deploying the Dridex malware and for their involvement in international bank fraud and computer hacking schemes. After that indictment, the hacking group began restructuring its tactics.

In June 2020, Fox-It published an article about ‚ÄúWastedLocker,‚Äù a new ransomware variant developed by EvilCorp. The name is derived from the filename it creates which includes an abbreviation of the victim‚Äôs name and the string ‚Äòwasted‚Äô.

In June 2020, the EvilCorp gang hacked into dozens of US newspaper websites owned by the same company in order to infect the employees of over 30 major US private firms.
The attackers were using fake software update alerts displayed by the malicious SocGholish JavaScript-based framework.

On July 27th, 2020, Garmin, the wearables and GPS tracker maker, announced that they suffered a ransomware attack that encrypted some of their systems. This attack, which took place four days prior to the announcement, was linked to EvilCorp. Garmin paid 10 million USD to release their systems.

In October 2020, the U.S. Department of the Treasury‚Äôs Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) issued an advisory alerting companies that engage with victims of ransomware attacks of the potential sanction risks for facilitating ransomware payments.

As part of this restructure, Evil Corp began distributing the WastedLocker ransomware in targeted attacks against businesses.

In October 2021, the group started to use another ransomware, dubbed "Macaw Locker." It was used in two recorded attacks that month against the Japanese technology company, Olympus, and the Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. The threat actor demanded a total of 68 million dollars ransom in the attacks.

In June 2022, Mandiant researchers reported that the UNC2165 group overlapping with Evil Corp started deploying the LockBit ransomware strain. This enabled Evil Corp to blend in with other LockBit affiliates and evade sanctions imposed by the U.S. Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC). In addition, it was assumed that the group moved to a Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) model in order to free resources that were invested in ransomware development, such as Hades.

In August 2022, eSentire researchers linked a member of UNC2165, mx1r, to an attack against the security vendor Cisco in May 2022 and an unnamed workforce management solutions company a month earlier. The threat actor used stolen VPN credentials and Cobalt Strike to gain initial system access. Then, it used various red team tools, such as network scanners and Active Domain crawlers, to move laterally in the targeted network through remote desktop protocol (RDP). In addition, the attacker attempted to launch a Kerberoasting attack to crack passwords within Windows Active Directory. The threat actor's Cobalt Strike infrastructure dubbed HiveStrike was previously used by a Conti affiliate to deploy Hive and Yanluowang ransomware strains. This led to the assumption that Conti might have lent its infrastructure to Evil Corp.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The ModernLoader RAT (AKA Avatar bot) has been active since at least 2019. The malware was observed targeting Eastern European users, specifically ones who speak Bulgarian, Polish, Hungarian, and Russian.

ModernLoader, written in .NET, was observed being deployed as a later-stage malware in an infection chain that starts with the download of an HTML Application file (HTA) masquerading as Amazon gift cards from compromised web applications (e.g. WordPress and CPanel). The HTA file runs a PowerShell script that deploys three modules: the ModernLoader payload, a module that injects it into a newly created process (e.g. RegSvcs.exe), and another that disables the Windows Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI). Once executed, ModernLoader can gather system information (e.g. IP address, OS version, and installed anti-malware software), execute arbitrary commands, and download additional malware from the command and control (C2) server, including the XMRig cryptominer and various infostealers. In some observed campaigns, ModernLoader acted as the main bot that communicated with the C2 server while maintaining remote access to the victim‚Äôs machine and enabling the download of malware like RedLine Stealer, SystemBC, and DCRat.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Prynt Stealer malware was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in April 2022. The infostealer is sold on cybercrime forums and marketplaces for time-limited subscriptions ranging between $100 and $700, or $900 for a lifetime license.

When deployed, Prynt Stealer creates folders for harvested data and steals documents, database files, source codes, and image files. Then, it collects sensitive web browser information, such as credit card information, autofill data, user credentials, cookies, and search history, account tokens for messaging apps (e.g. Telegram and Discord), gaming apps‚Äô files (e.g. Steam and Minecraft), and cryptocurrency information. Before the exfiltration, Prynt Stealer collects general system information about running processes, takes screenshots of the victim‚Äôs system, extracts the network credentials, and steals the Windows product key. Once the data collection process is completed, all the stolen information is exfiltrated to a remote command and control (C2) server through a Telegram bot.

Unlike common infostealers, Prynt Stealer also has a keylogger for recording user keystrokes and a clipper for monitoring cryptocurrency wallet addresses. Once a crypto transaction attempt is detected, the malware operators replace the recipient's address with the threat actor‚Äôs controlled accounts. In addition, Prynt Stealer features various anti-detection mechanisms. Its embedded binary contains hardcoded strings that are encrypted, as well as its C2 communications.
content.AdditionalInformation:
On April 26, 2022, Prynt Stealer‚Äôs source code was leaked on underground hacking forums. Security researchers, who examined the source code, concluded that the malware was based on AsyncRAT.

In September 2022, Zscaler researchers reported that the Prynt Stealer developer planted a backdoor in the malware's code that sends copies of victims' exfiltrated data gathered by other threat actors to the developer's private Telegram channel. Furthermore, according to the researchers, the Prynt Stealer builder was designed to deploy additional malware, DarkEye Stealer (a variant of Prynt Stealer) and LodaRAT.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The DarkAngels ransomware group has been active since at least May 2022. There is little information about the group‚Äôs specific targets. The DarkAngels ransomware strain seems to be a rebrand of Babuk and can target both Windows and Linux operating systems. 

DarkAngels gains initial access through malspam messages that distribute RATs, which then lead to the deployment of a SOCK5 backdoor to maintain persistence. Then, the threat actors scan the compromised network to obtain weak access points and valid credentials for lateral movement. DarkAngels access NAS instances and other enterprise assets using weak and common passwords and exfiltrate sensitive data before encrypting the system. The threat actors were observed lingering in the system for five months before initiating the encryption. 

Once executed, the DarkAngels ransomware strain, sometimes packed in an ELF format, calls an API that ensures the malware‚Äôs activities terminate only before the system shutdown. Another API makes a connection to the service control manager and gives the ransomware access to the service control manager database. Then, it enumerates the services that run on the victim‚Äôs machine (e.g. VSS, SQL, and Memtas) and terminates the ones that might interfere with the encryption process. To prevent system recovery, the DarkAngels ransomware deletes volume shadow copies and all items from the Recycle Bin. The encrypted files are appended with the .crypt or .crypted extension. Some files, such as EXE, DLL, and BABYK, are excluded from encryption. Finally, a ransom note (How_To_Restore_Your_Files.txt) with negotiation instructions is dropped in the encrypted folders. 

DarkAngels used to operate a Tor leak site, which currently seems offline. The group registers some of their associated domains using a privacy domain registration proxy service, probably to maintain anonymity. In addition, the threat actors appear to be using a TLS page to host their victim interactions and the Symfony framework to create web applications.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview: AgainstTheWest (AKA BlueHornet) is a hacking group affiliated with Anonymous. Despite the group's name, the threat actors claim to only target countries and companies that are hostile to Western interests.
content.AdditionalInformation:
On March 1, 2022, the group claimed to hack the Russian state-owned Sberbank bank and threatened to leak its data, including DNS infrastructure, private keys for SSL, Sberbank API, CLI, and SDKs. In addition, the group hacked the Russian tool manufacturer NPKTAIR, a Russian financial holding (OJSC Ak Bars Holding), and a Russian plane tracking system. The latter hack enabled the group members to view important flight information and also change their details.

On March 4, 2022, AgainstTheWest claimed that it breached and leaked the database of the Russian energy corporation giant Gazprom.

On September 2, 2022, AgainstTheWest claimed to hack TikTok and WeChat through an Alibaba cloud instance. The group published screenshots of a 790 GB database allegedly belonging to the companies and claimed that it contained 2.05 billion records of user data, platform statistics, software code, cookies, authentication tokens, server information, and more. While WeChat did not comment on the alleged incident, TikTok denied the threat actors' claims and stated that it was not breached.

content.Overview:
The JuiceLedger threat group, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in August 2022, has been active since at least the beginning of that year. The group indiscriminately targets Python Package Index (PyPI) users to conduct supply chain attacks.

JuiceLedger‚Äôs primary attack vectors include the sending of PyPI-themed phishing email messages with links to credential harvesting pages and weaponizing installer applications or PyPI packages. The threat actors shifted to poisoning legitimate open-source PyPI packages (e.g. the ‚Äúexotel‚Äù and ‚Äúspam‚Äù packages) to reach a larger audience. JuiceLedger either plants a malicious link inside the PyPI package‚Äôs code or uses typosquatting of popular packages. Once installed, the malicious packages fetch a .NET information stealer, JuiceStealer, that can search and exfiltrate Google Chrome passwords, query Chrome SQLite files, look for cryptocurrency vaults, and launch a Python installer from a ZIP archive. The harvested information is then sent to the connected command and control (C2) server over HTTP. The infostealer is usually signed with a valid digital certificate to avoid suspicion.
content.AdditionalInformation:
The malicious PyPI packages that were reported to the PyPI team were removed from the repository. Users who believe they may have been victims of a JuiceLedger attack are advised to reset passwords immediately and to report any suspicious activity to security@pypi.org.

content.Overview:
Moobot is a botnet family that was first observed by cybersecurity Netlab researchers in September 2019. The globally distributed botnet compromises technological devices, such as IoT devices, cameras, routers, ‚Äã‚Äãand DVRs, in countries such as the United States, South Korea, Japan, and India. Moobot is based on the notorious Mirai botnet, and is also similar to the Satori botnet.

Moobot spreads by leveraging weak telnet passwords and remotely exploitable vulnerabilities, some of which are zero-day, in order to launch distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks. The Moobot operators use port scanning to detect vulnerable devices and once found, they infect them with the botnet, and establish a command and control (C2) communication to take remote control and execute additional commands. Then, the C2 server creates a network overflow, by executing various flood commands, such as UDP, SYN, ACK, or ACK+PUSH.

The vulnerabilities that were observed to be exploited by Moobot include: zero-day vulnerability in the LILIN DVR‚Äôs NTPUpdate process, Tenda remote code execution (CVE-2020-10987), Huawei Router arbitrary command execution (CVE-2017-17215), and a command injection vulnerability in Hikvision cameras (CVE-2021-36260).
content.AdditionalInformation:
In September 2022, Palo Alto researchers reported a new Moobot campaign that was initiated in early August and targeted vulnerable D-Link routers through old and new exploits. Once gaining control over the devices, the malware operators could use them to conduct further attacks, such as DDoS. The exploited vulnerabilities (primarily remote code execution flaws) were already patched by D-Link, but not all customers have applied them.

Defense Evasion

content.Overview:
TA505, active since at least 2014, is a financially motivated threat group, likely of Russian origin, that is known for frequently changing malware and driving global trends in criminal malware distribution. The APT group targets multiple financial institutions and retail companies using malicious spam campaigns and different malware. In 2019, the group expanded its criminal operation to other industries.

TA505 is highly adaptable, frequently shifting techniques and malware to ‚Äúfollow the money,‚Äù while largely sticking to successful strategies where possible. This group is responsible for large malicious spam campaigns, mostly distributing instances of the Dridex banking Trojan, Locky ransomware, and the TrickBot banking Trojan. The group also used several other malware in very high volume attacks.

Exclusive malware to TA505 include: Jaff, Bart, and Rockloader.
content.AdditionalInformation:
On July 28, 2014, TA505 launched its first known attack using Dridex banking Trojan. These early campaigns were distributed via the Lerspeng downloader. Later campaigns occasionally used Pony or Andromeda as intermediate loaders to distribute various instances of Dridex. TA505 continued distributing Dridex via email attachments through early June 2017.

In October 2015, TA505 launched several campaigns that targeted Japanese and UK organizations using the Shifu banking Trojan, delivered through macro-laden Office document attachments. A few days after those attacks, TA505 returned to distribute Dridex in high volume.

In February 2016, TA505 introduced Locky ransomware. TA505 stopped distributing Dridex in July 2016, relying almost exclusively on Locky through December of that year.

In April 2016, TA505 first introduced Rockloader as an intermediate loader for Locky. At that time, Rockloader was the initial payload downloaded by malicious attached JavaScript files. Once Rockloader was installed, it downloaded Locky and, in some cases, Pony and Kegotip.
Pony is a loader with information-stealing capabilities while Kegotip is a credential and email address harvesting malware strain that appeared in a small number of TA505 campaigns on 2017 as the primary payload.

On June 24, 2016, Bart ransomware appeared for exactly one day. It was a secondary payload downloaded by Rockloader.

In mid-2016, TA505 used the Necurs botnet to drive their high-volume spam campaigns. TA505 was heavily reliant on this massive botnet to send out high-volume malicious spam campaigns. The disappearances of TA505 activity frequently accompany disruptions in Necurs.

In April 2017, TA505 briefly distributed the Kegotip information stealer. It was used to steal credentials from various FTP clients, Outlook, and Internet Explorer. It also gathered email addresses scraped from files stored on the computer.

In May 2017, TA505 started using Jaff ransomware. Jaff was not dramatically different from other ransomware strains that the group used.

in June 2017, TA505 first began distributing Trickbot banking Trojan in frequent, high-volume campaigns. The last TA505 campaigns featuring Trickbot appeared in mid-September 2017 with payloads alternating between Locky and Trickbot.

Philadelphia ransomware has been circulating since September 2016 in use in highly targeted campaigns. TA505 distributed it in one large campaign in July 2017.

At the end of July 2017, TA505 began including GlobeImposter in malicious spam campaigns. TA505 primarily distributed GlobeImposter in zipped script attachments through the beginning of September 2017.

In August 2017, TA505 started spreading Locky through phishing URLs. Most of these URLs were linked to malicious documents and scripts. The group had gone back to large attachment campaigns, primarily distributing various zipped scripts that downloaded Locky.

In November 2018, TA505 began distributing ServHelper backdoor. ServHelper has two variants: one acting as a remote desktop agent and one as a downloader for a RAT called FlawedGrace.

Since December 2018, TA505 has been using legitimate or compromised RATs (remote access Trojans) such as FlawedAmmyy, FlawedGrace, and Remote Manipulator System (RMS).

In April 2019, TA505 targeted Chile, Mexico, and Italy using either FlawedAmmyy RAT or RMS RAT as payload. By the end of April 2019, the group started going after targets in East Asian countries such as China, South Korea, and Taiwan, using FlawedAmmyy.

In June 2019, TA505 launched two spam campaigns distributing the downloader FlawedAmmyy (also called AndroMut), targeting the U.S, Singapore, UAE, and South Korea.

In July 2019, the group also started several malicious spam campaigns that distributed malware new strains. They used Gelup downloader and the FlowerPippi backdoor to attack targets from the Middle East, Japan, India, the Philippines, and Argentina.
Gelup downloader abuses user account control (UAC) bypass and works as a loader for other threats. The tool also uses the packer of FlawedAmmyy.

In October 2019, Security researchers observed that TA505 has been using a new RAT dubbed SDbot.

In January 2020, Microsoft published a report regarding an ongoing phishing campaign attributed to TA505. This phishing campaign was using attachments featuring HTML redirectors for delivering malicious Excel documents.

In February 2020, Fox-IT published a report in which they connected TA505 to a ransomware attack on a university in the Netherlands. Maastricht University (UM) disclosed that it paid a 30 bitcoin ransom requested by the attackers who encrypted some of its critical systems following a cyberattack that took place on December 23, 2019.

In March 2020, a new TA505 campaign was discovered. In this campaign, the group has targeted businesses in Germany via their human resources executives and Google drive.

In October 2020, Microsoft observed new threat activity exploiting the critical Zerologon vulnerability CVE-2020-1472. The campaign poses as software updates that lead to a UAC bypass and the use of wscript.exe to run malicious scripts connected with known TA505 command and control (C2) infrastructure.

On November 13, 2020, the Australian government issued a security alert urging local health sector organizations to check their cybersecurity defenses, and especially their controls for detecting and stopping ransomware attacks. They had observed increased targeting activity against the Australian Health sector by actors using the SDBBot remote access tool. Additionally, the ACSC says that SDBBot is also a known precursor of the Clop ransomware. While the ACSC did not provide any details about threat actors, the SDBBot RAT has been almost exclusively distributed by TA505, thus also tying them to the Clop ransomware.

In December 2020, security researchers discovered a new malware dubbed Clop ransomware. Clop ransomware is a variant of the Cryptomix ransomware, which was seen in use by TA505.

In October 2021, TA505 was linked to a phishing campaign dubbed MirrorBlast targeting organizations from multiple sectors in Canada, the United States, Hong Kong, Europe, and more. The threat actors sent their victims macro-embedded Excel documents deploying two malicious variants of the MSI package, REBOL and KiXtart. The malicious payloads were used to collect general system information, such as username and OS version, and exfiltrated this information to a remote server.

In July 2022, Maastricht University revealed that it managed to recover a ransom payment, which was made to TA505 after the group hit its systems in December 2019. At that time, TA505 breached the university's network and deployed the Clop ransomware on 267 Windows systems, encrypting the files that were stored on them. The group demanded a 30 Bitcoin ransom (roughly ‚Ç¨200,000 at the time), which was paid by the university. However, a few months later, the Dutch Public Prosecution Service seized a cryptocurrency wallet belonging to TA505, helping Maastricht University recover the paid ransom.

In September 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported that TA505 have started using a new control panel, TeslaGun, to manage the ServHelper backdoor. The threat actors were observed using the control panel as a C2 framework to issue commands across the compromised victim devices for operating ServHelper. The majority of the group's infrastructure was found to be located in Moldova.

content.Overview:
The Shikitega malware was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in September 2022. The malware targets Linux endpoints and IoT devices.

Shikitega is deployed using the polymorphic XOR additive feedback encoder ‚ÄúShikata Ga Nai.‚Äù It has a multistage infection chain where each module (starting from a small ELF file) delivers only a few hundred bytes of the payload and then downloads and executes the next one. Once the final shellcode is decrypted and executed, it communicates with the malware's command and control (C2) servers that are hosted on legitimate cloud hosting services, then it receives additional commands and executes files directly from memory. One of these commands executes ‚ÄúMettle,‚Äù a Metasploit Meterpreter payload that provides the attacker with further remote administration capabilities including webcam access and process control. It also enables the malware operators to run reverse shells and execute additional commands to retrieve a next-stage dropper. The dropper exploits known Linux vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-4034 and CVE-2021-3493) to gain elevated privileges and uses them to download and execute the final stage payload, the XMRig cryptominer. To achieve persistence, the malware executes five shell scripts and adds four root crontabs. As the crontabs are placed, Shikitega attempts to hide by deleting all the downloaded files from the system.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The DangerousSavana campaign, first reported by Check Point researchers in September 2022, has been ongoing since at least 2020. The campaign has been targeting major financial service groups in French-speaking African countries, such as Ivory Coast, Morocco, Cameroon, and Senegal. 

The DangerousSavana operators have been sending their victims spear phishing email messages that either contain PDF attachments (at earlier campaign stages, self-written executable loaders masquerading as PDFs) or Microsoft Office documents with malicious macro codes. Sometimes, the attachments are packed in ISO or ZIP archives to evade detection. To increase credibility, the French-language messages often impersonate African financial institutions, such as the Tunisian Foreign bank and Nedbank. The malicious attachments download different file types (e.g. LNK, VBE, and JAR) that lead to the deployment of both custom or open-source malware and tools, such as Metasploit, PoshC2, DWservice, and AsyncRAT, usually triggered by using PowerShell scripts. To evade detection, the threat actors run Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI) bypass commands, and inject their malicious binaries into legitimate Microsoft processes. System persistence is established by dropping batch files and creating scheduled tasks. Other tools that have been used during the DangerousSavana campaign include the Backstab open-source anti-EDR tool and an executable, POPULAIRE.exe (AKA LoggerStamp), that logs user keystrokes. 

The campaign‚Äôs motivation is likely financial, with the threat actors presumably attempting to access core banking systems, such as payment card issuing systems, SWIFT transfers, and ATM control systems.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The UAC-0098 threat group was first reported by the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) in April 2022, amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War. The group targets Ukrainian entities and European non-governmental organizations (NGOs). In September 2022, the Google Threat Analysis Group (TAG) assessed that UAC-0098 consists of former Conti members, with links to the TrickBot operation, and acts as an initial access broker for various threat groups, including the Quantum ransomware group and FIN12.

UAC-0098 usually gains initial access through phishing email messages that contain Microsoft Office documents (sometimes packed inside ZIP archives) with malicious macro codes. The messages often impersonate legitimate entities, such as Elon Musk's Star Link, the State Tax Service of Ukraine, and the Ukrainian National Cyber Police, and they use lure documents with intriguing names. The embedded macro codes are designed to exploit known Microsoft vulnerabilities (e.g. Follina - CVE-2022-30190) for the deployment of different malware, such as IcedID, Cobalt Strike, AnchorMail, Meterpreter, and GzipLoader. Sometimes, the malware are downloaded using a PowerShell script. In addition, UAC-0098 uses the EtterSilent malicious document builder and the ‚ÄúStolen Image Evidence‚Äù social engineering malware distribution service.     

It is unclear whether UAC-0098‚Äôs cyberattacks are directed by a government entity or purely financially motivated (perhaps a combination of the two).
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Lampion Trojan was first discovered in December 2019. The malware targets Portuguese entities using malspam email messages impersonating the Portuguese Government Finance & Tax. 

When the victim clicks on a link in the email message's body, the malware is downloaded from the command and control (C2) server. The downloaded file contains a VBScript file that acts as a dropper for the Trojan. Once executed, Lampion steals data from the victim's computer while concentrating on credential harvesting from bank accounts using overlay attacks. 

Researchers assess that the Lampion trojan belongs to the Trojan-Banker.Win32.ChePro family, but it contains improvements that make its detection and analysis harder than the rest of its families, such as anti-debug and anti-VM techniques. The malware operators include a lot of junk code inside the execution files to make analysis difficult.

Lampion's C2 server seems to be located in Russia. The malware's hostname was associated with other malicious operations, such as Bazaar and LockBit.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In September 2022, Cofense researchers reported a new Lampion campaign, in which the malware operators sent their victims phishing email messages from compromised company accounts. The messages contained links to download a "Proof of Payment" in the form of ZIP archives, hosted on WeTransfer. The archives contained VBS scripts that once executed, launched a WScript process leading to the deployment of DLL payloads. The DLLs were loaded directly into memory to evade security mechanisms.  

Among the banks and financial services whose users were targeted by Lampion: Citibank, Banco do Brasil, Banco BPI, Santander, Bankinter, ActivoBank, EuroBic, Travdesco, TravaBitco, and Credito Agricola.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Nemesis Kitten threat group (AKA DEV-0270) has been active since at least 2021. The Iranian state-sponsored group primarily targets Western organizations that are likely to interest the Iranian regime. Nemesis Kitten is a subgroup of APT35 (AKA Charming Kitten) and seems to overlap other APT35-associated groups, such as TunnelVision and Cobalt Mirage.

Nemesis Kitten usually gains initial access by exploiting known system vulnerabilities (e.g. ProxyLogon in Microsoft Exchange and the Apache Log4j) to inject a web shell into a privileged process or to create/activate a user account with admin privileges. Once infiltrating the system, the group runs discovery commands (e.g. ‚Äúwmic‚Äù and ‚Äúwhoami‚Äù) to collect general system information, uses living-off-the-land binaries (LOLBINs) to harvest credentials, and modifies registry keys to enable remote desktop (RDP) connections for the compromised device. The threat actors create scheduled tasks to maintain persistence and move laterally in the network using RDP and Impacket‚Äôs WMIExec. This occurs at the same time as executing commands for finding additional high-value targets and dumping credentials for escalating privileges. To evade detection, Nemesis Kitten shuts down Microsoft Defender and injects its malicious binaries into legitimate processes. Finally, the group was observed using BitLocker and DiskCryptor to encrypt hosts and workstations while demanding $8,000 for the decryption keys. This type of ransomware operation was recorded in May 2021 with the breach of Cox Media Group. 

In September 2022, Microsoft researchers assessed that Nemesis Kitten is operated by an Iranian-based company that functions under two public aliases: Secnerd and Lifeweb. The company was also linked to Najee Technology Hooshmand (ŸÜÿßÿ¨€å ÿ™⁄©ŸÜŸàŸÑŸà⁄ò€å ŸáŸàÿ¥ŸÖŸÜÿØ), located in Karaj, Iran.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Monti ransomware group has been active since at least May 2022. The group targets VMware ESXi servers by exploiting the Apache Log4j vulnerability (CVE-2021-44228). Monti‚Äôs ransomware strain is based on the leaked source code of Conti; however, it is unclear whether the group is a rebrand of Conti or merely a copycat.

After gaining initial system access, Monti downloads and installs two remote monitoring and maintenance (RMM) agents, AnyDesk and Action1, to establish persistence and provide additional remote access. Then, the threat actors use Windows built-in Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) to connect to other servers, access stored data files, and deploy their ransomware strain that encrypts multiple network hosts, including Veeam-based backups. The ransomware appends the encrypted files with the .PUUUK extension and drops a ransom note (encrypted using the ChaCha8 algorithm) that is almost identical to the one used by Conti.   

Monti uses temporary file transfer websites to fetch tools into the compromised network and exfiltrate data (e.g. MEGASync and PuTTY). In addition, the group was observed using GMER to remove endpoint security products and Mimikatz to dump credentials stored in memory. 

Monti operates an active leak site, in which it publishes the data of victims who refused the group‚Äôs ransom demands.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The EvilProxy phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) platform (AKA Moloch) was first reported by cybersecurity researchers in September 2022 after being advertised on underground hacking forums. The platform sells phishing kits that target users of various services, including Google, Apple‚Äôs iCloud, Dropbox, LinkedIn, Yandex, Facebook, Twitter, Yahoo, and WordPress. In addition, it is also designed to target software developers using GitHub, the Python Package Index (PyPI), RubyGems, and NPM.  

The phishing kits, sold by EvilProxy for $150-$600 (depending on the rental period and targeted account type) on Telegram, enable threat actors to create phishing landing pages, which are promoted through phishing messages. The phishing pages masquerade as the login portals of known services and use reverse proxies to harvest session cookies that contain authentication tokens for multi-factor authentication (MFA). These enable the phishing operators to log into the user accounts while bypassing MFA, steal additional sensitive data, and use the compromised accounts in subsequent attacks. EvilProxy also offers anti-analysis and anti-bot protection to keep out unwanted visitors on the phishing pages, such as analysis bots and security researchers.

The buyers of the EvilProxy phishing kits are only given access to the purchased service after being vetted by the platform operators, such as the underground forum user, ‚ÄúJohn_Malkovich.‚Äù After receiving access, the user is asked to provide SSH credentials to further deploy a Docker container and a set of scripts. Then, the scripts forward the victims‚Äô traffic through two gateways. EvilProxy is operated using a simple graphical user interface (GUI) that can be easily utilized by layman users, which might increase its potential malicious audience. 

The EvilProxy operators may be related to the JuiceLedger campaign that targeted PyPI users using weaponized PyPI packages.
content.AdditionalInformation: On September 14, 2022, Proofpoint researchers reported that threat actors used EvilProxy to create phishing lures related to the death of Queen Elizabeth II. The phishing messages included links to an online memory board of the late queen, which was in fact, a credential harvesting page used to target Microsoft account credentials, including MFA tokens.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The SparklingGoblin threat group, first reported by ESET researchers in August 2021, has been active since at least mid-2020. The Chinese APT group, with ties to APT41 (AKA Winnti, Earth Baku), primarily targets organizations in East and Southeast Asia, from sectors such as government, education, media, retail, and manufacturing.  

Although SparklingGoblin‚Äôs initial access vector was not disclosed, it is assumed to gain initial access through spear phishing email messages with malicious LNK files or by exploiting vulnerabilities in publicly facing web servers. Then, the group drops malware loaders (e.g. Motnug) to deploy its trademark backdoor, SideWalk (AKA ScrambleCross, StageClient), the very similar CROSSWALK backdoor, the Korplug RAT (AKA PlugX), and Cobalt Strike. SideWalk, encrypted with the ChaCha20 algorithm, is injected into a legitimate process using the process hollowing technique and establishes connection to the command and control (C2) server using Cloudflare workers. SideWalk can be used to load additional payloads, collect general system information (e.g. IP configuration, OS version, username, and computer name), and exfiltrate this information back to the C2 server over the HTTPS protocol. The malware has both Windows and Linux variants. The Linux variant, initially tracked as Specter RAT, can be used to target IP cameras, and NVR and DVR devices.
content.AdditionalInformation:
SparklingGoblin may overlap with another threat group that is tracked by Trend Micro as Grayfly (also strongly tied to APT41), whose members were indicted in the United States for their involvement in over 100 cyberattacks around the world. Grayfly was also attributed to the SideWalk backdoor.
