content.Overview:
The Webworm threat group, first reported by Symantec researchers in September 2022, has been active since at least 2017. The Chinese group targets government agencies, IT service and electric power providers, and aerospace enterprises in Russia, Georgia, Mongolia, and other Asian countries. Webworm heavily overlaps with the Space Pirates threat group, in both malware code and targets.

Webworm distributes its malware using dedicated droppers hidden behind decoy documents, likely sent through phishing messages. The group commonly uses customized versions of old RATs, including Trochilus RAT (corresponds to the Space Pirates‚Äô Deed RAT), Gh0st RAT, and 9002 RAT. These RATs, often embedded with defense evasion mechanisms, are used to execute arbitrary commands and fetch additional files and malware (e.g. PlugX).
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The LockerGoga ransomware first appeared in the second half of January 2019. It compromised aluminum and renewable energy company Norsk Hydro in March 2019 and allegedly, Altran Technologies in January 2019. Its origin might be Romanian or Polish, as the first identified sample was uploaded to Virus Total on the 24th of January 2019 from Romanian IP and each ransom note included polish contacts. LockerGoga has no fixed price for decryption. Instead, it requests the user to contact the threat actor by email for a price quote.

LockerGoga encrypts data very fast as it spawns hundreds of processes for encryption and ends up using every CPU core and thread (this could also be used to monitor ransomware activity). It implements symmetric Rijndael cipher more commonly known as AES, although in its ransom note it states that a mix of RSA-4096 and AES-256 is used. Encrypted files receive .locked extension. The ransom note that drops after the encryption is named README-NOW.txt. Malicious samples were signed by a legitimate certificate of MIKL Limited, issued by Comodo. The certificate has since been revoked. The ransomware does not have a lateral movement module and has to be deployed by an attacker who already has admin access.

In the case of Norsk Hydro, propagation of LockerGoga to endpoints occurred by using the company's own Active Directory against them. The hackers obtained admin credentials and then used windows built-in techniques to propagate. The malware allegedly propagated by creating scheduled tasks or services thus making each endpoint download and run the malware.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Hardcoded targeted extensions are the following:
.doc, .docb, .docx, .dot, .dotx, .pdf, .pot, .potx, .pps, .ppsx, .ppt, .pptx, .sldx, .wbk, .xlm, .xlsb, .xlsx, .xltx, .xlw

LockerGoga encrypts system files such as DLLs across the C: drive.

If the ransomware is executed with parameter '-w' it will try to encrypt every file it could get.

After the encryption is done, LockerGoga disables all network cards by using Network Command Shell (netsh.exe) process, changes every local administrator password, and logs them off, thus stopping IT from accessing the infected computer with remote tools and forcing them to clean the network endpoint by endpoint.

In order to protect the enterprise from LockerGoga, we suggest monitoring excessive use of new scheduled tasks and/or services, netsh.exe and logoff.exe processes. Implement Microsoft Local Administrator Password Solution to prevent Mimikatz and Pass The Hash attacks. Restrict and monitor access to Active Directory Group Policy Preferences.

In November 2019, the Dutch National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) published a report, naming three ransomware: LockerGoga, MegaCortex, and Ryuk, to be involved in attacks against at least 1,800 organizations while sharing the same infrastructure.

In December 2019, the FBI has issued an alert for the private sector about LockerGoga and MegaCortex ransomware. The alert stated that the two ransomware groups compromised networks across Europe using exploits, phishing, SQL injections, and stolen credentials. Once the network's data is exfiltrated, they encrypt all the connected devices, while disabling security services.

In October 2021, Europol announced the arrest of 12 individuals suspectedly linked to ransomware campaigns set against victims in 71 countries. The suspects deployed ransomware, such as LockerGoga, MegaCortex, and Dharma.

In September 2022, Bitdefender released a free decryptor for the victims of LockerGoga. The free tool is available for download from Bitdefender's servers and enables the recovery of encrypted files without paying a ransom.

content.Overview:
The OriginLogger malware has been active since at least 2018. As a commodity malware sold on underground hacking forums and marketplaces, OriginLogger has a potentially unlimited scope of targeting. The malware is considered the successor of the widely used information stealing malware, Agent Tesla, and was promoted by the Agent Tesla developers after they shut down their malware operation due to legal issues in March 2019. Thus, OriginLogger is often recognized as ‚ÄúAgentTesla v3.‚Äù

OriginLogger is usually distributed as part of phishing campaigns, in which macro-embedded Office documents are sent to the victims, likely through email messages. Once triggered, the VBA macro code leads to the deployment of the OriginLogger payload and its injection into a legitimate process (e.g. aspnet_compiler.exe) using the process hollowing technique. The OriginLogger‚Äôs builder features a command and control (C2) panel that enables its operators to choose the data to be exfiltrated from the victim‚Äôs network, including clipboard data and user credentials from a list of applications, such as web browsers or email clients. OriginLogger is primarily distributed to log user keystrokes and harvest user credentials that can later be used in business email compromise (BEC) scams and further network infiltration. In addition, it can take screenshots, monitor the compromised device‚Äôs webcam, and download additional payloads. The malware uses a variety of exfiltration channels, including SMTP, FTP, web uploads to the OrionLogger panel, and Telegram bots.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In May 2020, OriginLogger was observed to be used by the SilverTerrier threat group in a phishing campaign against over 70,000 targets located in various European countries, such as Italy, Turkey, Greece, Serbia, Croatia, Romania, and Bulgaria. 

In January 2022, Kaspersky researchers reported that OriginLogger was used, among other commodity malware, in the ‚ÄúAnomalous‚Äù spyware campaign that targeted email account credentials of employees in industrial enterprises through spear phishing email messages.

content.Overview:
The PrivateLoader pay-per-install (PPI) malware distribution service, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in February 2022, has been active since at least May 2021. PrivateLoader has been used to deliver a wide variety of globally-distributed malware, such as infostealers, banking Trojans, and ransomware, with significant infections in India and Brazil. The delivered malware include SmokeLoader, RedLine Stealer, Vidar, Raccoon, Dridex, Remcos, LockBit, NanoCore, TrickBot, njRAT, and more. 

PrivateLoader, written in C++, is primarily distributed through pirated software that are promoted to the top of the user‚Äôs search results using SEO poisoning techniques. The loader‚Äôs strings are heavily encrypted and contain junk code to obfuscate the program‚Äôs logic and control flow. Once deployed, PrivateLoader first checks that it is not running in a virtual environment and disables antivirus tools on the infected machine. In addition, it uses XOR to deobfuscate strings, such as the command and control (C2) server address, and then, downloads and executes another dropper component that decrypts the final payload. The malicious payloads are often hosted on Discord or VK. 

PrivateLoader is controlled through a set of C2 servers and has an administrator panel, developed with AdminLTE 3, that enables its operators to add new users, configure the payload‚Äôs download links, choose the targets‚Äô geolocation, and encrypt load files.
content.AdditionalInformation: In September 2022, cybersecurity researchers found connections between PrivateLoader and another PPI platform that was promoted on Russian underground hacking forums by a threat actor named ruzki (AKA les0k, zhigalsz). The threat actor was observed selling bundles of 1,000 installations on infected systems located across the world ($70), or specifically in Europe ($300) or the United States ($1,000). In addition, the researchers found four active PrivateLoader C2 servers located in Russia, the Czech Republic, and Germany.

content.Overview:
The TeamTNT group has been active since at least April 2020. It is known for deploying Monero cryptocurrency worm miners on exposed and misconfigured internet environments. The group compromised Kubernetes clusters, Jenkins build servers, and Docker systems.

In October 2020, Unit 42 researchers discovered several German-language phrases inserted into TeamTNT's cryptocurrency worms, which may indicate the origin of its operators.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In August 2020, Cado Security researchers discovered that the group is using a new variant of cryptocurrency worms. This variant contains advanced data-stealing functionalities that enable the threat group to scan and steal Amazon Web Services (AWS) credentials from infected servers. The worm scans for the credentials of victims that are stored in the AWS command-line interface shell in an unencrypted file. The credentials are then sent to the TeamTNT command and control (C2) server. The advanced variant of TeamTNT‚Äôs worm also scans and steals local credentials from misconfigured Docker systems, looking for open directories, using open ports (such as 2375, 2376, 2377, 4243, or 4244), as well as deploys publicly known offensive security tools, such as SSH post-exploitation tools, an Internet Relay Chat (IRC) backdoor, and the Diamorphine rootkit. Security researchers assume that this is the first cryptomining worm with AWS stealing functionalities.

In October 2020, Palo Alto Network‚Äôs researchers discovered that the group is using additional capabilities to the group's TTP. TeamTNT was observed using a new cryptomining variant dubbed Black-T. Black-T contains network scanning capabilities for identifying victims' exposed Docker APIs.

In December 2020, TeamTNT was observed to use a new IRC bot called TNTbotinger that can initiate distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks.

In January 2021, Trend Micro researchers reported that TeamTNT updated its malware code to make it more organized and descriptive. The threat actors also added a new feature that enables them to collect Docker API credentials, in addition to AWS credentials.

In the same month, AT&T Alien Labs reported that TeamTNT added more tools to its attack arsenal, the Golang-based Ezuri memory loader, and an open-source tool named libprocesshider. The latter was used to hide malicious processes by employing the preloading technique.

In February 2021, TeamTNT was observed using a new malware, dubbed Hildegard, to initiate a cryptojacking campaign targeting Kubernetes clusters. The Hildegard malware enabled the threat actors to gain initial system access, by abusing kubelet‚Äôs API to execute commands inside containers. The new malware featured different obfuscation mechanisms, such as mimicking a known Linux process (bioset) to disguise its activities, using the preloading technique to hide malicious processes, and encrypting its malicious payload inside a binary to make automated static analysis more difficult. In addition, it could use two ways to establish C2 connection, via a tmate reverse shell and an IRC channel. Once infiltrating the system, the threat actors downloaded tmate, a software application that provides a secure terminal sharing solution over an SSH connection, and established a reverse shell to tmate.io. Then, they used masscan to find other unsecured kubelet and deployed a cryptomining script (xmr.sh) to containers managed by these kubelets.

In October 2021, Uptycs researchers reported that TeamTNT was observed to deploy a malicious container image, hosted on Docker Hub under the alias "alpineos." The malicious Docker image had an embedded shell script that was used to download the ZGrab and masscanner scanning tools and find suitable targets. Once found, the threat actors deployed various malware, such as XMRig, the Tsunami IRC bo, and the Diamorphine rootkit.

In November 2021, Trend Micro researchers reported on a new TeamTNT campaign targeting vulnerable Docker servers to install Monero cryptominers. The group used over 150,000 pulls of images from its controlled Docker Hub accounts, to be deployed on the target host.

In April 2022, Cisco Talos researchers reported that TeamTNT modified its scripts to target exposed Docker API instances on Amazon Web Services. The threat actors also attempted to disable cloud security mechanisms, such as Alibaba's aegis cloud security agent, to evade detection and maintain persistence, enabling them to mine cryptocurrency for an extended amount of time.

On September 12, 2022, Trend Micro researchers discovered credentials for at least two DockerHub accounts used by TeamTNT. One of the accounts (alpineos) hosted a malicious container image, downloaded more than 150,000 times, that contained rootkits, kits for Docker container escape, the XMRig Monero miner, the Kinsing malware, credential stealers, and Kubernetes exploit kits. The threat actors were found to log into their DockerHub registry from IP addresses from Germany. Their goal was to exploit the Docker REST API and compromise the underlying server, in order to perform cryptojacking. 

On September 15, 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported three different attack vectors that have been used by TeamTNT in recent campaigns. The first type of attack, named ‚ÄúThe Kangaroo Attack‚Äù after the use of Pollard‚Äôs Kangaroo WIF solver, includes the exploitation of vulnerable Docker Daemons to deploy an AlpineOS image and a shell script (k.sh) that fetches the Bitcoin encryption solvers from GitHub. In the second type of attack, "Cronb Attack," the threat actors deploy shell files that lead to the execution of cron jobs to gain persistence, cryptominers to hijack resources, and rootkits to hide their activity. In addition, this attack includes the theft of SSH keys to conduct lateral movement in the victim's network. The third attack vector, "What Will Be," is similar to the second one, only it includes the exploitation of vulnerable Docker Daemons to deploy Alpine images, before the download and execution of shell scripts, rootkits, a cryptominer, cronjobs, and SSH scanners. In this type of attack, the threat actors added a new trick of optimizing the cryptomining performance by modifying the CPU's specific registers based on the system architecture.

content.Overview:
The GhostSec hacktivist group (AKA Ghost Security, GhostSecMafia, and GSM) has been active since at least 2015. The Anonymous-affiliated group gained prominence with the #OpIsis and #OpParis‚Äã‚Äã (following the Charlie Hebdo shooting in January 2015) campaigns, in which various hacktivist groups took down thousands of ISIS websites and social media accounts using defacement and distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks. Since then, GhostSec participated in other campaigns, such as #OpLebanon, #OpNigeria, #OpMyanmar, #OpEcuador, and #OpColombia. Other than these campaigns, the group has consistently targeted Israeli entities with ‚ÄúFree Palestine‚Äù messages. In addition, GhostSec goes strongly against pedophiles, repeatedly doxxing child molesters and exposing their identities.

GhostSec was co-founded by an online entity called Sebastian Delax or Sebastian Dante Alexander along with another entity that uses the moniker Ghost3301 (stylized as 
∆çHÔºØ·èïT3»úŒüŒô).     

In February 2022, amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War, GhostSec announced its support in Ukraine and took down Russian military and government websites using DDoS attacks. In addition, over the course of the war, the group claimed to access the IT systems of critical infrastructure organizations in Russia, such as Metrospetstekhnika, a provider of Russia‚Äôs metro.   

In June 2022, GhostSec joined the #OpIsrael campaign that targeted multiple Israeli companies while gaining access to their IoT interfaces and ICS/SCADA systems. The group claimed to breach the interfaces of various Israeli organizations, such as the Partner.co.il interface and ELNet, an energy and electrical power meter at MATAM (the Scientific Industries Center). Some of the attacks were made using the Metasploit framework module. 

In September 2022, it was reported that GhostSec compromised 55 Berghof programmable logic controllers (PLCs) used by Israeli organizations. The breach was assumed to be conducted by guessing commonly used login credentials. The group published screenshots from the compromised admin panels and leaked data that was stolen in the attacks.  

The GhostSec members maintain several GitHub accounts that contain commonly used tools. The main repository used by the group, ghostsec420, includes seven repositories, some of which include leaked data (e.g. NigeriaLeaks), vulnerability scanners, and exploits. In addition, the Sophisticated Cyber Penetration Attacks (SCPA) repository contains advanced attack tools and guides from various sources, such as the leaked Conti playbook.

GhostSec also maintains a Pastebin user account, xGhostSecx, that includes anti-Israeli logs from an online reconnaissance tool. The paste contains a target list of several companies‚Äô domains and their corresponding IP addresses. These can later be used to execute malicious activity against them.
content.AdditionalInformation:
As part of its battle against ISIS, GhostSec tipped law enforcement authorities about planned terrorist attacks in New York and Tunisia. This cooperation led the group to ‚Äúbecome legit‚Äù; it renamed itself "Ghost Security Group" (or GSG) and ended its association with Anonymous. Group members who opposed this transition continued their association with Anonymous under the old "GhostSec" umbrella. The ‚Äúlegitimate‚Äù entity operates a clear web website with information about the group‚Äôs activities, while the GhostSec faction operates an active Telegram channel with news about ongoing attacks and data leaks. 

One of the outspoken members of the Ghost Security Group is the Jordanian activist and former beauty queen, Lara Abdallat. 

On September 10, 2022, GhostSec allegedly compromised an Israeli hotel pool system and took control of the pool's pH and chlorine levels. The threat actors seemed to breach two Aegis II controllers exposed to the internet using default passwords.

content.Overview:
The Sparta ransomware group was first observed by cybersecurity researchers in September 2022. The group primarily targets Spanish organizations from various sectors, such as retail, insurance, technology, manufacturing, and industrial engineering. There is little information about the group‚Äôs attack vector.

Sparta operates an active Tor leak site for double extortion purposes.
content.AdditionalInformation: As of September 20, 2022, the Sparta leak site contains entries for 12 organizations, including Ferrer&Ojeda, Tema Litoclean Group, Grupo Galilea, Fundaci√≥ Sant Francesc d'Ass√≠s, Indiba, COMSA Corporaci√≥n, and Sercom Informatica SL.

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The RedLine Stealer malware was first detected in February-March 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic. It was part of a spam email campaign that encouraged victims to help fight the Coronavirus by installing a ‚Äúlegitimate‚Äù application on their system. The malware was offered for sale on several Russian underground forums, with its price varying depending on the version (standalone/subscription) and other customization services sold by the threat actor.

RedLine Stealer, written in C#, is constantly evolving improving its capabilities and efficiency. Its main purpose is to harvest information from the victims‚Äô infected machines such as saved login credentials, credit card numbers, FTP servers, web browser data, instant messaging clients, and cryptocurrency wallet numbers. The malware can bypass security products, steal downloading files, execute commands, and send all the collected data to a remote C&C server that can be managed via a simple GUI command and control (C2) panel.
content.AdditionalInformation:
Since its appearance, RedLine Stealer has been used by threat actors on several campaigns with alternating themes, subjects, or specific audiences.

On February 09, 2021, a security research team reported that threat actors tried to exploit the increasing activity of online gaming users following the COVID-19 outbreak, to spread malicious files with RedLine Stealer on Discord, an instant messaging application commonly used by the gaming community.

In May 2021, researchers identified threat actors who were utilizing pay-per-click (PPC) ads on Google‚Äôs search results to disguise a few malicious packages wrapped as ISO installers of popular apps such as Telegram, AnyDesk, and others.

In June 2021, RedLine operators targeted digital artists using digital tokens tied to digital assets called NFT (Non-Fungible Token). The victims reported being approached by the threat actors on different social media platforms or even directly via email to create new digital art and publish their work for sale on NFT marketplaces.

In December 2021, it was reported that undisclosed threat actors initiated a malspam campaign to distribute malicious Excel XLL files, executing the RedLine Stealer. The malware was used to steal sensitive data, such as user credentials and credit card information, from various types of web browsers (e.g. Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, and Mozilla Firefox). At the end of that month, the "Have I Been Pwned" data breach notification service added approximately 450,000 email addresses stolen by RedLine between August and September 2021. In case your email is listed, it is recommended to change all passwords used on the computer, including corporate VPN and email accounts and personal accounts, and to scan the system using antivirus software.

In the same month, cybersecurity researchers reported that RedLine has a built-in automatic login feature on web browsers. This feature enables it to harvest user credentials from the "Login Data" file found on all Chromium-based web browsers (e.g. Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge). Even when users refuse to store the credentials on the browser, an entry for the user's account is still added to the "Login Data" file and is classified as "blacklisted". Although threat actors do not have access to the credentials found on "blacklisted" account entries, they still know that such accounts exist and might perform some credential-stealing attack via phishing or social engineering.

In January 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on a new RedLine campaign targeting 12 unnamed countries. The malware operators distributed a COVID-19 Omicron file called ‚ÄúOmicron Stats.exe,‚Äù presumably via phishing email messages. Once the file was executed, a new variant of RedLine was deployed onto the victims' networks. The new variant added more data points to exfiltrate, such as the graphics card name, BIOS data, disk drive characteristics, and CPU information. In addition, it can exfiltrate Telegram and Discord data. The new variant also targets additional apps, such as Opera GX web browser, OpenVPN, and ProtonVPN.

In February 2022, it was reported that threat actors started to spread fake Windows 11 upgrade installers to Windows 10 users, tricking them into downloading and executing RedLine stealer. The threat actors used a seemingly legitimate domain to add credibility to their scheme and exhort the victims to download ZIP files with executables that deployed the malware.

In March 2022, ASEC researchers reported on a campaign disguising RedLine as game hacks for Valorant. The threat actors posted links on YouTube, leading to the download of RAR archives with RedLine executables. Once installed, the malware was used to collect general system information, user credentials, web browser data, cryptocurrency information, and more. The stolen information was then packed in a ZIP file and exfiltrated via a WebHook API POST request to a Discord server.

In April 2022, Bitdefender researchers reported on a new RedLine campaign, in which threat actors used the RIG Exploit Kit to distribute their malware. The attackers exploited an Internet Explorer memory corruption vulnerability (CVE-2021-26411) to compromise systems and infect them with the RedLine Stealer in a packed form. It was then unpacked in a six-stage process before being deployed as an obfuscated .NET executable. Once deployed, RedLine established a C2 connection and then could be used to steal and exfiltrate passwords, web browser cookies and stored credit card data, chat logs, VPN login credentials, cryptocurrency information, and more.

In May 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on a new campaign, in which threat actors promoted fake Binance NFT mystery box bots on YouTube to distribute RedLine. The YouTube videos exhorted the victims to download the fake bots, hosted on GitHub, dropping a malicious ZIP file and a Microsoft Visual C++ Redistributable installer. In addition, the ZIP file contained a TXT file with instructions on how to run the installer and in fact execute the RedLine infostealer. The malware was designed to terminate its operation if the host computer is located in one of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), e.g. Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus.

In August 2022, RedLine was observed to be deployed through YouTube videos allegedly guiding users to get paid subscriptions for free, but in fact, tricking them into installing the malicious software. The links to these software were often embedded in the video description.

Also in the same month, Zscaler researchers reported multiple ongoing campaigns, in which threat actors have used SEO poisoning methods to promote malicious pirated software (e.g. Adobe Acrobat Pro) that led to the deployment of RedLine (sometimes RecordBreaker stealer). The malicious executables were hosted on known file hosting services, such as Mediafire, and were downloaded as password-protected ZIP archives to evade antivirus detection. Once unpacked, using an attached text file with the password, the malware loader was executed as an encoded PowerShell command that launched a Windows command prompt (cmd.exe) after a 10 seconds timeout to evade sandbox analysis. Then, the loader connected to a C2 server and executed a DLL file that contained the RedLine Stealer payload.    

On September 6, 2022, Avast researchers reported on the Redline Stealer being distributed through compromised Facebook business pages. The compromised accounts from different countries (Brazil, Mexico, Slovakia, and the Philippines) promoted Trojanized apps, such as Adobe Acrobat Reader, that contained the malware.  

On September 15, 2022, RedLine was reported to be distributed through links to Youtube videos that advertised cheats and cracks to known video games, such as CrossFire, FIFA 22, and Final Fantasy XIV. The links led to the download of self-extracting RAR archives that contained the malware executables.

On September 20, 2022, it was disclosed that the American video game publisher 2K was hacked and its customers were infected with RedLine Stealer. The malware operators gained credentials of one of 2K's vendors and used them to compromise the company's help desk platform and send fake support email messages. Once the recipients opened the support tickets, they received another message that exhorted them to download a ZIP archive with the malware executable.

content.Overview:
AgentTesla is an advanced keylogger whose main abilities are clipboard logging, screen keylogging, screen capturing, and extracting stored passwords from different web browsers.
According to Secureworks, the threat actor behind this keylogger is a Nigerian TA named Gold Galleon.

Credits:https://www.secureworks.com/research/gold-galleon-how-a-nigerian-cyber-crew-plunders-the-shipping-industry

In 2016, researchers discovered an attack chain in which a phishing domain was being used to deliver AgentTesla, with an intent to steal confidential information.
The malicious domain, ‚Äúdiodetechs[.]com‚Äù was imitating diodetech[.]com, which belongs to a legitimate consulting firm that offers a variety of services to global enterprises.

In 2017, Fortinet researchers discovered a new AgentTesla variant that spreads via a Microsoft Word document that contained an auto-executable malicious VBA Macro. This new variant can collect user credentials from the system registry, local profile files, and SQLite database files.

In September 2017, a new obfuscation method was discovered by Palo Alto researchers with a JPG icon trying to create an illusion of legitimacy.

In 2018, a new variant of AgentTesla was spread via a Microsoft Word document that contained an embedded EXE file.

In 2019, a series of malicious email campaigns distributing Microsoft Word and Microsoft Excel attachments containing the WhiteShadow downloader used AgentTesla as one of their payloads.

In March 2020, Proofpoint researchers reported that they tracked attackers leveraging the coronavirus pandemic since January. The researchers found an email containing an attachment named ‚ÄúCOVID 19_List_cities_names.xlam‚Äù which downloaded And activated AgentTesla while opening it.

In April 2020, Palo Alto researchers reported regarding another campaign leveraging the coronavirus pandemic in which AgentTesla observed attacking a Canadian government healthcare organization and a Canadian medical research university.

On April 16, 2020, Malwarebytes researchers discovered that a new AgentTesla variant steals WiFi credentials.

In May 2020, a series of malspam campaigns dating back to November of 2019 was observed by Sophos researchers in which an unidentified group sent out waves of installers that drop remote administration tools (RAT) and information-stealing malware on victims‚Äô computers. One of the tools used in this campaign was AgentTesla.

In January 2021, ESET researchers discovered several attacks targeting Colombian entities related to the energy and metallurgical sectors. In this campaign, the targeted entities received an email with an attached PDF with an embedded link that downloads the AgentTesla keylogger after being opened.

In February 2021, Sophos researchers discovered that two new variants of this RAT are targeting Microsoft Anti-Malware Software Interface (AMSI), scanning and analysis software designed to prevent malware infections from taking hold.

In September 2022, Agent Tesla was observed being distributed as part of spam email messages with the senders pretending to be residents of non-English-speaking countries (e.g. Bulgaria or Malaysia). The messages were added with real logos and seemingly legitimate signatures to add credibility and contained ZIP attachments with the malware executables. According to Kaspersky, the malware‚Äôs activity from May till August 2022 was the highest in Europe, Asia, and Latin America, with the largest number of victims (20,941) recorded in Mexico, followed by Spain (18,090) and Germany (14,880).
content.AdditionalInformation: Known to leave open and accessible  web directories with payloads in its C&C server.

content.Overview:
The Scarlet Mimic threat group has been active since at least 2012. Although it is not directly associated with any governmental entity, its primary targets, minority rights activists in China (e.g. Uyghur and Tibetan), are compatible with the interests of the Chinese government. The group was also observed operating against government organizations in Russia and India, nations that track activists and terrorists.

Scarlet Mimic usually distributes its malware on PC and mobile devices through watering hole attacks or spear phishing email messages that contain decoy documents exploiting various software vulnerabilities (e.g. Microsoft Office and Adobe Reader). Some of the decoy documents are created using different toolkits, such as MNKit, WingD, and Tran Duy Linh. In addition, in some cases, the phishing email messages contain self-extracting RAR archives that use the right-to-left override character to mask the real file extension.

After gaining initial access, the group deploys the FakeM custom backdoor that has evolved over time to include functionalities such as logging user keystrokes, stealing user credentials, taking screenshots, and uploading files, all while maintaining a connection to a command and control (C2) server. The original FakeM backdoor masks its C2 communication by mimicking legitimate messenger applications, such as MSN and Yahoo! messengers; however, more advanced variants use SSL for encrypting C2 communication. The backdoor is deployed using nine different malware loaders, such as CrypticConvo, SkiBoot, and RaidBase.

Cybersecurity researchers observed some overlaps of the IP addresses used by Scarlet Mimic and the APT2 threat group (AKA Putter Panda); however, no solid link could be established between the groups.

Other malware that have been used by Scarlet Mimic include: FakeHighFive, PiggyBack, FullThrottle, FakeFish, BrutishCommand, SubtractThis, CallMe, MobileOrder, and Psylo.
content.AdditionalInformation: In September 2022, Check Point researchers reported a long-running Scarlet Mimic campaign against the Uyghur community that has been active since at least 2015. In the course of the campaign, the threat actors have used 20 different variants of the MobileOrder Android malware and distributed it through seemingly legitimate applications often masqueraded as PDF documents of books, photos, or audio files of the Quran. The malware could be used to collect device information, access and manipulate SMS, steal call logs and local files, record audio, and take screenshots. In addition, some of the malware versions asked for Device Admin and root access that granted the threat actors full control over the device.

content.Overview:
The Void Balaur threat group (AKA Rockethack, Hacknet), first reported by Trend Micro researchers in November 2021, has been active since at least September 2015. The Russian hacker-for-hire group targets organizations and individuals across the globe, from various sectors, such as government, telecommunications, retail, finance, media, and biotechnology. Most of the targets are located in Russia and surrounding countries.

Void Balaur sells access to webmail email accounts (e.g. Gmail, Protonmail, and Yandex), corporate email accounts, and social networks (e.g. Telegram, Facebook, and Instagram). The group‚Äôs services also include launching distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks and distributing phone spam messages (only in the Commonwealth of Independent States). The threat actors publish their services on dedicated websites and on Russian hacking forums, such as Darkmoney, Probiv, Tenec, and Dublikat.

In 2019, the group started to sell stolen data of individuals, including passport information, traffic camera snapshots, weapon registration, criminal records, credit history, and bank statements. In addition, Void Balaur sells data from cellular services, such as phone numbers, phone and SMS logs, phone or SIM card location, and text messages. This data is assumed to be acquired through insiders working at telecom companies. In addition, Void Balaur was observed using phishing domains to obtain user credentials, especially for cryptocurrency wallets of various exchange services (e.g. Binance, EXMO, BitPay, and YoBit). The group uses different types of infostealers and spyware for Windows and Android, such as Z*Stealer and DroidWatcher, which are deployed using a Delphi-based loader.

Void Balaur‚Äôs activity was connected to various incidents: an attack against human rights activists and journalists in Uzbekistan in 2016, against political entities in Belarus in 2020, and against government ministers in 2021. Also, in a long-running campaign that took place between September 2020 and August 2021, Void Balaur targeted high-level executives in a large Russian corporation.

Cybersecurity researchers found some overlap between Void Balaur and the Russian state-sponsored group APT28 (AKA Fancy Bear), in terms of victimology and obtained data; however, there is no solid proof of a collaboration between the two groups.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In June 2022, Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) announced that it blocked dozens of malicious domains and websites that were used as part of the infrastructure of hacker-for-hire groups, such as Void Balaur. The malicious infrastructure was used by Void Balaur to conduct phishing attacks for credential harvesting and to advertise the group‚Äôs services.

In September 2022, SentinelOne researchers reported that Void Balaur expanded its target range to include organizations and individuals with business or political interests related to Russia. In addition, the researchers managed to link Void Balaur‚Äôs infrastructure to the Russian Federal Protective Service (FSO), suggesting government involvement in the hacker group's activity.

content.Overview:
Fancy Bear (AKA APT 28, Pawn Storm, Sofacy Group, Sednit, and Strontium) is a state-sponsored hacking group associated with the Russian military intelligence agency GRU. The group has been active since 2007 and usually targets privileged information related to government, military, and security organizations. Among the Russian APT groups, Fancy Bear dominated in 2017, especially at the end of that year.

Between February 10 and 14, 2015, during the ceasefire in Donbas (East Ukraine), APT 28 scanned 8,536,272 Ukrainian IP addresses for possible vulnerabilities. After February 14, 2015, APT28 shifted its attention to the west. They have also scanned for vulnerabilities in these countries: Spain, the UK, Portugal, the USA, and Mexico.

According to the UK foreign secretary, Dominic Raab, APT28 was responsible for the 2015 cyber attacks on Germany‚Äôs Parliament. The official also said: ‚ÄúThe UK stands shoulder to shoulder with Germany and our European partners to hold Russia to account for cyberattacks designed to undermine Western democracies. This criminal behavior brings the Russian Government into further disrepute.‚Äù

In November 2017, it became known that Fancy Bear has actively exploited a newly discovered Microsoft Office vulnerability. Various widespread cyberattack campaigns were used to abuse it in the wild to infect several organizations with malware.

Microsoft‚Äôs feature, Dynamic Data Exchange (DDE), can be leveraged to perform code execution on the targeted device without requiring enabled macros or memory corruption. DDE protocol is one of several methods that Microsoft uses to allow two running applications to share the same data. The protocol is being used by many Microsoft apps.

Fancy Bear hackers leveraged the DDE vulnerability in October 2016. The campaign involved documents referencing a recent terrorist attack in New York in an attempt to trick victims into clicking on the malicious documents, which eventually infects their systems with malware. Since DDE is a Microsoft legitimate feature, most antivirus solutions don't flag any warning or block the documents with DDE fields.

In December 2017, it became known that Fancy Bear also targeted hundreds of journalists. At least 200 journalists have been targeted in a long-term attack that started as early as 2014. The list of victims included: 50 New York Times journalists, a Washington Post columnist, and a Daily Beast reporter. Along with American journalists, the attackers also tried to hack Ukrainian and Russian media personnel. According to the journalists, they have experienced spear-phishing attacks for years in an attempt to hack networks and access sources and information. In 2017, Fancy Bear also hacked Google accounts belonging to US military officials and various journalists.

In previous years, the group had been connected to the Hillary Clinton emails leak and the hack of the Olympic games, among other campaigns and attacks.

The most notable APT28 presumed targets are the American Democratic National Committee, the German parliament, and the French television network TV5Monde.
content.AdditionalInformation:
In August 2020, a joint report of the NSA and the FBI was released, in which they attributed a new malware to APT28 named Drovorub. Drovorub is a Linux malware consisting of an implant coupled with a kernel module rootkit, a file transfer, and port forwarding tool, and a command and control (C2) server. When deployed on a victim machine, the Drovorub implant (client) provides the capability for direct communications with the actor-controlled C2 infrastructure, file download and upload capabilities, execution of arbitrary commands as "root," and port forwarding of network traffic to other hosts on the network.

Also in the same month, the QuoIntelligence team disseminated a warning to its government customers in Europe about a new APT28 campaign. This campaign targets government bodies of NATO members (or countries cooperating with NATO). The researchers discovered a malicious file uploaded to VirusTotal, which ultimately drops a Zebrocy malware and communicates with a C2 in France.

In September 2020, Microsoft researchers reported that state-sponsored Russian hacking group APT28 was observed targeting organizations and individuals involved in the US presidential election. According to the researchers, the group‚Äôs efforts are focused on stealing the targets' credentials and compromising their accounts to potentially disrupt the elections and to harvest intelligence to be used as part of future attacks.

In addition, the U.S Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA)
published that they responded to a recent threat actor cyberattack on a federal agency enterprise network. By leveraging compromised credentials, the threat actor implanted sophisticated malware including multi-stage malware that evaded the affected agency‚Äôs anti-malware protection and gained persistent access through two reverse Socket Secure (SOCKS) proxies that exploited weaknesses in the agency‚Äôs firewall.

In October 2020, the UK announced it will enforce asset freezes and travel bans against two Russian GRU officers and APT28, aka Fancy Bear.

On November 13, 2020, Microsoft said it detected three state-sponsored APTs that have launched cyberattacks on at least seven prominent companies involved in COVID-19 vaccine research and treatments. The targeted companies were located in Canada, France, India, South Korea, and the US. Microsoft traced the attacks to the Russian-based APT28, the North Korean-based group Lazarus, aka Zink, and the Cerium groups.

On December 1, 2020, the Norwegian secret service published a press release saying that APT28 was most likely responsible for hacking the email accounts of the Norwegian Parliament in August 2020.

On December 9, 2020, Intezer labs wrote that in November 2020, they uncovered COVID-19 phishing lures that were used to deliver the Go version of Zebrocy- a known APT28 malware. The lures consisted of documents about Sinopharm International Corporation (a pharmaceutical company that is currently going through phase three clinical trials of the COVID-19 vaccine) and an impersonated evacuation letter from the Directorate General of Civil Aviation. The lure was delivered as part of a virtual hard drive file that requires victims to use Windows 10 to access the files. APT28 has employed password spraying and brute-force login attempts to obtain login credentials, break into victim accounts and steal sensitive information.

In May 2021, a security research team published a report regarding a new malware named ‚ÄúSkinnyBoy‚Äù attributed to APT28. The malware was used in spear phishing campaigns that started in early March, targeting government and military sectors and other political organizations. The victims received a spoofed invitation to an international scientific event held in Spain. While most of the victims were from the European Union, organizations in the United States were also impacted.

In July 2021, a joint advisory by American and British agencies warned about an ongoing global brute force campaign conducted by APT28. According to the advisory, the group uses containers to easily scale its brute force attempts. Upon obtaining credentials, the group exploited several vulnerabilities, including CVE 2020-0688 and CVE 2020-17144 for remote code execution on Microsoft Exchange servers.
The campaign was focused on US and European organizations from the following sectors: government, aerospace and defense, media, energy, legal, and education.

In October 2021, Google issued a warning that the group initiated a phishing campaign the previous month, targeting approximately 14 thousand Gmail users. However, the company claimed that the emails were classified as spam, and thus, not all of the accounts were compromised.

In March 2022, researchers from Google‚Äôs Threat Analysis Group (TAG) reported on several large credential phishing campaigns that were conducted by APT28 against users of a Ukrainian media company (UkrNet), amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War. The phishing email messages were sent from various compromised accounts and directed users to domains under the attackers' control. In some instances, the threat actors used Blogspot domains as initial landing sites that redirected users to credential harvesting pages. The observed phishing domains were blocked by Google.

In April 2022, Microsoft announced that it shut down domains that were used by APT28 to attack Ukrainian entities during the Russo-Ukrainian War. In addition, they were used to target US and EU government institutions and think tanks that deal with foreign policy.

In May 2022, Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) reported on five active threat groups, including APT28, targeting organizations and individuals in Eastern Europe. APT28 specifically targeted Ukrainian users with phishing email messages with password-protected ZIP files. These files contained malicious .Net executables that were used to steal web browser cookies and saved passwords.

In addition, the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) reported on an APT28 phishing campaign, in which the threat actors sent email messages impersonating the cybersecurity agency. The messages contained RAR archives with SFX files, distributing the malicious program CredoMap_v2. The program used HTTP POST requests to send stolen user credentials to a web resource, hosted on the Pipedream platform.

On June 17, 2022, the German Attorney General issued an arrest warrant for the Russian hacker Nikolaj Kozachek (AKA ‚Äúblabla1234565‚Äù and ‚Äúkazak‚Äù), linked to APT28, for initiating a cyber espionage attack against the NATO think tank Joint Air Power Competence Center in Germany. According to the findings of the German authorities, in April 2017, Kozachek hacked the IT systems of the NATO think tank in Kalkar and installed a keylogger to steal sensitive information. The cyber campaign was assumed to be conducted on behalf of the Russian military intelligence service (GRU).

On June 20, 2022, the CERT-UA warned that APT28 was observed exploiting the Follina MSDT zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2022-30190), as part of a phishing campaign against critical infrastructure in Ukraine. The threat actors sent malicious documents exploiting the vulnerability to deploy Cobalt Strike and a previously unknown malware named CredoMap. CredoMap was found to be an information-stealing malware, gathering and exfiltrating web browser data, such as user credentials and cookies.

On September 23, 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported a new code execution technique that has been employed by APT28. The technique involves the tracking of mouse movement over hyperlinks in Microsoft PowerPoint presentations, to trigger a malicious PowerShell script using the SyncAppvPublishingServer utility. The PowerShell script leads to the deployment of an encrypted DLL in the form of a JPEG file, which is executed through the rundll32.exe process. Then, another JPEG file is deployed and loaded into memory, leading to the download of the Graphite malware, which abuses the Microsoft Graph API and OneDrive for C2 communications to fetch additional payloads. This novel APT28 technique enables the threat actors to infect systems without using traditional malicious macro codes. 

On the same day, Mandiant researchers connected APT28 to the activity of three Telegram channels, ‚ÄúXakNet Team,‚Äù ‚ÄúInfoccentr,‚Äù and ‚ÄúCyberArmyofRussia_Reborn.‚Äù The channels have been operated by hacktivist groups of the same names that have conducted distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks and website defacements against Ukrainian entities. In addition, the hacktivist groups have used their Telegram channels to leak stolen data, some of which was obtained through APT28 campaigns.   

     
CISA recommends:

Deploy an Enterprise Firewall
Organizations should deploy an enterprise firewall to control what is allowed in and out of their network. If the organization chooses not to deploy an enterprise firewall, it should work with the internet service provider to ensure that the firewall is configured properly.

Block Unused Ports
Organizations should conduct a survey of the traffic in and out of their enterprise to determine the ports needed for organizational functions. They should then configure their firewall to block unnecessary ports. Organizations should develop a change control process to make control changes to those rules. Of special note is the blocking of unused SMB, SSH, and FTP ports.

Implement multi-factor authentication, especially for privileged accounts.
Use separate administrative accounts on separate administration workstations.
Implement the principle of least privilege on data access.
Secure RDP and other remote access solutions using multifactor authentication and ‚Äújump boxes‚Äù for access.
Deploy and maintain endpoint defense tools on all endpoints.

Credits:
https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-enforces-new-sanctions-against-russia-for-cyber-attack-on-german-parliament
https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-268a
https://www.wired.com/story/russias-fancy-bear-hack-us-federal-agency/
https://cluster25.io/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/2021-05_FancyBear.pdf (Yara Rules included)
https://labs.sentinelone.com/a-deep-dive-into-zebrocys-dropper-docs/ (Yara Rules included)

Techniques.Name: Exfiltration Over Asymmetric Encrypted Non-C2 Protocol

content.Overview:
At the beginning of 2022, the geopolitical tension between Russia and Ukraine reached a peak and started to crack into the cyberworld.

On January 14, 2022, Ukraine suffered an extensive cyberattack, in which 15 government websites were defaced. The websites displayed a message in Russian, Ukrainian, and Polish, stating that all the data on the computer was destroyed and mentioning some politically disputed Polish and Ukrainian regions. The Ukrainian government blamed the UNC1151 APT group (AKA Ghostwriter) for the campaign. The Belarusian state-sponsored group, presumably supported by Russia, was responsible for the Ghostwriter disinformation campaign that was initiated in March 2017. The campaign targeted European countries such as Lithuania, Latvia, and Poland, with the aim of spreading narratives that object to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization‚Äôs (NATO) presence in Eastern Europe.

In addition to the aforementioned attack, various Ukrainian organizations were infected with a new malware, dubbed WhisperGate. The malware was disguised as ransomware, but in fact only acted to wipe the disk and cause damage. These attacks were attributed to a previously unknown threat actor, dubbed DEV-0586. The Secret Service of Ukraine confirmed that the two incidents are related and that the threat actors exploited the critical Log4j vulnerabilities in some of the attacks.

On February 8, 2022, the Security Service of Ukraine stated that they uncovered and dismantled two bot farms based in Lviv that were allegedly used for managing 18,000 fake mobile accounts. These accounts were directed from Russia to spread fake news across social media, in order to create panic among the Ukrainian population.

On February 15, 2022, distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks, later attributed to the Russian GRU, were initiated against Ukraine‚Äôs Ministry of Defense, Armed Forces, and two state-owned banks. The attacks caused interruptions in the web services of the targeted organizations. In addition, cybersecurity researchers reported that the Gamaredon group attempted to compromise an undisclosed Western government entity operating in Ukraine. This was done as part of a phishing campaign in which the threat actors leveraged a Ukrainian job search and employment platform to upload a malware downloader masquerading as a resume for a job ad that was posted by the targeted organization.

On February 23, 2022, Russia started its armed invasion of Ukraine, which was followed by another set of DDoS attacks hitting several Ukrainian government agencies and two of the largest state-owned banks in the country. These attacks are probably also a product of the Russian government, trying to rattle the stability of Ukraine in the country. At the same time, cybersecurity researchers discovered a new data wiping malware, dubbed HermeticWiper (AKA KillDisk.NCV), that infected hundreds of Ukrainian machines in the last two months. The malware disguises as a ransomware, dropping a ransom note with a political message, but in fact deletes the data that is stored on the infected machines and shuts them down.

On February 24, 2022, the Anonymous hacktivist group officially declared a cyberwar against the Russian government. Anonymous propagated DDoS attacks against websites belonging to the Russian government, state-owned media outlets, such as RT News, and national banks. The attacks forced the shutdown of hundreds of websites, with some of them displaying political messages criticizing Russia and supporting Ukraine. In addition, the attackers leaked information allegedly belonging to Russia and its supporters, such as the email accounts of Belarusian weapons maker, Tetraedr, that was accused of providing logistical support to Russia.

This attack was followed by a statement made by the Ukrainian Minister for Digital Transformation Mykhaylo Fedorov, calling for volunteers to join Ukraine‚Äôs ‚ÄúIT army‚Äù and initiate cyberattacks against Russian entities.

On February 25, 2022, the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) warned about a spear phishing campaign that was attributed to UNC1151, targeting Ukrainian armed forces personnel. The attackers compromised the email accounts of their targets and sent phishing messages to their contact list.

In addition, the CERT UA attributed the UAC-0056 threat group (AKA TA471) with an attack against a Ukrainian energy organization. The threat actors used spear phishing email messages, allegedly on behalf of the National Police of Ukraine, suggesting that a certain individual (Belous Alexei Sergeevich) had committed a crime. This attack was associated with a larger campaign that was initiated by the group against Ukrainian entities from the beginning of 2021.

Also on February 25, 2022, the Conti ransomware group announced its support for the Russian government's attack on Ukraine. In addition, the threat actors threatened to attack the critical infrastructure of countries acting against Russia. In response, a Ukrainian security researcher leaked over 60,000 internal messages belonging to the Conti ransomware operation.

On February 26, 2022, the Anonymous-affiliated group, Network Battalion 65' (NB65), announced that they hacked the Nuclear Safety Institute of Moscow, followed by a release of 40,000 files associated with the leak.

On February 27, 2022, Anonymous announced that they breached the Belarusian railways, disrupting its services. The attack forced the Belarusian railways to switch to manual control mode, slowing down its operations.

In addition, the Russian-supporter Stormous group started shifting its focus towards Ukraine and US-based companies, publishing a leak from a Ukraine-based design company that creates drafts and plans for aircraft engines, followed by a leak from the Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and a US-based company.

On February 28, 2022, Anonymous took down more than 1,500 websites of the Russian and Belarusian governments, state media outlets, banks, and companies.

On March 1, 2022, the AgainstTheWest hacker group, connected to Anonymous, claimed to hack the Russian state-owned Sberbank bank and threatened to leak its data, including DNS infrastructure, private keys for SSL, Sberbank API, CLI, and SDKs. In addition, the group hacked the Russian tool manufacturer NPKTAIR, a Russian financial holding (OJSC Ak Bars Holding), and a Russian plane tracking system. The latter hack enabled the group members to view important flights information and also change their details.

On the other side, Stormous announced its "support for the Russian government" stating: "if any party in different parts of the world decides to organize a cyber-attack or cyber-attacks against Russia, we will be in the right direction and will make all our efforts to abandon the supplication of the West, especially the infrastructure." The group published a leak from a US-based fiberglass fabricator of composite-based products and parts for the military and commercial markets.

In addition, cybersecurity researchers reported on two novel malware that were used by Russian threat actors against Ukrainian entities. The first is IsaacWiper that was used to attack a Ukrainian government network and wipe its data. On some occasions, the malware was deployed alongside the RemCom remote access tool, which may imply a connection between both malware. The second reported malware is HermeticRansom (AKA PartyTicket, Elections GoRansom) that was observed to be distributed alongside the HermeticWiper malware, probably in an attempt to obscure the latter‚Äôs activity. Once deployed, the ransomware encrypts the files that are stored upon the victim‚Äôs computer, while dropping a ransomware note referencing a statement made by the United States President Joe Biden.

Furthermore, Proofpoint researchers reported on a phishing campaign, dubbed Asylum Ambuscade, that was likely conducted by nation-state sponsored threat actors targeting European government entities responsible for the logistics of the Ukrainian refugees (including transportation, budget allocation, administration, and population movement) within Europe. The campaign included the deployment of a Lua-based malware, named SunSeed. The Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) attributed the campaign to the UNC1151 APT group (AKA Ghostwriter) that was previously observed targeting NATO personnel; however, the researchers noted that this attribution is not definite.

On March 2, 2022, the Anonymous-affiliated group, NB65, shut down the Control Center of the Russian Space Agency "Roscosmos." In addition, another Anonymous-affiliated group, Ghost Squad, took down the Russian military air force website.

On the Russian end, Stormous announced they breached a school district in Phoenix, Arizona. In addition, it released login details of two US-based companies, an IT services company located in Palo Alto, California, and a company from the aerospace industry located in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.

On March 3, 2022, Anonymous and its affiliates hacked and leaked the access to the phone directory of the military prosecutor's office of the southern military district of Russia, as well as documents from the Rosatom State Atomic Energy Corporation. In addition, El Patron and other Anonymous affiliates took down the Russian news website lenta.ru.

On March 4, 2022, Anonymous announced that since the beginning of the Russo-Ukrainian War they hacked more than 2,500 websites linked to the Russian and Belarusian governments, state-owned media outlets spreading disinformation, Russian private organizations, banks, hospitals, and airports. Anonymous also leaked the database of the Russian Government website (gov.ru), including subdomains and back-end IPs for every server, and the website of the Ministry of Economic Development of Russia. In addition, the AgainstTheWest group claimed that it breached and leaked the database of the Russian energy corporation giant Gazprom.

On March 6, 2022, Anonymous hacked the Russian streaming services Wink and Ivi and the live TV channels Russia 24, Channel One, and Moscow 24. The group used these channels to broadcast war footage, demonstrating the Russian aggression against Ukrainian citizens.

On March 7, AnonGhost, affiliated with Anonymous, claimed to have hacked and shut down two Russian SCADA water supply systems.

In addition, researchers from Google‚Äôs Threat Analysis Group (TAG) reported on several large credential phishing campaigns that were conducted by APT28 against users of a Ukrainian media company (UkrNet), amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War. The phishing email messages were sent from various compromised accounts and directed users to domains under the attackers' control. In some instances, the threat actors used Blogspot domains as initial landing sites that redirected users to credential harvesting pages. The observed phishing domains were blocked by Google. The Google researchers also reported that UNC1151 actively conducts phishing campaigns against Polish and Ukrainian government and military organizations, while targeting webmail users from the following providers: i.ua, meta.ua, rambler.ru, ukr.net, wp.pl and yandex.ru. In addition, Google blocked phishing domains that were used in these campaigns.

On March 8, 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on a novel malware targeting Russia. The RURansom wiping malware is a new variant of an existing wiper and was used to encrypt files and then delete them. The keys are unique for each encrypted file and are not stored anywhere, making the encryption irreversible and marking the malware as a wiper rather than a ransomware variant, because of its irreversible destruction of encrypted files.

On March 9, 2022, Anonymous hacked more than 400 public cameras in Russia and broadcasted the live feeds of private businesses, restaurants, offices, schools, and more. In addition, the hackers displayed the message: "Putin is killing children, 352 Ukraine civilians dead. Russians lied to 200RF.com."

On March 10, 2022, Anonymous announced that they hacked Roskomnadzor, the Russian Federal Service for Supervision of Communications, Information Technology, and Mass Media. According to the group, the government agency controlled the disinformation campaign about the invasion of Ukraine and was responsible for censoring the Russian mass media. The hackers leaked 820 GB of data detailing the agency's activity.

In addition, Cisco Talos researchers reported on a new campaign set against the supporters of Ukraine leveraging people's willingness to help the country, in order to infect them with malware. The researchers observed threat actors using Telegram to promote a fake DDoS tool called "Liberator" allegedly meant to shut down "Russian propaganda websites." However, instead, the tool dropped the Phoenix infostealer into the victims' computers. Once deployed, the malware can collect web browser data, filesystem locations, and cryptocurrency information. Then, the obtained data was exfiltrated to a remote server with Russian IP.

On March 14, 2022, Anonymous claimed to hack the German branch of the Russian energy giant Rosneft, stealing 20 TB of data.

In addition, a new wiping malware, dubbed CaddyWiper, was observed by cybersecurity researchers in attacks against Ukrainian organizations. Once installed, the malware was used to destroy and overwrite the data from any drives that were attached to the compromised system. To maintain system access, it avoided erasing data on domain controllers.

On March 15, 2022, SentinelOne researchers reported that UAC-0056 targeted Ukrainian entities using a malicious Python-based package, masquerading as a Ukrainian language translation software. Once installed, the fake app deployed various malware, such as Cobalt Strike, GrimPlant, and GraphSteel.

On March 17, 2022, Anonymous announced that they breached Omega, the R&D division of the Transneft oil company. The threat actors claimed to steal 79 GB of data from the Russian state-controlled company. The allegedly stolen data included email messages and their contents, such as invoices and product shipment information.

On the same day, the Russian federal veterinary and phytosanitary supervision service, Rosselkhoznadzor, announced that the largest meat producer and distributor in Russia, Miratorg Agribusiness Holding, suffered a ransomware attack affecting 15 of its subsidiaries. The attack is assumed to be conducted by Western entities using Windows BitLocker, with sabotage motives rather than financial ones. Miratorg representatives stated that they work to restore their business to full capacity and that the supply and shipments to Russian citizens should be unaffected.

On March 18, 2022, the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) warned against phishing campaigns targeting Ukrainian organizations while spreading the LoadEdge backdoor. The phishing campaigns were attributed to the InvisiMole threat group (AKA UAC-0035), which is linked to the Russian APT Gamaredon.

On March 20, 2022, Anonymous warned Western companies to immediately pull their business from Russia or get hacked. A day later, the group fulfilled its threats with an attack on Nestl√©, leaking 10GB of allegedly stolen data, including email messages, user passwords, and customer information.

On March 22, 2022, the Computer Emergency Response Team of Ukraine (CERT-UA) warned against spear-phishing attacks targeting Ukrainian organizations and distributing the DoubleZero wiper. The attacks were attributed to the UAC-0088 threat group.

In addition, the CERT-UA reported on a Chinese APT group named Scarab (AKA UAC-0026) targeting Ukrainian entities. The group used phishing email messages with malicious macro-embedded documents to deploy the HeaderTip backdoor (formerly Scieron). The C++-based malware can collect general system information, such as the computer name and OS version, download and execute additional files, exfiltrate files from the victim‚Äôs computer, delete files, list directories, and move files to other folders. In addition, it can be used as a first-stage malware loader to fetch a tool with rootkit functionalities that can create and terminate processes, read, write, and delete registry entries and directories, launch remote shells, and more.

On March 23, 2022, the CERT-UA reported that UNC1151 deployed Cobalt Strike beacons in the devices of Ukrainian entities, using phishing email messages with macro-embedded documents.

On March 24, 2022, Anonymous claimed to compromise the Central Bank of Russia, allegedly stealing 35,000 files to be leaked in 48 hours. The group fulfilled its threats, leaking 28 GB of stolen data allegedly belonging to the bank.

On the same day, US government officials stated that the Russian military was responsible for a cyberattack on the KA-SAT satellite broadband network, owned by Viasat. The attack occurred on February 24, the day of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and is believed to have caused severe communications disruptions in Ukraine and the surrounding areas. About a week later, Viasat confirmed the cyberattack and SentinelOne researchers attributed it to a novel wiping malware dubbed AcidRain. AcidRain shares similarities with the VPNFilter stage 3 plugin ‚Äúdstr,‚Äù a wiper that was previously used by Russian state-sponsored APT groups, such as APT28 (AKA Fancy Bear) and Sandworm. Thus, it is assumed to be operated by the Russian government as well.

On March 25, 2022, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) added the Russian antivirus firm Kaspersky to the list of "communications equipment and services that pose an unacceptable risk to national security or the security and safety of U.S. persons." This is due to the company's perceived risk to engage in espionage and harm the United States. The FCC also added to the list the Chinese mobile service providers China Mobile International USA and China Telecom Americas. It means that three companies can no longer receive support through the FCC's Universal Service Fund. The FCC's decision follows the warning that was made by the German Federal Office for Information Security agency (BSI) against using Kaspersky products. In addition, HackerOne blocked Kaspersky's access to the platform and suspended its bug bounty program.

On the same day, the Anonymous-affiliated group NB65 claimed to hack the All-Russia State Television and Radio Broadcasting Company (VGTRK), accusing them of spreading Putin's propaganda. In addition, the hackers allegedly stole 870 GB of data from the company.

On March 28, 2022, Uktrtelecom, Ukraine's biggest fixed line telecommunications company, confirmed that it suffered a cyberattack disrupting its services across the country. The attack was considered by some as the most severe cyberattack since the start of the war. The identity of the attackers was not disclosed, but they are assumed to be Russian supporters. In addition, it is unclear whether it was a DDoS attack or something else.

On the same day, Anonymous claimed to hack the Russian construction company Rostproekt, leaking 2.4 GB of emails, allegedly belonging to the company. In addition, the group announced that it hacked the Russian manufacturer MashOiL, stealing and publishing approximately 140,000 of the company's email messages.

In addition, the Ukrainian Security Service (SSU) announced that since the beginning of the war, it has shut down five bot farms with over 100,000 fake social media accounts spreading fake news. The SSU attributed the actions to the Russian special services, wishing to destabilize the sociopolitical situation in Ukraine.

On March 29, 2022, the CERT-UA reported on a phishing campaign that was conducted by the Russian threat group Gamaredon, targeting Ukrainian entities. The phishing messages were used to distribute a C++-based malware dubbed PseudoSteel.

Also, the pro-Russian group of hacktivists, Killnet, claimed to breach the Bradley International Airport in Connecticut, in response to the United States military support to Ukraine.

On the same day, the Russian Civil Aviation Authority Rosaviatsiya was attacked by unnamed threat actors, erasing 65 TB of data and collapsing the government agency‚Äôs network. It was reported that at least some of the data had no backups and could not be restored. The attack was initially attributed to Anonymous, however, the group denied any relation to the incident and stated that they do not engage in cyberterrorism.

In addition, the Anonymous-affiliated group AgainstTheWest claimed to breach multiple Chinese organizations for supporting Russia. These include Alibaba Cloud, Amazon China, JD, Bank of China, All-China Federation of Trade Union, and others. The group also claimed that they stole data from the compromised companies to be gradually leaked on a dedicated website.

On March 30, 2022, Anonymous leaked 5,500 emails that were allegedly stolen from the Russian investment firm Thozis Corp, owned by the Russian oligarch Zakhar Smushkin. Some of the emails contained sensitive information about deals and investments that were made by the company. The group stated that the attack's goal was to put pressure on the Russian oligarchs supporting the Russian economy.

In addition, Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) reported on three threat actors operating in Eastern Europe. The report highlighted Callisto (AKA COLDRIVER), which initiated credential phishing campaigns against multiple entities siding with Ukraine, such as US non-government organizations and think tanks, and the NATO Centre of Excellence.

On March 31, 2022, Anonymous continued to hit companies owned by Russian oligarchs with a breach of the Russian investment company Marathon Group, owned by Alexander Vinokuro. In addition, the group leaked 62,000 emails allegedly belonging to the company.

On April 1, 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported that UAC-0056 targeted several Ukrainian entities, including the ICTV TV channel. The threat actors used spear phishing email messages with malicious macro-embedded Excel documents. These were used to install the Golang-based Elephant dropper and downloader, leading to the deployment of the GrimPlant and GraphSteel backdoors. The backdoors established command and control (C2) communication and exfiltrated stolen data, including general system information, browser credentials, and WiFi information.

In addition, Anonymous claimed to hack the Russian Orthodox Church‚Äôs charitable wing, leaking 15 GB of data, including around 57,000 emails, allegedly belonging to the church.

On April 4, 2022, the CERT-UA reported on phishing campaigns that were conducted by Gamaredon, targeting Ukrainian government agencies and institutions belonging to the European Union. The phishing messages contained attachments with lures concerning the Russo-Ukrainian War. These attachments eventually led to the download of an HTA file containing a VBScript. Then, the VBScript executed a PowerShell script (GammaLoad.PS1) to collect system data.

On the same day, Anonymous responded to the Russian brutal attack in Bucha with a leak of personal details allegedly belonging to Russian military personnel stationed in the town. The leak included names, ranks, and passport details.

On April 6, 2022, the Anonymous-affiliated group The Black Rabbit claimed that they gained access to the Kremlin CCTV system and published their live feeds on Twitter.

On April 7, 2022, Anonymous published three datasets including approximately 400,000 emails allegedly belonging to three major Russian companies: Petrovsky Fort (Petrofort), Aerogas, and Forest. Aerogas‚Äô clients include the largest state-owned oil and gas companies in Russia, such as Rosneft.

On the same day, Microsoft announced that it shut down domains that were used by APT28 to attack Ukrainian entities during the Russo-Ukrainian War. In addition, they were used to target US and EU government institutions and think tanks that deal with foreign policy.

On April 9, 2022, it was reported that the Anonymous-affiliated group NB65 attacked Russian organizations using a modified ransomware that was based on Conti's leaked source code. When encrypting the files that are stored on the infected computer, the ransomware appends them the .NB65 extension and creates a ransom note named R3ADM3.txt with accusations against President Vladimir Putin.

On April 11, 2022, Anonymous claimed to breach Russia‚Äôs Ministry of Culture, leaking 446 GB of data, including over 200,000 emails allegedly stolen from its databases. In another attack, the group of hacktivists claimed to hack the Tver Governor‚Äôs office, leaking 116 GB of data allegedly belonging to the governor and his staff.

On April 12, 2022, the CERT-UA reported that Sandworm attacked an ICS network of a Ukrainian energy organization using a new variant for the Industroyer malware, dubbed Industroyer2, and CaddyWiper. In addition, the threat actors used the OrcShred, Soloshred, and AwfulShred destructive scripts to sabotage Linux servers and Solaris operating systems. The general plan was to disrupt the power in a Ukrainian region. However, ESET researchers reported that the attack was unsuccessful. Other tools that were used in the attempted attack include the PowerGap PowerShell script for downloading malicious payloads and creating scheduled tasks, and Impacket for executing remote commands.

On April 13, 2022, Anonymous leaked almost half a million emails allegedly belonging to the Russian company Technotec. The company provides oil and gas field services to large energy organizations, such as Rosneft and Gazprom Neft.

On April 14, 2022, the CERT-UA reported on two new phishing campaigns targeting Ukrainian entities. In the first campaign, attributed to UAC-0097, the threat actors sent image files containing a JavaScript code for the exploitation of an XSS vulnerability in the Zimbra Collaboration Suite (CVE-2018-6882). The vulnerability enables threat actors to remotely inject arbitrary web scripts or HTML through a content-location header in email attachments. In the second reported campaign, attributed to UAC-0041, the attackers sent macro-embedded Excel documents that were used to deploy the GzipLoader malware and the IcedID banking Trojan (AKA BankBot).

On the same day, Anonymous claimed to breach Gazprom Linde Engineering, leaking 768,000 emails allegedly belonging to the company.

On April 15, 2022, the Anonymous-affiliated group NB65 announced the hack of Continent Express, the Russian largest independent travel agency, leaking nearly 400 GB of files and databases.

On April 18, 2022, the CERT-UA issued a warning against phishing attacks, attributed to the TrickBot operators, targeting Ukrainian organizations. The threat actors used macro-embedded documents with lures related to the Azovstal factory (connected to the Siege of Mariupol), leading to the deployment of Cobalt Strike.

On the same day, Anonymous published 222 GB of data allegedly belonging to the Russian construction company Gazregion.

On April 19, 2022, Anonymous claimed to breach the Russian financial firm Tendertech, leaking 426,000 of its alleged emails (160 GB). In addition, it leaked the alleged data of GUOV I GS, Russia's General Department of Troops and Civil Construction.

On the same day, Killnet announced that it breached the websites of Polish international airports, taking down their websites. The attack came in response to the Polish government's actions in providing weapons to the Ukrainian military.

On April 20, 2022, Anonymous announced that they hacked Worldwide Invest, an investment firm with alleged ties to the Russian railways, leaking 250,000 emails (130 GB). In addition, the group claimed to breach Sawatzky, a Russian property management organization that serves various Western companies, leaking over half a million emails allegedly belonging to Sawatzky.

On the same day, Symantec researchers reported that Gamaredon used four new variants of the Pteredo backdoor in attacks against Ukrainian entities. All these variants used obfuscated VBS droppers that add scheduled tasks and downloaded additional malicious modules from different C2 servers. However, each of them had slight functionality differences:
- Pterodo.B - a modified self-extracting 7-Zip archive that contains obfuscated VBScripts and is used for data collection and maintaining persistence.
