- Pterodo.C - designed to drop VBScripts and operates with an API hammering process as an anti-sandbox mechanism. In addition, it fetches PowerShell scripts from remote servers and executes them.
- Pterodo.D - another VBScript dropper that creates two files and executes them. It wipes the original executable to remove traces.
- Pterodo.E - a mix of all other variants that conducts API hammering before it extracts two VBScript files.
Other tools that were employed by Gamaredon include the UltraVNC remote access tool and the Microsoft Process Explorer that was used to gain information about DLL processes.

On April 21, 2022, Anonymous leaked 365,000 emails allegedly belonging to the Russian real-estate investment firm Accent Capital.

On April 22, 2022, Anonymous claimed to hack Enerpred, a leading producer of hydraulic tools in Russia and the CIS countries, leaking 645,000 company emails.

On April 25, 2022, Anonymous announced that it hacked ALET, a Russian customs broker for companies in the fuel and energy industries. In addition, the threat actors leaked 1.1 million emails allegedly belonging to the company.

On April 26, 2022, the CERT-UA reported on another UAC-0056 phishing campaign against Ukrainian entities. The threat actors used a compromised account of a Ukrainian state employee to send phishing email messages distributing the GraphSteel and GrimPlant malware.

On the same day, the Anonymous-affiliated group NB65 leaked 229,000 emails and 630,000 files allegedly belonging to Petersburg Social Commercial Bank (JSC Bank "PSCB").

On April 27, Secureworks researchers reported that Mustang Panda targeted Russian officials using phishing email messages. The messages included lure attachments that were allegedly sent by the European Union, containing sanction details against Belarus. The attachments in the form of Windows executables (.exe) downloaded a DLL Loader executing the PlugX malware. The state-sponsored group's campaign was assumed to indicate a shift in China's intelligence collection objectives amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War.

In addition, Microsoft published a detailed report about the cyberwarfare between Russia and Ukraine. Microsoft stated that since the beginning of the war, more than 237 cyberattacks were initiated against Ukrainian systems and critical infrastructure. A large portion of the attacks were carried out by six state-sponsored threat groups: APT28, APT29, Sandworm, Gamaredon, Energetic Bear, and Turla, deploying various types of destructive malware, such as WhisperGate, CaddyWiper, and Industroyer2. Another mentioned threat group, DEV-0586, was only suspected to be associated with the Russian government.

On the same day, Anonymous claimed to obtain 1.23 million emails (1.7 TB of data) from hacking Elektrocentromontazh, the largest power organization in Russia.

On April 28, 2022, the CERT-UA warned against ongoing DDoS attacks targeting pro-Ukraine websites and the government web portal. The threat actors, whose identity is unknown, compromised WordPress sites, injecting them a malicious JavaScript code (BrownFlood). The code was designed to run on the website visitor's computer and direct its resources to generate a large number of requests for predefined target URLs.

In addition, the CERT-UA reported on another phishing campaign conducted by UAC-0098 against Ukrainian state entities. The phishing messages contained malicious ISO files leading to the execution of a PowerShell script and the deployment of the Meterpreter hacking tool. This campaign was also associated with TrickBot.

On April 29, 2022, Killnet initiated a DDoS attack against Romanian government websites, including the official website of the Romanian government, the Ministry of Defense, Romanian Border Police, and Romania‚Äôs National Railway Transport Company. In addition, the threat actors targeted the Romanian website of OTP Bank. The hackers took down the websites and also deleted some of the data that was stored upon them. The Romanian Intelligence Service confirmed the attack and stated that the threat actors took control of networks by exploiting vulnerabilities. The attack probably resulted from the Romanian government's public support of Ukraine.

On May 3, 2022, Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) reported on five active threat groups, targeting organizations and individuals in Eastern Europe. The groups included: APT28 (AKA Fancy Bear), Turla, Ghostwriter (AKA UNC1151), COLDRIVER (AKA Callisto), and Curious Gorge. Interestingly, the latter group, assumed to be associated with China's Liberation Army Strategic Support Force (PLA SSF), was observed to target Russian organizations, including multiple defense contractors, manufacturers, and a logistics company.

On May 4, 2022, Crowdstrike researchers reported that unnamed pro-Ukraine threat actors used docker images to initiate DDoS attacks against 24 Russian and Belarusian websites managed by government, military, and news organizations (e.g. the TASS news agency). The malicious images, named ‚Äúerikmnkl/stoppropaganda‚Äù and ‚Äúabagayev/stop-russia,‚Äù were downloaded over 150,000 times, however the volume of compromised hosts was not verified.

In addition, Ukraine‚Äôs IT Army disrupted the distribution of alcoholic beverages in Russia by initiating a DDoS attack against the Unified State Automated Alcohol Accounting Information System (EGAIS) portal. The attack shut down the portal, making it difficult for alcohol producers and distributors to ship their products to customers.

On May 6, 2022, the CERT-UA reported on an APT28 phishing campaign, in which the threat actors sent email messages impersonating the cybersecurity agency. The messages contained RAR archives with SFX files, distributing the malicious program CredoMap_v2. The program used HTTP POST requests to send stolen user credentials to a web resource, hosted on the Pipedream platform.

On May 9, 2022, pro-Ukraine hackers took down the RuTube video streaming site during President Putin's speech on "Victory Day." The hackers defaced the online Russian TV schedule page to display anti-war messages, accusing Russia of killing Ukrainian citizens and spreading fake news.

On May 10, 2022, Anonoymous published 77,500 emails (106 GB) from the Port and Railway Projects Service of JSC UMMC, which operates two large Russian ports specializing in coal shipments.

On May 11, 2022, Anonymous announced that it hacked the Polar Branch of the Russian Federal Research Institute of Fisheries and Oceanography, leaking 466 GB of emails from the organization.

On May 12, 2022, Anonymous claimed to breach the Achinsk city government, stealing and leaking over 7,000 of its emails.

On the same day, the CERT-UA reported on another Gamaredon phishing campaign using lures related to the Battle of Kherson. The phishing messages contained HTA files starting an attack chain leading to the deployment of the GammaLoad.PS1_v2 malware.

On May 13, 2022, Italy's Computer Security Incident Response Team (CSIRT) reported that Killnet initiated DDoS attacks against government and military websites in the country. The threat actors used the "Slow HTTP" technique to overload the targeted servers and take down their hosted websites. Killnet acknowledged the attack and stated that further attacks may follow.

On May 14, 2022, Anonymous leaked 116,500 emails (130 GB) allegedly belonging to SOCAR Energoresource, which operates the Antipinsky Refinery and several oilfields.

On May 19, 2022, Check Point researchers reported a cyberespionage campaign dubbed Twisted Panda that was active from at least June 2021 through April 2022. The campaign intensified following the Russo-Ukrainian War and targeted Russian and Belarusian defense research institutes. The campaign operators, likely of Chinese origin, used spear phishing email messages with macro-embedded documents to deploy a previously undocumented backdoor, Spinner. The backdoor was used to collect system information (e.g. IP address, computer name, and OS version) and exfiltrate it to a remote command and control (C2) server.

On May 20, 2022, ESET researchers reported that Sandworm used the ArguePatch malware loader as part of an Industroyer2 attack against a Ukrainian energy provider and in other attacks involving the deployment of CaddyWiper. The loader could be used to execute a second-stage malware at a particular time, which replaces the former use of a Windows scheduled task. In addition, Sandworm was observed to use an executable that was stripped of its digital signature and whose code was overwritten, in order to hide ArguePatch from being detected.

On the same day, it was reported that the Russian state-owned bank Sberbank suffered the largest distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack in its history. The attack that occurred at the beginning of the month, was generated by a botnet with 27,000 compromised devices, located in the United States, the United Kingdom, Japan, and Taiwan. The attackers used various techniques to initiate the DDoS attack, including code injections into advertising scripts, malicious Chrome extensions, and weaponized Docker containers.

On May 23, 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported on a new reconnaissance and espionage campaign that was conducted by Turla, targeting the Austrian Economic Chamber, NATO‚Äôs eLearning platform JDAL, and the Baltic Defense College in Estonia. The threat actors used typosquatting domains to host Word documents containing PNG files. As these domains did not contain any malicious code, it was assumed that the PNG files were used solely for reconnaissance purposes while collecting general system information (e.g. the victim's IP address).

On the same day, Anonymous published a list of email accounts and passwords used by the pro-Russian group Killnet. This was part of the ongoing rivalry between the two hacktivist groups.

On May 24, 2022, analysts at the Malwarebytes Threat Intelligence team reported on four spear phishing campaigns that were initiated against Russian government entities since February 2022. The campaigns, likely conducted by a Chinese threat actor, used different phishing lures (e.g. Windows security updates and fake job ads) to distribute a custom malicious payload with anti-analysis and obfuscation mechanisms that received commands from a remote C2 server, such as uploading files, profiling the host, and exfiltrating a list of all files under a specified directory. The malware that was used in the campaign resembled Deep Panda's Sakula RAT. In addition, the campaign operators used the same macro builder as the TrickBot and BazarLoader operators, and the WolfSSL library, commonly used by the APT groups Lazarus and Tropic Trooper.

On May 26, 2022, researchers at 360 Qihoo reported that Gamaredon released a DDoS Trojan called LOIC as open-source, to help threat actors carry out attacks (probably against Ukrainian entities). The LOIC program was compiled at the beginning of March, soon after the Russian invasion of Ukraine. In addition to the LOIC code, Gamaredon shared hardcoded IP addresses and ports for the targets.

On May 29, 2022, Anonymous initiated a large-scale DDoS attack against the Belarusian government, taking down some of its websites.

On May 30, 2022, the Anonymous affiliates, B00da, Porteur, and Wh1t3 Sh4d0w, claimed to breach Metprom Group, a Russian metallurgic engineering and investment group. They also leaked a 184 GB archive allegedly containing company emails.

On June 1, 2022, Anonymous announced that it hacked the Russian Vyberi Radio group, leaking 1.5 million of its emails (823 GB).

On June 3, 2022, the Anonymous affiliates, B00da and Porteur, released a 1 TB archive with data allegedly stolen from Rustam Kurmaev and Partners (RKP Law), a Russian law firm that works with major organizations, including leading American companies, such as Caterpillar, Gillette, and Citibank.

On June 20, 2022, the CERT-UA warned that APT28 was observed exploiting the Follina MSDT zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2022-30190), as part of a phishing campaign against critical infrastructure in Ukraine. The threat actors sent malicious documents exploiting the vulnerability to deploy Cobalt Strike and a previously unknown malware named CredoMap. CredoMap was found to be an information-stealing malware, gathering and exfiltrating web browser data, such as user credentials and cookies.

On June 21, 2022, Legion declared war against Lithuanian organizations from different sectors, such as government entities, banks, logistic companies, internet providers, airports, energy firms, and mass media groups. Two days later, the National Cyber Security Center (NKSC) of Lithuania issued a warning against an increase in DDoS attacks targeting public authorities in the country. As a result of the attacks, Lithuania's transportation agencies, financial institutions, and others experienced temporary service disruptions. The NKSC did not blame Legion for the attacks, but the proximity of events suggests its attribution.

On June 24, 2022, the CERT-UA reported that threat actors used phishing email messages containing RAR archives with macro-embedded documents to distribute DarkCrystal RAT malware among Ukrainian telecommunications operators. The same type of malware was also used in an attack against Ukrainian media organizations two weeks earlier, in which the Follina MSDT vulnerability (CVE-2022-30190) was exploited.

On July 7, 2022, IBM Security X-Force published a broad overview of TrickBot's activity amidst the Russo-Ukrainian War. Since February 2022, the TrickBot operators have initiated at least six campaigns targeting Ukrainian entities. The threat actors used phishing email messages to distribute different types of malware and hacking tools, such as IcedID, CobaltStrike, AnchorMail, and Meterpreter. Some of which were deployed using a novel Microsoft Excel downloader. To evade detection, the threat actors used a new crypter dubbed Forest that was sometimes used in conjunction with the Bumblebee loader.

On July 19, 2022, Google's Threat Analysis Group (TAG) reported that Turla targeted Ukrainian entities using a malicious Android app. The app, hosted on a domain spoofing the Ukrainian Azov Regiment, was disguised as a DoS tool against Russian websites. Turla distributed the app through phishing links promoted on third party messaging services.

On August 15, 2022, Symantec researchers reported the continuing activity of Gamaredon against Ukrainian entities. In the reported campaign taking place between July 15 and August 8, 2022, the threat actors sent their victims phishing messages with self-extracting 7-Zip archives containing XML files that were used to deploy PowerShell-based infostealers. In some cases, Gamaredon utilized VBS downloaders leading to the deployment of the Pterodo and Giddome backdoors. The latter could be used to take screenshots, log the user's keystrokes, record audio, and download and execute EXE and DLL files. In addition, the threat actors were observed using the legitimate remote desktop protocol (RDP) tools Ammyy Admin and AnyDesk to gain remote system access.        

On August 18, 2022, Trustwave linked seven Russian-backed threat actors to dozens of attacks against Ukraine amidst the Russo-Ukranian War: APT29 (AKA Cozy Bear), APT28 (AKA Fancy Bear), Sandworm (AKA BlackEnergy), Dragonfly (AKA Energetic Bear), Gamaredon (AKA Primitive Bear), UNC2589 (AKA Ember Bear), and InvisiMole. The groups employed various attack techniques and tools, including wipers (e.g. HermeticWiper, IsaacWiper, and CaddyWiper), backdoors (e.g. LoadEdge, GraphSteel, and GrimPlant), and other known malware, such as Industroyer2, Cobalt Strike, DarkCrystal RAT, and CredoMap. In addition, the threat actors exploited known Microsoft vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-1636, CVE-2021-40444, and CVE-2022-30190) to gain system access.    

On September 15, 2022, Cisco Talos researchers reported a new Gamaredon campaign targeting Ukrainian entities using a novel custom infostealer, likely a component of the Giddome backdoor. The malware was distributed using phishing email messages with macro-embedded Office documents that downloaded RAR archives with LNK files. The LNK files ran mshta.exe to download and parse a remote XML file that executed a malicious PowerShell script and led to the deployment of the information stealing malware. The malware could be used to exfiltrate specific files of interest and to deploy additional malware.

On September 19, 2022, cybersecurity researchers reported that the UAC-0113 threat group, linked to Sandworm, masqueraded as telecommunication providers to target Ukrainian entities. The threat actors sent their victims phishing email messages with links to spoofed domains. The domains contained Base64-encoded ISO files that were downloaded automatically using the HTML smuggling technique and distributed the Colibri Loader and Warzone RAT malware.

On September 23, 2022, Anonymous claimed to breach the Russian Ministry of Defense and leaked a 90 MB TXT file that allegedly contained the personal data of over 300,000 Russian individuals, who are likely to be mobilized in the army. The leaked file contained PII information, such as names, birth dates, regions, and districts of each individual.

On the same day, Mandiant researchers connected APT28 to the activity of three Telegram channels, ‚ÄúXakNet Team,‚Äù ‚ÄúInfoccentr,‚Äù and ‚ÄúCyberArmyofRussia_Reborn.‚Äù The channels have been operated by hacktivist groups of the same names that have conducted distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks and website defacements against Ukrainian entities. In addition, the hacktivist groups have used their Telegram channels to leak stolen data, some of which was obtained through APT28 campaigns.
content.AdditionalInformation:
The CISA, FBI, and the NSA have released a joint cybersecurity advisory (CSA), warning organizations, federal entities, and states, of potential cyber threats. They included a list of TTPs utilized by Russian state-sponsored advanced persistent threat (APT) groups in the past. These groups are reputed with their sophisticated cyber capabilities and familiarity with exploiting specific vulnerabilities, for gaining initial access to the victims' systems, such as:

CVE-2018-13379 - FortiGate VPNs
CVE-2019-1653 - Cisco router
CVE-2019-2725 - Oracle WebLogic Server
CVE-2019-7609 - Kibana
CVE-2019-9670 - Zimbra software
CVE-2019-10149 - Exim Simple Mail Transfer Protocol
CVE-2019-11510 - Pulse Secure
CVE-2019-19781 Citrix
CVE-2020-0688 - Microsoft Exchange
CVE-2020-4006 - VMWare (note: this was a zero-day at time.)
CVE-2020-5902 - F5 Big-IP
CVE-2020-14882 - Oracle WebLogic
CVE-2021-26855 - Microsoft Exchange (Note: this vulnerability is frequently observed used in conjunction with CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065)

Recommendations:

- We recommend going over all the CVEs mentioned above (specifically related to CVE-2021-32648 and Log4j CVE-2021-44228) and following the steps and processes for mitigating according to the manufacturers, developers, governmental entities, and security vendors' instructions.

- Until the stabilization in the relations between the two countries returns, we recommend reinforcing the cybersecurity measures and staff during the weekends and holidays. Threat actors are known to target their victims when there are gaps in organizational cybersecurity, which are common on vacation days.

- We recommend preparing a dedicated team with a detailed workflow and a contact person that will be available in case of a cybersecurity incident.

- It is important to implement data backup procedures of the company networks and systems. Backup procedures should be conducted on a frequent, regular basis for immediate recovery.

- Please consider elevating the security awareness among the company employees worldwide and conducting simulations of cyberattacks, such as phishing attempts, in the following days.

- Please consider following the latest updates and recommendations provided by the cybersecurity vendors/companies and governmental security entities in specific press releases/alerts from the Ukraine CERT, The Security Service of Ukraine (SBU), and CISA.


* This cyber term accumulates the information and relevant IOCs that are related to the malware and threat actors that are part of the Russia-Ukraine cyberwarfare.

content.Overview:
The OpIran hacktivist campaign was launched by Anonymous in September 2022, following the death of Mahsa Amini by Iran‚Äôs morality police. The ongoing campaign has been targeting Iranian government, finance, and media websites through distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks and defacements. In addition, the threat actors steal the data of the breached organizations and leak them online. 

Among the compromised organizations were the Iranian Intelligence Agency, the Iranian Police, the Fars News Agency, the Central Bank of Iran, the Forensic Research Center, and the Iranian Assembly.

On September 22, 2022, Anonymous claimed to hack hundreds of security cameras In Iran by exploiting a known vulnerability in the Zulip server (CVE-2018-9999).
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

content.Overview:
The Brute Ratel C4 command and control (C2) framework (AKA BRc4) was first made public by the Indian security researcher, Chetan Nayak, in December 2020. The red team penetration toolkit, sold at $2,500 for a yearly license, is used by organizations to perform security testing; however, threat actors (e.g. APT29) have adopted it for malicious purposes in various campaigns targeting organizations from multiple sectors and countries, such as Argentina and Mexico.  

Like other C2 frameworks, Brute Ratel enables its users to deploy ‚ÄúBadgers‚Äù (similar to Cobalt Strike beacons) on remote hosts. These badgers connect back to the operator's C2 server to receive and execute commands. In addition, Brute Ratel can be used to create Windows system services, upload and download files, scan network ports, take screenshots, load shellcodes, and more. The tool is considered to be very stealthy and was specifically designed to evade detection by EDR and antivirus solutions.   

Brute Ratel was observed being deployed using an ISO file, likely sent through phishing messages. The ISO file contained a Windows shortcut (LNK) file, a legitimate copy of Microsoft OneDrive Updater, and a malicious payload DLL that loaded a Brute Ratel badger into the RuntimeBroker.exe process using the DLL search order hijacking technique. This enabled the toolkit operators to remotely access the compromised device, execute commands, and further spread in the network. Brute Ratel was also observed being loaded by the Bumblebee loader and used for post-exploitation activities. This, as part of the lateral movement phase that might lead to network encryption using ransomware payloads.   

Brute Ratel is only sold to registered companies and individuals with an official business email address/domain; however, threat actors might buy black market licenses or set up fake companies to be used as part of the verification process.
content.AdditionalInformation: In September 2022, cybersecurity researchers observed a cracked version of Brute Ratel shared for free across underground hacking forums. This means that the post-exploitation tool could be used without the formerly required activation key.

TargetCountries: Congo, The Democratic Republic of The
content.Overview:
The Metador threat group, first reported by SentinelOne researchers in September 2022, has been active since at least December 2020. The group primarily targets telecommunications organizations, internet service providers (ISPs), and universities in the Middle East and Africa.

While Metador‚Äôs initial access vector was not disclosed, its infection cycle seems to be primarily established on living-off-the-land (LotL) binaries that lead to the execution of two custom Windows-based malware, metaMain and Mafalda. Both malware are executed in memory, using the Microsoft Console Debugger (CDB) to evade detection. The metaMain backdoor can be used to maintain long-term system access, log user keystrokes, download and upload arbitrary files, execute shellcode, take screenshots, and decrypt Mafalda in memory. Mafalda is a heavily obfuscated malware framework that supports 67 commands, including various file operations, network reconnaissance, registry manipulation, and data exfiltration. In addition, Metador was observed using another custom implant, Cryshell, for bouncing connections in an internal network to external command and control (C2) servers, and an unknown Linux malware that gathers information from other connected machines in the compromised network and transfers them back to Mafalda. To evade detection, Metador uses segmentation of the attack infrastructure, i.e. using a single IP address per victim for C2 communications over either HTTP or raw TCP. The group‚Äôs servers are hosted on LiteServer, a Dutch hosting provider.      

Based on the documentation for Mafalda's commands, it seems that Metador‚Äôs malware are developed by one set of individuals, but operated by another.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Harly Android malware, first reported by Kaspersky researchers in September 2022, has been active since at least 2020. The Trojan spreads globally, masquerading as legitimate Google Play applications, and subscribes users to unwanted services. Harly is named after the known comic book villain, Harley Quinn (The Joker‚Äôs sidekick), due to the malware‚Äôs close resemblance to the Joker Android Trojan. 

Since 2020, Harly was observed in almost 200 Android applications with millions of downloads. The apps take many forms, such as organizer apps, translators, games, and photo editors. Once the app is launched, a code library is loaded and decrypts the file that contains the malicious Harly SDK. Then, the Trojan collects information about the user‚Äôs device and mobile network and connects a remote command and control (C2) server to fetch a list of subscription services. Next, Harly opens the subscription address in an invisible window, injects JavaScript code snippets, and registers the user‚Äôs device to a paid subscription by entering the phone number and harvested confirmation code. The malware can gather the confirmation code from both text messages and phone calls.
content.AdditionalInformation: N/A

TTPs: Collect General System and User Information
content.Overview:
The Erbium information stealing malware, first reported by cybersecurity researchers in September 2022, has been promoted on underground hacking forums since July 2022. The malware-as-a-service (MaaS) targets organizations and individuals around the world, in countries such as the United States, France, Colombia, Spain, Italy, India, Vietnam, and Malaysia. Erbium can potentially have a wide range of targets, as it is sold for a relatively low price of $100 per month or $1000 for a yearly license.

Erbium, written in Visual C++, is primarily distributed through drive-by downloads of fake cheats and cracks; however, it can also be distributed through spear phishing, malicious advertising, exploit kits, and malware loaders, such as SmokeLoader and Private Loader. The infostealer is deployed in a modular fashion, starting with a first-stage 32-bit PE executable with a highly obfuscated code that uses polymorphic techniques to change its identifiable features and evade detection. The first stage executable allocates memory in a new process and leads to the download of a second-stage implant that connects to the command and control (C2) server over HTTP and fetches the final DLL file. The DLL is loaded and executed in the memory of the legitimate process, AppLaunch.exe, and acts as the stealer itself. 

Erbium can collect general system information (e.g. geolocation, Windows version, PC name, and number of monitors), web browser data (e.g. cookies, user credentials, history, and autofill), cryptocurrency information, Steam and Telegram authorization files, Discord tokens, and two-factor authentication codes from various browser-based authenticators. In addition, the infostealer can load other libraries, processes, and DLLs in memory, enumerate drives, paths, files, and folders, and take screenshots. At the end of the collection process, the harvested data is exfiltrated to a remote command and control (C2) server through a built-in API system. The stolen information is presented on a dedicated control panel that is connected to the malware through three different URLs, including Discord's Content Delivery Network (CDN).
content.AdditionalInformation:
Snort rule:

alert tcp any any ->  any $HTTP_PORTS (
msg: "Cluster25 - Trojan/Erbium CnC Communication"; 
flow:established,to_server; 
content:"GET"; 
nocase; http_method; content:"/api.php"; 
content:"method=getstub"; 
content:"tag="; 
http_uri; 
sid:100004;
rev:1;
)
